HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: MEDICARE;
G.O.P. May 'Go It Alone' On Medicare

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, said today that he had reluctantly concluded that Republicans would have to "go it alone" in cutting projected spending on Medicare because President Clinton and Democrats in Congress had refused to join the effort.
But Mr. Barbour said Republicans could reap political dividends because they would receive most of the credit for saving Medicare from bankruptcy. 
 His comments were the first indication that Republicans were now contemplating unilateral action and party-line votes to redesign Medicare and slow the growth of the program, which serves 37 million elderly or disabled people.
"At this stage of the game it looks like the Republicans will have to go it alone," Mr. Barbour said today at a meeting with reporters. "As you know, we have asked repeatedly, publicly and privately, that the Administration join in a bipartisan effort to save Medicare."
But the White House has turned down such invitations, saying that House Republicans must first specify how they will reconcile their promises to balance the budget and cut taxes. In effect, the President has demanded that House Republicans drop their plans for a big tax cut before the Administration will discuss specific proposals to overhaul Medicare.
Republicans have enough votes in Congress to pass a Medicare bill, but not enough to override a veto. While Mr. Clinton might be inclined to veto a Republican bill that dealt only with Medicare, he may not get that opportunity. At least some of the changes needed to guarantee the program's solvency over the next 10 years may be wrapped into a bill cutting dozens of Federal programs. And before that, Congress may pass a bill requiring the Administration to submit recommendations to prevent depletion of the Medicare trust fund.
The six trustees responsible for the program, including four Administration officials, said last month that the Medicare trust fund would run out of money by the year 2002 if there were no changes in the current law.
But White House officials said the President was not interested in any plan to shore up the Medicare trust fund unless it also made improvements in the overall health care system and provided coverage to some of the 41 million Americans who have no health insurance now.
Disputing Mr. Barbour's assertions, Democrats said they doubted that the Republicans would win political credit for taking the steps now under consideration. Those steps include raising Medicare premiums, co-payments and other charges to beneficiaries.
"When co-payments start going up, you can't put a positive political spin on that," said Representative Earl Pomeroy, a Democrat from North Dakota who regulated health insurance as Insurance Commissioner of that state.
Gene Sperling, deputy assistant to the President for economic policy, said, "The real question is why the Republicans are refusing to work with us to reform Medicare in the context of a serious step-by-step approach to health care reform."
Mr. Barbour said he was not an expert on Medicare, but he displayed detailed knowledge of the program, its finances and the recommendations of various health policy experts. He said he believed that Republicans would not suffer devastating political damage if Americans understood the alternatives to the Republican proposals.
"I do not think there is a political dividend for dodging your responsibility in the face of what is a universally agreed crisis," Mr. Barbour said. "The Clinton Administration apparently thinks it's good politics to do nothing."
The fiscal blueprint approved today by the House would cut $283 billion, or 15 percent, from projected spending on Medicare over the next seven years. The plan developed by Senate Republicans would cut $256 billion, or 14 percent.
Mr. Barbour said such cutbacks "will not change in a drastic way the lives of the beneficiaries." But the American Association of Retired Persons said the changes would cause hardship for millions of elderly people, and the American Hospital Association said some inner-city hospitals would be forced to close.

HEADLINE: California Treasurer Joins Attack on Orange County

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
The California State Treasurer, Matthew Fong, yesterday joined the attack on officials of Orange County who are seeking to default on some $1.3 billion in short-term debt about to come due.
He said that such a default -- which appears increasingly imminent at the affluent, but bankrupt, county -- would raise borrowing costs for all California municipalities and could lead to a state takeover of Orange County's financial affairs by a control board similar to New York's Municipal Assistance Corporation. 
 Mr. Fong's words added strength to the growing outcry by mutual funds and investors who own Orange County securities.
He made his remarks at a municipal industry conference and after spending two days meeting with major holders of California securities in New York and Boston, including representatives of Fidelity Investments, Dreyfus Corporation, Alliance Capital and Putnam Investments, all of whom are alarmed by the possibility of a default.
"Orange County has got to get its head out of the sand and recognize that any default would create serious problems," Mr. Fong said in remarks before a conference sponsored by Grant's Interest Rate Observer, a trade publication. "This is a frustration that I have. It is still not clear that there is a message of conviction by Orange County's political leaders."
Currently, Orange County officials are seeking to "roll over" the $1.3 billion in borrowings that the county must repay in the next three months and possibly replace them with securities with longer maturities and lower returns. Some county officials have even suggested repudiating the debt entirely and are seeking legal ways to avoid meeting the county's debt obligations.
Mr. Fong said his "message" was that "rollovers should not be an option" sought by Orange County. "It's a question of accountability and responsibility," he said. "They are trying to disabuse themselves of any notion of accountability by saying 'the bankruptcy was not my fault and we don't want to pay for it.' "
Orange County, one of the nation's wealthiest counties, is also the home of widespread antitax sentiment. The unwillingness of the county to raise taxes and repay investors who lend the county money has angered holders of its short-term notes, primarily mutual funds, as well as the entire municipal finance industry.
The county's action threatens an underpinning of the industry: that the promise of a municipality to pay off its general obligation debt is ironclad.
Negotiations are now under way between the note holders and the county to reach some accommodation, which is expected by next week. The sides remain far apart; some close to the negotiations characterize the county's efforts as a "cramdown" that provides little for the note holders.
A June 27 ballot proposal will ask county residents to raise the county sales tax slightly to help pay off the debt -- but polls have indicated that even that modest proposal may be defeated.
Mr. Fong said that Orange County's stubbornness could hurt all California municipalities in the debt market. He predicted that short-term paper would cost the issuing municipalities a half to a full percentage point more in interest -- and that some less-affluent municipalities might find no lenders at all. Most municipalities need short-term borrowings to provide cash flow for municipal operations as they await the ebb and flow of tax receipts.
"It's already going to cost Los Angeles $25 million more to borrow short-term and that's money that could have gone for police or firemen," Mr. Fong said. "I hope the rest of the state can focus and see that this is going to become their problem, not just Orange County's problem."
Mr. Fong ruled out the possibility of any state bailout for Orange County. "Orange County made a mistake," Mr. Fong said. "Why should we bail them out?"
Orange County declared bankruptcy last December after a high-flying investment fund managed by the county collapsed, creating a $1.6 billion loss.
A state takeover of the county's financial affairs remains a slim possibility. Gov. Pete Wilson vetoed a bill proposing such a takeover last week, but Mr. Fong said that the State Legislature, still in an emergency session concerning Orange County, could pass such a measure -- and might do so if the county defaulted on its short-term securities and, in doing so, endangered the borrowings of other municipalities. "The problem with the bill Governor Wilson vetoed was not the bill itself, but that the timing was wrong," Mr. Fong said.
He also criticized Wall Street bankers who appeared to be willing to underwrite new Orange County securities, even as the county was seeking to default on its old ones.
"Investment bankers are smelling blood and are saying that there is life after bankruptcy," Mr. Fong said. "That causes me trouble. There may be life after bankruptcy. But is that fair for the other 2,000 municipalities in California that did nothing wrong but will get tarred and feathered for the poor management and lack of supervisory authority by Orange County?"

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Starting Over In Latin America;
Partnership Signals Revival Of Interest in Risky Market

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
It was hardly the typical leading indicator. But when Pedro-Pablo Kuczynski got into his red Porsche recently and headed south for Miami, that was as good a sign as any that the smart money was heading south, too, all the way back to Latin America.
Mr. Kuczynski, a trim 56-year-old investment banker, has been shifting his base to Miami for more than two years. Driving down in the Porsche with some of the last of his things, he was making a final break with his life up north, leaving behind a 33-year marriage and homes in New York and Washington. 
 Ahead was the new life he was forging with a woman he met some years ago, Nancy A. Lange, an analyst of institutional money managers. Also ahead was a bold plan to invest big again in Latin America. And since Mr. Kuczynski knows the region as well as anyone -- he was a pioneer there, "one of the only people doing Latin America 20 years ago," said Richard L. Grand-Jean, a former Salomon Brothers banker -- the move south can be read as something other than a midlife crisis.
Indeed, less than six months after Mexico's unexpected and drastic devaluation of the peso sent foreign investors skittering out of developing markets throughout the region, the dollars are starting to flow in again. And by relocating to Miami, an important pipeline for Latin-bound investment, Mr. Kuczynski (pronounced Ku-CHIN-ski) has been positioning himself to become one of the biggest conduits.
Now, Mr. Kuczynski has fully arrived. A former managing director at CS First Boston and a former Minister of Energy and Mines in Peru, where he grew up and remains a citizen, he has been signing the final papers this week to start up a $150 million fund that will take equity stakes in large privately held companies in Latin America.
The timing could not be better, he said, adding that the Latin American Enterprise Fund L. P. that he would be running with Ms. Lange and a few others was still attracting investors and could soon top $200 million.
"The Mexican crisis has increased the opportunities in the private equity market," he said, and "not only in Mexico," because it is now easier to win more favorable terms.
He's not the only one thinking that way. Nicholas F. Brady, the former Treasury Secretary, has teamed up with Daniel Marx, a former director of Argentina's central bank, to set up Darby Overseas Investments Ltd., which has already made some investments in Latin America. And Joseph G. Fogg 3d, a former head of investment banking at Morgan Stanley & Company, recently set up a private equity fund to invest in Peru.
Few who are making the return trip have Mr. Kuczynski's roots in the region -- his name derives from his father's Polish ancestry -- and his long years of investment experience there.
At CS First Boston, he helped privatize 18 Mexican banks, and he advised such companies as Vitro S.A., the Mexican glass maker, and YPF S.A., the Argentine energy company, about raising money on the New York Stock Exchange. He also helped George Soros, the billionaire fund manager, double his investment in a Peruvian brewery, Compania Nacional de Cerveza. Since leaving CS First Boston in 1992, he spent nearly three years restructuring and managing the Latin American portfolio of Stephan Schmidheiny, a Swiss tycoon. It was while doing that job that Mr. Kuczynski began to spend time in Miami.
That background -- complemented by Ms. Lange's extensive contacts with institutional investors -- has produced an enviable list of deep-pocket backers, including the Bank of America, a unit of the BankAmerica Corporation; the Chemical Banking Corporation; the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, and Internationale Nederlanden Groep N. V., or ING, the new parent of Barings P.L.C.
"He's very effective, he knows the business well and he knows the markets," said Jay H. Newman, a former managing director at Morgan Stanley whose firm has made investments in Latin America.
And no one is starting over in quite as dramatic a fashion.
Earlier this month, the final divorce papers came through for Mr. Kuczynski and his wife of more than three decades, Jane Casey. The couple, who have three children, had long been a fixture of the social circuit in Washington, where Ms. Casey works as a journalist at Voice of America. Mr. Kuczynski would shuttle down weekends from his New York apartment to join her, often taking the opportunity to hobnob with politicians and top officials from agencies like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. He worked at both prior to moving to Wall Street in the mid-1970's.
These days, he is living in the Coconut Grove section of Miami with Ms. Lange.
The two met almost a decade ago when Ms. Lange worked for Institutional Investor magazine arranging conferences for money managers. Mr. Kuczynski said he told his wife in 1992 that he wanted a divorce because of his relationship with Ms. Lange, who is now 40 and has never been married.
The new couple live just blocks from the office on fashionable South Bayshore Drive where their Westfield Capital Management Company will run the Latin American Enterprise Fund and other investment operations. The Westfield team includes Mr. Kuczynski, Ms. Lange and five investment bankers: Fernando Montero, Edouardo Elejalde and Gerardo Sepulveda in Miami; Jairo Edouardo Loureiro in Sao Paulo, Brazil, and Felipe de la Balze in Buenos Aires.
The company is "so lean, it's like an Indian fakir," Mr. Kuczynski said. There is nothing lean about the company's goals, however.
Mr. Kuczynski said he was looking for an annual return of 35 to 40 percent from buying and selling stakes in the right companies.
His fund will look to invest in companies with sales of at least $50 million a year. He estimated that 800 to 1,000 companies fell in the target group, but he was reluctant to identify any.
He would say, however, that beverage companies in Chile and Argentina are attractive. He was also looking at some basic steel and engineering businesses as well as newspapers and supermarket chains.
Of course, investing in Latin America is never a sure bet. The high returns that Mr. Kuczynski envisions are possible only because the area is such a risky proposition in the first place. Even some of the smartest investors with the best local connections were caught by surprise in such debacles as the regional debt crisis of the early 1980's and last December's peso devaluation. And the continuing recovery from that peso shock is certain to have its own surprises.
Still, foreign investors recently have started to become more confident about the region. After four months of decline, one sign is the net inflow of cash in March and April into mutual funds that invest in Latin American securities. Moreover, central bank reserves have started to rise again, said Ernest W. Brown, an economist at Morgan Stanley who follows Latin America. Mexico's reserves now stand at more than $8.3 billion, up from only $3.5 billion at the end of January.
The major Latin American stock markets have also recovered strongly since the beginning of the year. The Mexican stock market index, for example, closed yesterday at 2,014.76, compared with a low for the year of 1,447.52 at the end of February.
The slump in Latin American securities in January and February was probably overdone, experts now say. "There's no market that overshoots like the less-developed country market," said Mr. Newman, the former Morgan Stanley managing director. "The smart money believes that in the long term there's incredible value in Latin America."
American corporate investors seem to have gotten the message. Auto companies, telephone companies, airlines and state pension funds have all been buying Latin American debt and equity in recent weeks, said Stephen W. Dizard, a managing director at Salomon Brothers who specializes in emerging markets.
Why are some placing money with Mr. Kuczynski and his team?
Mr. Kuczynski "checks out very well," said Jeffrey C. Walker at Chemical Venture Partners, a unit of Chemical Banking. "Montero checks out very strongly. And Felipe de la Balze is one of the real stars in Buenos Aires."
The Chemical group decided to put $25 million into Mr. Kuczynski's fund, and hopes to get returns of "30 percent pretax per year and higher," Mr. Walker said. One attraction was that Mr. Kuczynski's fund covers all of Latin America, not just one country, making it less exposed to volatility, he added.
Former colleagues at First Boston generally speak well of Mr. Kuczynski, praising his marketing skills and high-level contacts. If they have criticisms, they are that he was more independent than most of his colleagues, that he may be a little vain and that he is generally better at marketing than at managing, but that he usually has found skilled associates to manage the business he brings in.
Raising money for his new venture -- a process that started in earnest early last year and had to weather Mexico's devaluation -- was not easy. "It was like having cancer," Mr. Kuczynski said. "You have a good couple of days and then you are set back for a day or two."
Ms. Lange was helpful in producing the good days. "The management team wasn't used to raising money," she said. "They thought it would go faster than it did, but I knew it wouldn't. I decided that I would call on banks and insurance companies first. They'd be more likely to give you a quick decision than a pension fund."
Now that the fund is almost up and running and he has settled into his new home base, Mr. Kuczynski said he was thrilled to be closer to Latin America. "To Chile, Argentina and Peru," he said, "New York is just too damn far."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
For many luxury auto makers and their agencies, the U.S.-Japan tariff battle is off limits.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
IMAGINE if for some reason the Federal Government imposed a tax on soft drinks sold in contoured bottles. How many minutes would Pepsi-Cola wait before unleashing an ad blitz intended to exploit its sudden advantage over Coca-Cola?
Automobiles, it seems, aren't quite like soda. Except for Cadillac, most marketers of luxury cars and their agencies say they are unlikely to undertake advertising or marketing efforts to benefit from the threat by the Clinton Administration to impose a 100 percent tariff on models of competitive Japanese marques like Lexus, Infiniti and Acura. 
 "We're not interested in any artificial advantage these tariffs might create," said Donna Boland, a spokeswoman for Mercedes-Benz of North America in Montvale, N.J., part of Daimler-Benz A.G.
Robert C. Austin, marketing communications director for Volvo Cars of North America in Rockleigh, N.J., a unit of Volvo A.B., said, "We are not planning any guerrilla tactics to take advantage of the situation."
And Kathleen Hamilton, manager for North American communications at the Jaguar Cars unit of the Ford Motor Company in Mahwah, N.J., said, "We don't have plans to exploit this in any sense of the word."
The auto marketers and their agencies offer a variety of reasons for their reticence, which may in part stem from the volatility of the situation and the chance that one or both sides in the touchy trade dispute will blink.
"I don't want to touch it," said Patrick R. Fallon, chairman of Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis, referring to the tariff issue. "It's not in our best interest."
"We might be jumping for joy in the short term," added Mr. Fallon, whose agency was awarded the creative part of the account of BMW of North America, part of BMW A.G., in late March. "But anything that interferes with the free market is, in the long term, bad for us."
Lawrence W. Gustin, a spokesman for the Buick division of the General Motors Corporation in Flint, Mich., offered a similar rationale. "We're in favor of open trade," he said.
In the relatively low-key and genteel realm of selling higher-priced cars, seizing on the misfortune of someone else might be, well, tacky.
"It's not particularly our style," said Barrie K. Hedge, president of Angotti, Thomas, Hedge in New York, one of two agencies working for Saab Cars USA, a unit of the Swedish auto maker Saab Automobile A.B.
"Our audience is pretty sophisticated," he added, referring to the buyers of higher-priced nameplates. "I'm not sure they're people who are terribly fond of" such tactics.
In addition, Mr. Hedge said, the potential buyers of Saabs are knowledgeable enough to realize "what a good value we are," regardless of whether competitors like the Toyota Motor Corporation, the Nissan Motor Company and the Honda Motor Company are forced to sell their luxury brands at far higher prices than now. (At the moment, however, the Japanese car makers say they will not pass on the higher tariff to their customers.)
"Do we need to prime the pump?" Mr. Hedge asked. "I think it would happen automatically."
That thought was echoed by Ms. Hamilton at Jaguar. "Right now, in terms of our advertising, the luxury value-price equation is working well for us," she said, citing an increase in sales in the American market of 31.7 percent for the first four months of 1995, compared with the corresponding period a year ago.
Mr. Austin at Volvo said: "The most important thing for us to do is get Volvo on the shopping lists of more people, and our campaign we feel is doing that because business is going rather well for us. So we don't want to detract from that." For the first four months of this year, Volvo sales in the United States rose 7.2 percent, compared with the corresponding period in 1994.
Robert C. Doherty, chairman and chief executive of McKinney & Silver in Raleigh, N.C., the agency for Audi of America, borrowed a term from political strategists to describe his intentions to continue emphasizing the themes now prevalent in the Audi campaign.
"You can anticipate no such advertising from Audi" centered on the tariff, he said, "because that would be 'off message.' " McKinney & Silver ads aggressively compare models of Audi, a unit of Volkswagen A.G., to imports like Volvo.
The exception to this trend is the Cadillac division of General Motors. "Even if the sanctions don't go through, this serves to highlight the critical situation relative to our trade imbalance with the Japanese," said Peter Levin, advertising director for Cadillac in Warren, Mich., "and should make the educated, sophisticated luxury-car buyer think twice about American alternatives."
"We see pretty significant opportunity, particularly for the Seville STS," he added, referring to a Cadillac model that costs about $48,000, "as it becomes more and more of a value" relative to tariff-taxed Japanese rivals.
Mr. Levin took issue with the belief that if the tariff took effect, shoppers suffering from sticker shock over Japanese imports would automatically gravitate to European imports and ignore American-built products. He cited research showing that "Seville and Seville STS are getting pretty high consideration levels and are starting to 'conquest' more and more."

HEADLINE: Harold M. Jacobs, 81; Civic and Religious Leader

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
Harold M. Jacobs, a former chairman of New York City's Board of Higher Education and a past president of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan.
He was 81 and lived in Lawrence, L.I.
A successful Brooklyn businessman, Mr. Jabobs held two distinct leadership roles, civic and religious, serving for more than two decades as a member and chairman of the Board of Higher Education and as a spokesman for Jewish orthodoxy in this country.
His final years on the board were marked by the controversy over the board's attempt to fire Dr. Leonard Jeffries as chairman of the black studies department at City College.
Mr. Jacobs was one of four board members who spoke out against Dr. Jeffries and actively sought his ouster because of the professor's anti-Semitic comments. As a result, Mr. Jacobs was one of four board members who were assessed $80,000 in damages in 1994 in a suit filed against the board by Dr. Jeffries in Federal Court in Manhattan. But a Federal appeals court in Manhattan reversed the ruling last month, holding that City College acted within its rights in removing Dr. Jeffries as chairman.
Mr. Jacobs was a lifelong friend of former Mayor Abraham D. Beame, who appointed him to the Board of Higher Education in 1974. Mr. Jacobs was named chairman two years later.
Mr. Jacobs was a strong advocate of charging tuition at the City University of New York, which began in 1975. He also advocated tough financial reforms during the city's fiscal crisis in 1976, and warned he would seek the resignation of the university's Chancellor, Robert J. Kibbee, unless they were implemented.
As head of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, he advocated a strong, pro-Israel American policy in the Middle East and a tight arms embargo against Israel's Arab neighbors.
The son of a prosperous manufacturer, Mr. Jacobs grew up in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, where he became active in Orthodox Jewish affairs.
Despite his family's wealth, he chose to work his way through college, attending St. John's University at night. His strong sense of self-reliance helped explain his support of tuition in the City University.
"Anyone who wants to go to college badly enough will find a way," he said in 1976. Mr. Jacobs received a master's degree in economics from Columbia University.
Mr. Jacobs built his own business, Precision Ware, into a profitable kitchenware company. He later headed Precision Equities, an investment company.
Mr. Jacobs also served as president of the National Council of Young Israel and as a member of New York State's advisory council for the Small Business Administration.
Mr. Jacobs's wife, Pearl, died last year. He is survived by two sons, Joseph, of Brooklyn, and Paul, of Toronto; a daughter, Vivian Chill of Manhattan, and a sister, Ruth Malinowitz of Queens.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
3 of Japan's Top Securities Firms Post Big Losses

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 18

 BODY:
Battered by Japan's prolonged stock market slump, three of the nation's four biggest securities firms today reported combined losses equivalent to more than $1 billion for the latest fiscal year, while the fourth, the NomuraSecurities Company, announced a sharp decline in profit.
Nomura, Japan's biggest brokerage firm, said pretax profit tumbled 87 percent in the fiscal year that ended on March 31, to 6.80 billion yen ($76 million at the exchange rate of 89 yen to the dollar on March 31) from 50.69 billion yen in the prior fiscal year. 
 The Daiwa Securities Company said it swung to a pretax loss of 24.90 billion yen from a profit of 52.03 billion yen in the previous year. The Yamaichi Securities Company reported a loss of 50.6 billion yen in contrast to a profit of 17.87 billion yen, and the Nikko Securities Company showed a loss of 19.25 billion yen from a profit of 35.02 billion yen.
The firms' results were for the parent companies only; they will report group results later. Also today, all of Japan's nine second-tier brokerage firms reported parent-company losses for the fiscal year.
The brokerage houses were hurt by low volume on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, which is slumping because of Japan's weak economy and sluggish corporate profits.
"We suffered from steep declines in commission income, in particular on stockbroking," said Nomura's managing director, Atsushi Saito. "We don't expect our revenue will drastically improve in the near future. Unless we take drastic steps, we may be overwhelmed by Western houses advancing into Japan and Japanese banks' securities subsidiaries."
 Analysts said financially weak brokerage houses would be forced to seek outside capital or close down. "But like Nomura, strong houses will become much stronger," an analyst at a domestic research institute said.
 Mr. Saito said: "The current conditions are the same as what happened in the United States in the 1970's, and we must diversify our strategy toward income sources. We see China and other Asian countries as a major source of future income."
Last month, Mr. Saito said, Nomura was profitable because of its bond business, even though average daily volume on the Tokyo Stock Exchange was only about 210 billion yen from the start of April through mid-May. Nomura views daily turnover of 250 billion yen as a break-even level. During the full fiscal year, volume averaged 330 billion yen a day, below the four firms' forecast of 400 billion yen.
 The three big firms that reported losses, Daiwa, Yamaichi and Nikko, said they expected to return to profitability in the current fiscal year.

HEADLINE: 4-Week Average of Jobless Claims Is Up

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for state unemployment benefits dipped slightly last week, but the more important four-week average shot up to the highest level in nearly a year, the Government said today.
New claims for unemployment pay decreased by 2,000, to 364,000, in the week that ended last Saturday, the Labor Department said. The weekly total exceeded Wall Street economists' forecasts of 361,000 initial claims. 
 The closely watched four-week moving average, which is considered a more accurate barometer of the labor market than the weekly figure because it irons out weekly fluctuations, climbed to 363,000 last week, the highest since 365,500 in the week that ended on May 28, 1994.

HEADLINE: Britannica Didn't Care Enough About Sales

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Slow-to-Adapt Encyclopaedia Britannica for Sale" (Business Day, May 16): At $1,500, is the price of the printed Britannica really so high? Each page has about 1,300 words, versus about 350 for a normal book. At 1,100 pages, each volume contains nearly a million-and-a-half words. Should the vast and indefinitely useful Britannica charge the market price for the nearly 600 scholarly books it represents -- $30,000? 
 I know a small-town newspaper editor who recently replaced her 1950's Britannica. She remarked that if the 1955 price had merely kept pace with inflation, it would have been several thousand dollars more.
You have to spend money to make money, and I fear the Britannica has been very phlegmatic on the sales side. It is not for sale in shops.
Two months ago I saw a small notice in a computer magazine about the Britannica CD. I called the number listed, and was informed that I couldn't buy the product except from a local sales office in New York, whose number was then provided.
The woman at the New York office never offered to take an order for her product. After a long discussion about whether I represented a business, educational or governmental entity, she promised to send "the information." It never arrived. If lazy management causes our cultural institutions to collapse, it must be seen as the enemy, not the marker, of civilization.
 
ADAM P. J. O'CONNOR
Editor in Chief
RILM Abstracts of Music Literature
New York, May 16, 1995

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Mix of Cultures, Politics and Bravado

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
Major exhibitions of contemporary African art are rare in New York City. The last one of note was the 1993 "Fusion: West African Artists at the Venice Biennale," a fascinating, tough-to-love show organized by the Museum for African Art for Europe and brought to SoHo last year.
Of its five artists, the outstanding presence was a 38-year-old painter who goes by the name Ouattara (pronounced wah-TARA). His big assemblages of paint, dirt and found objects, pierced with niches and crowned with architectural turrets, had the texture of mud-walled shrines, but their vibrant combination of graffitilike words and gestural abstraction recalled epic-minded Western pasticheurs like Anselm Kiefer and Julian Schnabel. 
 The artist is now having his first solo show with Gagosian Gallery, and it's a knockout. The new paintings are almost absurdly ambitious: grand in scale (13 feet across in some cases), broadly but confidently painted and packed with a dense pileup range of images in which African history and American rap music, voodoo and Joseph Beuys's shamanism, colonialist remnants and Pan African politics maintain an exhilarating coexistence.
This mix is entirely in line with Ouattara's own background. He was born in the Ivory Coast, and although by his own account his childhood was shaped by such traditional events as initiation rituals. An uncle, Draman Ouattara, was, for a time, the Ivorian Prime Minister and later an executive director for the World Bank in the United States. Ouattara himself left Africa for Paris to pursue his career as an artist. There he met the American artist Jean-Michel Basquiat, who not only bought his work in bulk, but also brought him to New York, where he now spends much of his time, while commuting to Paris and Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
American, European and African cultures mingle seamlessly in the new work, though from first to last it is Africa that predominates. The first painting in the show, the mural-size "Nkrouma Berlin 1885," is a vivid symbolic precis of the continent's modern history, beginning in 1885, when European powers gathered in Berlin to carve Africa up into the disruptive and arbitrary proprietary units still in place today.
Against the form of a vermilion cross stand two dark tutelary figures, one with bound arms, the other with hands raised in prayer. Between them, written in the Amharic language of Ethiopia, is the name of Kwame Nkrouma of Ghana, who was both President of Africa's first independent nation and who urged Pan African unity. Finally, at the painting's very center is a scrap of paper bearing the name of European cigarettes, a wry souvenir of the discarded but ever-present colonialist past.
Political references are still more pointed elsewhere. One painting makes allusions to the existence of contemporary slavery. A grotesque, headless, coffee-colored figure, derived from the artist's reading of the biblical apocalypse, seems to be in the process of exploding across a lemon-yellow ground. Legions of olive- and black-skinned figures -- a generic third world labor force -- stand in ranks around him, while a torn burlap bag used for exporting "naturally decaffeinated" coffee is glued to the upper left corner.
Like the work of Beuys, Ouattara's is framed in epochal and universalist socio-spiritual terms. It is an approach generally out of fashion in New York's mainstream art at present, but he makes a vividly convincing case for it in paintings like "Mami Wata," which brings together the Afro-Caribbean deity with a Christian cross and voodoo instruments in a symmetrical composition that actually suggests a ritual enactment in progress but manages to sustain an unpretentious, street-smart pop edge.
Popular culture itself is the subject of "Hip-Hop Jazz Makoussa," with its two horizontal bands of collaged record album covers, echoed by attenuated male and female African figures. Here Aretha Franklin and Bob Marley, John Coltrane and the Rolling Stones, Queen Latifah and African bands form an edge-to-edge continuum, which has African culture at its roots and which is "blessed," to quote the Amharic word on the painting's surface.
The distinctive blend of wit and gravity in the Gagosian show, which has been organized by Raymond Foye, is most arrestingly embodied in "Dark Star." Here the figure of death appears in the form of a gold skeleton, posed with the hip-slung insouciance of a rock hero as he pounds out rhythms on a drum. A skull fused with an ahnk, the Egyptian symbol of eternal life, appears elsewhere. The rest of the huge canvas is filled with circling blood-red footprints, left by the artist as he danced across its surface, and a sea of handprints like a communal gesture of either praise or dismay.
The sense of community -- of a kind of spiritual force field shared across cultures -- is strong here, as it was, in a crankier, angrier, specifically urban way in Basquiat's work. And indeed it is easy to see why the American artist championed his African colleague. In some ways they are mirror reflections: the black American artist channeling African influences and making them his own, the African channeling American influences and making them his own. The resemblance between the two ends there -- the work of one could never be mistaken for the other -- but the connection suggests vibrant future directions for contemporary art on both sides of the Atlantic.
The works of Ouattara remain at the Gagosian Gallery, 65 Thompson Street, SoHo, through June 10.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A detail of "Mami Wata" (1994), by Ouattara, at the Gagosian Gallery. (Orcott)

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Madonna Pitches In for High Art
Madonna and the Philadelphia Museum of Art might at first seem like strange bedfellows. But think about it. The rock star is a collector of 20th-century Mexican paintings and photographs, as well as a supporter of the arts. And the Philadelphia Museum, like all arts institutions, needs support for its special exhibitions.
So when Anne d'Harnoncourt, the museum's director, learned that Madonna was an admirer of the photographer Tina Modotti, she approached her to see if she would be interested in supporting a major Modotti exhibition scheduled to open in Philadelphia on Sept. 16. "We proposed and she accepted," Ms. d'Harnoncourt said. 
 But Madonna has a more creative notion of beneficence than simply writing a check. On June 10, Sotheby's in New York will auction her 1969 white convertible Mercedes 280 SE, the one she drove in her 1994 music video "Deeper and Deeper." It is expected to sell for $40,000 to $60,000, with proceeds going to the exhibition.
In the past, Madonna has donated items to charity auctions, but often the buyers would turn around and sell them at auction, making a substantial profit by using her name as the bait. "Now she would rather sell something directly than see it marked up 10 times and have the profits go to an individual," said her press agent, Liz Rosenberg. About Madonna's choice of an exhibition to finance, Ms. Rosenberg said it shouldn't be seen as unusual: "Madonna's always been a Modotti fan."
Ms. d'Harnoncourt said she hoped the car would "go through the roof," especially since the museum needs more than $125,000 for the show. She also said the show might attract an interesting crowd because of Madonna's involvement. "It certainly gives the show an extra spin, an added element of intrigue," she said. "But people may be surprised that Modotti is not as highly contemporary as Madonna is."
 
Expansion at the Cooper-Hewitt
 The Cooper-Hewitt, the National Design Museum that is part of the Washington-based Smithsonian Institution, has an ambitious agenda. It is about to embark on a $20 million renovation that will force the museum to close for a year, beginning on Aug. 21.
This will be the first time the institution has expanded its home in the Andrew Carnegie mansion on Fifth Avenue and 91st Street. The building was renovated into a museum in 1976, when the Cooper-Hewitt moved uptown from the Cooper Union.
"This is a major turning point for us," said Dianne H. Pilgrim, the Cooper-Hewitt's director. "Two and a half years ago, we hired Polshek & Partners to do the design."
Besides an upgraded climate control system and more efficient study and storage areas, which will better preserve the 250,000 objects in the Cooper-Hewitt's collection, more of the museum will be open to the public. The building will also be totally accessible to the disabled.
A new design research and resource center is also a major part of the scheme. It will be housed in two adjacent brownstones, 9 and 11 East 90th Street, which the museum owns. The two buildings will be linked internally and connected to the Carnegie mansion. Financing is a joint effort. The Smithsonian has provided $13 million, and the museum has raised almost $3 million privately. "We need to raise $4 million more," Mrs. Pilgrim said.
Though the museum will close its exhibitions, it will still offer its educational programs and workshops in its main building, and the library and curatorial departments will remain open.
That's not to say the Cooper-Hewitt has curtailed its curatorial efforts. The museum plans a number of off-site exhibitions during the renovations, among them "Six Bridges and the Making of the New York Megalopolis," scheduled to open in January at the Paine Webber Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, at 51st Street.
 
Bold Sculptures for the White House
 The First Lady's Garden at the White House has a new look. Instead of being dominated by demure spring flower beds, it is filled with bold sculptures by such artists as David Smith and Mark di Suvero, Beverly Pepper and David Deming.
The setting is the second in a four-part series called "20th-Century American Sculpture at the White House," organized by the Committee for the Preservation of the White House and the Association of Art Museum Directors. When conceiving the series, J. Carter Brown, the director emeritus of the National Gallery of Art in Washington and head of a sculpture subcommittee, said the panel had decided to divide the series into four geographic areas: Midwest, West, South and Northeast. The first exhibition in the series, "Statues Into Sculpture," which was on view for five months beginning in October, was organized by George W. Neubert, director of the Sheldon Memorial Art Gallery and Sculpture Garden at the University of Nebraska at Lincoln. It represented only Midwestern artists.
The new exhibition was organized by Townsend Wolfe, director and chief curator of the Arkansas Arts Center in Little Rock, and consists of 12 sculptures from museums in the Southeast. All the works were created since 1965. The first part "dealt with the development of sculpture from the turn of the century to the present," Mr. Wolfe said in a telephone interview this week. "This show deals with more contemporary artists."
 
Record Prices for Latin Artists

 Economic problems in Latin America don't seem to have hurt the market for Latin American art. On Wednesday, at a Sotheby's sale of Latin American paintings, drawings and sculpture, 11 artists made record prices. Ten works from the I.B.M. collection were included in the auction, and they were the stars of the evening. Frida Kahlo's 1942 "Self-Portrait With Monkey and Parrot" sold for $3.1 million, the highest-priced painting in the sale and a record price for the artist. The buyer was Eduardo Costantini, a financier from Buenos Aires. Another record was made for Diego Rivera's "Dance in Tehuantepec," which was bought by an unidentified pricate collector for $3 million.
"Ten years ago buyers tended to be nationalistic," said August Uribe, who heads Sotheby's department of Latin American art. "We are now seeing an internationalization in the market."

HEADLINE: Iran's Nuclear Goals Lie in Half-Built Plant

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: BUSHEHR, Iran, May 16

 BODY:
At a vast construction site baked by the sun and buffeted by the salty Persian Gulf air, two partly built nuclear reactors are frozen in time.
For the Iranians, the enormous steel and concrete structures represent what might have been and what might be, a symbol of their legal right to develop nuclear energy and of their potential to become a great regional power. 
 For the Americans, the reactors are an ominous sign of Iran's determination to build nuclear nergy Agency have never reported suspicious activity.
But the plant has strained Washington's relationship with Moscow, aggravated already inimical relations between the United States and Iran and trained the spotlight on a place that has yet to produce either a gram of enriched uranium or a watt of electricity.
The United States and Germany say they have amassed substantial evidence that Iran is secretly buying components and technology from abroad that point to a determined weapons program. The American view is that the Bushehr project is dangerous because it will bring hundreds, perhaps thousands of Russian experts to Iran who could help build nuclear bombs.
Despite the insistence of Iran's leaders that they have no intention of becoming a nuclear power, they have invited few outsiders to Bushehr, and in opening up the complex to a foreign reporter, they clearly intended to prove they have nothing to hide.
"We only want to get the benefit of the huge amount of money we have already spent," Reza Amrollahi, the head of Iran's nuclear program, said in an interview in Teheran. "We have the right, just like any other country, to develop a peaceful nuclear energy program."
Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi once said Iran would have nuclear weapons "without a doubt and sooner than one would think," and it was he who asked Siemens of Germany in the 1970's to build a nuclear energy complex for his country.
The revolutionaries who toppled the Shah in 1979 vowed, as they put it, not to waste the people's money on such a frivolous project, and they canceled the contract. Then, several years later, they changed their minds and decided to make good on the Shah's $6 billion investment.
But the German Government, suspicious of Iran's intentions and under intense American pressure, determined to avoid all nuclear cooperation with Iran. Then the Russians came along this past January with an irresistible bargain: they would build and install a light-water reactor in one structure for only $780 million, and finish the second one if the first went well.
"Because of the bad economic situation in Russia, the Russians can do industrial and technical magic here," said Kazem Khabir, the deputy manager of the site and a nuclear engineer who received his master's degree from the University of Oklahoma. "For such a small price, I don't think the West could have done such a thing."
The site has been largely untouched in the 16 years since the Shah was overthrown.
Although soldiers guard the entrance and at least one antiaircraft gun is on the site, the entire complex can easily be seen from the villages and farms nearby.
With 2,000 housing units, subsidized food shop, hospital, barber shop, elementary school, bakery, bank, laundry, swimming pools, playground, movie theater and vast dining halls capable of serving 4,000 people, the thousand-acre complex resembles a small Government-run village, not a sophisticated secret cell for learning how to build bombs.
Over the years, the authorities have tried to preserve the site exactly as it was at the time of the Shah. They have covered motor shafts and rotary blades with tar-based paint to lessen the corrosive affects of the humid salty air. Visitors are required to remove their shoes at the entrance to a sophisticated information center, to prevent salt from damaging the carpets.
German-made models of planned reactors are so detailed that they include all the auxiliary buildings, complete with vehicles, palm trees and even tiny workers dressed in white uniforms and caps. Electronic information boards explain how a thermal power plant operates.
Since the 1979 revolution, the complex has been home to 300 to 400 Iranians who maintain it, and it now houses an estimated 150 Russian engineers and inspectors who have arrived in recent months. The Iranians say 500 Russians will eventually be based on the site; the Russians say they will send 3,000.
Exactly where the Russians are is not clear; there were none to be seen. The ranking Russian official at the site declined a request for an interview, and the Russians have not allowed even official Iranian guests to photograph Russians at the site.
The Russians are said to live in a separate area and report to their own director. They have already imported their own cook, and will open their own primary school next year. People in Bushehr, about 15 miles away, say Russians come by bus and do their shopping every Thursday.
"They are scattered all around," Mr. Khabir explained. "Maybe there are two underneath us, two on top."
Some Russians have had problems adjusting to the rules of an Islamic republic. The few who have been found with women or alcohol have been sent home, according to officials at the complex. Russian women in bathing suits have tried -- without success -- to sneak into the Persian Gulf for a swim.
By all accounts the Russians have an extraordinary job ahead of them.
Iraqi war planes hit the site at least twice in the latter stages of the Iran-Iraq war in the 1980's, damaging one reactor so badly that the structure has been sealed and its protective dome of steel and concrete covered over with sheet metal.
The Germans withheld key blueprints and technical documents relating to the site. That will make it more difficult to fit 1,000-megawatt Russian-made reactors and turbines into a damaged structure intended for German-designed 1,200-megawatt reactors. If the Bushehr site causes anxiety ourside Iran, it may have little to do with the possible spread of bomb-making know-how and more to do with the issue of nuclear safety.
Already there are conflicting analyses of what structures Russia will be able to salvage. Iranian officials insist the metal dome and the partly completed concrete dome that surrounds it can be salvaged. Some Russian officials say the work may be much more extensive.
Sergei Tretyakov, Russia's Ambassador to Iran, said in an interview that Russia would have to lay a new foundation for the reactor; Mr. Khabir said he believed that the existing foundation was sound.
The Russians also question whether Iran, with its worsening economy, will be able to pay for the project.
"It's a cash deal, a commercial deal, and they'll have to pay in installments in advance," Mr. Tretyakov said. "If they pay, we will go on; if they don't, we'll stop."
The main work is yet to get started. During the Government-arranged visit, fewer than 50 Iranian workers could be seen, welding metal, moving equipment, bringing in electricity and serving meals and tea. Huge cranes on the top of the reactor stood idle.
"It's a monument," said one Iranian official connected with the nuclear energy program. "You visited a monument, a dead monument."

HEADLINE: Japanese-American Judges Reflect on Internment

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 18

 BODY:
The places themselves Tule Lake and Manzanar, Calif.; Minidoka, Idaho; Topaz, Utah -- have largely returned to dust. But for five Japanese-American judges, the internment camps of World War II still loom large, either because they claimed chunks of their childhoods or because, even for those too young to have been in them, they cast a long and gloomy shadow over their lives.
Last week, before an audience that included many others who had been interned, the five judges reflected on the relocation of 120,000 Japanese-Americans, two-thirds of them United States citizens, during the war and its effect on them and their offspring. And because one of those descendants is the judge presiding over the O. J. Simpson trial, the epoch moved from the footnotes to the footlights. 
 As seven television cameras recorded the scene, Judge Lance Allan Ito explained how his very name is a monument to the internment experience.
His parents, who met at a camp in Heart Mountain, Wyo., had named him Lance for the San Francisco lawyer who had unsuccessfully sued the Federal Government for what his parents lost during their three years of incarceration. It was an honor that came, in a sense, in lieu of a fee. Allan was for the pastor of the Mount Hollywood Congregational Church, who took care of his parents' homes while they languished 1,400 miles away.
Judge Ito was born in 1950, four years after the last of the 10 camps closed. But three other panelists at the gathering sponsored by the Japanese-American National Museum and the Los Angeles Jewish Federation were interned for three years of their youth. They recalled the indignities, like sleeping on mattresses they had stuffed with straw, or sharing toilets with hundreds of others, or covering knotholes in the flimsy wooden barracks walls with tin cans to keep out the dust.
They talked as well about the paradoxes of the relocation: being removed days after selling war bonds; being taught behind barbed wire about the glories of freedom; watching newly minted Gold Star mothers cry in captivity for their soldier sons who had served in the United States Army, and had died in battle.
The three who were interned reflected on how the years spent under watchtowers and searchlights had guided them toward the law and guide them still on the bench, sensitizing them to civil liberties and the rights of minorities.
"It has certainly affected me 26 hours a day," said Judge Robert M. Takasugi of Federal District Court in Los Angeles, calling his internment "an education to be fair."
Judge A. Wallace Tashima, also of the Federal District Court, concurred. "I'm still keenly aware that the Government can make mistakes, and probably more conscious than I otherwise would have been of the persecution of minorities," Judge Tashima said in an interview. He is soon to become the first American of Japanese ancestry to sit on the United States Court of Appeals.
For all the reminiscences, the speakers at the gathering here warned that anti-immigrant hysteria, particularly in economically hard-pressed California, was not some historic artifact; nor was anti-Japanese prejudice. Though unable -- or unwilling -- to summon his name, Judge Takasugi spoke caustically of the stereotypic sing-song impersonation of Judge Ito by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, in a recent radio interview, calling it "a disgrace."
At the same time, last week's event at the museum demonstrated how far Japanese-Americans have come since February 1942, when President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed Executive Order 9066, setting in motion the mass removal of people of Japanese ancestry. "If the five of us had been sitting as public officials in 1942, it's hard to conceive that we would have been forcibly removed from the state of California," said Judge Tashima, a California native who was interned in Poston, Ariz.
The evening also furnished a chance to see the newest new Judge Ito. As the Simpson trial drones on, the only emotion the new Judge Ito has come to show is annoyance. Here, as he recounted his maternal grandfather's suicide, a grandmother's citizenship ceremony, his two visits to Dachau, his voice cracked and his composure vanished.
In arranging the evening, the Los Angeles Jewish Federation attempted the delicate and sometimes thankless task of showing that while no wartime experience could compare with the Holocaust, no group had a monopoly on suffering. .
The Japanese-American National Museum is in the city's Little Tokyo section, close to -- in Los Angeles that means only a short drive from -- Judge Ito's courtroom. The program included a reception, in which Jews and Japanese-Americans shared kosher sushi and California rolls near an exhibition on the liberation of Dachau and a computer terminal where a sign stated: "Find Your War Relocation Records Here. Limit requests to 4 Per Family."
At the internment camps, apart from the heat and the cold, the rattlesnakes, the scorpions and the mud, the barracks so indistinguishable that youngsters sometimes got lost on their way "home" from the latrines, life was not always painful, at least for children. With hundreds of contemporaries in close proximity, they lacked neither for playmates nor activities: the Heart Mountain camp, for instance, had seven Boy Scout troops. (When the future Representative Norman Y. Mineta of California was allowed to leave the internment camp for a jamboree, his tent mate there was the future Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming.)
Nor, in a place where everyone ate in the same mess halls and lived in the same rude rectangles, were its legacies all deleterious. "It was a great leveler of class distinctions," Judge Tashima recalled, "and for someone like myself, coming from a poor background, it was probably advantageous."
But for older Japanese-Americans, who lost their homes, their property and their dignity, the experience was painful. Judge Takasugi's father, 57, died of a stroke brought on, his son believes, by feelings of helplessness at Tule Lake.
Judge Ito described how his maternal grandfather, an insurance salesman before the war, could not reclaim his job, declared bankruptcy and eventually killed himself.
Judge Fumiko Hachiya Wasserman of Los Angeles County Superior Court recalled the shame her father felt among his relatives for the humiliation of internment.
Only years later did Judge Hiroshi Fujisaki, also of Los Angeles County Superior Court, learn that his father had grown so despondent during the ordeal that he considered returning to Japan. It has taken Judge Fujisaki, who was 5 when he was interned at Manzanar, most of his life to shed the feeling that he had deserved to be there.
"I always felt that somehow or another I had something to apologize for," Judge Fujisaki said.
Less than two hours after millions of television viewers had watched him fine two lawyers in the Simpson case, Judge Ito stood alone with his thoughts in the museum's exhibition room, watching archival footage of people boarding Pacific Greyhound buses for the camps, or playing baseball under big, dry Western skies. He then walked across the street, where a shabby tar-paper barracks from Heart Mountain had been reconstructed. Six families had lived in it -- one, conceivably, his own.
Judge Takasugi, who stood nearby, was asked whether it resembled where he had lived. "Yeah, exactly," he replied, "but the floors were tar, so on a hot day we started sinking."
A photographer asked him if he was willing to step inside. "I don't want to go back in, really," Judge Takasugi said. "I'll take the loyalty oath."
Throughout the evening, everyone labored to make things easy for Judge Ito. Though there were frequent references to the Simpson case, all were gentle and affectionate. In an allusion to recent DNA testimony, the evening's moderator, Laurie Levenson of Loyola Law School in Los Angeles, called him "a man who is 1 in 9.7 million."
When Judge Ito's turn to speak came, he initially adopted the same clinical, understated tone in which he usually presides over People v. Simpson. He called the topic under discussion "the relocation experience," much as he calls the trial of the century "the Simpson matter."
But he spoke so quietly that the program's organizer, Heather Rothman of the Jewish federation, stood up and gestured for him to raise his voice. And when he started describing the ceremony in which his grandmother became a United States citizen, his lips twitched and his voice fell out of gear.
He faltered again when he spoke of a childhood visit with his parents in the 1960's to Dachau, which he called "one of the most profoundly moving experiences of my life," and described how he returned to that German camp last year with his wife, Margaret York.
"I told her it was very important," he said. "And I have to tell you, I agree that if it can happen to us, if it can happen to you, it can happen to anybody."

Judge Hiroshi Fujisaki of Superior Court, below, and Judge Robert M. Takasugi of Federal District Court, bottom, at the Japanese-American National Museum.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Are Down, But Investor Influx Cuts Loss

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday, hurt in part by profit taking after its recent rally. But a steep selloff in the stock market helped limit losses as investors fled equities for the relative safety of Treasury bills.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 14/32 , to 1096/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.89 percent from 6.86 percent. 
 The decline in the bond market began after a Government report showed surprising strength in imports and exports, suggesting that economic growth is moving at a faster pace than most people had expected.
The Commerce Department data reported that the overall shortfall between exports and imports fell fractionally to $9.12 billion in March from a revised $9.15 billion in February.
 Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said, "Stronger exports could put some further price pressures on the manufacturing sector, while stronger imports raise the possibility that the consumer may come back strong during the second half of the year."
In another report released yesterday, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said its index of regional business activity increased only slightly, to minus 16.4 this month from minus 16.7 in April The prices-paid subcomponent fell slightly to 28.3 from 31.7, registering the fourth consecutive monthly decline, while the prices received rose to 5.7 from 2.8, still at a relatively low level.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said while the market did take note of the Philadelphia Fed index as well as the trade data, market participants did little more than yawn given that the reports were close to expectations. "The major event taking place over the next few trading sessions, of course, will be the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Tuesday," Mr. Fine said. " But since the Fed is expected to keep its monetary policy unchanged, the major question facing everbody that day may well be, 'What's for lunch?' "
"The economy is presently not strong enough to produce an inflation threat and cause the Fed to tighten, while at the same time the current softness seen in some sectors may well prove temporary, which makes the concept of Fed easing seem very premature."
The bond market was helped yesterday by the biggest selloff in the stock market this year. Investors fleeing stocks typically turn to the relative safety of Treasury bills, which helps support the long end of the market as well.
Next week the Treasury will sell $29.25 billion of two- and five-year notes. In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.15 percent and the five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.40 percent, up two and three basis points, respectively, from the previous day.
In the corporate market, Viacom Inc. joined a number of borrowers that have brought to market more than $16 billion of new debt in the last month.
Yesterday Viacom sold $1 billion of 10-year noncallable junk notes with a 7 3/4 percent coupon at a price of 99.04, to yield 7.89 percent, or about 130 basis points more than the 10-year Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The company drew off a $3 billion shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Standard & Poor's rates Viacom's senior debt BB+, and Moody's Investors Service rates it Ba2. Analysts said the low yield at pricing was more akin to high-grade than junk, suggesting a strong demand for domestic issues.

HEADLINE: Crops Tailor-Made for Profit;
Farmers Alter Their Way of Life to Assure Sales

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: BURCHINAL, Iowa

 BODY:
When he was growing up, Mike Olk helped his father farm. He, too, became a farmer, and like most Midwest farmers he grew as much yellow feed corn or soybeans as possible. Some of the grain was fed to his own animals and the rest was sold to local elevators.
 So, last fall, why did the 39-year-old Mr. Olk spend $650,000 on fancy computerized machinery that weighs, stores and dries grain? 
 "It all boils down to money," Mr. Olk (pronounced Oak) said. By taking advantage of his fancy new machinery to win specialized contracts to grow higher-priced strains of corn and soybeans for domestic and foreign buyers, Mr. Olk can count on making tens of thousands of dollars more than he would if he had continued to follow in his father's footsteps.
 Crop contracts are part of a trend in the agricultural heartland toward reshaping farming to be more like industry. Contracting is not new to fruit and vegetable growers or to farmers producing crops like barley for the beer industry and the corn and beans that become next year's seed. But until recently it was rare in much of the Midwest.
 Now, with commodity prices in the doldrums and with Government price supports shrinking, more Midwest farmers are looking to lift profits by tailoring their crops to the needs of customers, even if that means having to invest in big-ticket machinery.
 Indeed, the food production and marketing chain is becoming more tightly linked, in a transformation that closely resembles what is happening to companies supplying industrial giants like General Motors and mass retailers like Wal-Mart.
 For the consumer, industrialization should lead to lower inflation in food prices. For farmers, it should lead to more stable earnings and spell the difference between profits and red ink in lean years. And for the middlemen, it clearly results in more efficiency and higher profits.
 Mr. Olk is growing 300 acres of white corn for use by Quaker Oats in Cap'n Crunch cereal; 350 acres of a recently developed strain of high-oil yellow corn that Du Pont is buying for export to Latin American poultry farms, and 700 acres of high-quality soybeans that Midwest Soya, a food broker in Clear Lake, Iowa, will export to Japanese food companies.
 Such crops must be dried and stored separately from standard grain, most of which goes to animal feed, just as an oil company keeps high-octane gasoline separate from regular blends. The aging grain elevator of the Burchinal Cooperative cannot store specialty crops separately from its several million bushels of regular soybeans and corn.
 For Mr. Olk, the crops under contract take up less than a quarter of his total acreage, but he expects the percentage to grow. He is also marketing his excess drying and storage capacity to neighbors, who can then look for their own contracts with Du Pont and Agri Industries, the unit of Cargill Inc. that handles contract buying for Quaker.
 The contracts and other aspects of industrialization -- from specialization to creating ever-larger farms by renting from landowners -- are a result of a combination of economics and the kind of advanced technology that gives farmers much greater control over their soil, animals and produce. Seed suppliers, for example, are manipulating plant genes to invent new crops with such traits as insect and pesticide resistance, unusually high oil or protein levels or lower fat content.
 The question on many farmers' minds now is how far industrialization will go. The most rapidly industrializing sector -- pork production -- has seen contract farming jump from 2 percent in 1980 to more than 20 percent, with no signs of slowing. The share of food and feed grain grown under contract has tripled by some estimates to 6 percent, from less than 2 percent in 1970.
 Some agricultural leaders like Thomas Urban Jr., chairman and chief executive of Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc., the country's largest seed company, expect the percentage of grain grown under contract to jump to 20 percent during the next 10 years.
 Mike Olk is almost a textbook case of the trend. He got rid of his livestock in the 1980's. His farm has grown to several thousand acres through renting land, and he has had to hire helpers. He is subcontracting work like pesticide spraying. And he has begun to plant and harvest for neighbors to help pay for the top-of-the-line equipment he has bought.
 But in the conservative heartland, a region wary of big business and newfangled technology, some aspects of industrialization have provoked conflict and anxiety.
 The downside of hog factories -- their rigid operating methods, their threat to small farmers, their neighbor-unfriendly stench -- has given rise to fears that the more subtle industrialization of grain farming could also have its unwelcome side. Ultimately, farmers have to decide whether farming is more a business than a way of life -- whether they will grow what customers want or stick to traditional commodities that give them more independence but less stability.
 An increasing number of grain farmers, according to the Agriculture Department, are taking the partial step of signing forward contracts. With the contracts, farmers plant what they choose and have complete control over how they handle their crop. But they commit themselves to a buyer -- and often a specific price -- long before harvest.
 Many farmers experimented with forward contracts in the 1970's when spikes in demand fueled by sporadic large grain sales to the Soviet Union caused prices to gyrate sharply. Now, more farmers see such contracts as a useful way to reduce risks in any market.
 Others are going further by signing contracts even before their crops are planted. The contracts may require investments like Mr. Olk's new grain-handling system, limit what the farmers plant and restrict some of their farming practices.
 Mr. Olk's contract with Du Pont, for example, requires him to use seed supplied by that company. To achieve the purity required of a premium specialty crop, he must plant his crop far enough from other corn so that wind-blown pollen from other strains will not contaminate it.
 And contracts may become more embracing. Frito-Lay, a unit of Pepsico, has begun experimenting with "whole farm" contracts, under which it buys everything a corn farmer grows at a specified price. Such contracts have been used in the past only in niche markets where so little produce is openly traded that it is hard to agree on a market price.
 Crop contracts underscore the increasing need for farmers to have the same management skills as other business executives. "The guy who knows soil and animal husbandry like the back of his hand may not do as well in years to come as the farmer who is a good negotiator," said Mitchell Moreheart, an Agriculture Department researcher who has been studying the impact of industrialization on farming.
 Critics of industrialization say Midwest grain farmers need look only at the pork industry to see how drastic the changes can be. Iowa is following the lead of states like North Carolina and Missouri in what some describe as a shift from breeding pigs to manufacturing pork. Small family-run enterprises are giving way to megafarms owned by a corporation, or other large investor, that raise hundreds, even thousands of hogs. A farmer gets a three- to five-year contract guaranteeing a final price. In buildings erected to corporate specifications, the farmer follows management's rules in breeding the animals -- in some cases specializing in just one part of their life, like the final fattening before slaughter.
 "It's the franchising of the farm economy," said Marty Strange, co-director of the Center for Rural Affairs in Walthill, Neb. The changes have sharply reduced the number of farmers needed to raise pigs and produced more uniform animals for processors. But they have also ignited bitter disputes among neighbors over the megafarms' odor.
 Few experts, however, expect grain farmers to become as tied to production contracts as the pork operators have. Hogs can be confined indoors, but even with improved strains of grain seed, weather remains a big variable for crops. Specialty crops may command a higher price per bushel, but unless they get optimal conditions they may also yield fewer bushels per acre.
 Farmers may also hold back from fear that the companies supplying the seed, chemicals, marketing connections and food-processing capabilities will drive harder and harder bargains as more farmers sign contracts. For example, purchasers might cut the premiums they are offering or demand that farmers buy expensive irrigation equipment.
 Yet the pressure on grain farmers to trade independence for customer satisfaction is bound to grow, industry leaders say.
 "Our goal," said Dean Kleckner, executive director of the Farm Bureau, a group based in Park Ridge, Ill., that represents 4.5 million farmers, "is no longer to sell what we can produce but to produce what we can sell."
