HEADLINE: Senior Clinton Aides Urging Full Relations With Vietnam

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
Senior Administration officials have recommended that the United States establish full diplomatic ties with Vietnam, Administration officials said today.
But Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, and other Republicans have introduced a bill to derail the proposal. 
 The question of normalizing relations flared anew on Tuesday after Vietnamese officials turned over a long-requested batch of documents about Americans missing in action.
Senior officials said there is increasing pressure in the Administration, especially within the State Department, to recognize Vietnam. They said that position is being pushed hardest by Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, but also by the President's economic advisers, especially Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown.
These officials and several people lobbying on the issue noted, however, that some National Security Council aides, notably Nancy Soderberg, chief of staff to the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, oppose the move because they fear it could hurt Mr. Clinton politically. Mr. Lake is leaning against full diplomatic relations with Vietnam, the officials said. Secretary of State Warren Christopher has not made up his mind, a senior aide said.
The question of recognition is one of the most emotional and delicate foreign policy issues the Administration faces. On one side are business groups worried about losing opportunities in the world's fastest-growing region and diplomats hoping to increase American influence as a counterweight to China. On the other are veterans' groups, the families of missing American servicemen and White House advisers who worry about reviving criticism of Mr. Clinton's avoidance of the draft.
The proposed Republican bill, co-sponsored by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, one of Mr. Dole's presidential rivals, said the President should not recognize Vietnam until it has provided full disclosure of all information about the 1,619 Americans missing in Vietnam.
Senator Robert Smith, a New Hampshire Republican who introduced the bill, said: "I think the Administration definitely wants to normalize. I think it's on a fast track within the Administration."
Proponents of normalization have also been scrambling in recent days to thwart that attack. Two decorated Vietnam veterans -- Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Senator John Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat -- maneuvered today to make it easier for Mr. Clinton to grant recognition by saying they would soon introduce a resolution calling on the President to recognize Vietnam -- a step being pursued by many business groups as well.
President Clinton lifted the two-decade-old trade embargo against Vietnam last year, after the Senate approved a bill that those two Senators had introduced calling for an end to the embargo.
"For the sake of America, maybe it's time we ended the war," Mr. McCain, who spent seven years as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam, said in an interview. "I believe normalization would be an important part of the healing process."
Administration officials said no formal recommendation would be made to Mr. Clinton until a Presidential delegation, comprised of officials from the Pentagon, State Department, National Security Council and Department of Veterans Affairs, returns next week from a trip to Vietnam and other Asian countries.
Several officials said the President might grant recognition before Secretary of State Christopher visits Asia in July, well before the presidential campaign heats up. Others said they would not be surprised if the President played it safe politically and granted recognition after the elections in November 1996.
Mr. McCain and several Administration officials asserted that normalization is the best strategy to pursue the main goal of the United States: to gain the fullest possible accounting of missing Americans. Opening an embassy, they say, would insure continued cooperation from the Vietnamese and make it easier for Washington to investigate such cases.
But Senator Smith argues that the only way to gain the fullest possible accounting is by not granting Vietnam the biggest carrot -- recognition -- until it has provided full disclosure of all information on the M.I.A.'s.
Other sponsors of his bill include Strom Thurmond, the South Carolina Republican who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee, and Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who heads the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Mr. Smith insists that Vietnam is not close to providing all the information it has. "It still refuses to release a lot of archival information," he said. "We know based on our own intelligence that there is still information they can provide us on a number of cases."
Under Senator Smith's bill, the President could grant recognition only after certifying that Hanoi has been "fully forthcoming" with information about missing servicemen.
When the Presidential delegation returns from Vietnam, it will analyze the more than 200 pages of analysis and documents Vietnam provided about missing Americans.
A senior State Department official said the view held by Mr. Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State, is that Vietnam deserves recognition because it has provided all the cooperation about missing servicemen that President Bush asked of it four years ago, when he laid out a road map of how it might win normalization.
"The Vietnamese are clearly trying to demonstrate as much cooperation as they can," a senior official said.
According to the President's advisers, Mr. Clinton might approach normalization in several ways. Having agreed to exchange liaison offices last January, he might next decide to open an embassy and exchange ambassadors. Another option would be to announce recognition but send a charge d'affaires instead of a full ambassador. If Vietnam showed continued cooperation on M.I.A.'s, then a decision to exchange ambassadors would follow.
To pave the way for recognition, Administration officials said, the State Department will soon fix up a mansion in Hanoi for the first American ambassador. In addition, the United States is holding talks with Vietnam about human rights, and Assistant Secretary of State Robert Gelbard will soon travel to Hanoi to discuss anti-narcotics efforts.
Corporate America is one of the major forces behind the push for normalization with this economically dynamic country of 75 million.
Major companies say normalization should include not just recognition but also preferential trade status. They also want the Overseas Private Investment Corporation to provide insurance for American companies doing business in Vietnam and the Export-Import Bank to provide low-cost financing.

HEADLINE: Debt-Plagued County Likely To Get Relief

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 19

 BODY:
Orange County is on the verge of an important step in its efforts to emerge from the largest municipal bankruptcy on record. Investors in nearly $1 billion of the county's bonds have agreed in principle to wait a year for repayment, county officials and lawyers involved in the negotiations said today.
The deal, if it is completed, would be a landmark, one of a very few such extensions ever worked out in the municipal bond market. 
 All those involved said the deal was a compromise that recognized the county's serious financial predicament while it avoided an outright default on the bonds, which would have come due over the next several months.
In addition to agreeing to extend the repayment for a year, bondholders have also agreed to significant reductions in the interest rate to be paid.
"This gives us some breathing room," said William J. Popejoy, the county's interim chief executive. "It is not a solution to our problems, but it looks very close, and we believe we're going to put together something that calms the marketplace and avoids an actual default on the bonds."
Bruce Bennett, the county's bankruptcy attorney, emphasized: "This doesn't improve the overall financial situation of the county. It gives us one year to come up with new sources of revenue. It's an important interim step."
Mr. Bennett said the agreement was likely to be completed and submitted to the court overseeing Orange County's bankruptcy next week. The complex plan is subject to the approval of the court and of 90 percent of the owners of the bonds about to come due.
Nevertheless, all sides said they had hopes that the agreement would hold; indeed, at this time it is regarded as the best the investors in the bonds can hope for. A committee representing the largest bondholders has already reviewed and appears to have tentatively approved most of the plan.
Orange County stunned the financial markets when it filed for bankruptcy on Dec. 6 after losing $1.7 billion in a big investment fund. Its former treasurer, Robert L. Citron, had made highly risky investments using complex securities called derivatives, which magnified the extent of his losses when interest rates rose last year and bond prices plunged.
The filing was particularly surprising because Orange County, an area of beaches, country clubs and affluent suburbs just south of here, is one of the wealthiest counties in the country, and its economy is generally sound.
Mr. Citron has since pleaded guilty to six felony charges related to the losses, and the county has been left to grope its way to financial recovery. It has slashed its budget by 41 percent, laid off about 10 percent of its work force and is selling assets in a desperate bid to regain its financial footing.
An agreement on extending the bond repayment dates has been described as one of two essential steps for stabilizing the county. The other step is passage of a half-cent increase in the sales tax, to 8.25 cents per dollar. The tax increase is being bitterly opposed in the conservative county, and a vote on June 27 is expected to be very close.
The tentative agreement reported today covers $975 million of bonds that come due in several steps over the next several months. Under the agreement, repayment would be deferred until June 30, 1996.
Also, the bondholders have agreed to accept a significantly lower interest rate over the next year because the county does not have the money to pay a full market rate.
At the end of the extended period, the bondholders and the county will negotiate payment of additional interest, with the amounts depending on the county's financial ability, the lawyers said.
"This is very, very difficult for them to accept," said Robert Moore, the lead attorney for the bondholders. But, he added, "We've made reasonable progress on all the open issues with the exception of one economic issue, and I'm hopeful there will be movement on that over the weekend."

HEADLINE: Rhode Island's Senate Sends Gay-Rights Bill to Governor

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
The Rhode Island Senate extended civil-rights guarantees to homosexuals last night, approving a measure that would bar discrimination in employment, housing, public accommodations and credit on the basis of sexual orientation.
Gov. Lincoln C. Almond, a Republican, will sign the measure into law, his spokesman said, perhaps as early as Monday. That would make Rhode Island the ninth state to offer specific civil rights protections to homosexuals and the first to do so in two years. 
 The 26-to-21 vote in the Rhode Island Senate capped 11 years of lobbying by gay and lesbian groups and came after four successive defeats in the Legislature. The House of Representatives approved the bill 57 to 41 in March.
The legislation was seen as an important gain nationally for the lesbian and gay civil rights movement, which suffered a major setback a week ago when a Federal appeals court upheld the right of Cincinnati voters to deprive homosexuals of legal protections.
State Senator William P. Fitzpatrick, Democrat of Cranston, who is openly gay and shepherded the Rhode Island bill through the State House in Providence, said, "It's a small state but it's a big victory." He said it was the most significant legislative success since 1993, when a similar measure was passed in Minnesota and signed by Gov. Arne Carlson, a Republican.
Other statewide measures have been enacted in California, Connecticut, Hawaii, Massachusetts, New Jersey, Vermont and Wisconsin.
Christine Nickerson, the president of the Rhode Island Alliance for Lesbian and Gay Civil Rights, said the bill took so many years to pass because "it took a long time to educate people, even to give them a chance to meet gay men and lesbians."
A former president of the alliance, Julie Pell, said there had been a cumulative effect of testimony about discrimination from men and women who were openly gay. "We all know our legislators," she said. "We run into them in the grocery store. When people come out, it makes even more of an impression."
Governor Almond's communications director, Jim Taricani, said the Governor believed the bill was "unfortunately necessary."
Opponents disagreed, arguing that homosexuals do not merit protected status because they are neither economically deprived nor lacking in political influence.
Jerry Burchette, the president of the Coalition to Preserve Traditional Values, also said the bill would "have the effect of trampling under foot the religious rights of the individual to make choices of conscience concerning homosexuality."
Religious leaders were found on both sides of the issue. Bishop Louis E. Gelineau of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence explained in the diocesan newspaper why he had not spoken out against the bill.
"If proposed legislation attempts to condone or promote homosexual activity by equating morally all forms of sexual behavior, then it should be defeated," Bishop Gelineau wrote. "If it merely seeks to afford protection from unjust discrimination, which is not now afforded under our laws, then those laws should be changed."
As the Rhode Island battle entered its final days, the Cincinnati case was often cited by opponents of the bill. The decision came from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, which said laws could not be drafted that protect an "unidentifiable" class of citizens, like homosexuals, who make themselves known only by their conduct.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Icahn Reported Buying Up Rockefeller Center's Debt

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Carl C. Icahn, the financier best-known for wresting Trans World Airlines from its management, has been buying up the debt of Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., the real estate investment trust that holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on Rockefeller Center.
Traders said yesterday that Mr. Icahn's investment firm had been accumulating the trust's bonds since two partnerships that own Rockefeller Center filed for bankruptcy on May 11. The trust is the largest creditor of the partnerships, in which the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Japan has an 80 percent stake and the Rockefeller family has a 20 percent stake. 
 Mr. Icahn was out of his office yesterday and could not be reached for comment.
 As of the end of last year, Mr. Icahn's firm also owned less than 1 percent of Rockefeller Center Properties' 38.26 million shares, most of which are held by individual investors.
 Once known as a corporate raider, Mr. Icahn in recent years has become one of a clique of investors who specialize in buying stakes in distressed companies and parlaying them into savvy investments.
 Many such "vulture" investors have stayed on the sidelines of the Rockefeller Center bankruptcy, however, because the real estate trust's debt has not traded at low enough prices to entice them. Recently, the convertible debentures carrying a 13 percent interest rate and maturing in 2000 have traded at about $97 for every $100 of face value, while the zero-coupon convertible debentures maturing in 2000 have traded at about $48 or $49.
 Separately, Alan Miller, the lawyer representing the real estate trust, said there was no truth to rumors swirling in the market yesterday that the trust planned to file a motion asking Judge Prudence B. Abram to appoint a trustee to administer Rockefeller Center during the bankruptcy.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Sumitomo, World's Biggest Bank, to Post Loss, a Rarity in Japanese Finance

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 19

 BODY:
It's the biggest bank in the world, owns a chunk of Goldman, Sachs, is being harassed and shot at by gangsters, and is little known outside Japan.
 Sumitomo Bank Ltd. has amassed the equivalent of about $624 billion in assets, about two and a half times as much as Citibank, by daring to blaze its own trail in a country that preaches conformity. But now it is facing an array of new challenges that underscore the turmoil in Japan's financial sector. 
 Since 1916, when Sumitomo became the first private bank in Japan to expand overseas, it has been one of the country's most aggressive and profitable institutions. Next week, its aggressiveness will take a new turn, as it takes losses in writing off a large chunk of bad debt. Sumitomo will report a loss for the fiscal year that ended on March 31, becoming the first Japanese bank in the postwar period to report an annual loss. At least three other Japanese banks are also expected to post losses this month.
 Analysts love this sort of aggressiveness, but customers often don't. A survey among corporate banking customers this month found that Sumitomo was the most unpopular bank in Japan -- apparently because it has the temerity to turn down credit risks.
 "If there is any Japanese bank that is most like an American bank, it is Sumitomo," said a Japanese banker at one of Sumitomo's competitors. "It is the most profit-driven. If your industry doesn't have potential, they won't lend to you."
Sumitomo's experience is a warning light to other banks with growth aspirations, particularly the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, which is expected to be formed next spring through the merger of the Bank of Tokyo Ltd. and Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. and will be more than one-third larger than Sumitomo is now.
 Just a few years ago, size and status were everything to a bank. That's why Sumitomo acquired a first class art collection, including a Renoir that reportedly cost $60 million.
 The problem is that in its quest for profits and size, Sumitomo failed to become more efficient at home. To be sure, most of the blame for Sumitomo's domestic inefficiency lies not with the executives of Sumitomo but with stifling Japanese regulations that never made the domestic consumer market very appealing or lucrative.
 But now the regulations are changing, opening up new areas like retail banking in ways that will probably touch off banking wars.
 Banks are facing other mine fields. Demand for credit has been weak for months, sinking interest rates threaten to erode loan margins, a depressed stock market is battering equity portfolios and write-offs of bad loans are shrinking the size of their capital.
 In the 1980's, when becoming an international superbank was a vision for many bankers around the world, the go-go growth in Japan led its bankers to lend recklessly at home and expand breathlessly overseas. Sumitomo added 14 offices abroad in the late 1980's, invested $500 million in Goldman, Sachs and racked up a pile of bad loans.
 It is now paying for that wild growth. It was forced to absorb a large client, Itoman, that collapsed in the middle of an art scandal and led to the resignation in 1990 of Sumitomo's chairman, Ichiro Isoda. Write-downs related to Itoman also make up a significant part of this year's losses, which are expected to be between 250 billion yen and 300 billion yen, or $3 billion to $3.6 billion.
 Then for more than a year, Sumitomo had a series of bizarre brushes with the Japanese underworld. It was the target of more than a dozen attacks, presumably stemming from business dealings with crime syndicates or loans turned sour.
 In 1993, a Molotov cocktail was tossed into the residence of Tatsumi Sotoo, the bank's current chairman. Then, apparently in a separate incident last fall, an executive director in the bank's Nagoya branch was fatally shot.
 Now Sumitomo seems to be turning a new page, at least bringing itself into line with banks in the rest of the modern world. It is building a new computer system, extending banking hours, expanding its lending to small companies and developing better techniques for risk management. It is also cleansing its books and trimming its size to prepare for the next bout of fierce competition.
 "Japan has been behind the United States by 10 years," said the refined president of Sumitomo, Toshio Morikawa, an English speaker who recently stepped down as the industry's leading spokesman. "We see this year as the dawn of a new era of liberalization."
 Last fall, the Ministry of Finance allowed banks to start setting their own rates on their deposits, and bankers worried they would be pulled into the kind of "toaster wars" -- free giveaways for new deposit customers -- that rattled the American retail banking industry in the 1980's.
 But prospects appear grim for that kind of rapid transformation in Japan. Indeed, while some small Japanese financial institutions are offering lottery tickets and savings account rates linked to baseball batting averages or summer temperatures, larger banks like Sumitomo believe such sales techniques are demeaning to their reputation.
 Moreover, the pressure to conform is still strong. The genteel banking association successfully enforces a rule on its member banks that limits the monetary value of souvenirs offered to customers to three small gifts each of 500 yen, or about $6.
 Some bankers and analysts say that rather than adopting an overarching strategy for the future, Sumitomo is still searching, still regrouping from several years of tumult.
 "Not only Sumitomo, but all the major banks are trying to find a way to survive," said a senior official at a Japanese bank. "For five decades after World War II, bankers have lived in a highly regulated industry and top banks look so similar to each other."
 Almost uniformly, the Japanese banks have neglected the consumer. Compared with American institutions, Japanese banks offer very few products -- no telephone banking, mutual funds, credit or debit cards, money market accounts or C.D.'s.
 While Japanese consumers take out home mortgages, they traditionally have been reluctant to borrow, and banks do not offer overdraft privileges or education loans. Even auto loans are limited.
 "The man in the street sees a bank as a place to put money, not get money," said Mark N. J. Faulkner, a bank analyst at S. G. Warburg Securities (Japan) Inc.
 But many bankers and analysts say that may be changing. And the bank that is leading the way ahead is Sumitomo's comrade in spirit, Citicorp, whose expansion in Japan with American-style service puts Sumitomo and other Japanese institutions to shame. Embracing primarily the affluent Japanese consumer, it has set up a network of A.T.M.'s and telephone services that run 24 hours a day. The bank also offers a variety of currency exchange and other products in several cities throughout the country.
 In contrast, Japanese A.T.M.'s are generally open only until 7 P.M., with limited hours on weekends. The problem is that in Japan, there is no checking system. No one writes checks, and no one has a checking account.
 So while some payments can be automatically debited, Japanese consumers rely on A.T.M.'s to pay for newspaper subscriptions, tuition, telephone, and electricity bills among others and must incur the costly charges. To improve its service to customers, Sumitomo is extending its A.T.M. hours to 9 P.M., but not until November.
 Not surprisingly, those who think Sumitomo is not aggressive enough, at least in reaching out to its customers, are Americans.
 "Sumitomo is well known, but staid and conservative," said Robert M. Berardy, consumer marketing manager of Japan operations at Citibank, N.A. "Why can't Sumitomo do 24-hour A.T.M. service?"

HEADLINE: $49.7 Billion Budget Surplus Posted in April, a U.S. Record

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
The Government reported today that it had its largest one-month budget surplus in history last month, reflecting record revenues and the annual flood of income tax payments from individuals close to the April 17 deadline.
 The $49.72 billion surplus for April was almost three times greater than the $17.454 billion surplus in the same month a year earlier, according to the Treasury's budget statement. In March, the United States posted a $49.927-billion deficit. 
 The impact of large individual and corporation tax deposits sent budget receipts to a record high of $165.4 billion last month, the Treasury Department said. Spending, meanwhile, declined from a year earlier.
 Not counting refunds, collections from individual taxpayers in April were $19.5 billion higher than in the same month a year earlier, the Treasury said.
 The April improvement continues a trend of narrowing Federal budget deficits since the Clinton Administration took office. For the first seven months of the fiscal year 1995, the deficit was $94.284 billion, down 28.9 percent from $132.688 billion for the October-through-April period in the previous fiscal year.
 The report came a day after the House approved a plan to eliminate the deficit by 2002.
 In addition to tax payments due in April, last month's budget surplus was bolstered by "a calendar quirk in March," said Scott Brown, an economist at the investment firm Raymond James & Associates Inc. in St. Petersburg, Fla.
 Because April 1 fell on a Saturday, the Government mailed entitlement checks to retirees, veterans and other beneficiaries in late March. That caused the March deficit to balloon by several billion dollars. Benefit checks, like Social Security, are not mailed on weekends or holidays.
 For the entire fiscal year, the budget deficit is on target to total $180 billion to $190 billion, analysts said, an improvement from the $203.267 billion deficit reported for the fiscal year 1994.
 If that happens, the budget deficit as a percentage of the gross domestic product would decline to 2.7 percent for this year from 4.9 percent in 1992, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Why Choose Times Sq. For a Hotel Complex?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your May 12 article on the plans by Disney and developers to build a hotel complex in Times Square and your editorial "Disney on 42d Street" (May 13): 
 Charles Gargano, chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation, said in his announcement of this project that "Times Square represents the vibrancy, creativity and soul of New York." What is so sacrosanct about Times Square?
The soul and greatness of New York can be found not in its popular sites, nor in its tall buildings, but in its people and their institutions.
The proposed gigantic project would prove to be a great blunder in urban planning. The area, the city's most traffic-congested spot, also teems with pedestrians. Any additional big structures would intensify the strangulation of the central area of the city.
There is no question that the seedy parts of Times Square need regeneration. However, the plan must be slimmed down and aimed not at increasing but at decreasing the density of commercial movement. The ideal solution would be to transform the area into an arts-and-culture hub, to reflect the real soul of our city.
And think also what lasting benefits New York would derive from a $300 million project developed elsewhere, in a more appropriate part of the city.
 
MAX M. TAMIR
New York, May 14, 1995
 
The writer is an urban planner.

HEADLINE: Ambitious for History

BYLINE: By Elaine Sciolino; Elaine Sciolino is the chief diplomatic correspondent of The New York Times.

 BODY:

BATTLING FOR PEACE
A Memoir.
By Shimon Peres.
Edited by David Landau.
Illustrated. 350 pp. New York:
Random House. $25. 
TOWARD the end of this memoir, Shimon Peres, the Israeli politician and leader, likens himself to the "unpaid dreamer" of a short story by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. Indeed, Mr. Peres has been vilified, not praised, by his own people for the visionary approach he has brought to a political career that spans six decades. Israeli politicians and journalists have castigated him as "Israel's Nixon" for what they see as his inauthenticity, and have dismissed him as superficial for his compulsion to churn out new ideas regardless of their weight or wisdom.
That explains why Mr. Peres, currently Israel's Foreign Minister, seeks to portray himself now as victor and victim, to stake out his place in history as a peacemaker and to settle scores like any other politician. He makes no excuses for his optimistic world view. On the contrary, he tries to explain and defend it, not only for posterity but for whatever remains of his political career. "I feel I have earned the right to dream," he writes. "This book is my personal testimony to the fact that it is permissible for a man to dream -- not just any dreams, but great dreams."
Although "Battling for Peace" is brief by American autobiographical standards, it traverses Mr. Peres's 71-year life and his performance in almost every key ministerial job. He speaks here with the voice of the unabashed romantic (which sounds fine in English, but is not likely to play well back home when the memoir is published in Hebrew). Born Shimon Persky, the "adored firstborn" of a well-off merchant family in a Belarussian shtetl, he relates his arrival in "Jewish Palestine" at age 10. As a teen-ager he devoured Dostoyevsky, edited his high school newspaper, flirted with Communism and dreamed of his future as a "brawny, sunburned kibbutz farmer, plowing the fields of the fertile Jezreel Valley by day, singing lustily in the common dining room at suppertime, guarding the perimeter fearlessly by night on a fleet-footed horse."
Yet the book is a reminder of the concrete achievements that Mr. Peres's dreams helped produce. As the 29-year-old director general of the Israeli Defense Ministry under his mentor, Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, Mr. Peres helped build Israel a modern army, secretly buying arms from Western and Eastern Europe. Against all odds, and despite a profound lack of enthusiasm in most of the Cabinet, he later helped make Israel a nuclear power -- covertly importing hundreds of French scientists, commissioning Israel's top architects and engineers, begging for money from Israel's friends around the world and building roads while laying miles of power lines and water pipes for the massive desert project at Dimona. During his two years as Prime Minister in the mid-1980's, he extricated most of Israel's troops from Lebanon, an occupation he called "bloody and pointless," and shrank Israel's inflation rate from 800 percent to 20 percent. Perhaps most important, had it not been for the combination of Mr. Peres's dreams and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin's sang-froid, a peace accord between Israelis and Palestinians might never have happened.
Mr. Peres is a master of the telling detail that both captures the moment and entrances the reader. There is the American diplomat Averell Harriman, seducing Mr. Peres into downing glasses of Russian vodka at a White House lunch, saying, "Let's drink it for its taste and ignore its origin." And Moshe Dayan as military Chief of Staff, shooting pigeons with his shotgun from his office balcony so that he would have a main course for his 39th-birthday party dinner. And Uganda's President Idi Amin, protecting the passengers on the hijacked jet at Entebbe after being sweet-talked by the Israelis into believing that he might win a Nobel Prize. And King Hussein, clearly one of Mr. Peres's heroes, joking irreverently about President Ronald Reagan's sincere inquiry about fishing in the Dead Sea.
The clarity of Mr. Peres's impressions in those instances makes one long for more. Peace with the Palestinians would have been impossible without the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, yet he appears only fleetingly. Even the casual reader will find it frustrating that Mr. Peres omits his intense exchanges with Mr. Arafat over ideology and territory, and their endless negotiations over such mundane issues as the color of the protective glass at Palestinian checkpoints.
The flaw of "Battling for Peace" is that Mr. Peres tries to answer history too soon. His memoir is two years too early and 200 pages too short. Like a meal with both satisfying and skimpy courses, the book is at times brilliant, at times uneven. Mr. Peres's only turn as Prime Minister is dealt with in a nine-page chapter; he shares his impressions of American Presidents -- from John F. Kennedy to George Bush -- in six pages at the end of his chapter on the Iran-contra affair. Bill Clinton is not included.
Still, Mr. Peres has produced a volume that combines a well-argued political analysis with elegant prose (perhaps with the help of his editor, the Israeli journalist David Landau). Unlike many other writers on the Middle East, he does not assume extensive knowledge of Israel, making his book accessible to nonexperts on the region.
The memoir gives Mr. Peres the opportunity to settle scores, and settle he does. His rivalry with Mr. Rabin has been well documented over the years, and Mr. Peres is torn between his desire to defend himself and his desire to stand, statesmanlike, above the fray. There was no "special comradeship between us," he writes.
Some of the complaints seem petty. Mr. Peres feels obliged, for example, to take exception to the charge in Mr. Rabin's own 1979 memoir that he opposed Mr. Ben-Gurion's appointment of Mr. Rabin as military Chief of Staff. He also writes that he was "aghast" to read in the same book that he told people before the 1967 Middle East war that Israel couldn't and mustn't fight. He calls Mr. Rabin's charge that he was involved in leaking records of his conversations with Henry Kissinger in the mid-1970's "another unfounded allegation." And he denies Mr. Rabin's assertion that he ever tried to undermine him during the 1974-77 Government led by Mr. Rabin.
With strains like these, it is hard to comprehend how the two men have actually worked with each other. But somehow, when it comes to serious matters, Israel's ministers seem to stick together. Thus Mr. Peres explains how Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, Mr. Rabin and he circled the wagons during the Reagan Administration's ill-fated venture into swapping arms for hostages with Iran. And after his galling defeat by Mr. Rabin for Prime Minister in June 1992, Mr. Peres concludes that "bitterness is not statesmanship," and he credits Mr. Rabin with giving him the chance to carry out the months of secret negotiations with the Palestine Liberation Organization that led to the Israeli-Palestinian accord. Mr. Rabin "was skeptical about the Oslo talks," Mr. Peres writes of the crucial weeks in the late spring of 1993. "Sometimes he wholly disbelieved in them. . . . Nonetheless, he gave me, and the talks, a chance. And ultimately, when the final goal became attainable, he did not draw back."
SINCE Mr. Peres is still working for Mr. Rabin, it is not surprising that he withholds the stories of their continuing animosity: his deep resentment on the day of the Israeli-Palestinian signing ceremony at the White House, when Mr. Rabin at first excluded him from the Israeli delegation; his humiliation when, in meetings with American officials, Mr. Rabin interrupted him to deliver the punch lines of his jokes.
As statesmanlike as he tries to be, Mr. Peres makes no effort to hide his most painful diplomatic disappointment: his failure in the late 1980's to make a separate peace with Jordan. A lifelong admirer of King Hussein, he reveals the details of their secret meeting in London in 1987, which produced a written framework for peace between the two countries. Both the King and Mr. Peres wanted the Americans to present the agreement as an American proposal. But Prime Minister Shamir sabotaged the scheme by secretly sending his envoy, Moshe Arens, to Washington to inform Secretary of State George P. Shultz that if the United States presented the plan, it would be considered crass interference in Israel's internal affairs. Mr. Shultz agreed, and Mr. Peres, who expected more from the Americans, never forgave him.
That sense of betrayal, Mr. Peres now writes, was one of his reasons, six years later, for excluding the Clinton Administration from the secret channel in Oslo that produced the accord with the Palestinians. "I learned my lesson from the London agreement," Mr. Peres says he told Warren Christopher, Bill Clinton's Secretary of State. "Shultz got cold feet at the last moment." According to the American side, these words were never spoken.
"Battling for Peace" is neither the beginning nor the end of the story. Mr. Peres's 1993 book, "The New Middle East," was a sweeping, albeit fantastic, vision of a region where peace and prosperity would one day reign. In this volume, he tells his readers: "My life's work is not yet done. The final, crowning chapters of my biography are still being written at this time."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 28; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1133 words

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
Fix-It Journalism

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL 

 BODY:
A HALF-CENTURY ago, Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger detected what she thought was an appalling ignorance of American history among allegedly educated college graduates. The daughter, wife and mother of newspaper executives, she used her influence to encourage The New York Times to test her hypothesis in a national survey. The survey found that only 18 percent of the nation's colleges and universities required students to take a course in American history. The revelation prompted many schools to change their degree requirements and won a Pulitzer Prize for The Times. Since then, unfortunately, a lot more American history, including Mrs. Sulzberger's modest crusade, has been forgotten.
I invoke its memory now because present newspaper owners and editors think they are inventing a new ideology when they ask journalists to use their skills and influence to promote civic virtue. Their movement, which they call "public" or "civic" journalism, seeks a new "connection" with the community to cure it of "political disaffection." That will happen, they believe, if news coverage becomes a more deliberate act of citizenship, dedicated to the solution and not just description of social problems. And while many of them would praise Mrs. Sulzberger for having done just that 52 years ago, the true devotees of civic journalism would deride her willingness to settle for a few articles that only incidentally shamed college deans into action. 
 The ardent civic journalists of today are not content to tell it like it is. They want to tell it and fix it all at once. They would summon those college deans to a conference and make them either defend their neglect of history or promise prompt remedial action, with front-page punishment or reward. Also invited to the conference would be legislators and foundation heads so that they could be badgered into providing the funds to endow the necessary new chairs in American history. Famous names from business and academia would grace the stage and alliances with television would guarantee more attention than newspapers alone can command.
Just such conferences -- to air public concerns and to propel communities into action -- figure prominently in the list of "public life projects" that civic journalists are organizing around the country.
The Detroit Free Press has been waging a "Children First" campaign, raising money for summer recreation, summoning cabinet members and experts to a forum on violence against children, giving reporters time off for volunteer work in schools. The Charlotte Observer is rousing citizens in a campaign called "Taking Back Our Neighborhoods" -- leading televised discussions and directing charities to the most neglected parts of town. The Sun in Bremerton, Wash., teamed up with the local electric company to promote economic development that could compensate for the loss of military installations. The San Jose Mercury News lavished special coverage and free newspapers on one low-income precinct to try, inconclusively, to get out the vote last November. The Norfolk Virginian-Pilot formed a "public life team" of reporters formally pledged to "revitalize a democracy that has grown sick with disenchantment" and to "lead the community to discover itself and act on what it has learned."
Newspapers in the Knight-Ridder chain have been in the forefront of this campaign. Most of their editors, coming from elsewhere, think civic journalism will keep their staffs in touch with local readers without compromising traditional standards of fairness and nonpartisanship. But some of their publishers, and also those in the Gannett chain, love the idea for less disinterested reasons. They think their staffs' community involvement can sell papers and advertising. Some think civic journalism is the perfect response to declining readership. The Knight Foundation and the Pew Charitable Trusts are major supporters of the movement, and Jay Rosen's Project on Public Life and the Press at New York University provides logistic support and philosophical justification.
Rosen's best argument is that newspapers risk alienation from the community if they mindlessly focus coverage on ineffective governments and disconnected public officials. "The political problem in journalism right now," he has said, "is to find a more immediate, flesh and blood connection to citizens in the public world." But some of his own examples of brilliantly "connected" reportage prove that energetic legwork and empathetic writing could stop well short of community action.
Civic journalists have encountered two valid lines of criticism. Some critics argue that if newspapers aim only to put more reporters "in touch" with ordinary people -- without using their influence to sponsor social or political causes -- then they're only doing what they should have been doing all along. But other critics contend that the emphasis on "solutions" and "connections" will inevitably distort the news agenda, devalue problems for which no easy remedy is apparent and end up compromising the paper's independence.
In response, Rosen has argued that "objectivity" in reporting is an illusion and that even the quest for fairness or balance in news articles can obstruct the truth or understanding of it. But his debunking of some journalistic cliches hardly justifies a new ideology that holds journalism duty bound to stimulate and organize public opinion and action. The elemental tasks of describing events and discerning their causes are already beyond the skills and budgets of many American newsrooms. Running forums, finding speakers and raising money are diversions for most television and newspaper staffs even if such activity had no compromising side effects.
Recipes for action that could safely "connect" a newspaper with its readers sound like recipes for making omelets without breaking eggs. Such action will be either superficial or extremely messy and embarrassing. Given Mrs. Sulzberger's concern about American history, civic journalists would either be content, as she was, to describe the situation or, organizing solutions, they would end up trapped in the crossfire of contending histories -- those of classicists, feminists, ethnicists and all the other obvious factions. And what if college deans thought that mathematics was even more neglected than history? The more energetic a newspaper's initial agitation, the more difficult and incredible would be its retreat to trustworthy observation.
American journalism sorely needs improvement. But redefining journalism as a quest for a better tomorrow will never compensate for its poor performance at explaining yesterday. Reporters, editors and publishers have their hands full learning to tell it right. They should leave reforms to reformers.

LENGTH: 725 words

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Tighter Rules Proposed On Ferry Transport

BYLINE: BY RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Far more than in the United States, ferries are a common means of transportation in Europe. So it was not surprising that the sinking of the ferry Estonia in the Baltic Sea last fall, with the loss of more than 900 lives, sent shudders of fear across the Continent and the islands arrayed around it.
Investigations into the Estonia, which was en route from Tallinn to Stockholm, quickly pinpointed the cause, a faulty bow door that allowed in enough water to destabilize the ship, causing it to list heavily and sink in rough, icy seas. But subsequent studies of how to improve ferry safety have raised a host of questions about ferry design, crew training, evacuation procedures and the trade-offs between maximum passenger safety and economic viability for ferry operators. 
 Whether they are shuttling tourists among the Greek islands, carrying business executives from Stockholm to Helsinki or plying the busy sea lanes across the Channel between England and France, ferries in Europe, and in most of the rest of the world, are regulated by the International Maritime Organization, an agency of the United Nations based in London.
Although safety rules imposed by the organization have become substantially tighter in the last five years, a panel of 22 experts convened by the agency following the loss of the Estonia issued proposals for further regulations last month. The proposals, which are still being debated and perhaps modified within the I.M.O., will be put to a vote by the group's 151 member nations in November.
The focus of the proposals was the class of ship known as the roll-on, roll-off ferry, or ro-ro's. Ro-ro's have large doors at bow and stern that allow cars, trucks and buses to drive directly on and off. The Estonia was a ro-ro, as was the other large European ferry to be involved in a major accident in recent years, the Herald of Free Enterprise, which partly sank near Zeebrugge, Belgium, in 1987, with 134 deaths. Investigators ruled that the most likely cause of that accident was an open bow door.
It takes only a moderate amount of water sloshing around on the vehicle deck of a ro-ro to put the vessel at risk of tipping over. So the safety debate has centered on proposals to require watertight bulkheads, or walls, on the vehicle deck to keep any water in a confined space, minimizing the destabilizing effects.
Some naval architects think multiple bulkheads are a good idea; others think they could create new problems. Ferry companies generally don't want them because they would be extremely expensive to install in existing ships, and would slow the process of getting vehicles on and off. The British Government supports mandatory use of bulkheads, but most other governments are less committed to them.
The I.M.O. panel opted not to require bulkheads in its proposals. Instead, the panel outlined stricter stability requirements for the vessels, and left it to ferry operators and designers how best to meet them. But the stability requirements specifically require designers to consider the effects of large amounts of water on the vehicle deck and of rougher seas.
The panel also proposed that there be an inner door behind the bow door as a second line of defense; that drainage of water from the vehicle deck be improved; that crew members all be able to speak the same language (reportedly a problem on the Estonia, where Finns, Estonians and Swedes worked alongside one another), and that there be better alarms on hull doors.
"The panel is aware that some of its proposals will have severe implications to existing ro-ro passenger ships and may even lead to some ships being forced out of service," the International Maritime Organization group said.
Most of the ferries that would have trouble meeting the new standards, industry executives said, are in southern Europe. They said that the I.M.O. and member countries, including Italy and Greece, were likely to have continuing debates over whether the proposals are too tough, given that many local and regional economies, reliant on ferries for transportation and tourism, would be devastated if ferries were forced out of service.
The ferries that ply the English Channel are already among the newest and most advanced in use anywhere, industry officials said, and would be only moderately affected by the new standards.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
A Flare For Fantasy: 'Miami Vice' Meets 42d Street

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
KA-BOOM! ARQUITECTONICA HAS LANDED. LANDed the job, anyhow. The Miami-based architects, renowned for their colorfully jazzed-up modern designs, have been chosen to create a keystone to the multi-building complex that represents the rebirth of Times Square -- the major new convention hotel planned for Eighth Avenue and 42d Street. The legendary mecca of raffish good times and the architectural firm with rhythm, 42d Street and Arquitectonica are a match made in honky-tonk heaven.
The fruit of their union will not be mistaken for the Plaza. Don't expect oak paneling, marble columns or palm trees wafting gently over decorous afternoon teas. Instead, this glitzy Ritz (actually, a Westin) will erupt with vibrant color and flashing lights in a building designed to look like an exploding meteor. Scheduled for completion by Jan. 1, 2000, it's a jazz fanfare for the millennium, an apocalypse with room service. 
 Selected May 11 over competing designs by two internationally prominent architects, Michael Graves and Zaha Hadid, the hotel will be Arquitectonica's first building in New York. It will also enlarge the Times Square presence of the Disney Corporation, which is affiliated in the project with the designated developer, the Tishman Urban Development Corporation, and also responsible for the renovation of the New Amsterdam Theater just east of the hotel site. As the participation of those corporate Goliaths suggests, this architectural fantasy is big-time business, though money for its completion is yet to be raised. Economic return, not esthetic merit, is the paramount goal of the project's government sponsors, the New York State Urban Development Corporation and the New York City Economic Development Corporation.
But the best guys won anyhow. While all three designs were good, Arquitectonica's captured the spirit of place: the unsubtle fusion of erotics and economics that is Times Square. Their design embodies the drives, defenses, fantasies and symbols that animate this legendary crossroads of dollars and desire.
The design is a vertical triptych. Stretching along the north side of 42d Street will be an entertainment and retail complex designed by specialists in retail outlets, D'Agostino Izzo Quirk Architects. Housed in a mix of new and renovated structures, the complex will retain the existing scale of the neighboring low-rise buildings while pumping it full of new life. Restaurants, shops, superstores and an Imax theater are among the uses currently planned.
A 10-story Disney Vacation Club, containing 100 time-share apartments, will anchor the corner of 42d and Eighth, or possibly blow it away, for the jagged-edged structure is supposed to represent a meteor moments after the crash. Rising above the fallen body is the 680-room hotel, a 47-story tower sheathed with colored glass. A curving streak of light, representing the meteor's trail, splits the skyscraper down the middle. Blue-toned glass clads the west side of the tower in a pattern of vertical stripes, while the east side is glazed with horizontal bands of copper and orange. Some will find the tower's esthetic unpleasantly reminiscent of the 1964-65 New York World's Fair. I like the flashback to that populuxe extravaganza.
In accordance with the guidelines for the project, the design makes heavy use of lighting and signs. Immense "supersigns" will march across the retail and entertainment complex in a neon pop art parade. The tower will erupt periodically in a light show designed by Fisher Marantz, the lighting wizards. High-powered beams within the curving "meteor path" will shoot up into the sky, while clouds of "pixie dust" explode at the base.
New York's leading avant-garde architects, Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio, have designed a tower of video monitors for the hotel's Eighth Avenue corner, while a 10-story mural of glass mosaics will cover the vacation club with postcard images of New York landmarks. Why should Arquitectonica resort to these Chamber of Commerce cliches? These architects have already demonstrated an unrivaled talent to create dazzling urban icons of their own.
You may have already seen one. The "sky patio," an outdoor terrace punched into the side of one of Arquitectonica's early high-rises in Miami, was featured in the weekly opening credits of the flashy 80's television series "Miami Vice." The design epitomized the firm's ability to enliven a spare modern architectural framework with sensuous, surrealistic flair.
A single, iconic palm tree rises in the patio against the blue sky of tropical paradise. But there's a snake in this garden, a red spiral staircase coiling up behind the palm as if to pluck something from its fronds. Who said that the forbidden fruit wasn't a coconut? Or a Coca-Cola? Or coke?
The colors here are primary; so are the implied emotions. A red balcony juts out from a yellow wall, suspended like a diving platform over a blue-tiled Jacuzzi. The red is the color of lipstick on a collar, of passion, perhaps danger. Will we fall or be pushed? Into the whirlpool or into heaven? Pleasure and risk go hand in hand in this vertiginous realm of the senses.
Arquitectonica started building young. That's the first important thing to know about them. Bernardo Fort-Brescia and Laurinda Spear, who founded the firm in 1977, were the first architects of the baby-boom generation to build prominent, large-scale projects, like the string of residential high-rises they set along Brickell Avenue in Miami in the early 1980's. At an age when most architects are still in their apprenticeship years, Fort-Brescia and Spear were helping to shape a new image for Miami. That image was youthful, it was sexy, and, above all, it was modern.
That's the second important thing to know about Arquitectonica. As the first voice of its generation to make itself heard in major projects, the firm let it be known that post-modernism had peaked. The younger generation just wasn't picking up on it. Modern architecture, it turned out, hadn't come to an end with I. M. Pei. Indeed, in Arquitectonica's Bauhaus-does-the-rhumba version, modernism never looked livelier.
The firm's vision was evident in their first building, the Spear House, designed in 1977 for Ms. Spear's parents. Much used as a backdrop by fashion photographers in the late 1970's, this was a Bruce Weber photograph of a building: a lean, muscular structure that showed a lot of skin. With a blue swimming pool screened by a wall of glass blocks and pink stucco, the house fused the era's twin obsessions with voyeurism and flesh.
Arquitectonica were hardly the first to bring sensuality to modern design. In the 1930's, Latin American architects forged a sultry tropical version of the International Style. But for those who still equated modern buildings with bleak glass boxes and brutal concrete sheds, Arquitectonica's hedonistic update of Latin modernism came as a jolt, and not always a pleasant one.
I ONCE SAW FORT-BRESCIA DRIVE A student audience crazy with a presentation that dramatized how architecture could be at once esthetically progressive and socially hard to swallow. One project, a home for a Florida couple, had the students bouncing off the walls. It seemed that the couple enjoyed swimming together, but he liked to swim in fresh water while she liked to swim in sea water. The ingenious solution? A pair of serpentine pools that overlapped each other, I don't remember how, in a kind of acquatic duet. As I recall, there was also a third lane, for exotic fish. And the pool was to be outfitted with a glass bottom, so swimmers, peering down, could behold a temperature-controlled cellar of rare vintage wines.
Then followed the staggeringly beautiful Banco de Credito in Lima, Peru, with board rooms as glamorous as the sets for a 40's Hollywood musical and an oval entrance atrium that recalled the 1594 anatomical theater at the University of Padua. But those entering the atrium were more likely to be maimed than healed, for its function was to provide surveillance for terrorist attacks; the bank was not a beloved institution when the revolutionary group Shining Path was on the rampage. When a journalist friend of mine flew down to write about the building, she was alarmed to find that security guards, toting machine guns, were on hand to accompany her to the bank from her hotel. And she wasn't even making a deposit.
I had a similar experience two years ago when I went to write about Edison Terrace, a low-income housing project Arquitectonica had designed for the Liberty City neighborhood of Miami. The area had recently been in the news -- a tourist passing through had been dragged from her car and run over -- and the architects were reluctant to let me visit the building unless I agreed to be driven there by someone from their office and promised to stay in the car. Most architects who build in cities today have to deal with security issues, but somehow Arquitectonica's esthetic seems to capture this unsettling contemporary mixture of danger and glamour, eros and death.
Visitors to Times Square do not generally take bodyguards, despite the area's notoriety as a combat zone. But here a hazard is also likely to come from those who resent the whole 42d Street project and detest its sanitized razzmatazz. Those who relish the authentically seedy can hardly be expected to welcome the flag of Disney, the co-sponsor, raised over a street corner better known to viewers of the late-night "Robin Byrd Show."
Some wouldn't want to see Disney putting down roots in any part of town. To them, the company stands for theme parks, for fantasylands that are at once irresponsibly escapist and oppressively controlled. Do we want to welcome the arrival of that dubious formula within the city gates? Like it or not, it's here. And its arrival should provoke us to recognize that fantasy and control were shaping urban space long before Disney showed up.
It's odd the way we keep compulsively rubbing this spot, Times Square, as if the prurience it signifies had not escaped long ago into the atmosphere and filtered into the culture at large. The French writer Jean Baudrillard once theorized that the function of Disneyland is to keep Americans from seeing that their country is Disney land; the genuine imitations differ only in the accuracy of the simulation. Perhaps one reason we make such a fetish of "cleaning up" Times Square is that it diverts attention from the degree to which the entire culture has become eroticized.
It's hard to take cleaning up Times Square seriously with all those Calvin Klein billboard models bulging voluptuously at skyscraper scale. Still, the billboards help clarify the line between permissible and impermissible desire. What's taboo is not desire but its satisfaction. Consumer culture thrives on appetite; satisfaction makes the market wither. You can wear Calvin Klein's Escape, but you cannot escape Calvin Klein: cannot avoid the constant bombardment of images designed to keep us in a constant state of craving.
If we really wanted to clean up Times Square, we should probably start by banning skyscrapers, not building new ones. Is the city's indefatigable vertical thrust really suitable for viewing by children under 17? Arquitectonica's tower is not much naughtier than most. From some angles, the building will appear to be doing a strip, peeling back its glass skin to reveal the reveling of conventioneers. And that orgasmic 47-story light show should be a local landmark like no other. Sometimes a cigar is just a cigar, but an explosion of "pixie dust"? In Times Square?
THE ARCHITECTS HAVE DEscribed the project as a deliberate evocation of chaos. The eclectic mix of signs, styles and storefronts in the retail base, especially, is meant to look like a jumbled heap. One could interpret this on a purely cartoon level as the physical upheaval caused by the meteor's impact. Or, on a more sophisticated level of urbanism, one could view the jumble as a metaphor for the havoc unleashed by development in a city from which planning, for the most part, has all but disappeared.
I see this outstandingly smart design as a study in urban psychology. It seeks to visualize the forces that link private emotions and public space. The design's chaotic pileup of signs, stores and attractions are an invitation not just to consume, but to be hungry. I can think of no other recent work of architecture that pictures more accurately the disordered universe that desire brings in its wake.
This is the private universe, the life shaken up by the drives that bring people to the city, to connect with others, with destiny, with themselves. And it's the universe of the city itself, propelled through time by its unflagging willingness to sacrifice order to ambition.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Midtown Leasing;
After a Deluge of Deals, a Sudden Downturn

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
TALK about short-lived euphoria. After six months of frenzied leasing activity throughout midtown, the brakes are on the deal-making process. And landlords, brokers and tenants, most of whom had finally settled into the idea of a steadily recovering real estate market, are all trying to make sense of the unexpected downturn.
"We are definitely seeing less traffic coming through our buildings," said Douglas Durst, executive vice president of the Durst Organization. Another local landlord, who insisted on anonymity because he did not want to appear to be "negotiating from a position of weakness," was a lot more blunt. "This market is dead," he said. 
 Nor is it just a lull between the start of space searches and the closing of deals. "There definitely were fewer new assignments coming in in April, and that could certainly impact 1996," said Stephen B. Siegel, chief executive of the Edward S. Gordon real estate company.
The numbers certainly indicate a sickly market. According to the Gordon company, midtown activity peaked last October, when nearly 1.7 million square feet were leased. Activity remained comfortably above 1.3 million square feet a month for the next five months, too. Then, in April, it plunged to a piddling 815,000 square feet rented. And May is not looking much better.
The amount of space available is creeping up, too. According to RELocate, which tracks commercial leases, available space in midtown dropped at the end of 1994 and hit a low of 22.9 million square feet in January. Last month that number was back up to nearly 24 million square feet. The amount of available sublet space, meanwhile, has moved up and down between 4.5 million and 5 million square feet since November.
"The sublet situation is not as glaring, but available direct space is inching up," said Bruce Weissberg, RELocate's president.
So why the slump?
As with most real estate subjects, different players offer widely divergent rationales. But many agree that the boomlet of the last six to eight months was as much a result of smoke and mirrors as of genuine recovery. They note that many tenants had waited until the 11th hour to sign new leases, hoping rents would continue to plummet, then simply ran out of time and had to make deals. Others reacted to the first whiff of a stabilizing market as though it were their last chance to lock in bargain rents, and rushed to find new space or agree to early renewals on existing leases.
NOW the pent-up demand has been pretty well satisfied. "Up until the end of last year we could concentrate on renewing tenants," said Alan L. Stein, a senior vice president of Rockefeller Center Management. "Now we have to bring in new tenants, new blood." It is not easy, he has discovered: As of April 30, about 7.3 percent of the space in Rockefeller Center was empty; a year ago the vacancy rate was only 3.3 percent.
(Two weeks ago, in a development related more to depressed rents than to vacancy rates, the partnerships that own 12 of the Rockefeller Center buildings filed for protection under the Bankruptcy Code.)
The downturn isn't causing widespread doom and gloom -- yet. "Last year was an aberration, a feeding frenzy, and all that's happened is we're back to a normal pace," said Mr. Siegel. "Sure, if we have three months of just 800,000 square feet leased, I'll be upset, but I don't think that will happen."
Neither does Joseph G. Costabile, an executive director of Cushman & Wakefield. "Yes, April and May have been quiet, but I think it's temporary," he said. "The residential market is booming, the stock market is fine, and there's not that much space available." Mr. Costabile expects that the traditional summer slowdown (conspicuously absent last year) just hit early.
Others say that the current slowdown signifies nothing more than the market digesting the remnants of a heavy meal.
"Last year represented the culmination of a lot of deals that had been circling the market for several years prior," said Mitchell S. Steir, an executive vice president with the Julien J. Studley brokerage. "Now the market needs to digest those deals and move sideways for a while. There's a limit to how many record years you can have."
Of course, if landlords would drop rents again, tenants might rush back to market. When Edward Minskoff was asking for an annual rent of about $50 a square foot at 590 Madison Avenue, the old I.B.M. building at 56th Street that he bought last year, he got only one taker, BHF-Bank, a German bank. Now, brokers report, he has dropped his price to the $40's, and a very large tenant is considering a 200,000-square-foot-plus deal.
But few landlords are similarly ready to drop prices. Most of those who survived the recession are presiding over buildings that are fairly full and that have cash flows that cover operating expenses and debt service. Financially, they do not need to rent every last drop of space; psychologically, they do not want to backtrack to the time when they had to do so.
"It took so long and was so painful to climb out of the last hole, and none of us have the huge amount of available space we had a few years ago," Mr. Durst said. "Our attitude is that we can wait it out."
When tenants have that attitude as well, the result is stalemate. Mr. Durst recently tried to negotiate an early renewal of a lease with one tenant whose rent had escalated to $38 a foot in a building where the going rent now is about $30 a foot. Mr. Durst was willing to split the difference, and set a rent in the mid-$30's. The tenant opted instead to wait out the two years left on its lease, and decide later if it wants to stay or move.
"It doesn't pay for a tenant to give up flexibility to save just a few dollars in rent," Mr. Durst said.
FLEXIBILITY has grown particularly important to those tenants who are suffering their own economic disappointments. Many companies that were thinking about expanding when the recovery began are now hunkering down for another spate of difficult times.
"As recently as last quarter, tenants were still investigating their options, looking around, focusing attention on real estate," said James S. Meiskin, president of the Plymouth Partners brokerage. "Now they have to focus single-mindedly on their basic businesses."
This is particularly true in financial services. "So many of the investment banks are reporting losses, or at least earnings that are off," noted Bruce E. Mosler, chief executive of the Galbreath Company, a real estate service firm. Mr. Mosler predicts that leasing activity in the second half of 1995 will be flat at best, and that 1996 will be a "decent but slow-growth year." His reason: "As the financial services industry goes, so goes New York."
Perhaps the only truly upbeat people around are the investors -- and thus, the sales brokers. While sales of residential buildings have slowed down, brokers report that commercial sales remain brisk.
"Investors still feel the city's economy is viable," said Daun Paris, president of Eastern Consolidated Properties, a real estate-oriented investment bank.
Foreign investors, particularly, are attracted by the prices, said Scott Latham, Eastern Consolidated's executive director. Mr. Latham said there is "tremendous interest" in 535-545 Fifth Avenue, adjoining buildings at 44th Street that Eastern has put on the market for about $130 a square foot.
"That's not only reasonable for Fifth Avenue north of 42d Street, but it is incredibly cheap compared to the prices in Hong Kong or Tokyo," he said.
And there are pockets of vibrancy even in commercial leasing. The entertainment industry, for one, continues to rent more space. Brokers report that Sony, Time Warner and Viacom, all of which have rented space of late, are looking for more.
Still, few real estate experts expect the slump to end very soon. "I've been advising my landlords to make the best deals they can make now, because I think '96 will be a slower year than '95," said Mr. Costabile.
Mr. Durst agreed. "This slump will last another year or year and a half," he said. "We won't see a big decline in rents, but we won't see a lot of leasing activity, either."
