SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2354 words

HEADLINE: For Home Buyers, Patience Has Paid Off

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
INTEREST rates are falling. Interest rates are falling. It's a mantra being intoned by almost every real estate broker, mortgage banker and potential home buyer these days. And unlike other industry slogans -- like "now is a good time to buy" or "prices are rising" -- this one is unarguable, at least for now.
The average interest rate on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages in the New York metropolitan area has plunged in the last few months, dropping more than a full percentage point to 8.06 as of last Wednesday from its recent high of 9.39 percent on Dec. 16, according to HSH Associates, a mortgage research company in Butler, N.J. That means that anyone who simply waited five months to buy a home with a fixed-rate mortgage may have saved, before taxes, $95 a month on a $100,000 mortgage; the payments would have dropped to $738 from $833. Rates on adjustable-rate mortgages also have dropped -- but not as much. The average interest rate on a one-year A.R.M. in the New York metropolitan area fell to 5.69 as of last Wednesday from its recent high of 6.54 percent on Jan. 13, according to HSH Associates. That means the average monthly payment for a new A.R.M. fell $55 on a $100,000 loan, to $580 from $635. 
 "Patience has indeed paid off for a lot of people," said Keith T. Gumbinger, an analyst with HSH Associates, adding that rates were slightly higher for co-ops and some condominiums.
Considering the favorable trends in interest rates, it may seem to be a bit of a conundrum, then, that the real estate market remains so weak.
Projections by the National Association of Realtors for this year's total sales, based on first-quarter figures, declined in New York (by 10.3 percent), in New Jersey (by 8.1 percent) and in Connecticut (by 0.6 percent). And the median sale price of existing homes in the New York region fell 3.5 percent from $173,200 last year to $167,200 for the first three months of this year.
Interest rates, however, generally reflect demand for loans -- not the other way around. For example, in the mid-80's, when a surging demand for housing pushed residential real estate prices through the roof, mortgage rates for both fixed and adjustable rates had double digits and, for fixed-rate loans, the suffix "-teen" applied in some years.
Thus lower interest rates may provide a good opportunity for home buyers -- and anyone considering refinancing an existing mortgage. They are not, though, necessarily positive indicators of the health of the real estate market. Indeed, when rates hit their 20-year lows in the fall of 1993, the increase in resales and home appreciation was, generally, lackluster, although refinancings increased tremendously.
"Refinancings are almost strictly driven by interest rates, but the interest rates are only part of the picture in rest of the housing market," Mr. Gumbinger said.
He noted that buyers might not be stampeding into the market because rates have not collapsed to the 25-year lows that existed just 18 to 24 months ago, when fixed-rate mortgages were as low as 7 percent, and A.R.M.'s had teaser or special low-ball promotional rates as low as 3 percent.
Buyers, he speculated, also may be more likely to enter the market when rates start to rise (to try to beat further increases) and they may delay buying when rates are declining (to wait until rates hit bottom).
Mr. Gumbinger noted that there was a lack of affordable starter homes in the New York region, too, and that that was the market niche with the highest demand.
"PEOPLE can't find what they want at a price they want, so they don't buy," he said. "And the people who have the homes to sell bought them at such high prices that they can't afford to lower them below a certain point. So they don't sell, which means they can't trade up, which means the trade-up's can trade-up again, and it becomes a cycle."
There are, of course, other factors, like consumer confidence, demographic changes and job formation at play in the market for first mortgages. And these factors, according to economists, are neutral or negative in much of the New York region.
"The biggest problem with New York, and to a lesser extent New Jersey, is that we are not getting the job formation," said Rae D. Rosen, a senior economist with the Federal Reserve Board in New York. "So, if you don't have job growth, particularly upper-income level job growth, people are going to be reluctant to purchase homes or to trade up."
She estimated that, according to surveys of realtor groups, home sales had declined about 5 to 10 percent over the last year, and that prices might have dropped by as much as 10 percent.
"Things were improving, then in about June of last year, job formation stopped, and we hit a brick wall," she said. "People in the city, city employees in particular, are worried about losing their jobs or losing pay. And that means they are not going to be buying homes."
Ms. Rosen added that a more ominous sign might be that the size of New York's labor force was actually declining slightly, not just increasing slowly.
"It may be because of out-migration, or people have just given up looking for work," Ms. Rosen said. "Either way, it's not good. It's an indicator that the economy is weak -- but it's not collapsing. For the private sector, we are probably bouncing along a trough, and for the public sectors we have more cuts ahead."
"This is not true, though, in New Jersey, because they have had a high level of immigration," she added. "That's one of the factors."
The weak economy is often attributed to the Fed's decision to raise short-term interest rates seven times between February 1994 and February of this year to cap what it believed to be growing inflationary pressures.
The higher short-term rates made it more costly to borrow, which may have snuffed out inflation for the time being. They also, however, stunted, if not aborted, an economic recovery that began nationally in late 1992 but did not get under way in the New York region until early last year or late 1993.
"THE Fed's raising of interest rates seven times last year may have had a negative impact on consumer confidence as well as some big employer layoffs," said Carl DeMusz, president of the New Jersey Association of Realtors. "We also expected first-quarter sales this year to be lower than in '94 because last year's resales were at the second-highest quarterly level for that time period of all time."
In recent months, interest rates have started to recede because of a widespread belief in the bond market that the Fed has stopped raising short-term rates and may even, sensing that inflation is no longer a significant danger, lower rates to head off a recession. (Others, of course, are not so optimistic. They believe the Fed may again raise rates either because of new signs of inflation or because of the weak dollar in Japan and Germany.)
This interplay with the bond market may sound arcane, but it is important because interest rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages usually track in the same direction as the interest rate on the 30-year Treasury bond, or long bond as it is sometimes called. (The rate on the long bond had fallen to 6.85 percent on Wednesday from a recent of high of 8.25 percent on Nov. 7, the day before Election Day.)
The interest rate that lenders charge on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage is not linked directly to the long bond, however, at least not in the manner that some adjustable-rate mortgages are pegged to short-term Treasury rates with the lender adding on a premium.
Instead, the rate on fixed-rate 30-year mortgages is usually developed by the secondary market -- Government-sponsored enterprises like Freddie Mac, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Fannie Mae, the Federal National Mortgage Association -- which buys mortgages from lenders and essentially set the lending standards.
These buyers in the secondary market offer to pay a certain interest rate on certain types of fixed-rate mortgages after weighing the likelihood of inflation over the next seven years; homes are usually sold or mortgages refinanced within seven years. (They also, to be sure, consider the likelihood of default and other risk characteristics.)
Then originating lenders -- institutions like a local savings-and-loan or a mortgage banker -- pass along to borrowers the secondary-market rates with a premium of about three-eighths of a percentage point for their profit, loan servicing and administration.
(This rate rate may also be "discounted" or reduced if the borrower prepays interest on the mortgage by paying up front what are commonly known as "points." A point is equal to 1 percent of the loan's total value. Rates and premiums may be higher for so-called jumbo mortgages, which are loans over $200,000, and nonconforming mortgages, which are often loans to borrowers with credit problems.)
"All of these things explain the spread -- right now it's about 1.2 points -- between the rate on the 30-year bond and a 30-year mortgage," said Mr. Gumbinger of HSH Associates. "There is a slight additional risk."
Adjustable-rate mortgages haven't declined as much as fixed-rate mortgages over the last five months simply because they are pegged to short-term Treasuries, which haven't declined as much long-term Treasury bonds. A.R.M. rates are usually the rate for the one-year Treasury security plus a premium of about 2.75 percent, not taking into consideration discounting, points or teaser rates, which are artificially low rates for the first year and are sometimes even lower than the Treasury security rate with no premium attached.
(Some A.R.M.'s, particularly those that adjust monthly, every 90 days or every 180 days, are linked to other short-term rates, like the less volatile London Interbank Offering Rate, or Libor, or the 11th District Federal Home Loan Bank's cost of funds index, known as Cofi.)
PREDICTABLY, home buyers have reacted to the greater decline in fixed-rate mortgage rates by buying more fixed-rate loans. In March -- the most recent month for which data is available from the Federal Housing Finance Board in Washington -- 56 percent of all the home loans made had fixed rates. By comparison, in January only 41 percent of home buyers took out fixed-rate loans. (The figures for A.R.M.'s includes hybrids, mortgages that are fixed for several years and then adjust.)
Mr. Gumbinger also noted that the spread between the lowest A.R.M available and the average fixed-rate mortgage had shrunk from 5 to 5.5 percentage points, which is an unusually wide gap, last fall to about 3 percentage points today. "The low end of the A.R.M.'s has closed up considerably, mostly because of the rise in short-term rates, related to the Fed's moves," Mr. Gumbinger said. "Basically, lenders couldn't afford to give away the store anymore."
"Generally, when rates go up you can expect people to buy more A.R.M.'s," he added. "And when rates go down, they'll buy more fixed. They want to lock in the low rate and get rid of some of the risk. When rates are high, they go with the A.R.M. just because it's cheaper."
The declining rates have also started to spark a small outburst of refinancings, but the numbers are still small -- about 10 percent of all mortgage originations, according to HSH Associates. In 1992 and 1993, when rates were 1 to 2 percentage points lower, refinancings made up as much as 70 percent of mortgage originations.
"We are starting to see people who want to do it, and we are getting a lot of calls from people inquiring," said Bruce R. Lublin, president of Homerica Mortgage Corporation in Mamaroneck, N.Y. "The rates aren't quite low enough yet to spark anything like what we saw a few years ago, though."
Maybe not, but they are low -- very low -- by historic standards. The current average A.R.M. rate of 5.69 percent is not substantially higher than the all-time low of 4.15 percent on Oct. 29, 1993; A.R.M.s have only really been around since 1980. Moreover, the current average fixed-rate mortgage of 8.06 percent is not much above the 6.87 percent that it fell to on Oct. 15, 1993, and that marked the lowest point in fixed rates since 1965.
The recent decline in both fixed and adjustable rates came as surprise to most mortgage-market watchers. A year ago, when the Fed was in the midst of increasing rates and inflation seemed to be looming, many economists predicted that fixed-rate mortgages might be as high as 10 percent by now.
ANALYSTS are divided on whether rates will fall much further or start to rise again. Should rates rise, the impact on the resale market, which dwarfs the new home market in the New York area, would almost certainly be negative. If they fall, though, the impact may be less substantial than expected, though far from not negligible.
Again, other factors are at least as important, if not more so. "People are very hesitant to enter into their most significant financial commitment without a certain degree of long-term job stability," said Charles M. Staro, executive vice president of the New York State Association of Realtors.
Mr. Gumbinger speculated that demographics could become a dominant factor in the years ahead, as they were in the 70's and 80's. He noted that in 5 or 10 years, many baby boomers would start to become empty-nesters and would likely look to sell the large, multi-bedroom houses in which they raised families.
This could mean, he said, that a wave of baby boomers will try to sell their homes all at the same time (to a smaller cohort that will likely be buying homes even later than their parents did) and depress prices -- much as they all bought homes at the same time and helped make prices rise 10 and 20 years ago.
In the nearer term, though, there is some degree of optimism that home resale volume in the second quarter, which is the prime home-buying season, will benefit from the lower interest rates.
"With the weather warming up and interest rates at attractive levels, we expect this year's second quarter to bounce back," said Mr. DeMusz of the New Jersey Association of Realtors.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE;
When the Office Park Becomes a White Elephant

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: WAYNE

 BODY:
If the American Cyanamid site here is eventually put on the market, it will join a growing roster of corporate campuses waiting for another user.
"In the New York area, these campuses are expensive to run, the taxes are unbelievable and everyone's looking to downsize," said Rick Gelmetti, senior vice president with Weichert Commercial Realtors in Morris Plains. 
 No one is sure how many of New Jersey's sprawling corporate campuses -- loosely defined as sites of 60 acres or more -- are either unoccupied or available.
But officials from Senior Campus Living in Baltimore say they have visited about 30 such sites in northern New Jersey -- some still operating, like American Cyanamid, and some defunct, like the I.B.M. property in Franklin Lakes -- with the idea of turning them into self-contained retirement communities for 2,000 or more elderly people.
These sites are not always easy to find, because having a defunct corporate campus is not exactly something businesses like to advertise.
"It's really sensitive," said Fred Walker, vice president of acquisitions for Senior Campus Living. "With some of these companies, they're still in business and they're not sure what they're going to do."
But it is growing more and more apparent that the days of the vast corporate campus may be ending.
Robert G. McCafferty, senior vice president of the Garibaldi Group, a corporate real estate firm in Chatham, says many campuses were born in the speculative building boom that followed the sharp rise, then equally steep drop, in interest rates in the early 1980's.
Developers built office parks without specific tenants in mind. When the economy soured, companies were forced to cut costs -- and one way they did was to try to sell off their suburban corporate parks.
Now the towns saddled with abandoned campuses, like I.B.M.'s in Franklin Lakes, are trying to figure out what should be done with them.
"We have seen a movement toward adaptive re-use," said Andrew J. Merin, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield of New Jersey Inc. "We're seeing towns, under the pressure of taxes, that are more open to zoning changes."
Similarly, officials in Wayne are looking at the Cyanamid campus with an eye to the future.
"In this economic climate, just by the mere fact that there is so much office space available in New Jersey, it's going to be hard to sell that building out, lease it, rent it out," said Councilman Scott Rumana. "To fill it with a company for its present use is going to be virtually impossible, at best, very, very difficult." DAVID W. CHEN

HEADLINE: The View From: New London;
Another Marine Attraction Vies for Waterfront Attention

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
PILES of rubble littering a 24-acre peninsula on New London's shoreline will soon be cleared to make way for Ocean Quest, a $41 million center devoted to the study of the sea.
The Ocean Quest marine sciences camp and oceanography museum lies at the center of New London's plans for economic revival. The brick mill buildings that once stood on the waterfront site, known as the New London Mills property, have been torn down. In their place, a 150-room Marriott Hotel and an 87,500-square-foot center, which includes an amphitheater, will be built during the first phase of construction. The second phase consists of a 360-degree theater, exhibition areas and expansion of the learning center. A whaling village with shops is scheduled for the third phase. Plans also include a restaurant and cafeteria, conference rooms, a waterfront park, a dock and moorings. Construction is expected to start this spring, and opening day is planned for July 4, 1996. The venture is to be financed with a $2.4 million state grant and private support, said Philip J. Slack III, a director of the project. 
 The marine sciences camp and museum, to be situated at the mouth of the Thames River, will be another link in a chain of attractions that promote southeastern Connecticut's maritime history and marine science resources. Proposals have been made to renovate and expand Mystic Marinelife Aquarium, improve Mystic Seaport, develop the Thames River Maritime Heritage Park in New London and expand the marine sciences center at the University of Connecticut's Avery Point campus.
"I look at Ocean Quest as another major tourist destination. We hope people will buy package tickets to all the region's activities," Mr. Slack said.
Modeled after the Space Camp and the Space and Rocket Center in Huntsville, Ala., Ocean Quest will use hands-on devices, computer graphics, animation, video and simulation to teach visitors about the ocean and undersea technology. Students at the Ocean Quest Learning Center will attend one of three overnight camps. And tourists visiting exhibitions at the Ocean Science Center will learn about everything from ocean environments and undersea experiments to discoveries in the oceans.
Campers will learn what it feels like to be aboard a submarine by operating two simulators donated by the Navy. The simulators, formerly used by Navy trainees, replicate a submarine control room. The Navy has also agreed to give Ocean Quest steering and diving training equipment it no longer needs, Mr. Slack said. Teams of campers will be given missions to complete aboard the simulator, ones like traveling to the Arctic to map the thickness and contours of the ice. As the simulator is moved, computer-generated displays will show the undersea world.
Ocean Quest will take advantage of nearby resources, including the USS Nautilus Museum and the Naval Undersea Warfare Center in New London. In addition, Jean-Michel Cousteau, son of Jacques Cousteau, and Edward Buckbee, founder and director of Space Camp in Alabama, have agreed to act as consultants.
The exhibitions and camp are expected to draw about 330,000 visitors during the first year of operation and create an estimated 300 full-time jobs and another 80 part-time positions, Mr. Slack said. Displaced military-contract workers with technical skills will be needed in the development of programs. Students and teachers at local schools will also be hired to work on curriculum and in other areas, Mr. Slack said.
Mr. Slack and another director, Michael O'Donnell, formerly Navy sonar technicians, were managers at Analysis and Technology Inc., a military contractor in North Stonington, before resigning to work full time on Ocean Quest. The New London Citizens Council approached Analysis and Technology early in 1992 with an idea for a tourist attraction using a display of surplus Navy training equipment. When the company decided not to pursue the project, Mr. Slack and Mr. O'Donnell took it over. Although they had no experience as real estate developers, they were able to convince local legislators, city officials and state grant administrators that Ocean Quest could create jobs and income for southeastern Connecticut.
The work Mr. Slack and Mr. O'Donnell have done promoting their project has paid off. Ocean Quest has won acceptance throughout the community, the director of development and planning for New London, Peter D. Gillespie, said. "There has been overwhelming support for the project, which you don't say all the time," Mr. Gillespie said. "New London has been a working waterfront community. Tourism hasn't been something the city has marketed. It's been overlooked."
"From a historical point of view, it's a perfect fit," said Vivian Stanley, director of Mystic and More, a regional tourism agency. "If you look at the Thames River, starting with the clipper ships and ending with submarines, you have this wonderful history of the water."
Ms. Stanley said she was not concerned that other entertainment in the region would draw tourists away from Ocean Quest. While Mystic Seaport attracts high-income tourists, and the earnings of patrons at Foxwoods High Stakes and Bingo Casino are lower, Ocean Quest's market is in between, Ms. Stanley said.
New London would not have to make major street changes or deal with traffic as heavy as the stream of cars that travel through Ledyard to Foxwoods, Mr. Gillespie said. "The good thing about this location is that you can get to Ocean Quest by using several different routes," he said, "and the traffic is broken up."
On a summer weekend day, 1,860 cars might travel through New London on their way to Ocean Quest, said Mr. Gillespie, quoting from a traffic study. Tourists would follow signs from Interstate 95, 395 and Route 32 through the downtown to Ocean Quest on Pequot Avenue. Downtown businesses would benefit when tourists stop along the way, Mr. Slack said.
People would be able to visit several places in New London and take a boat across the river to sites in Groton, Mr. Gillespie said. The goal for Mystic and More is to persuade vacationers to spend a couple of days visiting the places that make the region an educational type of destination, Ms. Stanley said. "Ocean Quest is part of that cluster," she added.
Ocean Quest appears to symbolize a nationwide trend of disappearing manufacturing plants and flourishing service industries. The buildings on the New London Mills property, which at different times included a textile mill, a printing press plant and a linoleum factory, will be replaced by a sleek building of glass and steel housing high-technology exhibits. "Southeastern Connecticut has a lot of natural reasons why tourism is a big industry," said a spokesman for the state Department of Economic Development, Joseph M. Cohen.
"That's not something that should be avoided. With manufacturing jobs shriveling across the country, you can't force manufacturing to happen."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3284 words

HEADLINE: Tall Timber And the E.P.A.

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
YOU are a multibillion-dollar corporation and Federal regulators are sniffing suspiciously at your factories, building a case that your industry has broadly violated the country's environmental laws.
What to do? 
 Your lawyers' guesses about which side might prevail if the case ends up in court are just that -- guesses. You could pre-empt the Feds by volunteering to install pollution gear, but that might cost tens of millions of dollars and raise the price of your product.
And what happens if one of your competitors plays hardball with regulators, or goes to Congress for a legislative fix, and doesn't have to put on the expensive control equipment? No company wants to be tarred in the press as an environmental villain. But there are also dangers in capitulating too easily, and becoming known as a pushover for any Federal regulator looking for a patsy.
Three of the nation's largest wood products companies found themselves pondering this Rubik's cube of uncertainties and risks in the early 1990's, when the Environmental Protection Agency began a nationwide investigation of the industry. Although they make similar products at comparable factories, they chose very different courses, and the outcome remains much in doubt.
The Weyerhaeuser Company, of Tacoma, Wash., took the most conciliatory approach, agreeing to put tens of millions of dollars of controls on its plants before the E.P.A. brought its case. It paid more than $1.5 million in fines to state authorities, but is still arguing with Federal officials over whether it should pay further penalties. The company does not disagree with the E.P.A. estimate of how much pollution its wood products plants give off.
The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, based in Portland, Ore., paid an $11 million Federal fine and pledged to install more than $70 million in pollution-control equipment a few months after the E.P.A. served notice of possible Clean Air Act violations.
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation of Atlanta has been the most pugnacious. It disputes the scientific and legal foundations of the Government's case, says the E.P.A. estimates of its pollution are overstated and has argued that the agency is unfairly applying present-day standards to decisions made 10 to 15 years ago. Last November, the company fired off a blistering, 243-page response to the E.P.A. that dismissed the agency's allegations as "difficult to fathom" and "extraordinarily stale."
This year, Georgia-Pacific took the fight to Capitol Hill and persuaded the new Republican majority on the Senate Judiciary Committee to approve an amendment that derails the pending E.P.A. investigation. According to Clinton Administration officials and Weyerhaeuser, the measure could allow Georgia-Pacific to avoid installing pollution gear at many of its plants.
All three companies defend their strategies. But in an unusual, high-stakes lobbying battle, Weyerhaeuser executives are now working hard on Capitol Hill to undo Georgia-Pacific's legislative success. The amendment at issue is part of Senator Bob Dole's regulatory reform bill, which will come before the Senate for a vote later this year.
Weyerhaeuser fears that if the amendment stands, it will wind up at a disadvantage. Operating costs at plants with the controls, company executives say, are $1 million a year higher, and when the lumber market goes into a cyclical downturn, as it does every few years, that extra cost could mean the difference between closing a marginal mill and keeping it open.
Georgia-Pacific executives have said they are going to Congress just as any citizen would do to redress an injustice. Moreover, they say, studies by company consultants suggest that the current E.P.A. test method overstates the emissions from wood products factories. Nonetheless, they said they would install controls at plants that need them.
Lee Thomas, a former E.P.A. Administrator who is now a senior executive at the company, said the case was an instance in which E.P.A. enforcement officials had "stretched beyond where they should be going."
But Sara Shreiner Kendall, Weyerhaeuser's director of environmental affairs, said her company's own studies confirmed the E.P.A. view of how much pollution was going into the air, and the need for controls at such factories. The legislation at issue, which was slipped into Senator Dole's bill more or less as Georgia-Pacific drafted it, "sends exactly the wrong signal," she said. "We're finding ourselves in the position of being penalized for coming into compliance. We think that's unfair."
Such an open split between Fortune 500 rivals in the same industry is an unusual spectacle -- even for Washington. It stems directly from the companies' differing tactics for dealing with Federal regulators and for maximizing returns for shareholders.
Those differences, industry analysts and environmental lawyers say, are not surprising. Dealing with the Government's environmental enforcement officials poses the most subjective, and most uncertain, of business decisions. The laws are among the most arcane in the statute book, and subject to varying interpretations. Many times, basic technical facts are in dispute, even among independent scientists. And shifting politics in Washington further cloud the picture.
Companies like Georgia-Pacific and Weyerhaeuser, with far-reaching business empires, also have to worry about whether a pitched battle over one case will generally sour relations with Federal regulators who have vast powers to issue permits and begin investigations year-in, year-out.
There are also the vagaries of public relations. "Even if you win, you can lose by being tarred as a bad corporate player by the Government," said Mark Rogers, a paper and forest products analyst at Prudential Securities. "Everybody would always like to 'get it behind them,' but the question is always: at what cost?"
THE E.P.A. has been wrestling with how to regulate the wood products industry for more than a decade. In the early 1980's, the agency considered imposing limits on the emissions at all new plywood mills, but dropped the effort because of technical difficulties in measuring the pollutants and because the industry was losing money.
Air pollution is an inevitable byproduct of manufacturing plywood and other wood products. At the mills, logs are peeled and sliced into veneer or smaller chips. Then, the green wood is dried at high temperatures before being glued and pressed together. Most emissions come from the dryer.
The E.P.A. focused on what are called volatile organic compounds, or V.O.C.'s, substances that can combine with nitrogen oxides from car exhausts and other sources to form smog. The V.O.C.'s waft skyward when the water, sap and other juices in wood are vaporized by heat.
The agency's retreat from imposing new emission limits did not mean the companies were off the hook when it came to V.O.C.'s. Under the 1977 amendments to the Clean Air Act, companies operating in regions with the cleanest air -- like the forested areas in which most plywood and waferboard mills are situated -- must undergo stringent review. They have to apply for permits from state or Federal agencies if they build new plants that emit more than 250 tons a year of V.O.C.'s or other key pollutants. Permits are also required for any modification of an existing plant that increases emissions of these compounds by more than 40 tons a year. Companies applying for permits can be ordered to install expensive pollution-control technologies.
As the economy roared back to life in the mid-1980's, and homebuilding took off, the plywood and wood products industry revived with it. New mills were built, primarily in the South, and old ones expanded. Managers had to estimate their plants' emissions and decide whether to apply for permits.
Many companies and states, which typically administer the permit programs, turned to an E.P.A. document known as AP-42 that provides formulas for industries to calculate emissions. The section on emissions by plywood dryers was based on a study by Washington State University. For reasons that remain unclear, one of the numbers in this section was incorrect; as a result, anyone using the table to calculate the emissions, the E.P.A. now argues, would end up with a number roughly one-tenth what it should have been.
In 1983, the research arm of the wood products industry published a report that said plywood dryers were emitting pollution at much higher levels than what was set out in the E.P.A. document. The National Council of the Paper Industry for Air and Stream Improvement, a group financed by the pulp and paper industry, included the higher figures in its Technical Bulletin 405.
Charles Simon, a chief researcher in the industry's study, said he described the bulletin's findings to regional meetings of plywood company executives. Copies of the bulletin, he said, were mailed to the research departments of all the major companies and to scientists at the E.P.A.
Mr. Simon, who is now a consultant to the Government in its continuing investigation of the industry, said it was inconceivable that the companies' top scientists would have been unaware of the research arm's test results. If companies had used them to estimate their plants' emissions, many of the new or expanded mills of the 1980's would have been applying for permits under the Clean Air Act.
That didn't happen. Instead, the E.P.A. republished the AP-42 document, with the mistake, in 1984, 1987 and 1991, and company executives used it to justify not applying for permits. In using the E.P.A.'s erroneous formula, Mr. Simon said, "the industry was taking advantage of a regulatory agency's lack of knowledge. That's crystal clear to me."
In a telephone interview, Mr. Simon said he was reluctant at first to join the Government's side -- and take on his friends and colleagues in the wood products industry -- but changed his mind after reading Georgia-Pacific's vehement opposition to the E.P.A.'s case. Mr. Simon said he became increasingly upset as he read what he felt was a distorted, inaccurate account of the industry's ignorance of V.O.C. emissions in the 1980's. He said company executives appeared to be "thumbing their noses at the regulators."
EIGHT years after the industry's study of V.O.C.'s was published, the E.P.A. decided to investigate the wood products industry. It began with suspicions about a single company, Louisiana-Pacific, which had been hit with a scattering of local pollution actions.
By 1991, the company had grabbed nearly half of the growing market for waferboard, a plywood substitute made from wafers of wood glued and pressed together.
Many of the company's plants had been built without controls for V.O.C.'s because Louisiana-Pacific estimated the emissions as being less than 250 tons annually.
E.P.A. officials had their doubts about the level of V.O.C.'s and other pollutants and decided to open an investigation.
As they reviewed documents and tested the company's dryers and presses, E.P.A. officials began to conclude that Louisiana-Pacific had understated its emissions, sometimes by thousands of tons a year. E.P.A. officials widened the inquiry to other companies and other segments of the wood products industry, including plywood and particle board.
The agency sent requests for information to Georgia-Pacific, Weyerhaeuser and seven other companies. And in July 1992, the E.P.A. served notice on Louisiana-Pacific of possible violations of the Clean Air Act at eight plants. Six other plants were added later.
Soon after, the company began to talk seriously about striking a deal with the Government. In a settlement announced by the Clinton Administration in May 1993, the company paid an $11 million civil penalty -- the largest in the history of the Clean Air Act -- and pledged to install $70 million in pollution control equipment. More than 9,000 tons of volatile organic compounds that the company plants had been belching into the atmosphere would now be incinerated before they could escape.
The company signed a consent decree in which it admitted no wrongdoing. But court papers filed in the case by the Government accused the company of concealing its emissions in several instances.
Carol Browner, the E.P.A. Administrator, and Janet Reno, the Attorney General, held a news conference in which they triumphantly declared the Government had sent a "loud and clear message" to polluters.
Louisiana-Pacific executives declined to give interviews for this article or explain why they were so quick to settle. Industry analysts noted that the deal came at a time of a booming market in wood products. The company, they said, may well have feared the E.P.A. would use its ultimate sanction: shutting down the plants while the case was pending.
After the announcement, Louisiana-Pacific executives were disappointed at how the news media portrayed the case. Harry A. Merlo, the company's chairman, complained in a letter to shareholders that press accounts had "zeroed in on the fine we were required to pay and ignored the joint nature of the agreement and the environmental advances we will pioneer."
WEYERHAEUSER knew it had a problem even before the E.P.A. began its investigation, but the company said it was unaware of the mistake in the AP-42 document.
Ms. Kendall, the company's director of environmental affairs, disputes the E.P.A.'s theory that the industry intentionally disregarded its own 1983 study of V.O.C. emissions. Interviews with present and former company employees, she said, turned up no evidence that anyone had deliberately used the E.P.A.'s erroneous formula to understate a plant's pollution.
Instead, she says, Weyerhaeuser stumbled on the problem in August 1991, when a test at the company's waferboard plant in Elkin, N.C., found startlingly high V.O.C. emissions: A rate of 1,000 tons a year, 10 times what the company had reported to state authorities.
A second test confirmed the results, and Ms. Kendall asked one of the company's scientists how many other Weyerhaeuser mills might be in similar straits. He came back with a list of at least a dozen.
"At that point," she said, "we realized we had a big problem."
As Ms. Kendall viewed it, environmental law relies on what is, essentially, an honor system. Companies have the chief responsibility for understanding their own processes and figuring out how much they pollute. Ignorance is not much of a defense. After the Elkin test results were in, Ms. Kendall said, the company had little choice but to look at all its operations and see if they were similarly polluting.
"We felt if we sat on the information we had, we could expose ourselves to a risk of criminal prosecution," she recalled.
In April 1992, the company began to test all of its wood products plants. Many of them were emitting more than 250 tons a year of V.O.C.'s, and did not have the appropriate permits.
Weyerhaeuser executives weighed the pros and cons of the matter. While there were no "slam dunk" legal arguments, Ms. Kendall said, the confusing technical situation and the E.P.A.'s own inaccurate formula in AP-42 gave the company some legs to stand on. But ultimately, she said, Weyerhaeuser's senior management felt it would be better to come forward, voluntarily install controls and adopt a "pro-active" stance that might persuade Federal officials not to file a case.
Weyerhaeuser told state officials about the V.O.C. findings and applied for Clean Air Act permits, a step that meant installing new control equipment. It also asked state officials to impose fines for the violations, in the hopes of heading off citizens' lawsuits and Federal action. Ms. Kendall said some states were reluctant to impose fines because they did not view the violations as significant.
William Ruckelshaus, a former E.P.A. Administrator who serves on the Weyerhaeuser board, sounded out William K. Reilly, the head of the agency at the time, about the company's approach. Ms. Kendall said the reply was encouraging.
A few weeks later, Weyerhaeuser was startled to receive a letter from E.P.A. enforcement officials requesting information that might be used in an enforcement action. Over the next few months, Weyerhaeuser appealed to the E.P.A. not to go forward with an enforcement case, but agency officials told the company they were required, by law, to recoup the economic benefit the company had gained by operating without controls. That meant filing a civil case, and seeking fines.
Weyerhaeuser has countered that fines are inappropriate because, it says, it reaped no benefits. Nonetheless, last August, the E.P.A. served notice of possible violations at nine Weyerhaeuser plants, the first step toward a civil suit.
The case is pending, even as the company installs pollution control gear and seeks permits. Federal officials have not decided whether to file a civil suit and seek fines.
"We felt we owned some of this problem," Ms. Kendall said, "but we don't feel that we should be penalized when everyone -- the states, the companies and the Federal Government -- contributed to this mutual mistake."
AT Georgia-Pacific, executives were analyzing similar facts and reaching vastly different conclusions.
Gordon Alphonso, senior counsel, said that beginning in 1992, the company took a close look at the foundations of the E.P.A.'s case, and saw a string of dubious assumptions as well as an inappropriate attempt to apply new rules retroactively.
Mr. Alphonso noted that different states had different definitions of what constituted a volatile organic compound. The E.P.A. itself, he said, was never able to agree on what test method should be used. State and Federal officials reviewed, and approved, all of the company's decisions not to apply for permits under the Clean Air Act.
In several instances, he said, E.P.A. regional officials had insisted that state agencies and Georgia-Pacific stick to E.P.A. methodology, and specifically ordered them not to substitute their own estimates. As for the industry's 1983 study, Mr. Alphonso said it was riddled with caveats, and was later discounted by the E.P.A.
According to Mr. Alphonso's view of environmental law, it was up to the E.P.A. to develop pollution standards and testing methods. He said there was a place to turn for calculating emissions and that place was the agency's own document, AP-42.
Even so, Mr. Thomas, the former E.P.A. Administrator who now works for Georgia-Pacific, said the company stood ready to settle the case and might even install controls at some plants. It has already promised to do so in Michigan.
But there is a gulf between the two sides over how many of the other plants will ultimately get new controls. Mr. Alphonso said the company's own studies indicate that many of the plants simply do not emit enough V.O.C.'s to need more controls.
In August 1994, the E.P.A. filed a notice of possible clean air violations by Georgia-Pacific, citing 26 plants. The company submitted its detailed challenge to the E.P.A.'s case in November.
The company also took its case to Capitol Hill. It drafted an amendment that would bar Federal agencies from taking action against companies whose decisions had been approved by state officials, or had relied on documents like the E.P.A.'s mistaken emissions formula. The company asked Senator David Pryor, the Arkansas Democrat, to propose the measure. He declined, but a few weeks later, a similar version turned up in Senator Dole's regulatory reform bill, as refined by Senators Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, and Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
If the Hair Is Gray, Con Artists See Green

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
BETTY NORMAN was no match for the telephone con men who emptied her pockets of more than $40,000.
A plain-talking widow who runs a small motel in Ionia, Mich., a town of state prisons and apple orchards, Mrs. Norman, born and raised here, was taught to believe that people are essentially honest. So she trusted salespeople who picked up details about her life in seemingly casual telephone chat while pitching her pens, costume jewelry and other trinkets. And after being swindled out of thousands of dollars, she lost even more to people promising to recover her original investments. 
 "It makes you feel like taking your life, to think you've been skinned," said Mrs. Norman, 68, who for months was too mortified to reveal it to her grown children. "I've been struggling along. People here have lent me money, and I'm trying to get it paid back."
Few have been hurt as badly as Mrs. Norman, but millions of older Americans know what it is to be hounded by marketers -- some legitimate, some not -- who consider the elderly easy marks. With plenty of assets, ranging from life-insurance payouts to mortgage-free homes, they are seen as lonely and more trusting than cynical baby boomers. They tend to worry about interest rates: high rates signal inflation eating away their nest eggs, while low ones mean certificates of deposit will yield less.
All this makes them prime targets for people trying to sell, sell, sell -- everything from interests in wireless cable, obscure metals and "dirt piles" said to conceal nuggets of gold to mutual fund shares and limited partnerships that promise the moon.
Not that the elderly are the only victims. It's just that they don't often see themselves as pigeons. In a recent survey sponsored by AT&T, 18 percent of Americans, up from 14 percent two years ago, admitted to being scam victims. And even though fewer respondents over 65 said they knew a victim, younger respondents said they thought the elderly were the most likely to be preyed upon. Law-enforcement officials agree; indeed, F.B.I. agents working a telephone-marketing sting in 1993 got many salespeople to admit they targeted the elderly.
What's more, it is harder for the elderly to bounce back after being swindled -- either by taking legal action, earning enough to repair their finances, or turning for help to their children who might see the mishap as proof of a loss in judgment or sign of frailty.
"It's often very, very difficult for them to admit they've been exploited because it's so humiliating," said Herbert Rosedale, a Manhattan lawyer who helps elder victims of fraud. "It's not like a kid who can say, 'So, I bought into a scam. I'll grow out of it.' "
Finding victims is simple. Older people are fairly easy to contact, either through zip codes or mailing lists of retirees. Sometimes they're taken for a ride by apparent friends, whether it's young people who turn up on doorsteps offering to carry groceries or middle-aged people who ease into church groups.
Even trusted local business people can turn into predators. The elderly "just like the Marcus Welby view of the world, that people in business are basically honest," says Philip A. Feigin, Colorado's securities commissioner and president of the North American Securities Administrators Association, which tracks investment fraud. "So many times when we crack a scam, the investors who call us are absolutely furious that we broke it up."
Of course, any investment, made at any age, can go sour. But "if you blow it when you're 30, you've got 35 years to make it up before you retire," says Barbara Roper, director of investment protection for the Consumer Federation of America. "If you blow it at 65, you may have to go back to work for the rest of your life."
The elderly are also prime targets for cults, many of which flourish in the nursing homes and sunnier climes where senior citizens are clustered. They are often expert at exploiting the loneliness that comes with living far from kin and at persuading recruits to turn over all their assets.
"Twenty-five years ago I had people calling me to say their young-adult offspring had been picked up by a cult," said Margaret Singer, a Berkeley, Calif., psychologist and leading authority on cults. "In the last five years, it's adults calling me and saying a certain cult has got their mother or their grandmother."
What follows are the main investment frauds and hazards that older Americans, and their adult children, should be aware of.
 
In the Mail, On the Phone
 Fraud that reaches the elderly by mail or telephone has been refined to a high art. Telemarketing fraud alone is believed to be a $40 billion business. Sometimes the scam starts with a puzzle or a contest, promising prizes; other times a breathless broker, complete with ticker-tape sound effects, pushes a trendy commodity or a stock too hot to resist.
"I had a lot of time to waste," said Bea Johnson, a 77-year-old retired beautician who lives alone in Roseville, Minn., and became addicted to puzzles she got in the mail. The puzzles, mostly word or number games, were supposed to qualify her for prizes like new cars or $10,000 in cash; she merely had to return them a check for $10 or $50 or more.
Mrs. Johnson lost $11,000 over two years by the time she quit in 1993. The case wound up with the Minnesota Attorney General and Mrs. Johnson became something of a celebrity, as the widow who learned to say, "No." "I still work on those puzzles they send me, but I don't send them in."
Bill Duryea, a retired Sears service representative who lives in Casa Grande, Ariz., got taken in several years ago by a salesman who called and urged him to invest in wireless cable. Mr. Duryea sent a check for $6,400. "He was blabbering and jabbering, and I don't listen to them too good," said Mr. Duryea, 80. But the same salesman had once urged him to buy shares in a cellular phone company, and Mr. Duryea regretted ignoring that pitch.
He sent off his money in 1991 -- a cashier's check, fetched by a courier (two clear warning signs of a fraud in progress). He has received nothing but a telemarketing barrage since then.
Now, he says with a chuckle, he has an answering machine that says, "If you're trying to sell me something, forget it."
Investigators say telemarketers sell one another "mooch lists" of people like Mr. Duryea, people who once took the bait, and are thus considered likely to do so again. Such lists sell for $5 to $10 a name, compared with 50 cents a name for typical mail-order lists, Mr. Barker said.
Mrs. Norman described being called repeatedly, at all hours, by a man claiming to be with an outfit called the National Recovery Service. "He would tell me to go to Western Union and send him $300, or $1,500, and he'd send me my money," she said. "One time he called and I was on the phone, and he had the operator butt in and say it was an emergency and he was my grandson. Another time he said he was driving to Michigan to bring me my money. He said he was driving a little Ford Pinto, and told me the color."
He and the Pinto never arrived, and neither did her money. She ended up spending $32,000, just for the supposed recovery, between September and December of last year. She had lost perhaps $10,000 on various contests before that, she said.
 
With Friends Like These . . .
 Often the elderly are persuaded by people they think of as friends to make inappropriate investments, or to otherwise be reckless with their money. Louise Fletcher, an 86-year-old widow, trusted the branch manager of the Scarsdale branch of the Dime Savings Bank so thoroughly that she gave him her passbooks to perform transactions. The manager, John F. Bald, was charged Friday with stealing $260,000 from Mrs. Fletcher over the last six years. Even being very rich provides no immunity. When a court-appointed investigator concluded last month that the butler to Doris Duke, the late tobacco heiress, had gone on a spending spree with money she had entrusted to him, the case was front-page news. But garden-variety scams flourish every day of the year.
In January, a Denver investment artist named Randy Romero was sentenced to four years in prison and ordered to pay $98,000 in restitution to people he had defrauded through phony securities sales. One of his techniques, said Mr. Feigin, the Colorado securities commissioner, was to win people's trust by joining church groups. His victims included a retired Lutheran pastor and several elderly parishioners.
"He used to get on his knees and pray with his fellow victims-to-be that their investment would turn out well," Mr. Feigin said. "They thought that was great."
In another case, a 77-year-old retired teacher in Maine invested almost all her savings -- $77,000 -- with a man who visited her regularly and whom she came to consider her best friend. He sold her shares of a nonexistent fund, for which he produced fake account statements that promised a 12 percent yield, said Christine Bruenn, an official with the Maine Securities Division. The man, Christopher P. Mussenden, had been well known in small Maine towns, where he had sold insurance, legitimately, for years. He was sentenced to 33 months in prison in 1993 for defrauding 25 people.
Breaking the news about him to his victims was painful, Ms. Bruenn said. "She was rocking in her rocking chair, with her cat on her lap," she said. "And I had to tell her this man she considered her best friend had done all this. She told me the cat was her only friend left."
A retired mechanic in Emigsville, Pa., had spent months discussing his financial situation with a man who repaired his roof. "We were friends for years," said the retiree, who did not want to be further identified.
But the roof man became a salesman for something variously called Tri-State Water Haven Club and Brighter Community Inc., which sold shares in a water-purification system that promised a 15 percent annual return. The retiree put in $4,000 in severance pay he had told the roofer about.
"He knew what was going on in my world," he says, "and I knew what was going on in his world. And he knew about my life savings, and there you go -- I don't have it anymore."
 
Cults
 From groups run by Lyndon LaRouche to Elizabeth Clare Prophet, cults have shifted their focus to the elderly.
"Cults recruit the elderly on the basis of their loneliness," says Margaret Singer, Berkeley, Calif., psychologist and a leading authority on cults whose book, "Cults in Our Midst" (Jossey-Bass, 1995), discusses the increasing number of elderly people joining up. "But they're going for their assets. Cults on the whole are out to get more money and more power, not to benefit the lives of the members."
Some cults play on the elderly's fears of mortality, promising eternal life, as in People Forever International Inc., based in Scottsdale, Ariz., Dr. Singer said. Others feature conspiracy theories, like the untrustworthiness of the Federal Government and the undependability of the nation's banks.
"I had a call the other day from a woman whose elderly mother had given $75,000 to organizations that were milking her for conspiracy theories," said Cynthia Kisser, executive director of the Chicago-based Cult Awareness Network. She "didn't feel the public was being told the whole truth by the media, and was being exploited because of that."
Doomsday cults urge elderly recruits to surrender money, cars and houses on the theory that since the world is about to end, they'll lose it anyway.
Ms. Kisser's organization also collected testimony from elderly people who had given money to the Lyndon LaRouche Foundation thinking this was a charitable deduction but then could not qualify for tax deductions. "One woman gave what she thought was a contribution, and they told her they would give literature to the college library of her choice," she said. Because the gift didn't come directly from her, however, the woman was ineligible for a tax deduction.
Sometimes cult recruiters perform small favors, like mowing lawns or toting grocery bags, to build up guilt in older people so they feel they have to attend a meeting. Or they might offer classes in, say, money management, that start out inexpensively but then build to ever-more-costly levels.
 
Real Deals That Mislead
 Even when the product is legitimate, many elderly people can be victimized simply by being led into making the wrong investment.
The confusion can begin at the front office, either at a bank or a brokerage house, where employees who are rewarded for their sales volumes carry titles like "financial adviser" or "financial consultant."
"This is one of my pet peeves," said Ms. Roper of the Consumer Federation. "It's particularly a problem when you have a large sum of money to invest, from a lump-sum pension or a life-insurance payout, and you go to a financial adviser at Shearson or Prudential or Merrill Lynch. They're salespeople but they're not advertised that way. "
But the securities industry begs to differ. "They're more than just salespeople," said Jeffrey M. Schaefer, director of research for the Securities Industry Association in New York. "The emphasis is on building a relationship. Those who try to concentrate on one particular transaction don't last too long."
To avoid confusion, Ms. Roper suggests contacting a fee-only financial planner, who has no financial incentive to steer clients into specific products. Consumers should then choose investments with care. Elderly people whose financial derring-do goes no farther than rolling over a certificate of deposit now and then should be especially wary when other financial products such as mutual funds are being pushed at their local bank branch.
"Sometimes the same vice president who's selling them to a retired couple is the person who gave them that college loan or the money for an extension on their house," said Mr. Feigin. "What's worse is that many of the salespeople are new to the industry, don't have good training and may think what they're selling is good for the client."
With mutual funds, titles can be misleading and the funds themselves inappropriate for older people, who, like everyone else, can neglect to read the prospectus's fine print. Ms. Roper points to the Piper Jaffray Institutional Government Fund Portfolio -- it sounded as sturdy and all-American as apple pie, but it actually contained high-risk mortgage-backed derivatives. The fund lost 28 percent of its value last year alone.
In Maine, regulators joined counterparts from several other states to bring a lawsuit against First Investors Corporation, which had marketed high-yield funds to local residents, many of them elderly.
When interest rates fell in the early 1990's, "a lot of elderly people became vulnerable to investment pitches that promised them a continuing high level of interest without additional risk," said Stephen Diamond, the state securities administrator. But certain funds, like First Investors' Income Fund and High Yield Fund, contained junk bonds. "They were overtly or at least subtly misleading these people about the risk," he said. The case culminated in a $9 million judgment in December against Merchants Trust, the bank that had marketed the fund.
"We tend to blame the victims, but no one can say they're immune to this," said Mr. Feigin. "It could be your mother next time."
 
 
 
What to Look For And Whom to Contact
 EXPERTS offer the following tips for dealing with telephone salespeople.
1. Just hang up. Or better yet, get an answering machine, which prevents that verbal foot-in-the-door.
"Never do investment business over the phone," says Philip A. Feigin, president of the North American Securities Administrators Association.
2. Beware any salesman who says he or she will send a courier to pick up your check.This began as a means of skirting Federal mail-fraud laws, Mr. Feigin said.
3. Any salesman who calls should be willing to meet in person, to give addresses of local sales offices and to send a prospectus.
Even so, it's helpful to check out his or her credentials, as well as the firm's -- through the state Attorney General's office, the state securities administrator or other watchdog agencies.
4. Investigate every angle of a mutual fund. Read the prospectus; find out what's being included in the fund.
Ask what relationship exists between the bank selling the fund and the fund's management. Ask about fees and front-end loads.
Remember that not everything is insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
5. Be cynical. If something seems too good to be true, it usually is.
6. For children of the elderly, continuous contact can help avoid problems. Loneliness is frequently a factor when older people take affection, services or other bait from someone who is after their money.
People who suspect they may have been victims of an investment fraud can contact their state Attorney General's office or local securities administrators.
In addition, the following agencies and organizations may be helpful in reporting or averting fraud.
The National Fraud Information Center operates a special telephone line weekdays from 9 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.: (800) 876-7060.
For referrals to fee-only financial planners, contact the National Association of Personal Financial Advisers, (800) 366-2732.
To investigate the credentials of a stockbroker or securities firm, call the North American Association of Securities Administrators, at (202) 737-0900.
For guidance on investing in mutual funds, the S.E.C. publishes a brochure,"Invest Wisely," which is available by calling (202) 942-7040.
For information on cults, sources include the Cult Awareness Network, (312) 267-7777; the International Cult Education Project, (212) 439-1550, and the Maynard Bernstein Center for Cult Education, (213) 852-1234.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1279 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Small Funds Bulk Up With Borrowed Money as Stocks Soar

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
IS your mutual fund on steroids?
A handful of funds are. They have turned to the financial equivalent of steroids -- leverage -- in search of heftier returns. What they do is leverage their assets, by borrowing money from a bank, to invest more than their shareholders have contributed. 
 But heavy borrowing by a fund should give pause to any investor who is not prepared for a high degree of volatility. Financial leverage sharpens performance on the way up but magnifies losses on the way down. A swooning stock market, therefore, could leave a leveraged fund reeling.
In such a great year for stocks, there would seem to be few reasons for fund managers to use any artificial performance enhancers. According to Lipper Analytical Services, nearly two-thirds of all equity funds have gained more than 10 percent so far this year. But only 148 of 1,701 equity funds, or 8.7 percent, have outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500 index.
By borrowing money to invest, funds improve their chances of beating the average in a rising market.
Trying to maximize gains is a common pursuit these days. The most recent data from the Investment Company Institute, the Washington trade group for mutual funds, show that cash levels in domestic stock funds fell to 7 percent of total assets at the end of March -- the lowest level since 1978. Normally, fund managers maintain higher cash levels to cover any shareholder redemptions and to provide a cushion should share prices decline. But holding cash this year has meant below-par returns.
One indicator of whether a fund has taken the next step and begun borrowing is when its cash position turns negative, something tracked since 1986 by Morningstar Inc., the fund researchers in Chicago. A search of the Morningstar data base found that 2.4 percent of the 2,000 equity funds it tracks had a negative cash position at the end of the first quarter. Though high, that is well below the record of 4.3 percent with negative cash positions in the tumultuous fourth quarter of 1987.
Screened out then were international funds, which might borrow to hedge against currency losses, and hybrid funds, which often contain more bonds than stocks. Of the pure domestic equity portfolios remaining on the list, most had negative cash positions of less than 2 percent of assets. Four funds had very heavy borrowing, led by Yorktown Classic Value at nearly 50 percent, making them particularly vulnerable should stock prices retreat.
Mutual funds can borrow money only if the possibility is spelled out in the prospectus, and then the cash must be borrowed from a bank. Under the Investment Company Act of 1940, the money cannot be borrowed from a brokerage firm, and funds cannot buy stocks on margin.
But as with so many contingencies detailed in those impenetrable documents, most funds rarely avail themselves of the right to borrow. When they do, it is often for short periods -- a few days perhaps, to pay a large shareholder who wants a redemption.
A handful of aggressive funds turn to leverage more regularly, sometimes borrowing for months at a time. The results can be spectacular. the Yorktown Classic Value fund, which had far and away the most leverage in the Morningstar data search, is one of the best performers this year in its class of growth stocks. The $5.7 million fund has gained nearly 23 percent since Jan. 1.
But in its first two years, the fund seriously trailed the Standard & Poor's 500, by 6.5 percentage points in 1993 and 5.3 percentage points last year.
"We've used leverage since Day 1," said David D. Basten, manager of the Yorktown fund. "And we probably always will as long as interest rates and inflation are stable. It's a tremendous advantage to be able to borrow cheaply, at about 9 percent, and earn more than double that amount in returns."
A mutual fund is allowed to borrow the equivalent of 50 percent of its net assets. Put another way, one-third of a fund's total assets can be borrowed money. Yorktown Classic Value nearly always borrows up to the limit: At the end of the first quarter, borrowing totaled 47.3 percent of net assets.
Yorktown's concentrated portfolio of only about 20 stocks at a time may add to the fund's volatility, Mr. Basten said. But he insists that because the fund focuses on high-quality stocks -- its biggest holdings are May Department Stores, at 12 percent of assets, and Owens Corning-Fiberglas at 9 percent -- leverage does not guarantee disaster when the market turns negative.
"If the market takes a severe hit, sure our stocks will get hit," Mr. Basten said. "But if you're already in strong, high-quality issues, half the portfolio might get hammered, but the other half will only get semi-hammered. And we increase our position in the less battered ones."
Simple math, however, shows how leverage can hurt. Suppose funds A and B each have $10 million in assets. Both funds invest all their money, but Fund B borrows an additional $5 million, at an annual interest rate of 10 percent, and invests it.
If the stocks in each fund rise 20 percent, Fund B, after repaying the $5 million it borrowed and interest of $500,000, ends the year with a gain of $2.5 million, or 25 percent. Fund A, of course, finishes with a 20 percent gain.
BUT suppose the funds' investments fall 20 percent. Then Fund B, after repaying its borrowing and interest costs, is left with $6.5 million, a loss of 35 percent, compared with Fund A's 20 percent loss.
A negative cash position, though, may reflect factors other than borrowing to buy stock. A March 31 snapshot of Bull & Bear Special Equities showed a negative cash position of nearly 19 percent.
Brett Sneed, the manager of the fund, said he had borrowed some money to invest and then on the last day of the quarter shareholders requested redemptions representing nearly 10 percent of the fund's assets. Rather than sell that much of the portfolio immediately, Mr. Sneed borrowed most of the amount to repay the investors. Since then, he has reduced much of the debt.
"Right now, our borrowings are at about 6.4 percent," Mr. Sneed said, calling that a typical amount. "If we have money in the fund that might be deemed warm or hot, that might move quickly out, we are more likely to stay away from leveraging. We don't want to be caught with a down market and have money running out."
Some funds use leverage sporadically. Mark D. Beckerman, manager of the 44 Wall Street Equity fund, pointed to good years from 1991 to 1993, when the fund gained 18 percent to 26 percent each year, without borrowing.
At the end of last year, however, with bullish sentiment rising, the manager decided to increase borrowing, to near its current level of 11.6 percent. In recent weeks, the fund's return has spiked upward as well. "If we had a more extensive use of leverage, we might be scaling back," Mr. Beckerman said. "But we still have stocks that haven't appreciated that much, so we probably will stay about where we are now.
"Leverage is simply a tool," he added, "and when it's used properly it's going to work for you."
Shelton Swei, co-manager of two Alger funds that use leverage, notes that if declining stock prices push a fund above the permissible amount of leverage, it has three days to sell stocks to return to the limit. Although his funds can buy more volatile instruments than stocks using leverage, they have done so "only very modestly," he said.
When the bond market turned south last year, investors in some leveraged bond funds learned about the danger of borrowed money. Investors in stock funds that are using leverage face the same painful lesson if stocks reverse course.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Playing the Game of Tariff Tag

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:
SUPPOSE that instead of a used car, you're in the market for a Lexus or an Infiniti. What do you do now that the Clinton Administration has slapped 100 percent tariffs on these and other Japanese luxury cars?
The tariff went into effect for cars not on these shores yesterday, though it won't be applied until June 28. So while politicians tryto work things out, prospective car buyers are left to agonize over the next step. 
 After all, with that killer tariff, a $30,000 Acura Legend would top $50,000, while a top-of-the-line $50,000 Lexus would be . . . no, you don't want to know. The Japanese car makers are saying they will hold dealer prices steady for now, covering the tariffs themselves if the sanctions hold. So their loyal fans are rushing to lock in today's prices.
Dealers, of course, could take advantage of the situation by padding prices, but visions of a stampede down the street to the Mercedes or BMW dealer might give them pause. "Jaguar and BMW must be licking their chops," said one trade lawyer, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
 Susan Jacobs, a consultant in Rutherford, N.J., to the auto industry, said buyers with their "hearts set on a Lexus should probably go ahead and close the deal." For if June drags on with no resolution, she said, prices will start to rise. But she added, "If you're undecided between a Lexus and a European vehicle, it's better to wait."
Many impatient souls were spotted at dealers last week. "I'm sure a lot of people will rush out to buy" Japanese luxury cars, said Ted Orme, spokesman for the National Automobile Dealers Association. He estimated that dealers had a 60- to 80-day supply of cars. But he said that if you rush to buy at what is unlikely to be the best price, "you may be jumping the gun, gambling that the tariffs will go through."
 That's the big question: Will the tariffs stick? The trade lawyer predicted that the World Trade Organization would rule the sanctions illegal, but that could take months. And John Jackson, a University of Michigan law professor and a top trade scholar, has said that the Japanese have a "flat-out easy case."
But Ms. Jacobs, calling herself a pessimist, said she "wouldn't be surprised if we end up with some sort of sanctions." If full sanctions hold, she said, the affected dealers "would be transformed" though most would still be around. Since auto parts are not affected, the dealers could still provide service.
But will parts be readily available years down the road? And will your dealer -- the one you had counted on for service -- survive? Either loss could make life bumpy.
 What all this adds up to is if you're dead set on buying a Japanese luxury car, do it now -- but don't expect a plum deal. (And don't forget that the luxury tax kicks in at $32,000.) If you're wavering, keep wavering.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BEFORD STUYVESANT;
Vendors Fear Another Block Could Be Another Country

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Pulsing to the rhythms of dance hall reggae, the intersection of Fulton Street and Nostrand Avenue is a kind of Caribbean and African bazaar where street vendors hawk herbs such as sea moss and bacano, handmade leather hats, purses carved from calabash gourds and landscapes that are painted while you wait.
But the burgeoning outdoor market is scheduled to close on June 1, when the city says it will move the vendors off Fulton Street. The vendors are worried about the plan, which calls for them to leave the commercial hub of Bedford-Stuyvesant for a vacant lot on Tompkins Avenue, three blocks away. 
 "If customers have to leave where they're walking and look for us in some parking lot, they're not going to come find us," said Raphael Charles, a 40-year-old from Grenada who sells West Indian herbs. "This is a good form of self-employment."
The impetus for the city's actions comes, in part, from neighborhood merchants with whom the vendors had peacefully coexisted for years. But the sluggish economy has prompted complaints from store owners worried about sidewalk congestion and competition from merchants who don't pay rent.
"At first, nine out of 10 merchants said that they would let vendors sell in front of their stores as long as they did not sell the same things," said Joe Long, the chairman of the Fulton-Nostrand United Merchants Association. "It only changed when the economy changed."
Their efforts to remove the vendors were bolstered after Mayor Giuliani ordered vendors removed from 125th Street in Harlem and other major thoroughfares in the city. Mr. Long, who owns Birdy's Tapes and Audio Store on Fulton Street, contacted City Councilwoman Annette M. Robinson, who represents the area, to plan the move. "We are hopeful that there will not be a lot of resistance because we've been planning this for years," Ms. Robinson said.
Lewis A. Watkins, the district manager of Community Board 3, agreed that the streets are often overcrowded, but he said he would like some vendors to remain on Fulton Street. "The city established a policy that they want to clear all the vendors," he said. "It's not about a community demand. I think the community should have some say-so."
Many street vendors said they felt betrayed by the impending city action. "America is a country of freedom and rights, a country that encourages business and enterprise," said Simeon Chickosie, a 40-year-old from Arima, Trinidad, who sewed a leather hat as he spoke. "I don't see why they should stop us."
"It's sad," said Mucai Albert, a 45-year-old from Senegal who was forced to stop selling his $5 sunglasses on the Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan last year. "This is not Manhattan, this is not downtown -- it's Brooklyn. I don't know what will happen if we move. But God is good."
Mr. Long and Ms. Robinson said they would leaflet the neighborhood and send out sound trucks to try to drum up business for the new market on Tompkins Avenue.
But Otis Andrews, a 27-year-old from Port-of-Spain, Trinidad, who was working on a leather bracelet with an awl, said that Tompkins Avenue may be too out-of-the-way.
"The vendors bring sales to the stores," he said. "People come to see us and then they go to the stores."
John Baldeo, the owner of Tony's Country Life Food Shop, a store on Fulton Street, agreed. "A lot of people come here for the outdoor market," he said. "People like crowds. New York is about crowds. If this becomes a lonely street people will be scared to walk here."
Outside Tony's, Franklin Holland and his friend, who gave his name only as Mark, set out cosmetics, tube socks, tapes and Mike Tyson T-shirts. Mr. Baldeo said that he would like to let them continue selling there.
"They keep the sidewalk clean, they help me close at night," he said. "In the winter they even shovel the snow." MICHAEL COOPER
