HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
A Gathering of Clans Puts Power in Relief

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
In an unusual alignment of opposing political constellations, the Republicans and the Democrats are both on the road in New Jersey this weekend, the Republicans to celebrate a sense of power and purpose, the Democrats literally wondering what to do next.
The Republicans are spending the weekend in Atlantic City for the Republican Leadership Conference, a gathering of Northeastern state party chairmen operating on an agenda whose absence of strenuousness says a lot about the G.O.P.'s confident mood. Several of the leading Presidential contenders were scheduled to speak, Governor Whitman should see her national reputation burnished, a few strategy sessions will spell out campaign themes, but gripping and grinning is about as much work as there is to do. 
 New Jersey state Democrats met on a smaller scale Friday and Saturday in Long Branch, a town that might have politely changed its name to Square One in honor of the Democrats' situation. "A Party of Ideas" was the theme, and its purpose was to decide what the Democrats stand for in the age of Whitman.
One thing is clear, according to a statement of party principles that Tom Byrne, the state chairman, put out Tuesday: New Jersey Democrats are in the "the post-Florio era," which was the era of the old Democratic ideas about state intervention when the opportunity arose, and higher taxes if necessary.
"As a party, we are committed to a government that is lean without being mean," Mr. Byrne said, paraphrasing Mrs. Whitman's catch phrase for Republican management, "leaner and smarter." "Democrats," Mr. Byrne continued, "are proud of their long tradition of commonsense solutions to the problems of everyday working men and women."
That tradition has written some brave chapters in New Jersey. The income tax, enacted when Mr. Byrne's father, Brendan T. Byrne, was Governor, broke the cycle of ever-rising property taxes and put school financing on a rational and fair basis. Democrats began the long and still unfinished task of winning an equal break for inner-city schools. New Jersey's environmental laws are some of the most thorough in the country, although the Republicans have certainly participated in their enactment. Mr. Florio, now largely ignored by his own state party, outfaced the Republicans on his assault- rifle ban, which was a worthy task just on principle in a society besotted with firepower, even though the firearms that he outlawed were rarely used in crimes.
But politics is heartless, and its operating motto is "What have you done for me lately?" With many of the fundamentals in place, the Democrats took too long in figuring out that "everyday working men and women" had found new things to worry about.
Take a very minor example, the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit. Begun in the name of fuel economy, retained in the name of safety, it is as frustrating as it is ignored by everyday men and women. Yet from Boston to Albany to Trenton, Democratic administrations dismissed talk of changing it. Now, for reasons that have nothing to do with speed limits but lots to do with frustration, Republicans are running those states and before long, the speed limits on the appropriate, Federally certifed stretches of highway, will be back at 65, as they already are in Massachussetts.
When the new signs go up in New Jersey, a lot of everyday people are going to say a silent, "Thanks, Christie." By then the Democrats will have endorsed the idea, but "me too" is a losers's strategy.
"The comparison I see is to the Republicans in the 1950's," said Stephen Salmore, a grizzled Republican strategist whose wisdom is rooted in his skepticism, including where Mrs. Whitman is concerned. "In the 50's the Republicans said the Democrats' ideas weren't bad but that Republicans could do them better because they were businessmen. Now the Democrats are saying, 'The Republicans' ideas are good but they can't do it compassionately.' "
The 1993 campaign said something about the appeal of compassion in a state like New Jersey, where a lot of people were too worried about jobs and their value of their homes to fret for others. At several points in the campaign, Mrs. Whitman even used the compassion argument against Mr. Florio, accusing him of cruelty to welfare mothers for the limits on benefits contained in his welfare reform.
It did not catch on with the voters, and in a grab for an issue that is universally described as desperate, she uttered the only words that are beyond the reach of even me-too Democrats: tax cut.
So this weekend, the Republicans are relaxing in Atlantic City, and the Democrats are back at a place called Square One.

HEADLINE: NEWS AND TOPICS;
Pay: Low. Future: None. Still Want a Summer Job? Get in Line.

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
As Memorial Day approaches and the school year slouches to a close, a frenetic ritual is well under way. The teen-agers of New Jersey are scrambling for summer work, and despite slight improvements in the state's economy, those jobs are still relatively scarce.
After several years of recession, when young people were competing with adults for summer jobs, the market finally improved last year. In the third quarter of 1994, unemployment among New Jersey residents age 16 to 19 was 16 percent, down from 20.7 percent in 1993. But the chances of finding a job were much slimmer than in the late 1980's, when a labor shortage made it a summer job-seeker's market, and the State Department of Labor's annual employer outlook survey, to be published in June, suggests that the market will remain stagnant this summer as well. 
 "What we hear is that employers expect hiring to be about the same as last year," said Jan DeJong, chief of the labor department's Bureau of Labor Market Information. "We have definitely improved over the recession levels, but it doesn't look like there will be considerable change this summer."
An exception could be the shore region, where 54 percent of all tourist dollars are spent and businesses experienced an economic rebound last summer. In fact, the shore offers more seasonal jobs than any other part of the state, so thousands of adolescents flock there each June, seemingly eager to hawk T-shirts, dispense snow cones and deliver seafood platters to tables of tourists.
But even when the economy is thriving at the shore, the number of summer jobs does not necessarily grow. The Casino Pier and Waterworks in Seaside Heights hires about 700 employees every summer, regardless of the economic mood.
"It may vary by 10 or 20 people, but the number of jobs doesn't change," said Bill Erwin, the general manager, adding that he would be hiring slightly fewer people this season. Like many shore businesses, the amusement pier has far more applicants than jobs. Typically, Mr. Erwin said, 700 teen-agers apply for 180 positions at the pier's water park.
For job-seekers who lack seaside lodging, there is a popular alternative: the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park.
The park, located in Jackson, is the state's largest private summer employer. Last summer, about 5,000 high school and college students worked as ride attendants, maintenance workers and security guards, among other things. So far this year, almost 8,000 people have applied for summer jobs at the park, and 3,558 -- mostly teen-agers -- have been hired.
Like boardwalk businesses, Great Adventure lures the same employees back year after year. MaryBeth Clayton, the public relations manager, said 60 percent of the park's employees from last summer were returning for another season. Some, like Zhi Zhi Kurokawa, confess to wanting a year-round job there.
"It's a great place because the company shows us how much they appreciate us," said Miss Kurokawa, who at 22 has spent seven summers at Great Adventure. Barbecues and bingo games for employees, she said, make up for the long shifts spent under a hot sun. And the friendships that blossom among park employees continue after Labor Day.
Another perk is transportation: Because many teen-agers lack cars, Great Adventure transports employees between the park and 18 locations in Burlington, Mercer, Monmouth and Ocean counties.
While most summer jobs are found by combing the classified section or scouting out "Help Wanted" signs, Great Adventure actively seeks employees with a corporate approach. In January, the park holds a "rehire reunion," giving the previous summer's employees the first crack at positions for the coming summer. (The most popular job? Ride attendant, by a long shot.)
It then recruits at 53 colleges and 46 high schools throughout New Jersey, including inner-city schools in Trenton. Applicants, who must be at least 16, go through three interviews. Those who are hired must endure rigorous training in the art of being "guest friendly." (In other words, if someone asks directions to the Viper roller coaster, a park worker must cheerfully explain a route.)
Despite the park's efforts to hire in advance, it is flooded with calls from skittish parents well into June. Latecomers need not abandon hope: Many young people cannot work the entire summer, so jobs open up constantly.
"It's a Catch-22 working with kids because their schedules are so unpredictable," Ms. Clayton said. "So if someone leaves in August, we'll hire someone else to work through Labor Day."
Like most summer jobs, the pay at Great Adventure is not a major incentive. Beginners earn a minimum wage of $5.05 an hour, while people with seniority earn up to $7. The money apparently doesn't matter to Miss Kurokawa, who said she turned down a lucrative marketing job at Trump's Castle in Atlantic City to return to the park.
"I actually started working there, but I missed this place so much that I couldn't stay," she said. "Knowing I could be here, I couldn't stand being somewhere else."

 Here are some suggestions from several guidance counselors.

STATE PARKS Many need extra maintenance workers. Check the blue pages of the phone book.
RECREATION DEPARTMENTS Municipalities hire workers for maintenance work and recreation programs. Call your town's recreation department, listed in the blue pages.
TEMPORARY SECRETARIAL WORK Jobs can last from a day to a few months. Typing and some computer skills are usually required. Call placement services, listed in the yellow pages under Employment Agencies.

HEADLINE: The World;
Japan's Secret Weapon Is the Piggy Bank

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
AS America hurtles toward a trade war with Japan, most economists think the United States' trade deficit has little to do with protectionism in Japan. The real problem, they say, is that Joe Sixpack uses his paycheck to buy CD's from Wal-Mart while Joko Sixpackayama uses hers to buy CD's from a bank.
 How's that? 
 The underlying reason for the American trade deficit, the economists say, is that Americans have a miserable record of saving for the future. And one of the most fundamental principles of economics -- and among the least understood -- is that trade balances reflect how countries save and invest their money.
 So even if Washington forces Japan to buy more American cars and parts, don't expect a decline in the trade deficit. Since it is savings and investment that mainly determine trade deficits, the overall deficit would stay about the same.
 "The reason you will find very few economists who will disagree with that is simply that it comes straight out of the basic national income accounting that we teach students in the very first week of the very first economics course," said Peter B. Kenen, a Princeton economics professor.
 This may be essential to understanding trade disputes, but hardly anyone understands it. Nor is there recognition of the prospect that Japan's aging population and dropping savings rate may solve the problem, giving Japan its own trade deficit.
 The bottom line is this: If a country saves more than it invests in new factories and equipment, it will definitely run a trade surplus. Or, in America's case, vice-versa.
 "If the U.S. addressed the domestic problems that it has, such as the budget deficit and the household savings rate, all this U.S.-Japan protectionism argument would appear as nothing more than a hill of beans," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist of Salomon Brothers in Tokyo.

 
 
Take That
 The United States primed its artillery in the trade war a few days ago by imposing 100 percent tariffs that will make the Lexus, Infiniti and other luxury cars unsalable in the United States. The tariffs will be revoked if the two countries reach agreement in the next six weeks.
 In the meantime both countries are taking the case to the newly created World Trade Organization. Many experts believe the United States is likely to lose the suit brought by Japan.
 Most economists think the Japanese Government is less responsible for America's trade deficit than the American Government -- which borrows to cover the budget deficit -- and the American people, who save only around 5 percent of their disposable incomes. In contrast, Japan is a champion saver, the world's richest creditor nation, whose people save about 14 percent of their disposable incomes.
 So what's the connection with the trade deficit?
 It works like this: Last year Americans bought $155 billion more in Toyota cars, German beer and whatnot than foreigners bought in American products. That means a $155 billion deficit in the current account, which is the broadest measure of trade.
 So how do Americans make up the bill? They borrow: Other countries lend $155 billion of their extra savings. This is called the capital account, and it measures the extra savings that flow across borders. It exactly equals the current account.
 Japan exports its excess savings -- exporting $125 billion of capital last year. And that means that it had to run a current account surplus of $125 billion as well.

 
 
From Lexus to Mercedes

 The United States had a shortfall of savings, requiring an infusion of $155 billion last year. And that means that it had to run a current account deficit of $155 billion.
 So unless the relationship between savings and investment changes, in either Japan or the United States, it doesn't help to force Japanese to use American spark plugs. This might help the spark plug workers, but if the overall American trade deficit is unchanged, it just means that some other American exports have been crowded out: a spark plug factory in Michigan is saved, but a logging camp in Oregon goes bankrupt.
 "Let's suppose we succeed in really clobbering the Japanese auto industry," suggested William R. Cline, a trade expert at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. The high tariffs would mean that the United States would buy several billion dollars less in luxury Japanese cars, although the money might be used to buy German Mercedes-Benzes instead.
 The Japanese car makers would then face an economic crisis, and Mazda in particularly might not survive. The Japanese economy would slow down a bit, and Japanese auto executives would stop ordering log homes from Oregon, or even Jeep Cherokees from Chrysler. Over all, American employment would be unchanged.
 If economists think trade pressure on Japan isn't going to make much difference, what is the Clinton Administration up to?
 Partly, the answer is politics. Extra support among union members will outweigh any lost votes among economics professors.
 There are also more charitable explanations. For starters, there are economists who disagree to some extent with this conventional view. There are also some Japan specialists who complain that economic theory is virtually useless in explaining what goes on in Japan.
 Perhaps more important, the Clinton Administration points out that there is the issue of fairness. For half a century, Japanese industry and Government have colluded to place all kinds of obstacles in the way of American and other exporters, and threats have been the only way to reduce these barriers. Almost all economists would agree that the world has an interest in trying to get Japan to play by the same rules as other countries.
 The problem with the fairness issue is that in this dispute the United States has acted in such a way that it is about the only country that thinks it has right on its side.
 Almost everybody shares the American annoyance with Japanese officials, and the conviction that foreign exporters and Japanese consumers alike would benefit from a liberalization of rules. But in this case, there is a widespread feeling that the United States had adopted the wrong tactics, and that it is unjustified in bypassing the international trade system -- the World Trade Organization -- that has just been set up.
 The European Community a few days ago rebuked the United States for undermining the World Trade Organization, and the Economist magazine accused Washington of "truly breathtaking hypocrisy." The Financial Times warned in an editorial that "rarely -- perhaps never -- has U.S. action posed such a clear and direct threat to the fundamental principles of the multilateral trading system."
 Is a trade deficit bad? The answer, as with anything in economics, is: It depends. (President Truman, frustrated with economists always saying "on the other hand," once asked for a one-armed economist.)
 In the 19th century, the United States ran trade deficits, and this was the wise thing to do. The trade deficit meant that the United States was borrowing from foreign countries, and the money was used to build railroads and steel plants. These were sensible reasons to borrow.
 But mature economies, like the United States today, normally are lenders, not borrowers. There is no huge American construction program that requires foreign loans. And the trade deficit means that American children will have to pay back the loans their parents are taking out today.
 If the United States is serious about cutting its trade deficit, economists say, it should look for ways to boost its savings rate. Eliminating the tax-deductibility of mortgage payments would discourage people from borrowing to buy homes. Making interest income tax-free would encourage savings, and so would a high national sales tax in place of part of the income tax.
 Japan uses some of these methods. It has a national value-added tax, and its cut-rate taxes on interest income encourage savings. But these approaches primarily help the richest people, and in America they would be politically difficult or impossible to put in place.

 
 
The Graying of Japan

 In any case, the underlying role of savings and investment could mean that Japan's trade surplus will disappear on its own over the next two decades. This is because the Japanese population is aging rapidly, as its baby boomers become denture boomers. By the year 2020, a quarter of Japanese may be over 65.
 People normally save during their careers, and withdraw money from savings when they retire. So when Japan has more old people, it may have fewer people depositing into savings accounts, and more retirees withdrawing from their accounts.
 "Our savings rates will fall as our population ages," said Yukio Noguchi, an economics professor at Hitotsubashi University near Tokyo. Professor Noguchi's research suggests that savings will fall even lower than investment by about 2005 or 2010. That would mean that Japan would then be running a trade deficit.
 And then Japan, horrified by its trade deficits, may begin screaming about American protectionism.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Balancing Ax;
Doing Well in a Deficit-Free America. Or Not So Well.

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
FOR the first time since the golden 60's, the goal of a balanced budget suddenly seems within reach. The idea is hugely popular. The new Republican majority apparently has the clout to make it happen. And now the House and Senate Republicans have produced their versions of a balanced budget, complete with timetables and dollar targets.
 Many of the particulars will change as Congress hammers out a compromise. And no one can know whether the moment's political resolve will buckle -- it's happened before -- or whether the plan will indeed whittle the deficit from $200 billion to zero in a mere seven years. But whatever comes of the negotiations is bound to follow the current formula of stiff restraints on health care spending, a freeze on defense and deep cuts in Government programs. 
If the balancing act actually works, there will be lots of obvious losers, from forest rangers to Medicare recipients. Less easy to spot in the $1 trillion-plus of spending cuts are the winners.
 Some groups would escape the ax almost completely. Others would reap rewards from tax cuts. Still others -- a majority, most economists say -- would gain more from the benefits of deficit reduction to the economy than they would lose in Government services and checks. Economists figure that interest rates could fall by a percentage point or two as the Government borrows less and total demand for credit shrinks, and that the dollar will become even cheaper, spurring exports. Job and income growth are apt to be slightly faster than they would be if deficits kept piling up.
 Here are some of the probable winners and losers in this scenario.

 
 
The Elderly
 America's retirees have long been one of the biggest beneficiaries of Government largess. Now they will feel a squeeze. Almost half the savings -- over $400 billion -- is supposed to come from limiting growth in Medicare and Medicaid, which together make up the biggest item in the Federal budget after Social Security. Total spending would keep rising, but at a rate much lower than the double-digit pace of recent years. Further, though Social Security is off the table, the cost-of-living increase would shrink if a more accurate inflation measure replaces the Consumer Price Index. "The elderly, obviously, are the big losers," said Alan Auerbach of the University of California at Berkeley, former chief economist of the Congressional Joint Tax Committee. Still, he said, these blows are likely to be softened if interest rates fall: that would push up the price of most assets, from homes to stocks, and older Americans own most of these.

 
 
The Young
 If today's elderly pay for a bigger share of what they receive, tomorrow's workers can only benefit. Economists say current policies mean astronomical tax rates -- or huge benefit cuts -- for future generations. Lawrence Kotlikoff, an economist at Boston University, said that under the Senate proposal, the tax rate on future generations would drop to 72 percent of their lifetime wages. While that's a big improvement from the 84 percent that he projects under current policies, it is still "twice as high as current generations and still infeasible," he said. Of course, the plan also envisions cuts in some benefits for young Americans, including college loans and job training.

 
 
Washington, D.C.
 For Government employees and contractors, particularly those clustered in and around Washington, the Republican budget qualifies as a neutron bomb -- the kind that leaves buildings standing but eliminates people inside. The House version calls for abolishing the Commerce, Education and Energy Departments and the Interstate Commerce Commission. The Senate plan includes a seven-year pay freeze for senior Government officials. Mark Zandi, an economist at Regional Financial Associates in Philadelphia, calculates that the cuts would cost the nation's capital almost 12,000 jobs, or 2 percent of its job base, by the year 2003. New York and New Jersey, by contrast, stand to gain 60,000 jobs over the same period, spurred by tax changes.

 
 
Military Types
 Talk about dodging bullets. At the end of nearly every war in American history, Congress has slashed military spending to the bone. Not so after the cold war. True, the Republican budget blueprints call for freezing the defense budget at last year's level. Assuming an inflation rate of 3 percent, that would amount to a cut of more than 20 percent in real terms, and points to continued consolidation among weapons manufacturers. Nonetheless, says Stephen Moore, an economist at the Cato Institute, that is extremely gradual by historical standards. "Republicans are still fighting the cold war that doesn't exist anymore," he said. "They could do 40 percent."

 
 
Home Builders
 An interest-rate decline of a point or two would almost certainly fuel a housing boom, boost construction employment and spur lumber and appliance sales. Other interest-sensitive industries, from cars to computers, would get a lift, too. When rates declined in the early 1990's, new single-home construction and car sales helped pull the economy out of a recession.

 
 
Unions
 The Republican budget plans include several land mines for organized labor. One is the elimination of the Davis-Bacon Act, a law that requires union-scale wages for workers on government construction projects; striking it from the books would almost surely depress pay scales. And urban transit subsidies, for the most part, bolster the pay of transit workers. And there would be direct hits to government employment, just about the only area where unionization is growing.

 
 
Farmers
 An increasingly important Republican constituency, farmers may do rather well in the budget balancing process. The budget plans call for cuts in rural programs, like soil conservation and waste and water treatment, but major crop subsidies look likely to survive. Further, farmers are large net borrowers and own lots of assets. So they would be among the biggest beneficiaries of an interest-rate decline.

 
 
Doctors
 The pain of Medicare and Medicaid cuts for the poor and elderly would almost certainly be shared by their doctors and hospitals. Some of the squeeze would probably be felt by the privately insured, who may, in effect, subsidize patients with Government insurance.

 
 
Exporters
 Lower rates tend to keep the dollar cheap, too, as investors pass up American assets to buy up those of countries offering higher returns. So a deficit that's heading toward zero should, other things being equal, keep the dollar on the weak side. That's good for exporters, like makers of jet aircraft and fabricators of specialty steels.

 
 
The Poor
 Even enthusiasts of welfare changes agree that poor people who depend on the Government for cash, food, housing and medical care are likely to suffer. Both the House and Senate budget plans envision steep cuts. Part of the impact on the poor could be offset by new job opportunities. "The number of jobs overall will increase," said Roger Brinner, chief economist at Data Resources Inc. of Lexington, Mass. "With all these interest-sensitive sectors expanding, there will be more unskilled jobs in manufacturing and construction, as well as highly skilled ones."

 
 
The Middle Class
 It's the middle class that stands to gain most if deficit reduction swells national saving, encourages investment and leads to greater productivity gains and faster wage growth. But the middle class stands to gain in the short term, too.
 With lower interest rates, homeowners can refinance mortgages and stand to see their homes appreciate in value. Those who hold bonds or stocks benefit from asset appreciation as yields decline. Lower taxes on capital gains and estates would also raise the return to investing.
 Some benefits would be offset by cuts in Government services like student loans and possibly tougher tax treatment of fringe benefits. But in general, "since Social Security won't be cut, the middle class has been spared," said Joel Prakken, an economist at Laurence Meyer in St. Louis. "The tax cuts go to a lot of people, including the rich."

 
 
The Economists
 These tireless advocates of the benefits of zero deficits are about to get a kick in the teeth. At least under the Senate plan, the entire social sciences portion of the National Science Foundation, the independent Government agency that finances most of the research by most of the field's superstars, is about to be wiped out.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Riding on Straw And Other Polls

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
HERE'S a news flash from the Presidential campaign headquarters of Lamar Alexander: A survey of likely Republican primary voters across the country concluded that Mr. Alexander "leads overall and in every region of the country." Bar graphs show vividly that he even beats Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, 34 percent to 25 percent, and that he is wildly popular with female voters. 
 But there's a hitch. These expected voters were not actually expressing support for Mr. Alexander, but for a mythical contender named "Candidate B."

 
 
Faux Poll to the Rescue
 Since Mr. Alexander, a former Tennessee Governor and Education Secretary, barely registers on most voter surveys, his campaign needed to do something to convince reporters, fund raisers and others that he is gaining steam. And since no actual votes are cast until next February, contenders must somehow establish credibility to boost their organizational and financial efforts.
 Thus, the faux poll. "You only publicize it when it's good for you," said Michael Murphy, one of Mr. Alexander's top advisers. "But if I were the Dole campaign, the numbers would scare the hell out of me."
 While candidates have long toyed with ways to inflate their political stature, those running for the 1996 nomination have begun the process particularly early and, increasingly, are spending money on sophisticated strategies like polling. The pressure for them to appear significant is greater than ever because the primary schedule has been socrowded and truncated that the selection of a nominee could be settled only weeks after the first contests next February.
 "Every candidate tries to maximize whatever strength they have," said Senator Paul Simon, an Illinois Democrat who ran for President in 1988. "I don't remember putting out phony polls, but we did other things that exaggerated my strength. If some newspaper -- even if it only had 27 circulation -- had a supportive editorial, we'd distribute that."
 (For whatever it's worth, Mr. Simon did not last past the primary in his home state.)
 Although Mr. Dole is far ahead of his rivals in almost every poll where candidates' names are used, he is going all out to remind people of his strength. So he does not have to manufacture good news.
 The others are more desperate.
 Advisers to Gov. Pete Wilson of California, determined to prove that his flagging campaign was coming on strong even before he formally announces his candidacy, called reporters to let them know that he had raised $8 million in pledges. Sounds impressive but there was no way to verify the pledges -- or, more important, that they would turn into cash.
 The campaign of Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, distributed a newsletter that trumpeted "Iowans Warming to Buchanan." Then there was this quote: "I have not seen a Presidential candidate draw such responsive crowds in this part of the state, this early, and from a candidate who has barely visited Iowa." The observer? Guy Rodgers, Mr. Buchanan's campaign manager.
 A favorite tactic is assorted "straw polls" conducted by state parties and local political organizations. Hardly scientific, these polls often have as much to do with how many tables a campaign bought at a fund-raising dinner as anything else.

 
 
This Guy's a Comer!
 After coming in second in a straw poll at a Republican convention in Oklahoma City last month, Alan L. Keyes, a twice-failed candidate for Senate from Maryland, issued a news release. "Only a month into Alan Keyes' campaign for the White House," it said, "his political star is rising fast."
 Mr. Alexander's advisers insist that their polls were far more legitimate than straw polls. But the other campaigns may disagree with the descriptions of the generic candidates proposed by Mr. Alexander's pollster, Whit Ayres. He sums up their ideology as follows:
 Candidate A (Senator Phil Gramm): "He is a staunch conservative who has concentrated on economic issues during his time in Congress, with particular emphasis on cutting spending to balance the Federal budget."
 Candidate B (Mr. Alexander): "He is a conservative who stresses personal responsibility and returning much of the power of the Federal Government to the states."
 Candidate C (Mr. Dole): "He is a conservative who emphasizes balancing the Federal budget, and he is skilled at reaching compromises."
 Candidate D (Mr. Wilson): "He is a moderate on most social and economic issues."
 Of course, Mr. Wilson probably would not describe himself as a moderate. More people would probably describe Mr. Alexander as a moderate than as a conservative. And Mr. Dole might note that he emphasizes returning power to the states.
 Donald L. Fowler, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said such polls are created out of self-interest: "It's like asking: 'If you had somebody who was the combination of John F. Kennedy, Jesus Christ and Moses, would you vote for him?' Well, I'm that person."

HEADLINE: Travel Industry Anticipates Biggest Summer Season Ever

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Spurred by an improving economy, widespread discounts and growing consumer confidence, the travel industry is anticipating America's biggest ever summer vacation season.
Because the industry defines summer as the three and a half months between Memorial Day and Labor Day, the calendar and the summer solstice notwithstanding, Summer 1995 is expected to get off to a roaring start next week when about 29.8 million travelers take advantage of the long Memorial Day weekend to visit relatives or friends, amusement parks or art museums, beaches or baccarat tables. 
 The American Automobile Association and the Air Transport Association have predicted that Memorial Day will mark the beginning of a summer of record crowds on the highways and in the air. By Labor Day, if the projections prove correct, Americans will have taken a record 230 million summer trips of 100 miles or more away from home, an increase of 2 percent over last summer. Moreover, industry officials see signs that for the first time in years, summer vacationers plan to loosen the grip on their wallets.
"Americans will take a break from the thrifty 90's and turn the clock back to the luxury 80's, as high-ticket items will be on many travelers' 'have to have' lists rather than 'wish I had' lists," said William S. Norman, chief executive of the Travel Industry Association of America, a trade group based in Washington.
In keeping with the recent trend toward shorter and more frequent getaways, 58 percent of the travelers surveyed by the association said they were planning more than one vacation this summer.
Among this season's multiple vacationers will be Provvi Panarisi and David Jakubowski, a wife and husband from Queens who find that short vacations fit well with their separate work schedules.
"We're flying to Boston next Saturday and staying through Wednesday, while we explore Cambridge and surrounding areas," said Ms. Panarisi, a sales assistant in New York for Hyatt Hotels and Resorts. "And in July we'll drive to Cape Cod to spend a few days at an inn in Falmouth, then visit Martha's Vineyard."
Tourism should also get a lift this summer from the expected huge influx of Europeans who, after exchanging their strong currency for cheap dollars, will find that prices at hotels, restaurants and just about everywhere else resemble a gigantic fire sale.
And that is good news for Death Valley National Park, which draws almost a million visitors a year.
"Almost all our summer visitors are Europeans," Ann Titus, a spokeswoman for the park, said in an interview by telephone from the park's headquarters in Furnace Creek, Calif. Summer temperatures at the park average 115 degrees, she said, "but last year's high hit 128 degrees -- that's why we don't get more Americans that time of year."
This year, gasoline is 9 cents a gallon higher than last Memorial Day. But the American Automobile Association said that gas prices adjusted for inflation are 3 cents less now than in 1990, and 26 cents less than in 1985.
"This summer a vacationing family of two adults and two children can expect to spend an average of $221.80 per day for meals, lodging and vehicle operating costs," said Graeme Clarke, a senior vice president of the association. "That compares to an inflation-adjusted $245 in 1988."
In two recent industrywide air fare sales, good for summer travel, fares were cut as much as 60 percent and allowed passengers to buy tickets 14 days in advance of travel, rather than the standard 21 days.
Moreover, cruise lines are discounting heavily for summer trips to the Caribbean and to Alaska. And hotel bargains abound, except at the most popular destinations.
The apparent anomaly of dangling discounts before record numbers of summer vacationers is not as bizarre as it may appear, travel industry experts say. It is precisely those discounts that will generate the record number of vacationers, they say. And beyond that, the airline and hotel industries -- despite slowly improving fortunes -- are still so traumatized by huge losses that they fear that higher prices will result in half-empty planes and hotel rooms.
"A strong summer is the key for the industry's financial recovery, but even a good summer like the one we are anticipating is just the start of a long road back to profitability," said Carol Hallett, president of the Air Transport Association. "After five years of losses totaling $13 billion, airlines have had to postpone the delivery of new aircraft and plans for expansion, so passengers should expect planes to be fuller than usual."
On a year-round basis, airlines on average fill about 65 percent of their seats, but Ms. Hallett's association is projecting that the averages will rise to 70 percent or 80 percent on six of the seven days between next Wednesday and May 30. The exception will be Sunday, May 28, when it is expected to fall to 63.2.
For the sixth consecutive year, Orlando, Fla., home of Disney World and Epcot Center, heads the list of most popular summer destinations, according to the automobile association. Next are Myrtle Beach, S.C., a newcomer to the list, having displaced Washington, Grand Canyon National Park, Yellowstone National Park and Williamsburg, Va.
In a poll of the five most popular destinations this summer, compiled by the American Society of Travel Agents, New York City ranked third, behind Orlando and Las Vegas, Nev.
Lucy, the six-story wood-and-tin elephant in Margate, N.J., cannot compete with the major summer vacation attractions, including the gambling casinos in nearby Atlantic City. But the 114-year-old "architectural folly," as it has been called, each summer attracts about 25,000 children and adults, who climb the spiral staircases in Lucy's legs to gaze out her eyes at the Atlantic Ocean.
"Right now we're repairing its howdah -- the seat with a canopy and railing that the maharajahs used for riding on the back of an elephant," said Josephine Harron, president of the volunteers who work with Lucy, which has been designated a National Historic Landmark. "But it'll be fixed in a few weeks, and then Lucy will be ready for what we expect will be a busy summer."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Overlooking the Atlantic Ocean, Lucy, a six-story wood-and-tin elephant in Margate, N.J., a National Historic Landmark several miles south of Atlantic City, attracts 25,000 visitors each summer. (The Press of Atlantic City)

HEADLINE: In Asia, Fears U.S. Bill May Impede Boat People's Return

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 20

 BODY:
Legislation has been proposed in the United States Congress that could result in offers of resettlement to half the 40,000 Vietnamese boat people now facing deportation to Vietnam from camps throughout Asia.
The proposal has alarmed the United Nations and some Asian Governments because it threaten to scuttle an international effort endorsed by the Clinton Administration to send home the last of the Vietnamese in the camps. 
 The plan is contained in a foreign affairs appropriations bill drafted by House Republicans. Although the Administration opposes the measure, it has already been approved by the House International Relations Committee and is awaiting a vote before the full House.
The bill would earmark $30 million for the resettlement of up to 20,000 Vietnamese who have been seeking asylum in the United States, while placing nearly insurmountable obstacles to new American contributions to the United Nations-backed program to return the last of the boat people to Vietnam. The United States has promised to provide about $25 million to the program this year. Prospects for the legislation are uncertain.
Refugee workers say that word of the American plan has already begun circulating in detention camps in Hong Kong, and that some of the Vietnamese who had once agreed to return home voluntarily are reconsidering because of the possibility they may be allowed instead to fulfill their dream of resettlement in the United States.
"Many of these people would be refugees by any fair definition of the word," said Representative Christopher H. Smith, a New Jersey Republican who is a member of the International Relations Committee and a sponsor of the plan. "It is grotesque that we should now be paying to force them back to Vietnam."
Refugee workers say that, even if the bill is rejected by Congress or vetoed by President Clinton, the renewed debate in Washington may have convinced many Vietnamese to resist deportation, as they recognize there is still a powerful constituency willing to fight to let them into the United States.
The people now in the camps are the last of more than a million Vietnamese who fled their homeland, many in rickety boats, after the Communist troops of North Vietnam overran the southern half of the country in April 1975. Most of the so-called boat people ended up in the United States.
If the House plan became law, it would mean a reversal of American policy, which for several years has held that the vast majority of Vietnamese who remain in camps in Asia are economic migrants who have no realistic fear of persecution in Vietnam and who are thus not entitled to asylum.
Although the State Department would not be forced to offer resettlement to 20,000 Vietnamese if the bill became law, the $30 million earmarked for the program could not be spent for any other purpose.
Jahanshah Assadi, the chief of mission in Hong Kong for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, characterized the House proposal as "playing with fire."
"People in the camps are being given false hopes and false expectations," he said.
Mr. Assadi, who oversees detention camps that now hold 21,000 Vietnamese, warned that if word of the American proposal reached Vietnam, it could set off another exodus of people who would see it as a new chance to go to the United States.
"It doesn't take very much to spark that off," he said, noting that nearly 1,000 Vietnamese left the country last year in boats headed for Japan, apparently as a result of unfounded rumors that the Government was offering jobs and cash payments to migrants.
The 40,000 Vietnamese who have not been resettled or returned home have been denied status as political refugees and are waiting to be sent back to Vietnam either voluntarily or by force. In addition to the camps in Hong Kong, there are large camps in Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand.
The House plan has outraged officials in Hong Kong, which has been trying for years to shut the detention camps there by persuading -- or forcing -- the Vietnames to go home. The camps have turned increasingly violent as thousands of Vietnamese there face the prospect of being forced to board airplanes headed for Vietnam.
Just today, 19 Government riot officers in Hong Kong were injured as they battled Vietnamese who were protesting attempts to move them to a different camp. [In a statement early Sunday, officials in Hong Kong put the toll of injured at nearly 200, The Associated Press reported. Most of the injured were riot policemen who were using tear gas to end the demonstration and were attacked with spears and rocks, The A.P. said. The disturbances continued early Sunday.]
On May 11, 47 Hong Kong police and corrections officers were wounded, including two who were stabbed, in a battle with other Vietnamese detainees who were desperate not to return home. At least eight Vietnamese were injured.
The South China Morning Post, the city's largest English-language newspaper, suggested in an editorial on Thursday that the American plan was being offered by politicians "blind to the havoc created on this side of the Pacific by their attempts to expiate that guilt" about the plight of the boat people.
In a statement, Representative Smith contended that many of the Vietnamese now in detention camps had been unfairly denied refugee status because of inadequate screening. He said some camp residents had been "persecuted for anti-Communist political views, for religious practices or for past associations with the United States."
Because of the American involvement in the Vietnam War, he said, "we Americans have a special relationship to people who have managed to escape from Vietnam."
"These are our guys," he said. "We left them behind."
The United Nations, which is responsible for monitoring the condition of the 71,000 Vietnamese who have been returned home, says it has been unable to document a single case in which a returning migrant has faced persecution.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Legislation before the United States Congress could scuttle efforts to send Vietnamese boat people in camps throughout Asia back to Vietnam. At a Hong Kong camp yesterday, police fired tear gas when Vietnamese rioted because of efforts to move them to another camp. The disturbances worsened today. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Medicare Talk Brings Anxiety To Heartland

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: OMAHA, May 19

 BODY:
To Mike Brown, who runs a tiny county health care center about an hour's drive from here, the $250 billion or so in Medicare savings that Congressional Republicans want to achieve over the next seven years is more than an abstract figure in a Washington budget battle.
Like many rural hospitals, his center, Saunders County Health Services, ministers to a population that is largely elderly and exceedingly dependent on Medicare. The health insurance program for the elderly accounts for about 40 percent of hospital revenue nationally but for more than 80 percent of the hospital revenue at the Saunders County center. 
 As a result, Mr. Brown said one cool spring morning this week, he fears that new spending controls on Medicare would have a significant impact on his 30-bed hospital. It lost money last year, hopes to break even this year and has been struggling since the mid-1980's, he said.
In a little burst of feeling amid the dry policy talk, he argues that his center has "real value" for its aging population, often cared for by aging children, for whom the drive to Lincoln or Omaha for regular treatments would loom large.
When planners and politicians talk about potential "disruptions in the health care delivery system" from the new Republican budgets, they are often talking about hospitals like this one. But even in Omaha, in the high-rise temples of medicine that dwarf the one-story Saunders County hospital, the Medicare policies being created in Washington instill anxiety and frustration.
Hospital administrators say that they are not trying to preserve or defend the status quo and that they recognize the need for restructuring the Medicare program. But they say they have already taken numerous steps to control their costs, and they bristle at the idea that there is still a great deal of easily identifiable fat to be quickly wrung from the system. Even here in Omaha, a comparative latecomer to the competitive new world of managed care, hospitals say they have felt increasing cost pressures from private payers.
Given all these forces in play, and the expectation of new constraints on Medicaid at least as tough as those proposed for Medicare, several hospital administrators here said they feared that Congress was moving too far, too fast.
"I'm confident that we can come up with a better system for caring for Medicare patients and doing it in a more economical fashion," said Charles J. Marr, president and chief executive officer of Immanuel Medical Center, a nonprofit hospital sponsored by the Lutheran Church of America. "But they shouldn't throw us into a tailspin and force that change over a short period of time."
John M. Fraser, chief operating officer of Methodist Hospital, across town, noted more than once during an interview that he is a Republican and said both deficit reduction and Medicare overhaul were valid issues. "But you don't do this in six months on Capitol Hill," he added.
Republicans, of course, maintain that extracting these savings from Medicare is essential to insuring the continued solvency of the 30-year-old program. Under their plans, they note, spending on Medicare would continue to grow, just at a slower rate than the current average of about 10 percent a year.
Representative Jon Christensen, a Republican freshman who represents Omaha and who voted for the House Republican budget this week, declined an interview request. But in a statement he defended the plan.
"The simple fact is that Medicare is going bankrupt," he said. "Would it hurt Nebraska's hospitals less to let the Medicare program collapse?"
Many health planners dispute Mr. Christensen's argument that this level of reduction in projected spending is necessary for the sake of the Medicare system. Democrats assert that Republicans are simply using Medicare as a piggy bank to pay for their political promises of a balanced budget and a tax cut.
Nobody yet knows exactly how these spending reductions would be achieved or how much they would affect payments to hospitals; that will be resolved in Congress.
What is clear, away from Washington, is not only how enmeshed Medicare is in the health care system but also how vulnerable that system is to large-scale changes in the program.
Here in Nebraska, state officials say, it is the rural health care system that is most "fragile," as Dr. Mark Horton, the state director of health, put it. Eighteen percent of Nebraska's rural population is over 65; many of the hospitals in rural areas, and many of the primary care physicians there, are extraordinarily dependent on the Medicare program. Tinkering with its complicated reimbursement system, which some hospital officials say already makes it hard for them to recover the cost of rendering care, can thus have a major effect on the overall health system, officials say.
"You could argue that maybe some of these hospitals should close," said Dr. Horton. On the other hand, he added, these small community hospitals are often the most cost-effective places to treat common ailments like pneumonia.
Mr. Brown's center, which also depends on a county levy, includes a small attached nursing home, an outpatient clinic and a home health care agency. Its hospital beds are generally filled with patients suffering from pneumonia and other heart and lung ailments that afflict the aged, he said. There is little flexibility in his budget. "When you don't have any private paying patients to speak of," he said, "there's no place to shift the cost to."
Harlan M. Heald, president of the Nebraska Association of Health Systems, said of the expected round of spending reductions, "The more Medicare patients you have in your mix, the more it's like that old Nebraska farm joke: if you're not making back your costs, you're not going to make it up in volume."
C. Edward Schwartz, chief executive officer of the University of Nebraska Medical Center, works at the opposite end of the spectrum from Mr. Brown. Mr. Schwartz runs an academic medical center that prides itself on its liver, bone-marrow and pancreas transplant programs. Yet he too describes Medicare as "absolutely crucial" to his institution's future, in part because it recognizes and helps subsidize the cost of medical education at such centers.
Mr. Schwartz argues that the people who should be most alarmed about new controls on Medicare are private employers, because hospitals could be driven to renewed cost shifting. "We have to be honest with ourselves," he said, adding, "I thought business was well past the point of wanting to pay the taxes Congress didn't want to collect."
The debate over Medicare, in short, looks decidedly less abstract at the grass roots, a fact that opponents of Republican proposal are counting on in the coming months.
Diana Smalley, chief executive officer of Midlands Community Hospital, a 208-bed center south of Omaha, said she was looking forward to putting together a health forum for Representative Christensen, whom she met at a recent function of the local Chamber of Commerce. As head of the chamber, Mrs. Smalley is more than able to brief her Congressman on the importance of her hospital to the community's economy. It is the largest civilian employer in the county, she noted.
"I'd rather work with him if I can," she said. "I admire, I guess you could say, the zeal that we see to get things done. I just worry about the time frame."

HEADLINE: PATAKI IN ACCORD WITH LAWMAKERS ON TAX-CUT PLAN

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 20

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and the state's legislative leaders have agreed on a three-year plan to cut state income taxes that would give two-thirds of all taxpayers a 25 percent reduction in rates by 1997, state officials disclosed today.
The agreement represents a compromise between the Governor, a Republican, and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat. Mr. Pataki wanted a four-year plan that would have cut rates for everyone by 25 percent. Mr. Silver wanted a less expensive two-year plan that would have given a larger share of the savings to low-income and middle-income New Yorkers. 
 Under the compromise, the greatest benefit would go to those with adjusted gross incomes of $55,000 or less, according to the state officials, who insisted on anonymity. People earning less than $55,000 would see their top tax rates drop by 25 percent by 1997. Those earning more than $55,000 would have their top rates fall by 13 percent.
State officials estimate that a family of four making $50,000 a year and claiming the standard deduction would pay $663 less in taxes for 1997 than for 1994. If the same family made $100,000 and itemized its deductions, its estimated savings would be $868, the officials said.
The tax cut agreement now becomes the driving force behind the budget that ultimately will be enacted in Mr. Pataki's first year and that will represent an uneasy consensus between the Republicans and Democrats who share power in Albany. The tax cut reflects the new priority placed on tax relief after years of unchecked growth in state spending.
The tax cut deal was settled late this week during closed-door budget discussions involving Mr. Pataki, Mr. Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Rensselaer County Republican. The three leaders said on Friday that they hoped to complete their budget negotiations before Memorial Day. This year's impasse -- the fiscal year started on April 1 -- is one of the longest in state history.
In recent weeks, the negotiations on tax cuts became intertwined with talks on Mr. Pataki's proposals for deep reductions in welfare spending. In the end, Mr. Silver, who must satisfy an ideologically diverse group of Democrats, agreed to a deeper tax cut than he wanted. And Mr. Pataki agreed to arrange the tax cut more to Mr. Silver's liking and to drop his demand for the biggest welfare cuts, which would have reduced benefit levels and imposed time limits on payments to able-bodied recipients.
Even so, lawmakers and gubernatorial aides have predicted that the remaining spending cuts will be so severe that many Democrats in the Assembly will vote against the budget. That would force Mr. Silver to seek votes from the Republican minority to pass the budget, which would be extremely rare in Albany.
The state officials who disclosed details about the tax cut agreement said it was firm. But there is always the potential of its falling apart if negotiations on the larger budget agreement break down.
Last week, it became clear that Mr. Pataki and the legislative leaders were nearing the end of their grueling negotiations, which were embittered by high political stakes and intense ideological combat between new players.
The leaders are still discussing how to cut Medicaid, how to finance criminal justice programs and how to pay for athletic stadium construction projects around the state. But they have essentially agreed on most major issues, including a slight increase in financing for schools and cuts that would leave state university students with a tuition increase of about $750 a year. Total state spending, which Mr. Pataki had hoped to reduce by 3.5 percent, would drop by about 1 percent, state officials said.
Mr. Pataki made his promise of a 25 percent tax cut the centerpiece of his 1994 campaign, arguing that a large cut would be essential to New York's economic recovery. The Governor is expected to push for further income tax relief next year.
Despite pressure from more liberal Democrats to resist the tax-cutting fever generated by Mr. Pataki's election, Mr. Silver announced early this year that the Assembly Democrats would also support a reduction. But with the state already facing a budget gap of more than $4 billion, he argued that a tax cut as large as Mr. Pataki's would require unacceptable reductions in spending on education and social programs.
The compromise tax-cut package would cost the state $555 million in revenues in the 1995 tax year, $2.2 billion in 1996 and just over $3.5 billion in 1997, the state officials said. Other state officials said the value of the tax cut in the third year could be as high as $3.8 billion. The income tax is the largest single source of revenue for the state, accounting for $17.6 billion of the state's $33.4 billion general fund budget last year.
Mr. Pataki's original income tax cut proposal would have cost $720 million this year, $2.1 billion in 1996, $4.4 billion in 1997, and $6.8 billion in 1998. Mr. Silver's plan would have cost $720 million in 1995 and $1.7 billion in 1996.
Under the income tax agreement, there would be five income brackets, as now. But the boundaries of those brackets would change, as would the tax rates, meaning that fewer people would pay the top rate and it would be lower.
For instance, the top tax rate, currently 7.875 percent for married filers with taxable incomes of $26,000 and above and single filers with incomes of $13,000 and above, would be reduced gradually to 7.59375 percent for 1995, 7.125 percent for 1996 and 6.85 percent for 1997. The top bracket would be changed to include only married filers making $40,000 and above and single filers making $20,000 and above.
The Governor and legislative leaders have also agreed to the broad outlines of a plan that would require recipients of Home Relief, the welfare program for childless, able-bodied adults, to work off their benefits in jobs with government or nonprofit agencies. If they miss work once without a legitimate excuse, their benefits would be suspended for 90 days. A second absence would bring a 150-day suspension. A third violation would mean a 180-day cutoff.
While Mr. Pataki apparently will win his demand for workfare, he failed to persuade the Assembly Democrats to reduce benefit levels for welfare recipients and to limit payments to those recipients to 60 days.
But the welfare agreement will apparently include a requirement that recipients keep their children in school or face a loss of some benefits. The sanctions would take effect after a student is truant three times in one quarter and would apply to students through the sixth grade.
Other welfare changes would tighten eligibility screening, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has done in New York City, and strengthen fraud detection. Electronic fingerprinting of welfare applicants, an anti-fraud measure, would become mandatory in all counties.
Youngsters under 18 who are on welfare would be required to live at home rather than in their own households, unless they could demonstrate a well-founded fear of abuse. New residents of the state would be limited to the welfare benefits paid in their former states for the first six months they live in New York.
While they are still discussing details of Medicaid cuts, the leaders have agreed to reduce the $1.2 billion reduction proposed by Mr. Pataki to a cut of $500 million to $700 million, state officials said.
The leaders have also agreed to use Urban Development Corporation bonding to buy two New York City jails that primarily house state inmates, giving Mr. Giuliani a $120 million infusion for his budget. In light of the state's deep financial problems, resistance has dropped to a "Quick Draw" video lottery game expected to raise about $100 million.
In addition to the income tax cut, the leaders have also agreed, according to state officials, to enact $50 million worth of cuts in business taxes. Legislative aides said the business taxes would grow to $170 million in 1996 and to $250 million to $300 million in 1997.
They have yet to make final decisions on which business taxes will be cut and by how much. But container taxes on soda and beer would probably be cut in half; the petroleum business tax would be reduced for trucks, airplanes and nonprofit organizations; the estate tax would be exempted for homes worth up to $250,000, and the parimutuel tax would be cut. Still under consideration are cuts in taxes on sales of real estate for more than $1 million, and on utilities.
The leaders have also agreed to Mr. Pataki's proposal to accelerate the phased enactment of the state's earned income tax credit for the working poor, which was first approved last year. Under the new plan, the state credit would jump from 10 percent of the Federal Government's credit this year to 20 percent in 1996, rather than 10 percent this year to 15 percent in 1996 and 20 percent in 1997.

HEADLINE: Strapped for Money, Washington Suffers Indignities and Insults

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
A financial crisis is one thing. No toilet paper is quite another.
While the Clinton Administration prepares to name a control board to oversee the District of Columbia's finances, an action expected next week, and Republican members of Congress continue studying how to improve city agencies, local residents are enduring the effects of the District's $722 million budget deficit in ways large, small and annoying. 
 Garbage pickups have been reduced. City employees have been forced to take furloughs and pay cuts. The housing authority has been placed in receivership. And now, with insufficient funds to pay city vendors, restrooms in municipal buildings have no toilet paper.
"Can you imagine the nation's capital, there's all kinds of jokes flying around," Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. said this week.
Mr. Barry expressed all due embarrassment but quickly blamed the City Council for cutting the $28 million budget of the Department of Administrative Services to $10.7 million. He vetoed the cut, but the Council overrode his veto.
The city owes more than $30 million to about 500 vendors, and it owes $1.25 million alone to the CPF Corporation, which cleans and maintains 34 municipal buildings. This week the company drew the line. Its crews cleaned restrooms in the buildings but stopped restocking toilet paper. That sent several managers scurrying to nearby drug stores to buy supplies, and some municipal workers began bringing their own.
"Look, we're slow pay, and we're going to be until we come out of this," Johnny Allem, a spokesman for Mr. Barry, said today. "Out of nowhere, the Council cut our budget on this after the city spent $28 million every year for these expenses. We've long since exceeded $10 million in spending this year."
Critics of the city's administration said that the toilet paper shortage was an appropriate symbol for a city going down a fiscal drain and strongly reflects the reasons Congress passed legislation to create an oversight board.
The five-member panel to be appointed by President Clinton will have final say over all financial operations of the city, which grew worse through the administration of Mr. Barry's predecessor, Sharon Pratt Kelly.
In addition, Speaker Newt Gingrich has asked several of his Republican colleagues to examine city agencies and recommend changes to make them more efficient.
Mr. Barry, who blames Mrs. Kelly for the debts and inefficiencies he inherited, said he welcomed their suggestions as long as lawmakers solicit ideas from residents before making any final pronouncements.
Using the city's beleaguered schools as an example, he said: "Gingrich knows the D.C. education system needs reform. I know it needs reform. The question is how are we going to do it?"
Mr. Barry has tried to weather the storm stoically, proclaiming the worst of the crisis has passed and things are under control.
Even with his wife, Cora Masters Barry, under investigation by local and Federal authorities over accusations that she helped divert campaign funds last year, Mr. Barry felt comfortable enough with the city's predicament to spend 10 days this month touring West Africa, ostensibly to drum up tourism and business interest for Washington.
One Ivory Coast village, Sikensi, was so honored to have Mr. Barry and his wife visit that village leaders crowned them King Yede and Queen Hypo and gave them an acre of land.
Then, they asked Mr. Barry for $130,000 to build a new town hall.

HEADLINE: How the Clinton Administration Reversed U.S. Policy on Cuban Refugees

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
It took just over a month for a small group of top Clinton Administration officials to overturn 30 years of American policy toward Cuba.
The process started when Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, went to the Oval Office one Friday afternoon in late March to deliver a warning. He told President Clinton of the rage building among the thousands of Cubans detained at the Guantanamo Bay naval base -- a warning that the general in charge of the region was starting to send up the Pentagon chain of command. 
 "I told the President there was an increasingly unsustainable situation at the Guantanamo camp," Senator Graham said.
Two weeks earlier, he had visited the refugees, who were being detained indefinitely after setting sail last August. "It couldn't last through the summer without the strong potential of a riot," he said.
The process ended in a series of secret meetings between a top State Department official and a confidant of President Fidel Castro in a New York bar and a Toronto hotel -- meetings that culminated in a deal, announced on May 2, that the Administration called a breakthrough and that many Cuban-Americans have called a betrayal.
The deal had two prongs. First, President Clinton decided to admit the 21,000 Cubans at Guantanamo, brushing aside a vow never to allow them on American shores.
The second prong was an even more stunning reversal: Cubans picked up at sea would be returned to their Communist-ruled island, scrapping the 35-year-old policy against sending intercepted boat people back to Cuba.
The new policy came under heavy attack at a House subcommittee hearing on Thursday when Democratic lawmakers joined their Republican counterparts and Cuban-American leaders to denounce the policy reversal as well as the secrecy with which it was made. The Administration fears a similar assault at a Senate hearing on Cuba scheduled in the coming week.
For a foreign policy team known for leaks, indecisiveness and delays, the policy shift was uncharacteristic. It was made swiftly, secretly and with a willingness to offend powerful constituent groups that it had long courted. And, because the matter was so explosive, it was handled by an unusually small group of advisers, leaving out those who were likely to object.
Even so, interviews with Administration officials, members of Congress and Florida officials indicate that the process in a larger sense was characteristic of an Administration in which foreign policy has often been made more in response to pressing, practical problems than on the basis of longer-term strategies or strongly held beliefs.
Moreover, in this case the new Cuba policy was a practical fix to the problems created by an earlier practical fix. When the Administration last August sought to deter Cuban refugees by sending them to Guantanamo, it abandoned a three-decade practice of granting asylum to most Cubans who flee their homeland for the United States. It was warned that sooner or later it would face this quandary: if they can't stay in Guantanamo forever, where will they go?
Senator Graham hammered that point home to Mr. Clinton at the very time that Gen. John J. Sheehan, chief of the Atlantic Command, was starting to warn the Pentagon that Guantanamo was turning into a tinderbox.
"It was not a long-term solution to leave 15 or 20 thousand migrants permanently in the camp at Guantanamo," General Sheehan said in an interview. "Civil disturbance was clearly an option."
Mr. Graham and General Sheehan made the same recommendation: the more than 20,000 Cubans there should be admitted to the United States.
But it was clear to all that this solution could create another explosive problem. As soon as the Guantanamo detainees were allowed into the country in large numbers, many of the 11 million people in Cuba might be encouraged to set to sea, confident that they, too, would be taken to a haven in Guantanamo and then ultimately to Florida.
This was the same pressure that had forced the decision last summer to vow never to admit that wave of refugees.
One of the last things the White House wants is a new tidal wave of Cuban boat people, least of all as the 1996 Presidential campaign heats up, because it could cripple Mr. Clinton's already troubled prospects in Florida, a key state.
After meeting with Senator Graham, the President handed the problem to his national security advisers. Samuel R. Berger, the deputy national security adviser, became the point man, and he brought in just two other officials to work on the issue with him: Morton H. Halperin, a senior aide, and Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff.
By early April, Administration officials say, Mr. Berger, Mr. Halperin and Mr. Tarnoff agreed that the Cubans at Guantanamo should be allowed in.
But the only outsiders they consulted, Senator Graham and Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida, also a Democrat, warned of political complications: Floridians might hold it against Mr. Clinton in 1996 if the Guantanamo Cubans were seen as another tidal wave of immigrants.
To get around this, they suggested that the Guantanamo Cubans be included as part of a quota of 20,000 Cubans allowed in each year, and not added on top of it. Last September the Administration agreed to that quota as part of a deal to persuade Havana to stop the exodus of boat people the month before.
Persuading Mr. Castro to include them as part of the 20,000 quota might be hard, the Administration feared, because he treated that quota as a safety valve for pushing out dissidents.
Complicating matters, Governor Chiles opposed admitting the Guantanamo Cubans unless there was a muscular interdiction policy.
So the President's advisers sifted through four options: allow future Cuban boat people into the United States, send them to third countries, hold them in Guantanamo or return them to Cuba.
Admitting future boat people was rejected because it would lead to a new exodus, while sending them to third countries was dismissed in light of the Administration's past difficulties in getting other countries to take Cubans. And sending future boat people to Guantanamo was ruled out because it would create the very problem the Administration was wrestling with.
"There was a consensus right away," one official said. Consensus was made easy because the policy review excluded officials who were likely to object. Also left out were Cuban-American leaders like Jorge Mas Canosa, chairman of the powerful Cuban-American National Foundation, whom the Administration consulted in the crisis last August.
"We wanted to keep this to a very small circle," a senior official said. The fear was that if such an explosive policy change leaked out, it would be derailed.
In mid-April, President Clinton approved the two-pronged plan to empty Guantanamo and return Cubans.
On April 17, Mr. Tarnoff flew to New York, ostensibly for a conference on the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. But the main reason was to present the Administration's proposal secretly to Ricardo Alarcon, the longtime diplomat and Castro confidant who heads Cuba's Parliament.
That evening Mr. Tarnoff met the Cuban over drinks in a hotel bar near the United Nations. "He was interested but guarded," a senior Administration official said. "He had to report back to Havana."
Mr. Alarcon complained about the three-decade-old trade embargo, and a Republican-sponsored bill to tighten it, but Mr. Tarnoff said he was there to discuss just one thing: immigration. To the Cuban-American groups that learned of the talks later, Washington's willingness to hold such high-level talks was a dangerous step toward "normalization."
The next day, Mr. Alarcon met at the United States Mission to the United Nations with Dennis Hays, the State Department's coordinator of Cuban affairs, for previously scheduled talks about carrying out last September's immigration agreement. Mr. Hays, a hard-liner who has opposed cooperating with Mr. Castro, was left in the dark about the high-stakes talks the night before.
Although it was hard to predict Mr. Castro's response, the Administration believed that it was pushing on an open door. Havana had never hid its unhappiness about the more than 20,000 anti-Castro Cubans in Guantanamo -- if unrest exploded there, it could sow disorder elsewhere on the island.
The American proposal was attractive to Cuba in another way: normalizing immigration policy could stimulate investment, since it could give foreigners the impression that normalized economic relations might soon follow.
The way Americans saw it, as the price for the benefits of the accord, Cuba would agree to let the Guantanamo Cubans be counted among the 60,000 Cubans to be admitted over three years under the quota system.
After Mr. Alarcon consulted in Havana for a week, he called Mr. Tarnoff to say the Cuban Government liked the proposals. He urged Mr. Tarnoff to meet him in Toronto the weekend of April 29 and 30. Negotiating in a hotel suite there, they pieced together an accord.
Late that Sunday, they returned to their capitals to show the agreement to their superiors. After a few small adjustments were made, the two men talked on the telephone at noon on Monday. They had a deal.
Even though the policy shift has flopped with Cuban-Americans in Miami, Administration officials say they believe that it will be a political plus because most Floridians want firmer controls on immigration.
"Florida's two leading politicians told us that most Floridians would accept this without much of a problem," a senior official said. "So far that seems to be the case."
