HEADLINE: Imperiled Agencies Mount Life-Saving Efforts

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
Republicans often portray Federal agencies as slothful, lethargic, unresponsive. But many agencies have snapped into action in the last two weeks, galvanized by Republican plans to end their existence or cut their budgets.
The agencies on the Republican hit list are mobilizing supporters and deploying their troops on Capitol Hill, pleading with Congress to spare them. Among them are the Departments of Energy, Commerce and Education, the Voice of America, the Agency for International Development and the National Endowment for the Arts. 
 Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary told Congress this week that her agency was needed to guarantee civilian control of nuclear weapons, and she said that computers built to design such weapons now had myriad civilian uses, at textile factories and in other industries.
Clifton R. Gaus, head of the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, an arm of the Public Health Service with 270 employees and a budget of $163 million this year, argued that his agency actually saved money for the Government by controlling health costs. Guidelines developed by the agency had shown that cataract surgery, prostate surgery and back surgery are often unnecessary, he said.
His message to Congress was simple: "We are not part of the problem. We are part of the solution to Medicare's budget problems."
The House budget resolution would eliminate the health policy agency. The Senate would cut its budget by 75 percent, on the ground that its work could be "more appropriately performed by the private sector."
The Agency for International Development has infuriated some Republicans with the intensity of its lobbying. Somehow the Republicans obtained a copy of an internal memorandum in which a top Agency for International Development official described the Administration's strategy: "delay, postpone, obfuscate, derail" the Republican plan. It also used the phrase "backdoor isolationist" to describe lawmakers who want to cut foreign aid.
The Administration is fiercely resisting Congressional efforts to merge the Agency for International Development, the United States Information Agency and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency into the State Department, saying that the agencies should retain a large degree of independence.
Officials from these agencies have fanned out across Capitol Hill to spread their message, and Jay Byrne, a spokesman for A.I.D., said his agency had begun "an intensive public outreach and information campaign."
At a recent hearing of the Committee on International Relations, Representative Dana Rohrabacher, Republican of California, asked people in the room who actually worked for the affected agencies to stand up. More than three-fourths of the 200 people in the audience rose, the Congressman recalled.
"Usually, you have outside interest groups swarming around," Mr. Rohrabacher said in an interview. "But today you have as many people from inside the Government as from outside the Government lobbying Congress. It's like a big battlefield. Republican forces are on the offensive, and you have all these Government bureaucrats fortifying the high ground to beat back the attack."
Senator Craig Thomas, Republican of Wyoming, said he was incensed by the attitude of Agency for International Development officials. "Instead of looking for ways to work with members of Congress to streamline its operations, cut waste and bloating, and accept the downsizing that the American people expect of every other agency of the Federal Government," Mr. Thomas said, "A.I.D. has taken on, as its first priority, saving its own skin."
J. Brian Atwood, administrator of the Agency for International Development, said, "I am not intimidated by those who would prefer that I keep my mouth shut." And he insisted that members of Congress trying to cut the foreign affairs budget were "leading us to isolationism through the back door."
To fend off budget-cutters, the agency highlights its efforts to combat the deadly Ebola virus in Zaire; the agency is coordinating the United States response to the health crisis.
And the agency says the budget cuts contemplated by Congress would have "truly horrific" results: fewer children immunized, fewer condoms distributed, more unsafe abortions and more cases of AIDS around the world.
Some agencies on the chopping block are old, like the Interstate Commerce Commission, created in 1887 to regulate railroads. Others are newcomers like the Corporation for National Service, created in 1993 to run the volunteer program known as Americorps.
The House and Senate Budget Committees both recommend abolishing Americorps, with its budget of $575 million. This is a slap at President Clinton, who proposed increasing the number of volunteers to 47,000 from the current 20,000.
Americorps officials said they had little hope of changing the budget resolutions. But they are pleading with friends and supporters on the Appropriations Committees, which could provide money for Americorps if they made deeper cuts at other agencies. Americorps has invited members of Congress to visit its volunteers at work in elementary schools and homeless shelters around the country.
"To eliminate this agency would be tragic, like killing a puppy," said Jay Toscano, a spokesman for Americorps. "The Republicans should use this agency as a model, not a target."
Some agencies threatened with extinction, like the Legal Services Corporation and the Education Department, have overcome similar threats in the past. But some, like the National Institutes of Health, which have enjoyed strong bipartisan support, now face significant budget cuts for the first time.

HEADLINE: The Fresh Aid Fund;
'Shadowing' the Music Professionals

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Yahaira Vargas was looking forward to working with Mariah Carey again.
"She's like a little kid, but as an adult," said Yahaira, who is 13, as she and six other youngsters waited for Ms. Carey, the pop singer, to emerge from the studio where she was recording a new album. Just then, she burst into the waiting room and began a raid on the group's McDonald's Happy Meals. 
 "You guys don't want those prizes?" Ms. Carey asked. "Can I have them?"
Aside from that, Ms. Carey, who at the age of 25 has already sold more than 55 million records, was all business at a "job shadowing" event organized by the Fresh Air Fund. The children, music-minded seventh and eighth graders from all over New York City, had come to the Hit Factory on 54th Street in Manhattan to learn about the recording industry by shadowing professionals on the job.
Ms. Carey is a special friend to the fund. Last year, she donated $1 million to the fund for a career awareness camp in Fishkill, N.Y., which is now named for her. The seven youngsters are among the 2,900 economically disadvantaged New York City children who will attend Fresh Air camps this summer. Yahaira, a South Bronx resident, and several others were returning to Camp Mariah for a second year.
Ms. Carey, wearing dark glasses and black nail polish and redolent of strawberry chewing gum, ushered her young charges into a control room lined with a Star Trek-like array of sleek black gizmos, buttons and lights.
First she let them grill her producer, Jermaine Dupri, a 23-year-old who produced his first record at 14 and now boasts a hit rap record, "Funkdafied," by Da Brat, and his own label, So So Def.
"What's your greatest pleasure in your job?" asked Sonseray Cummings, 13.
"Seeing a group that I create from scratch grow into something that everybody knows," Mr. Dupri replied.
"What's your ambition?" someone else asked.
"I want to write big songs that stay around," Mr. Dupri said. "Maybe one of you all will do them over someday."
Then Ms. Carey introduced her engineer, Jay Healy, commander of the 72-track console. Mr. Healy punched a command into his computer and 72 volume controls slid up and down in a neatly choreographed dance.
Mr. Healy, who broke into the business answering phones at the Hit Factory 12 years ago, added, "There are schools and colleges and programs you can go to, but there's no substitute for working on the board."
The theme, as at fund job shadowings in law offices, restaurants, hospitals and other work places, was to emphasize that in any field there are many kinds of jobs.
"Kids today know about poor people and they know about doctors and lawyers and stars, but they don't know too much about the vast middle," said Jenny Morgenthau, executive director of the Fresh Air Fund. "In music, you can be the technician, the marketer, the makeup person, the receptionist."
Finally it was time to get to work. Ms. Carey led the youngsters into the recording studio, a dramatically lighted wood-paneled room the size of a school gym but with considerably better acoustics. She handed out headphones and had them sing a chorus of "Hero," one of her biggest hits and a song she said she wrote with young people in mind.
Everyone knew the words. "When you feel like hope is gone," they sang, "look inside you and be strong. And you'll finally see the truth, that the hero lies in you."
After seven takes, some really loud and some just whispering, Ms. Carey invited the children back into the control room. Mr. Healy hit a switch and a 49-voice children's chorus swelled into being, rich voices filled with emotion and deft imitations of Ms. Carey's trademark swoops and glides.
"I'm going to keep that one," Ms. Carey said. "I might use it someday." She had the kids record a new outgoing message on her answering machine and bade them farewell.
Back in the waiting room, everyone was raving. Aurelius Mayfield, a gangly 12-year-old choirboy from Coney Island in a Camp Mariah sweatshirt, was just about speechless.
"That was so . . . wonderful!" he said. "She's so wonderful, she's just wonderful, and she's nice and so pretty and the way she sings is just wonderful."
Andrae Mitchell, a pint-sized aspiring talk-show host from East New York, was considerably more composed.
"You know," he said, "People think artists are tired after doing all this work for everybody, and that they're so hard, but if you just sit down and talk to them one on one without the middleman, everything goes easy."
Lisa Watson, the Fresh Air Fund's career awareness director, reminded the young people that Ms. Carey had a good reason to be in such a good mood.
"She was having a good time because she was in her element, doing what makes her happy," Ms. Watson said. "Everyone should pursue careers that make them happy. You should follow your heart, no matter what people tell you."
It costs $912 to send a child to Fresh Air camp. Tax-deductible contributions may be sent to the Fresh Air Fund, 1040 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10018. People wishing to volunteer for the fund's camping and career awareness programs may call (212) 221-0900.

With Mariah Carey in the recording room were Andrae Mitchell, at left; Sonseray Cummings, at the microphone, and Cherie-Nicole Dennis. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Votes in Congress

 BODY:
Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
 
House
 
1. Clean Water: Vote on a bill revising the Clean Water Act that would give more authority to the states and more weight to economic considerations when water quality standards are set. Approved 240 to 185, May 16.
 
2. Budget: Vote on an alternative budget proposal backed by conservative Democrats that would eliminate the tax cuts proposed in a Republican plan and would ease reductions in Medicare, agriculture and other programs. Rejected 325 to 100, May 18.
 
3. Budget: Vote on a Republican-sponsored budget blueprint intended to reduce future spending by $1.5 trillion and cut taxes by some $350 billion. Approved 238 to 193, May 18.
 
4. Spending Cuts: Vote on a House-Senate compromise bill that would cut $16.5 billion in spending from the current year's budget and allot money for for disaster relief in California and Oklahoma City. Approved 235 to 189, May 18.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Japan, a Frog and a Pail

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
After the U.S. imposed trade sanctions on Japan last week, I found myself thinking back to that old science class experiment where the teacher puts a frog in a pail of water on the stove and gradually turns up the heat. The frog, which is very good at adapting, adjusts to each new level of heat. Eventually, though, the frog boils to death, because it is so good at adapting it never thinks to jump out of the pail.
 The Japanese have become so good at adapting to trade threats and the ever-rising value of the yen that instead of doing what a normal country would do -- jump out of the pail by opening its economy -- the Japanese simply keep the foreigners out and adapt to the consequences. They just tighten their belts another notch, sacrifice some profits and move their factories to lower-cost labor markets around Asia. 
 But with the U.S. having just slapped a 100 percent tariff on Japanese luxury cars and, more importantly, with the yen having soared in value by 20 percent this past year, making everything Japan sells here 20 percent more expensive, what will Japan do now? Jump, adapt or finally boil into stagnation?
 My guess is that Japan will try to adapt again, and not open its markets. The Japanese Government is too weak to take the tough steps to deregulate its economy, and its instinct for adapting to foreign pressures is too deeply ingrained. That's why President Clinton was right to raise the stakes to a boil. The President's only option is to create so much pain for Japanese manufacturers -- and so much pleasure for Japanese consumers, by weakening the dollar and making U.S. goods temptingly cheap to buy -- that instead of trying to adapt, they will finally work to remove Japan's trade barriers.
 I hope Mr. Clinton has the stomach to keep the heat on, because here's how I think Japan will initially respond: Japanese businesses will use the strong yen to buy, at bargain-basement prices, more and more factories in cheap labor markets around Asia. This will lower their production costs and nullify the effects of the higher yen on their exports. Sure, Japanese companies may have to eat some losses this quarter. But Japan, unlike America, doesn't worry about quarterly profits. It worries about quarter-century profits, and in a quarter century, with the yen having such buying power, Japan will own every other factory from southern China to Burma. So the U.S. can bar all Japan's exports, and Japan will just slip them in through these other markets.
 True, this will mean fewer jobs in Japan, and a hollowing out of its economy, and that in itself will force Japan to import more from abroad. But the Japanese aren't just going to sit back and live off their investments in Asia. If history is any guide, they will also adapt by finding more efficient ways to produce in the industries they do keep at home. With the strong yen forcing them to streamline in order to stay competitive, Japanese companies will move even faster into the knowledge-intensive, high-wage, high-skilled economy of tomorrow that the U.S. still dreams of.
 No, no, say the classical economists. This time Japan won't be able to adapt. This time they jump or boil. Oh? That's what they said when oil prices quadrupled in the 1970's, but Japan adapted. That's what they said when the yen rose by 50 percent in the 1980's, but Japan adapted. Only a fool would bet against them trying to adapt again, while opening their markets as little as possible.
 Unless one thing happens: Japanese consumers decide they are tired of tightening their belts, living in houses the size of a walk-in closet and being the world's richest country and poorest people. That would be nice, but history also teaches that there is a deep cultural tradition in Japan, shared even by many Japanese consumers, that consumer welfare must always give way to the national welfare, and the national welfare is to win the 100-year trade war, not the battle of 1995.
 But hey, if you think this time Japan can't adapt and will open instead, then buy Ford Motor stock; they make a hot little right-hand-drive Mustang for the Japan market. If you think Japan can adapt, without opening much, then buy the yen. That's the bet. The structure of U.S.-Japan competition in the 21st century is riding on the outcome.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

LENGTH: 711 words

HEADLINE: Journal;
The Unkindest Cut

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
High up on any list of ain't-broke, don't-fix-'em institutions is America's huge web of universities. As Vartan Gregorian, the president of Brown, puts it: "As many as three-quarters of the best universities in the world are located in the United States. What sector of our economy or society can make a similar claim?"
 But Dr. Gregorian -- in a powerful, post-election speech to the National Press Club in Washington last fall and in a phone conversation last week -- now feels he must campaign for the American university's survival, and fast. Why? The Republican budget plans sailing through the 104th Congress would end a 50-year government-university partnership that has made our country's higher education the best. 
 For all the talk about funding cutbacks in student loans, surprisingly little attention has been paid to how the G.O.P. budget will damage the educational institutions themselves. Now reality is setting in. As Harvey Fineberg, the dean of Harvard's School of Public Health, said in an interview last week: "We thought the case was so self-evident we didn't think the cutbacks were actually going to happen. Now that the proposals have come forward, people are just dumbstruck."
 The G.O.P. assault on higher education began not as a budget-balancing strategy but as an ideological campaign in this winter's Congressional hearings on the National Endowment for the Humanities. Arguing that the N.E.H. should be abolished, representatives of right-wing think tanks led by William Bennett and Lynne Cheney condemned universities en masse as subversive hotbeds of political correctness.
 Are there indeed the radical feminists and multiculturalists that Mr. Bennett decries on campus? Of course. Do some of them get N.E.H. grants? Yes -- and why not, given that they're Americans too? But the Bennett-Cheney characterization of academia was an indiscriminate smear, as was their description of the N.E.H. The endowment's typical (and largest) grants go not for Marxist deconstructions of "I Love Lucy" but to underwrite Euripides translations (University of Virginia), or edit the papers of Andrew Johnson (University of Tennessee), or assist an archeological dig (University of Wyoming).
 Just the same, the Bennett-Cheney strategy did the deed; under the House budget proposal, the N.E.H. will be killed.
 With respect for our universities so low in the new Congress, it was inevitable that no one would think twice about axing the Federal contribution to academic science research as well. One example: The proposed cuts at the National Institutes of Health alone will radically alter the nation's medical schools, given that roughly 16 percent of their income derives from Federal research grants, mainly from the N.I.H.
 In practical terms, Dr. Fineberg explains, this is "like eating the seed corn." Fewer grants will slow scientific breakthroughs in disease prevention and cure, which from the Salk vaccine to recent advances in breast cancer have mostly happened at American universities. With less research come fewer opportunities to nurture new researchers. "We will destroy the future by turning a generation of would-be scientists away," Dr. Fineberg says.
 Ask G.O.P. leaders how universities will replace Federal funding, and the mantra-like answer is "privatization." But lately industry has paid for only 7 percent of academic scientific research and development, compared with the Federal Government's 57 percent. "Anyone who dreams these cuts will be replaced though private philanthropy or industry is fooling himself," says Dr. Fineberg. The research that might unlock the genetic origins of a disease, after all, does not immediately produce a product industry can sell.
 Just as bleak are prospects for privatization in the humanities. Richard Ekman of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation has calculated that the N.E.H., tiny as it is, gives three times as much to the humanities as all the private foundations in America combined -- which makes it "highly unlikely" that those foundations can even begin to replace the endowment's support of university scholarship. If it's dumb and dumber this country wants, it couldn't find a more foolproof scenario than the one now being drafted on Capitol Hill.

HEADLINE: Forever In Debt

BYLINE: By Paul Johnson; Paul Johnson, author, most recently, of "Modern Times: The World From the Twenties to the Nineties," is at work on a new book, "A History of the United States People."

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
The U.S. national debt is $4.7 trillion and increasing by $38,158 every four seconds, as a clock posted in the House Budget Committee hearing room reminds us. On Thursday, the House approved a proposal to balance the budget by the year 2002; the Senate is scheduled to vote on its own plan this week. But whatever compromise plan emerges, even if made law, will not necessarily balance the budget: it will only set spending goals. Congress can ignore those goals just as it did those set by the deficit-reduction bills passed in the mid-1980's.
 Meanwhile, the debt mounts, and no one, it seems, has a long-term proposal to get rid of it altogether. The burden the country will almost certainly lay on the shoulders of its children in the 21st century is disgraceful. 
 Americans are historically hard-working and provident, and rightly proud that they live in the world's most powerful democracy and its oldest republic. So how did they get into this mess?
 It is comparatively recent. The United States has a long record of sound public finance, ever since Alexander Hamilton took over the Treasury in 1789 and introduced fiscal realism, balancing the budget for the first time. In 1835, President Andrew Jackson actually contrived to eliminate the debt altogether. Thereafter the debt fluctuated, as is reasonable, according to the emergencies through which the nation passed. The Civil War, World War I, the Great Depression and World War II all led to large-scale increases in the public debt. But the calms that followed these storms all saw it systematically reduced. During the last period of debt reduction, 1946 to 1975, it was cut by half.
 Then an odd and sinister thing happened. Without any emergency or world war or even a deep recession, the debt began to rise. At the beginning of Ronald Reagan's Presidency, it had reached $914 billion; on his retirement, it was $3 trillion. Today, of course, the debt is closing in on $5 trillion, so it is not surprising that the dollar is at a historic low against the yen and the German mark. Indeed, it could be argued that the dollar's reputation is more fragile now than at any time since the 1780's.
 The reasons are not far to seek: huge increases in Government employees (well over 20 percent of the work force) and in unfunded long-term liabilities (over $15 trillion), and, not least, a colossal commitment to transfer payments ($300 billion for poverty relief alone this year).
 The United States is running the most costly welfare state in history, as well as acting -- reluctantly and not consistently but certainly expensively -- as the world's policeman.
 Even to eliminate the deficit, let alone reduce the debt, Federal spending will have to be fundamentally reformed. This will mean, among other things, ending the welfare state as it exists today. It may not be as hard as some people think -- after all, it is scarcely a generation old.
 But if at the same time taxes are also to be reduced -- at between 35 and 40 percent of personal income they are a real brake on economic dynamism -- then the cuts must be not only deep but ubiquitous. The Government must go from being a prodigal to a frugal -- better yet, a stingy -- spender.

That is by no means impossible. If Congress wants to know how a Scrooge-like mentality operates, it need only study almost any Treasury correspondence dating from 1815 to 1860. For the reform to become reality, however, there are three political prerequisites.
 The first is sufficient Congressional support. That has already been achieved. For the first time in 40 years -- longer than the U.S. welfare state has existed in fully developed form -- the Scrooges have taken over from the Micawbers. There appears to be a majority in both the House and Senate for some sort of balanced-budget strategy, and the momentum for reform appears to be growing.
 The second prerequisite is a popular consensus. Every sign indicates that there is one. The nation appears to be in the mood to do the right thing, even if it means sacrifices. Public opinion surveys, including a New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted in April, all seem to indicate a new spirit of fiscal rectitude among ordinary people. When asked to choose between a tax cut and balancing the budget, a majority chose the budget.
 Congress is ready for reform; so are the people. But history shows that neither means much without a dedicated leader.
 Normally one would expect such leadership to come from the President. In the past, the White House has shown a much greater concern for financial probity than Capitol Hill. When Congress passed Mr. Clinton's deficit-reduction package during his first year in office, it did so with hardly a vote to spare in both houses.
 But Mr. Clinton is not a leader, though he can sometimes be persuaded that it is in his interest to be an energetic follower. No. Leadership will have to come from the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich.
 Here is Mr. Gingrich's opportunity to transform himself from a successful gadfly into a political heavyweight. It may be necessary for him to bite the bullet and give up his cherished plan for tax cuts, at any rate for the moment, as the Senate has done. In any event, he should take up the challenge and lead the movement to transform America into a model of frugality.
 Certainly the world needs such an example. All over the third world, progress is held back by the unwillingness of governments to balance their books, even under direct pressure from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The ascent of the former Communist world to freedom and prosperity is imperiled by precisely the same vice.
 Even in Europe, which ought to know better, a dozen governments are piling up deficits and debts for fear of voters who in fact are desperate for thrifty leaders. The United States would add immeasurably to the moral debt the world already owes it if Washington could take the lead in bringing us all back to good old-fashioned providence.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

BANKRUPTCIES
Implant Mess: What Is Real?
Dow Corning filed for bankruptcy protection last week, swamped by lawsuits over breast implants. But the odd thing about this multibillion-dollar mess is that there is considerable doubt about whether the implants are actually harmful. Scientific doubt, that is. The legal system seems convinced that implants cause a variety of maladies, but a number of scientific studies balk at that -- finding that the diseases are real, but the cause not established. The bankruptcy is real, though, halting all new lawsuits and delaying settlement of existing ones -- for at least two years and probably longer. And the company's owners, Dow Chemical and Corning, will no doubt see their investments go to women's claims.
 
TOBACCO
Smoke, but Fire Next Year
That huge class-action suit against the tobacco companies will have to wait. A big group of lawyers in New Orleans was going full speed ahead in its attempt to show, among other things, that cigarette makers concealed knowledge that nicotine is addictive. And they had plans to notify -- through nationwide ads -- up to 90 million smokers that they were part of the class. But last week the judge allowed an appeal now -- on whether the class should be certified. The bad news for the lawyers is that this means a delay of six months to a year -- just when they had their engines running. But one lawyer saw a silver lining -- that they could get the certification question cleared up now, before spending vast sums on the case.
 
PUBLISHING
Words, Words, Words for Sale
The Encyclopaedia Britannica was first published in 1768, before the existence of the United States -- or, yes, even Microsoft -- and is still going. But not surprisingly -- at a time when many homes have more computers than books -- sales are dropping, from 117,000 sets in 1990 to 51,000 last year. Then again, look at it this way: even in the age of the CD-ROM, fully 51,000 people and libraries shelled out $1,500 for the 32 volumes of this ultimate reference work. But that's not enough, and Britannica is losing money -- and last week its owner, a private trust called the William Benton Foundation, put it up for sale. And as befits the age, the potential buyers included not just publishers like Simon & Schuster but, you guessed it, Microsoft.
 
TRADE WARS
Tyrannosaurus Lexus?
A world without Lexuses (Lexi?) would be a sorry place indeed. Some people would probably have to settle for lapel buttons saying, "I'm so loaded I could spend $50,000 for a mere car." But just such a world loomed as a possibility last week as the Administration, making its move in some convoluted political game, plunked a 100 percent tariff on Japan's luxury cars. It's effective for cars arriving now, but won't be applied till late June -- allowing time for a settlement, or for this saber-rattling to pass. But if it sticks, that'll be it for new Lexuses, Infinitis and the like -- $30,000 to $50,000 is one thing, but $50,000 to $80,000? To the Mercedes dealer, Jeeves. And those of you scooping up "bargain" Lexuses now may find dealers few and far between.
 
BANKING
Musical Bank Chairs
Anyone inclined to brand loyalty must have a hard time when it comes to banks. These days, the "venerable" banks are the ones that haven't changed their name or ownership in, say, five years. Until 1988, Bowery Savings was a New York fixture, but then it was bought by H.F. Ahmanson, its branches turned into Home Savings offices. But then last week Greenpoint bought 60 Home Savings outlets -- mostly old Bowery branches. It paid dearly -- $660 million -- but Greenpoint used to be a mutual savings bank, and after going public it had a lot of money to spend. Now it has spent it -- and old Bowery customers face a new identity crisis.
 
AUTOS
Chrysler Can Spare a Dime
Chrysler tossed Kirk Kerkorian a bone last week, raising its dividend from 40 cents to 50 at its annual meeting -- after saying in December that there would be no increases this year. Not that it was admitting being swayed by Mr. Kerkorian's effort to buy the company, and his push for a far bigger dividend increase. "That was not the dominant issue at all," said Robert Eaton, the chairman. Now, Mr. Eaton said, he simply hoped the "disruptive force" of Mr. Kerkorian's nudging just "goes away." And Chrysler's tough stance seems to have worked, for no other big shareholders rallied to Mr. Kerkorian's cause, apparently a vote of confidence in Chrysler's cautious long-term plan. And the stock has settled at around $42, above the $39 before the bid but well below the $55 Mr. Kerkorian offered.
 
STOCK MARKET
Dow Drops 82; Life Goes On
So why did the Dow industrials plunge 82 points on Thursday, the year's biggest drop? You could trot out the usual suspects -- trade deficits, bond prices, an economy too strong or too weak (pick one). Or you could just look at the numbers: the Dow had risen 750 since November, traders with a fear of heights were glancing warily about to see who'd jump first, and on Thursday some jumped. And remember: 82 points ain't what it used to be. In the days of an 800 Dow, that would have been a scary 10 percent. At today's lofty levels, this drop doesn't even weigh in at 2 percent. So there's a good chance the world is not coming to an end.
 
CONGRESS
Tame the Deficit or Bust
Balancing the budget has become almost a religious crusade for Republicans, with the House last week charging ahead and voting a specific plan to break even by 2002. Specific, that is, except for things like how they'll save $280 billion on Medicare. If the Senate passes its own cuts this week, they'll have to work out the differences -- mainly that $350 billion House tax cut. But then comes a likely veto -- the House vote, 238 to 193, is not veto-proof. . . . Senate budget-cutters, meanwhile, want to do away with taxpayer-financed elections, which were created as a post-Watergate reform, saying Government should stay out of politics. What did the Democrats think? It would create an "obscene race for dollars," said Senator Christopher Dodd.
 
FUGITIVES
How to Steal a Billion
It's hard to steal billions of dollars -- because, well, most people don't leave billions of dollars lying around waiting to be stolen. But a German developer named Jurgen Schneider is accused of doing just that -- a year ago, his vast real estate empire collapsed and he disappeared, leaving $5 billion in debts. And last week -- after continuing reports that put him in places like Switzerland and Iran -- he was arrested in Hollywood, Fla., trying hard to look like your basic retiree. Does he have something stashed away? Who knows. But the real question is, How could German banks have let this happen? They may be asked that more often now that Mr. Schneider's dream vacation is over.
 
HOLLYWOOD
All Eyes on Mr. Ovitz
One thing is certain: Michael Ovitz will continue to call a lot of shots in Hollywood. The only question: where he'll be sitting. There was talk last week that he might leave the Creative Artists Agency, which practically owns Hollywood, to head MCA, which Seagram just bought. But the math gets tricky: Creative Artists could be worth $400 million now, and Mr. Ovitz probably owns half of it, but if he leaves and takes some top agents with him, it'll look a lot less valuable. In short, he's an awfully valuable man, so one wonders whether Seagram -- and its shareholders -- are ready to pay what it will take to get him.

HEADLINE: Japan's Low Crime Rate Offers Us No Lessons

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Japanese Say No to Crime: Tough Methods, at a Price" (front page, May 14): 
 "More than any other developed country," you write, "Japan has resolved to 'just say no' to crime," and "Japan may offer some lessons about ways to achieve security -- and the price of that safety." You describe how the Japanese police and courts have more extensive powers than those in the United States, how handguns are banned and how prisons are harsh places where inmates are expected to learn to feel remorse for their crimes.
 You give these policies causal significance in Japan's low crime rates, mentioning only as an afterthought the influence of Japan's egalitarian distribution of wealth. You also imply a causal link between rates of crime and rates of single motherhood, as well as a link between crime and the degree of "permissiveness" in American society.
 How does your correspondent know that authoritarian crime policies and a lack of "permissiveness" keep crime rates low? Could it not just as plausibly be that Japan's higher and more equal level of economic opportunity and relatively generous social safety net make people less desperate and make it less likely they will feel so socially alienated as to commit violent crime?
 There is certainly no consensus among sociologists about whether it is the absence of a father or the absence of economic opportunity that leads children of broken families to commit crimes in greater numbers.
We should not be led to expect that changes in the criminal justice system can have an impact on crime while increasing numbers of Americans are impoverished, alienated and desperate, and society offers them little assistance, compassion or hope.
 
APRIL DAVIS
Berkeley, Calif., May 15, 1995

SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3119 words

HEADLINE: The Brochures Pile Up. The Decision Presses. The Question: To Join or Not to Join?

BYLINE: By HOLCOMB B. NOBLE 

 BODY:
LOREN KALISH was 24 and frightened.
Burson-Marsteller, the public relations giant on Park Avenue South where she works as an associate, had just announced that all employees had to choose a health-maintenance organization. She knew H.M.O.'s usually require patients to see only doctors in their networks and insist on approving any visit to a specialist. But a "wonderful doctor" at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center had seen her through the ordeal of several irregular Pap smear readings, and she dreaded being treated by anyone else. 
 "I was not about to give him up," she says. "I was afraid I was going to have to pay for him myself!" She didn't have to. Ms. Kalish learned she had an option that would let her see an out-of-network specialist. "That," she says, "was an enormous relief -- my mother died of cancer so I know how important it is to find the best doctor you can." She saves money by using her H.M.O. doctor for routine care but sees her trusted gynecologist occasionally.
For Robert Fasano, a 43-year-old graphic designer who lives on the Upper East Side, the decision about a health-care plan was more traumatic and immediate. In 1990, he underwent a liver transplant at Mt. Sinai Hospital. At the time, he was covered under an insurance plan that let him pick his own doctors and reimbursed him for much of their cost. Last year, while covered under his wife's H.M.O., he started feeling terrible.
"The MetLife network physician, a nice guy who did not know much about post-transplant problems, did not figure out what was wrong," he recalls. "I called a doctor associated with the original transplant team, and in a few minutes on the phone he diagnosed cellulitis, got me to an emergency room and may have saved my life."
These two cases illustrate the often agonizing decisions New Yorkers now face as the nation's medical system -- after more than a decade of skyrocketing costs -- undergoes a fundamental and tortuous transformation.
When it comes time to select a heath-care plan, you will probably find yourself staring, glassy-eyed, at a formidable bundle of folders, each with vast amounts of information about H.M.O.'s, other managed-care plans and traditional fee-for-service insurance. What to do?
* Should you continue to get health care in the traditional manner, by seeing your own independent doctors, paying a fee and filing a claim with an insurance company?
* Or, like much of the rest of the nation, should you switch to managed care and an H.M.O., which promises to provide health care at a much lower cost but without sacrificing quality?
* If you do switch, how can you decide which H.M.O. to join and how to use it to best advantage?
As recently as two years ago, only 10 percent of all city residents were enrolled in an H.M.O., according to the state Department of Health. Today that number has nearly doubled and is rising rapidly. Currently, 12 H.M.O.'s operate in the city.
This shift toward managed care has ignited a furious debate whose main ingredients are money, medical ethics and the quality of treatment. Though there is little dispute that managed-care companies have lowered health-care costs, many in the medical community argue that their determination to do just that has compromised the quality of care. For their part, the companies insist that their care is every bit as good as that provided under fee for service.
Several studies are grappling with these issues, but their answers are a long way away. In announcing one such analysis to be done by the Hudson Center, an independent research group in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation said that while managed-care executives constantly strive to beef up efficiency and pare costs, "they do not yet have a systematic method for assessing the ethical dimensions of their decisions."
The angst surrounding all the point-counterpoint is heightened as more and more local companies apply economic pressure to switch to managed care -- dangling carrots and wielding sticks to keep their own health-insurance costs in check.
An H.M.O., already the dominant form of health care in some parts of the country, is usually a private, for-profit company that hires doctors under contract to treat patients for a set range of fees. Once in an H.M.O., you pick a primary-care doctor -- a "gatekeeper," -- who will do checkups and treat common illnesses. Usually, part of the primary-care doctor's job is to decide if a patient needs a specialist and to pick one in the H.M.O. network. There is normally a small co-payment, from about $2 to $15, for each doctor visit, but no deductible and no paperwork. There can be a catch: a gatekeeper who keeps the gate closed and denies permission to see a specialist. An appeal can be tedious, time-consuming, and sometimes, fruitless.
Most H.M.O.'s also offer what may, for now, be the best of all worlds, a "point-of-service option," which, for more money, allows visits to a specialist outside the network.
Another common, and simpler, form of managed-care company is a preferred-provider organization, or P.P.O., usually a network of doctors who sign up with an insurance company and agree to treat its customers at below-standard rates. It's important to be aware that, even in traditional fee-for-service medicine, there now may be some form of managed care -- someone who watches over a doctor's treatment decisions and fees. It may be a company hired by the insurer, or by your own employer. The goal is the same: to help keep down overall costs.
Medical-care costs are dropping, and economists attribute the reductions in large measure to managed care. The average cost of health benefits for American workers declined last year to $3,741 from $3,781, according to Foster Higgins, a benefits consulting firm. The Federal Labor Department reports that during the same period, health-insurance costs paid by employers dropped by 1 percent after increasing by as much as 18 percent a year during the last decade.
But those economies cut to the heart of the debate. Fee-for-service doctors' basic view is this: the quality of medicine suffers when patient and doctor are forced to give up their mutual trust and the physician's knowledge of a patient's history, built up over the years. Furthermore, they say, when a health-care corporation restricts the treatment a patient may or may not have, it may be putting money before medicine, the interests of its stockholders ahead of its patients.
Dr. Norma M. T. Braun, a pulmonary specialist at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, says she often has to wage time-consuming battles to get managed-care companies to approve needed treatment for her patients.
"There are now 12 to 15 percent annual salary increases for the chief executives of these managed-care companies," Dr. Braun says, "the rationale being that the companies have to stay competitive or they will lose the best executives. But we really have to look at the cost of cost containment -- it's become enormous, and the patient suffers. I'm as much against waste as anyone. But the first obligation in medicine has to be to the patient, not the pocketbook."
Dr. Braun treats patients covered under both fee-for-service plans and several H.M.O.'s that approached her and that she has signed with. Her colleagues call her a brilliant example of the kind of doctor you want under any system; her patients are equally effusive. A prominent Upper West Side musicologist who suffers from asthma, high-blood pressure, several broken ribs and cancer calls Dr. Braun a "one-person H.M.O." because "she does so much herself and then makes so many excellent referrals." But in Dr. Braun's experience, managed care often makes it difficult to practice the best medicine: "You're spending all your time arguing instead of treating your patient."
The H.M.O.'s complain that the doctors present isolated, anecdotal "horror" stories and that there are an equal number of similar upsetting accounts under fee-for-service medicine. As for the argument that patient-doctor relationships will be severed under H.M.O.'s, they insist that many consumers find it easier and receive better care by staying with one doctor, the H.M.O. primary-care physician, than they did when they were switching from one costly specialist to another. They contend, too, that when patients have to pay very little to be treated as often as necessary, the primary-care doctor is more likely to practice successful preventative medicine, like making sure routine checkups and tests are done and health regimens followed.
Leslie Moran, director of communications for the New York State H.M.O. Council, a private trade association, says: "H.M.O.'s are making sure that patients get the appropriate care at all levels. It's in their own best interests to put the consumers' interest first -- we don't want people unhappy or unwell."
The H.M.O.'s also point to their own national surveys, which often show a level of patient satisfaction approaching 90 percent. But it is not always easy to know precisely what is being surveyed. Tod Cooperman, president of CareData Reports, an independent research group, said that while "the plans try to put their best material forward, naturally," the range of satisfaction goes from a high of 70 percent "highly satisfied" to 62 percent "dissatisfied."
Generally, the satisfied patients they are talking about are people like Faye Joyce of the Upper West Side, who has been a member of the Health Insurance Plan (HIP) of Greater New York since 1976 and uses its center at Amsterdam Avenue and 68th Street.
"When my husband had trouble getting over the flu," she says, "HIP did a battery of routine tests, and then their specialists came in. He had a stress test, saw a psychiatrist and a neurologist and it was determined that he had Parkinson's disease -- and they got second and third opinions."
 
SEEING A SPECIALIST CAN BE TRICKY
But the critics of H.M.O.'s and other forms of managed care insist that problems they see are more than isolated cases of bad medicine -- and that they fall into four main areas: failure to refer patients to proper specialists, emergency decisions, premature hospital discharges and inadequate mental-health care.
The specialist problem is reflected in the case of a 40-year-old woman who suffers from a rare blood-clotting disorder that caused her to suffer strokes and, in turn, almost uncontrollable epileptic seizures. Dr. Orrin Devinsky, director of the New York University/Hospital for Joint Diseases Epilepsy Center, at 17th Street and Second Avenue, was called in on the case by Dr. James A. Charles, a neurologist.
Dr. Charles, a consultant to the woman's primary-care physician in H.M.O.-Blue of New Jersey, requested that she be transferred to Dr. Devinsky's care.
"I received a phone call from an H.M.O.-Blue nurse," Dr. Charles recalled. "She said she had never heard of the disease and directed me to the physicians' supervisor. He told me he was looking to cut costs, and that the patient could be treated in New Jersey. He berated me, saying he had heard stories before from other physicians who want to transfer patients to New York or Philadelphia or Boston for more expensive treatment out of network."
The transfer was denied, Dr. Charles said, but "this story had a happy ending: Her husband's insurance company authorized the transfer; she was treated in New York and is now doing well."
H.M.O.-Blue of New Jersey said it would not comment on the case out of respect for patient confidentiality. The new president of Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield in New York, Dr. Michael Stocker, points out that Blue Cross in New York is operated separately from New Jersey but added, "It is utterly obvious that this woman should have been transferred." And spokesmen for the H.M.O. industry say its doctors are as eager as anyone to have a top-notch specialist treat a complicated case when necessary.
Nevertheless, Dr. Devinsky maintains, "The H.M.O.'s do vary with regard to the ease with which a patient can be referred out of network. And some restrict the criteria for use of important tests or procedures."
He tells the story of one of his patients, a Manhattan man who had been treated for epilepsy for 43 years by some of the nation's leading neurologists. "We found out doing a diagnostic video-EEG during one of the patient's seizures that he didn't have epilepsy at all," Dr. Devinsky said, "but rather cardiac arrhythmia that slowed blood flow to the brain -- and had been treated for the wrong thing all that time."
Had the patient been in an H.M.O., it is unlikely the video-EEG (video-electroencephalogram) test would have been approved, he said. "You can only use an in-patient video-EEG for surgery, for example, to locate where in the brain a patient's seizures come from. But not for general diagnosis." Since the correct diagnosis was made, Dr. Devinsky said, the patient "has a Pacemaker and has been seizure-free for three years."
Some doctors who work for H.M.O.'s in the city say the companies have told them to transfer patients from non-network hospitals to network hospitals, even though the patients were too sick to be moved. Similarly, they tell of being discouraged from moving critically ill patients into intensive-care units at non-network hospitals, even when there are no ICU beds at network hospitals. Others complain about pressure to discharge mothers and their newborn babies even though another child or someone else may be sick at home. The doctors were unwilling to speak for attribution, saying they feared having their H.M.O. contracts canceled.
Kathryn Allen, president of the New York State H.M.O. Council, denied that H.M.O.'s pressure doctors to take any steps that would put patients at risk. "To do so would be self-defeating," she said.
Some H.M.O. doctors say colleagues fear their contracts may not be renewed if they disagree too often or too vigorously with the administrators of their plans. But an Upper East Side dermatologist who belongs to several H.M.O.'s said an effective way to resolve a battle is to "simply send an overnight certified letter, return-receipt requested, to management, stating the urgency of the treatment you demand -- and you send a copy to the patient!"
The last main area of debate is mental health. Psychiatrists in the city complain that H.M.O.'s offer little or no managed care for patients with serious long-term conditions -- clinical depression and anxiety, bipolarism and schizophrenia. Some plans, they say, do not have enough psychiatrists or child psychiatrists.
"There is the fear in general that mental-health coverage leads you to a black hole of unending costs," says Dr. John C. Markowitz, an attending psychiatrist at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center and an associate professor of clinical psychiatry at Cornell University Medical College. "But studies show that this isn't so -- failure to treat mental health properly is in the long run much more costly in lost productivity and future illnesses than almost all other forms of sickness."
Dr. Markowitz cited a case of what he called badly managed managed care, in which a 17-year-old patient developed manic depression, became delusional and thought himself the Messiah. The managed-care company, which the doctor declined to name, wanted the boy released from the hospital before Dr. Markowitz thought he was ready. When the company told his parents it would no longer pay for their son's hospitalization, they agreed to his discharge. "The boy was back in another hospital in two weeks," Dr. Markowitz said.
Psychiatrists also complain of a tendency of some primary-care doctors to treat psychiatric problems themselves. Often they prescribe the antidepressant Prozac, thinking there are no side effects; true in most cases, but not all. Or, they say, a medical doctor may believe incorrectly that he or she can detect a chronic schizophrenic who has stopped taking medication.
Many employers now use "carve-out" companies to manage mental-health care, and critics contend their real intent is to limit such care. Workers are often required to get approval from such companies or from the employer's own employee-assistance program before they will pay for any psychiatric help.
But Aetna, which operates both a carve-out division and H.M.O.'s that provide mental-health care, insists that the care given by both is equal in quality to that of individual psychiatrists. "To do otherwise," Dr. Jack Montgomery, an Aetna vice president, said, "would be penny-wise and pound-foolish." And Dr. Leonard Reich, the New York vice president for mental-health services at HIP, said it, too, provides high-quality mental-health care under its plans' basic provisions. He added, however, that employers looking to cut costs often cut mental health coverage first.
 
SOME SAY ALL H.M.O.'S ARE NOT CREATED EQUAL
Where does all this back-and-forth leave the New Yorker who, for economic or whatever reason, is going the H.M.O. route and trying to figure out which company and plan best suits his or her needs?
One of the fastest-growing H.M.O.'s in the city is Oxford. Its managers contend that one reason is its emphasis on point of service, the option that allows patients to go out of network. David Snow, Oxford's executive vice president, said another reason is that Oxford has "always treated our physicians as partners," allowing them far more autonomy than many H.M.O.'s.
Both Oxford's basic plan and its point-of-service plan finished at the top of a survey of overall patient satisfaction with H.M.O.'s in the city, as well as on Long Island and in Westchester, Rockland, Putnam and Orange counties. The survey, by CareData of New York, the independent research firm, questioned 3,397 metropolitan area residents.
Another H.M.O. available in the city, ChoiceCare, finished first in four of the survey's sub-categories: satisfaction with primary-care physicians, administration, choice of hospitals and choice of pharmacies.
And then there is an H.M.O. being set up in the city by First Option, which was founded last July by doctors and hospitals in New Jersey. Echoing those who contend that bottom-line considerations outweigh medical ones under some managed-care companies, First Option's president, John Odessa, says: "What makes us different is that we have no shareholders requiring 20 to 25 percent profit margins. Our primary incentive is to provide optimal health care."
First Option is a for-profit corporation owned by doctors and hospitals who are stockholders. But its board has voted to limit its profit margin to 5 percent.

 CORRECTION:
A chart last Sunday with an article about health maintenance organizations misstated the number of Aetna's members in New York State. It is 131,252, not 31,252. The chart also misstated the telephone number for U.S. Healthcare. It is (800) 323-9930.

Lopez/The New York Times); "I'm as much against waste as anyone," says Dr. Norma M. T. Braun. "But the first obligation in medicine has to be to the patient, not the pocketbook." (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times); David Snow, Oxford's executive vice president, says patients like Oxford's out-of-network options. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times) (pg. 12)
 
Charts: "EXIT SIGNS: Going Out of Network"
Basic H.M.O. plans do not allow you to see out-of-network doctors. But most offer options that do, called point-of-service (P.O.S.) plans. Monthly premiums for such plans range from 10% to 20% higher than for basic H.M.O. membership, but other payments stay the same unless a consumer sees an out-of-network doctor. Many consumers, therefore, use their primary-care H.M.O. doctor for routine check-ups and leave the network only to visit a specialist. When they do, it triggers deductibles, reimbursement and out-of-pocket expense limits - the total amount a comsumer has to pay in a year. Most companies offer several point-of-service plans. HEADLINE: The Lowcountry Of South Carolina

BYLINE: By GUY GARCIA; GUY GARCIA is a frequent visitor to South Carolina's
Lowcountry.

 BODY:
STEEPED in history and studded with some of the most elegant examples of American Colonial architecture, the great plantations of South Carolina have long been a mecca for anyone seeking the quintessence of gracious hospitality. But the stately houses and exquisite gardens of antebellum landmarks like Middleton Place, Drayton Hall and Magnolia Gardens are only part of the story. For a fuller taste of pre-Civil War life, a visitor can also experience the rice fields, swamps and meandering rivers that were once the economic engines of the Lowcountry estates, connecting the landed families of the region with each other and the outside world.
 Until recently, exploring the waterways and hinterlands of South Carolina's sprawling plantations was either unwieldly or impossible. But that has changed with the advent of two popular advances in recreational technology -- the kayak and the all-terrain mountain bike. Together they offer an opportunity to see the Colonial South from an off-road perspective that emphasizes the hidden history and natural beauty of the region. 
Intrigued by the notion of an eco-sensitive tour of Middleton Place plantation, my wife, Cathleen, and I signed up with W3 Outfitters (for Water, Woods and Wildlife), a Charleston-based company that runs ecological mountain bike and kayak tours through Middleton's 6,500 acres of rivers, rice fields, swamps and forest. We joined a group kayaking trip down the Ashley River on the first afternoon; the second day I set out with a single guide for a mountain bike and swamp tour. W3 operates by reservation only; the trips begin and end at the Middleton Inn, a 55-room hotel where we booked a room, though accommodations at the inn are not included in any W3 package.
 Opened to the public in 1986, the inn is a sleekly modern assembly of two-story and three-story buildings made of wood, glass and concrete that sits next to Middleton's noted formal gardens. The geometrical open spaces in the main building frame the surrounding foliage and echo the ruins of the main house of the estate, which was burned by Sherman's troops in 1865. Our room was a spacious studio on the second floor, with a fireplace, cypress-paneled walls, oak floors and furniture upholstered in shades of vanilla. Floor to ceiling windows, outfitted with double rows of pine shutters, afforded a view of the wooded footpath that follows the Ashley River to Middleton Place.
 We spent the morning of our first day strolling through the grounds, one of the oldest formal gardens in the United States. Planted in 1741 under the direction of Henry Middleton, the first president of the Continental Congress, the gardens fell into neglect after the great earthquake of 1886, but were restored and enhanced in the early 20th century. Designed to take advantage of Middleton's sloped river-bank site, they are a labyrinth of angular pathways, reflecting ponds and stepped lawns.
 During a picnic lunch by the pool at the inn, we met with Ben Chapman, the proprietor of W3 Outfitters, and the rest of our party, which included a magazine publisher, a real estate appraiser, a lawyer and the Charleston-based watercolorist Rhett Thurman. A strapping, energetic man with a neatly cropped beard, Mr. Chapman, who is a former board member of the South Carolina chapter of the national Nature Conservancy, founded W3 in 1993 as a venture dedicated to "historical, nature-based experiences." His affinity for the lore and land of the Lowcountry was immediately apparent as he began pointing out how the inn itself was built on the site of a century-old phosphate processing plant. "See those trees right there?" he asked, pointing to a pair of long-stemmed saplings growing near the pool. "Those are Chinese parasol trees. They aren't indigenous -- the seeds were blown in from the Caribbean during Hurricane Hugo. Aren't they pretty?"
 Mr. Chapman then strode over to the lawn, where a half-dozen 16-foot plastic and glass fiber sea kayaks were in a neat row. Sitting in the hull of one he demonstrated the proper way to get in and out, how to paddle ("The principle of paddling is based on leverage not muscle") and what to do if the kayaker should tip over ("Relax, hold on to your paddle and get out of the boat"). Thus prepared, we shoved off into the tannin-tinted water of the Ashley and began paddling north, past Middleton's jade lawns and butterfly lakes, all the while doing our best to navigate the wake from an occasional passing speedboat. The recreational craft that buzz up and down the river are a particular peeve of Mr. Chapman, who grimly pointed out erosion of the bank caused by their wakes. The river ranges from 30 to several hundred feet wide at the landing at Middleton.
 We kept paddling away from the plantation until all we could hear was the sound of the wind whipping through the gold-green curtain of spartina grass sprouting from the banks. Along the water line, armies of fiddler crabs scurried over the rocks as egrets and osprey wheeled in the limpid sky. Now and again we came upon a lone fisherman, his pole raised over the glistening water. These wetlands, Mr. Chapman told us, are home to bald eagles, loggerhead turtles, wood storks, alligators and dozens of other rare or endangered species. On the way back, paddling against the current, we kept a lookout for the 16-foot-long alligator that Mr. Chapman had spotted a few days earlier. At the end of our two-hour excursion, as we turned the final bend, the sun was slanting through the branches of Middleton's giant river oaks and for a moment the plantation seemed restored to the grandeur of its 18th-century self.
 LATER that evening, Mr. Chapman offered to drive us to a rice pond about a half-mile from the inn to watch the sunset. Sitting in a wooden duck blind that he built himself ("The only kind of shooting that goes on here is with a camera," he told us), we sipped wine and watched as the sky ignited in neonshades of salmon and magenta. When the sun dipped behind the treeline, the earth seemed to hold its breath for moments before exploding into a nocturnal fugue of croaking marsh frogs.
 Next morning, as first light touched the treetops, we watched from our bed as a redheaded woodpecker cavorted in the branches outside our room. The pale blanket of fog that had covered the Ashley overnight burned off by the time we walked to the lodge for a breakfast of omelets, muffins, cereal and fresh juices. Mr. Chapman soon arrived with a pair of 22-speed Univega Rover mountain bikes for our five-hour bike tour. He led the way as we cycled past the riding stables and across highway 61, where 50 miles of dirt paths and utility roads crisscross the property, which takes up the better part of Dorchester County.
 We rode single file past flowering dogwood trees and groves of 200-year-old longleaf pine, pausing frequently as Mr. Chapman identified botanical and historic points of interest. Breaking on a sandy rise, Mr. Chapman scrutinized the foliage. "There's a lot going on here," he announced, plucking off a leaf of southern bay and crushing it between his fingers. "Smell that," he said. "That's pungent, I use it for cooking all the time." Taking a few steps, he leaned over and snapped off a branch of Lowcountry cane, stripping away the thin brown bark to reveal the bamboo stem underneath. Taking out his pocketknife, Mr. Chapman split the bark and bent it into a small hoop. "The Indians used this to make baskets," he noted.
 We had biked several more miles when the road dipped and the terrain became lusher. We were getting closer to the swamp. Along the way, we stopped to admire a solitary atamasco lily growing in the center of the road beside the green fan of a scrub palmetto. A few minutes later we arrived at an old swamp dike that had survived for at least 200 years. The land to our left, once used to grow corn, indigo and other cash crops, was dry and overgrown with brush; on the right was a rice field that had reverted to swamp.
 The tangled foliage of the swamp was alive with the cacophonous music of warblers, crows and woodpeckers. Mr. Chapman bent over to show me an otter slide on the edge of a drainage canal. Then, in a voice that made me stiffen, he told me to "Turn around, very slowly." I did as he said and immediately spotted an alligator about 10 feet away, drifting toward us. The alligator was a juvenile about four feet long, but I nevertheless felt a visceral tingle of apprehension. As we strolled along the dike, the animal followed, watching us with open curiosity. Before we left, I scanned the still surface of the water, hoping to see it again, but our amphibious friend was too perfectly camouflaged in his natural habitat.
 From the dike it was a short ride to the wooden shed where Mr. Chapman had stored several plastic swamp kayaks. Sliding the boats into the indigo water, we pushed off from the bank for about a 90-minute trip and entered a primordial world of giant bull rushes, floating creepers and stalagmite-like root formations -- all reflected in the swamp's still surface, which duplicated and magnified the foliage like a fun house mirror. Producing bags of Cajun-style boiled peanuts, a local delicacy, Mr. Chapman handed me some and munched a few himself. Then he dipped a plastic bottle under the carpet of floating leaves and lifted it out full. The water was clear with a reddish tint, like weak iced tea. "Go ahead and take a drink," Mr. Chapman said. "It's pure rainwater. Delicious." After a moment's hesitation, I did. It tasted like iced tea, too.
 We paddled deeper into the swamp, listening to the staccato banter of a dozen different birds. Sunlight filtered through the growing emerald canopy and, bent by the ripples from our boats, made luminous bands that undulated over mammoth cypress trunks. The effect was enchanting, like being inside an aquarium. "This is the place that, once I bring people in here, I have to drag them out because they don't ever want to leave," Mr. Chapman remarked. As I drifted farther into the leafy cavern of pulsating light and color, I had no trouble understanding why.

 
A Lowcountry visitor's guide

 W3 Outfitters offers guided mountain bike tours at $15 for a half day or $22 for a full day.  Tours usually require a minimum of six people. I had a private guide for my combination biking and kayaking tour on the second day of my trip; the cost is $150 for a half day, $250 for a full day. The kayaking that we did in the swamp is seasonal, available only when the water level allows it.

HEADLINE: It Doesn't Add Up

BYLINE: By Jim Holt; Jim Holt writes on scientific and philosophical matters for The Wall Street Journal, The New Republic and Harper's Magazine.

 BODY:

THE TYRANNY OF NUMBERS
Mismeasurement and Misrule.
By Nicholas Eberstadt.
305 pp. Washington:
The AEI Press. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $16.95. 
THE modern liberal democracy is an edifice built on numbers. Rationalist, problem-solving and expansive in nature, it strives to better the lot of its citizens by charting policy against statistics. In the process, however, it inevitably transgresses the limits of knowledge. The result: misrule born of mismeasurement.
So goes Nicholas Eberstadt's line of argument in "The Tyranny of Numbers." One might expect him to support it by looking at the states that have ventured farthest in the rationalist, "meliorative" direction he thinks is so perilous: France and Germany, say, where government spending accounts for roughly half the national output, or the even more socialized Scandinavian countries, where the figure is almost two-thirds.
But while Mr. Eberstadt, a visiting scholar at the somewhat right-of-center American Enterprise Institute and a visiting fellow of the Harvard University Center for Population and Development Studies, has profitable observations to make about the world food problem, poverty in South Africa and literacy under Communism, the only liberal democracy he directly considers is the United States. That is odd. Our public sector, after all, is relatively small. As a nation we tend to agree with Ronald Reagan that "government is the problem." So by the author's lights we should be better off than our counterparts in the more meddlesome European welfare states.
Why, then, is our poverty level so stubbornly high? Why is our rate of infant mortality an international disgrace? Mr. Eberstadt has a ready answer. These are but statistical illusions, he argues -- another manifestation of the tyranny of numbers.
Take infant mortality, a key index of national well-being. Our rate may be one of the worst among the industrialized nations, Mr. Eberstadt concedes, but "U.S. babies at any given birth weight appear to have unusually good chances of surviving the perinatal period, regardless of race." The real problem is our tendency to produce babies with low birth weights -- a tendency that according to the author's painstaking analysis is associated not so much with poverty or lack of access to health care as it is with parental negligence during the prenatal period.
Mr. Eberstadt may not be right to blame low birth weight for American infant mortality; the latest study indicates that being born too soon rather than too small is the main cause of infant death. (For a given length of pregnancy, lighter babies are as likely to survive as heavier ones.) Yet his logic gives rise to deeper misgivings. When it suits him, he will explain away bad numbers by pointing to individual choices that the state cannot do much about. Thus infant mortality in the United States, far from being Washington's fault for failing to provide funds for better prenatal care, is a result of Americans -- single mothers in particular -- freely exercising "the right to be a negligent parent." In other cases, however, the system seems to be guilty. The collapse of health standards in the former Soviet bloc, for instance, is a black mark against Communism, even though (as Mr. Eberstadt shows) it was in large part brought on by the prodigious consumption of hard liquor and cigarettes.
Oddly, the farther Mr. Eberstadt strays from his philosophical premise, the better his book gets. His diagnosis of why the C.I.A. blundered so badly in estimating the size of the Soviet economy is superb. Even better is his careful demographic debunking of the myth, propagated by Unicef among others, that the third-world debt crisis is killing millions of children.
No doubt policy by statistics -- plagued as it is by false precision, biased indexes and sheer invention of numbers -- has resulted in a great deal of governmental mischief, not to say tyranny. Yet Mr. Eberstadt's suggestion that the United States is already bumping up against the "immutable limits" of state knowledge, and hence perfectibility, strikes me as unduly cautious. It should not be forgotten that there are some nations today, no richer or cleverer than ours, where you can't tell the economic class of a child by looking at his teeth.
