HEADLINE: Aides to Clinton Say He Will Defy Beijing and Issue Visa to Taiwan's President

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
President Clinton has decided to grant a visa to the President of Taiwan, senior Administration officials said today. The action would break a 16-year-old policy and risk retaliation by China, which vehemently opposes the move on the ground that the United States has no official relations with Taiwan.
The officials said President Clinton had decided to risk a run-in with China by admitting President Lee Teng-hui because of intense pressure from the Republican-dominated Congress. 
 Earlier this month, the Senate voted 97 to 1 and the House 396 to 0 to urge Mr. Clinton to reverse the longstanding policy and allow Mr. Lee to attend Cornell University's alumni reunion next month in Ithaca, N.Y.
With this move and the decision to impose trade sanctions on Japanese cars, President Clinton will in one week have angered the two most powerful Asian Governments, China and Japan, at a time when many experts on Asia say American relations with the world's most dynamic continent are already strained.
No President of Taiwan has been allowed to visit the United States since 1979, when the United States adopted a policy that recognizes Beijing as the sole Government of China. Until then, Washington had recognized the Chinese Nationalists, who fled mainland China for Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war with the Communists, as the legitimate Chinese Government.
Under intense pressure from China, the United States now maintains only unofficial ties with Taiwan, which the Government in Beijing views as a breakaway province.
A senior Administration official said that when Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, and Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff met China's Ambassador to the United States, Li Daoyu, on Saturday to inform him of the decision, Mr. Li said his Government was "very unhappy." Another official said the Ambassador responded that his country would have "a sharp reaction."
A spokesman for China's Foreign Ministry in Beijing, asked about the decision to allow Lee Teng-hui to visit the United States, said that the ministry would not have any immediate comment.
Shortly after Congress adopted its resolution urging that President Lee be granted a visa, China's Foreign Ministry said that admitting him for either an offical or a private visit would have "serious consequences."
American diplomats acknowledged today that they feared that China might somehow retaliate, but they added that they had sought to assuage the Chinese by saying Congressional pressure was making such a decision inevitable.
"We expect China to be unhappy about this, but we'll have to wait and see exactly how they react," said a senior State Department official, who said the visa did not signal a change in the Administration's policy toward China or Taiwan.
In discussing the decision, which is expected to be announced on Monday, members of the Administration sought to minimize the likelihood of an angry Chinese response by noting that President's Lee trip would be a short, private visit in which he would not meet any American officials.
Mr. Lee, who received a doctorate in agricultural economics from Cornell in 1968, has been invited to be the main speaker at the university's alumni weekend, from June 8 to 10.
China is expected to accuse the United States of violating a commitment by admitting Mr. Lee because last September, after a long policy review, the Administration assured China's Government that President Lee would not be allowed into the country except for a transit stop for safety, comfort or convenience. Last May, his plane was allowed to stop in Hawaii to refuel, but the Administration barred him from staying overnight and meeting friends.
Even though they excluded Mr. Lee in the past, State Department officials said they liked him, and they praised him for solidifying democracy in Taiwan.
Republicans in Congress welcomed the decision. "The White House had to address the realities in Congress," said Senator Frank Murkowski, the Alaska Republican who sponsored the resolution on Taiwan in the Senate. "When we look at the significance of President Lee in the development of Taiwan -- they'll have free elections this year -- keeping him out was a situation that had to end, and I'm glad to see President Clinton move on it."
One senior official acknowledged that the nonbinding resolution approved by Congress had forced the Administration's hand, since continuing to bar Mr. Lee would give the impression that Mr. Clinton was bowing to Chinese pressure.
The President has sought to shake that image since last May, when he extended China's preferential trade status even though its human rights performance fell far short of what he had demanded.
When Mr. Lake and Mr. Tarnoff met with Ambassador Li, they told the Chinese diplomat that if Mr. Clinton did not soon grant a visa to Taiwan's President, Congress might overwhelmingly adopt a binding resolution that would not only require him to do so, but would also upgrade the American relationship with Taiwan -- something that China bitterly opposes.
"The Taiwan issue is very important symbolically for China and we have to manage it very carefully," a senior State Department official said. "There was a desire by this Administration to pre-empt new binding legislation that could hurt our relations with China."
Administration officials said they had no idea whether or how China might retaliate. After President Bush announced plans in 1992 to sell F-16's to Taiwan, China protested and, many Asia experts say, retaliated by ignoring American pleas not to sell missile technology to Pakistan and nuclear technology to Iran.
"The Chinese aren't going to like this one bit," said Harry Harding, an expert on China who is dean of the Elliott School of International Affairs at George Washington University. "It's possible, even likely, that they will take some retaliatory action. It's difficult to know what they will do, but I think when they find an issue that is more important to us than to them, they will decide not to be cooperative."
Administration officials say Secretary of State Warren Christopher overruled some low-level officials when he recommended to the President last week that Mr. Lee be admitted. Several Asia experts in the State Department opposed granting Mr. Lee a visa, fearing that it would do too much damage to relations with China when Mr. Christopher's diplomatic vision is to try to maintain strong relations with the world's major powers.
But some other advisers were recommending a visa for Mr. Lee to avoid a high-stakes showdown with Congress that the White House was likely to lose. Their fear was that Congress would adopt a binding resolution to admit Mr. Lee with enough of a majority to withstand a Presidential veto.
"We will be quite delighted if President Lee is able to attend the alumni reunion weekend," said Henrik Dullea, Cornell's vice president for university relations. "It will be the capstone of the weekend."
Cornell's President, Frank H. T. Rhodes, had urged the Administration to admit Mr. Lee, as had a petition from students, faculty and alumni.
One factor that weighed in the decision, Administration officials said, was that China was slowly increasing economic ties and unofficial diplomatic exchanges with Taiwan even as it pressed the United States and dozens of other countries to keep contacts with Taiwan to a minimum.

HEADLINE: Government Also Adds to Property Values;
A Tax to Set It Right

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Unlikely Alliances Attack Property Rights Measures" (front page, May 15): There does exist a very appropriate financial mechanism for compensation to property owners. It is the land value increment tax, formerly known as a betterment tax. The idea is old, simple and widely considered fair. 
 An increase in land value, as opposed to changes in the property value resulting from improvements erected on land, is basically an increase in site value. The land owner typically has done nothing to produce the incremental value. This increase usually results from population growth, economic growth and the infrastructural investments made by local governments, such as roads, water supply and sewerage.
These increments are unearned by the property owner and could be taxed away without affecting resource allocation. That is, such taxation would not impair the potential for the land market to assign land to its "highest and best" use.
It is an easy argument that such increments in value fairly belong to society, and not to the land owner. Thus an appropriate source of funds for paying financial compensation for public "takings" of private wealth is to raise revenue from private "takings" of that value created by society. These are called "rents" in economics, which by definition are unearned.
As an example, California farmers who benefit from subsidized water would by this measure have that increase in land value caused by access to subsidized water taxed away, and thus any compensation to be paid would be a perfect wash.
It might cause those who express outrage over the regulations, such as developers, to reconsider their position.
 
HAYNES C. GODDARD
Professor of Economics
University of Cincinnati
Cincinnati, Ohio, May 16, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: White House Memo;
Administration Bides Its Time as Budget Debate Start to Boil

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The Clinton White House has many faces and voices. But when it comes to negotiations on the future shape of the Federal budget, they all speak these days in one portentous rumble: "All in good time," they say.
"This is not the moment for us to offer an alternative," Alice M. Rivlin, director of the Office of Management and Budget, told reporters on Friday morning. 
 Hours later Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the President's chief economic policy adviser, said, "It's not the appropriate moment to propose an alternative."
And the same day, the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said: "The President will, at the proper point, be ready to engage and to offer up some ideas. But, you know, the timing is his choice and not yours."
That strategy reflects not only a remarkable unity of purpose for a White House known for talking out of turn but also the realization that, in the words of one senior Clinton adviser, "the budget is the whole ball game" this year in determining the direction of the Government and Mr. Clinton's prospects for re-election.
Accordingly, under the direction of the White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, who is steeped in budget gamesmanship from his days as chairman of the House Budget Committee, the Administration is singing as one. Ms. Tyson has added senior political and communications aides to the list of top economic advisers who meet twice a week to plan tactics, and any dissenters either keep quiet or have left the Administration, with their advice relegated to the opinion pages of newspapers.
Having passed his own economic plan two years ago without a single Republican vote, and having seen his health care plan picked to pieces by a steady drumbeat of criticism, Mr. Clinton has resolved to torture the Republicans by "explaining" what he thinks their proposals for balancing the Federal budget by 2002 would do to a range of popular programs like Medicare. For the last two weeks he or top aides have done so almost every day.
At the same time, Mr. Clinton has laid out his conditions for cooperation: abandonment of Republican tax cuts, which he contends unfairly favor the wealthy; protection of aid for education and programs like his national service corps, and cuts in the growth of Medicare and Medicaid spending only as part of a broader overhaul of the health care system.
The Republicans have responded by accusing Mr. Clinton of abandoning leadership -- or going AWOL, in the not-so-subtle idiom of the Senate's Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas -- and indeed, the risk of the White House strategy is that Mr. Clinton may look intransigent.
The Administration's approach may be transparent, but like many obvious ideas, it appears to be working, at least in the short term.
The President's popularity is rising in public opinion polls. And the Republicans are at some pains to defend their plans, unable to muster the votes needed to override Mr. Clinton's threatened veto of $16.4 billion worth of cuts in spending for the current year -- cuts that the President says protect roads and building projects at the expense of education and the environment.
On the other hand, Mr. Clinton has not been a font of bold proposals. His own budget message deliberately avoided the hard choices on deeper reductions in the deficit, because he was confident the Republicans would simply seize any cuts he proposed while ignoring his spending preferences, and the Senate defeated his proposal 99 to 0 last week in a symbolic vote intended only to embarrass him.
The real debate is just beginning, and the specific spending and tax bills that will set priorities and perhaps prompt Presidential vetoes will come this summer. Some Democrats, like Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, who is also the general chairman of the Democratic National Committee, are already suggesting that the Administration should drop its own proposed tax cuts, which are only about one-third the size of those proposed by House Republicans, as a sign of good faith and willingness to grapple with the deficit.
Ms. Rivlin said: "There will come a moment of negotiation. Exactly what form that'll take is not clear yet. What we have been doing is making clear exactly what we don't like."
Many moderate Democrats and Republicans believe that the White House missed an opportunity for compromise on health care last year. Asked how the Administration's judgment could be expected to be any better now, Ms. Rivlin acknowledged, "We certainly didn't judge things very well last year on the health plan, nor do we have any exact date for when we think is the moment for engagement."
For now, curiosities abound in the role reversal of the two parties since the Republican electoral sweep last fall.
When Mr. Clinton proposed $118 billion in cuts in the growth of Medicare spending to help finance his health care overhaul, Republicans denounced the plan as likely to increase deductibles paid by the elderly and limit participants' choices of doctors. Now the White House registers the same complaints about the Republicans' plans to force up to $300 billion in Medicare savings, with Hillary Rodham Clinton denouncing the proposals as "deep and arbitrary cuts."
Republicans defeated Mr. Clinton's proposed economic stimulus package in 1993 by attacking it as pork barrel spending, pent up and hastily assembled after 12 years of Republican administrations. Last week, the President attacked the Republican plan to cut this year's budget by $16.4 billion as putting pork over people, though he had actually supported some of the protected projects in the past and agreed with all but about $1.5 billion of the choices proposed in the final bill.
Having included significant deficit reduction in his first budget and received almost no discernible credit for it with voters, Mr. Clinton would now let the deficit stay at about $200 billion a year through the turn of the century, and his advisers criticize Republican plans to balance the budget by 2002 as arbitrary and impractical.
The only hint that the Administration finds that switch hard to defend is subtle but widely noted among regulars at White House briefings. When Ms. Rivlin is asked routine questions about the budget, her voice has the smoky timbre of Bette Davis. When she is asked why the Administration is not pursuing deeper deficit reduction, she slides three octaves into the nervous chirp of Betty Boop.

HEADLINE: Of G.O.P. Suitors, 2 Are Just Flirting

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Maybe they are reacting to a lack of excitement over the current crop of contenders for the Republican Presidential nomination. Maybe they feel a call to greater public service. Or maybe it is plain ego.
Just when it appeared that the field was settled, now come two party luminaries -- one a Washington insider and the other an outsider -- who want it known that they are available for their party's nomination: Speaker Newt Gingrich and Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin. 
 While Mr. Gingrich says he is not running for President in 1996, his statements on the subject are far from definitive. And he touched off a new round of speculation last week with the release of a full itinerary for a trip to New Hampshire next month. It is so crammed with events -- even moose hunting with Representative Bill Zeliff -- that the Speaker's advisers were considering chartering buses for a full-scale campaign-style motorcade around the state.
Mr. Thompson is far less subtle about his longing for the White House. He has already visited Iowa and New Hampshire and has more trips planned.
His aspirations were obvious this weekend at a regional meeting of Republicans in Green Bay, Wis., where he tried to upstage the Presidential candidates at the event by calling a news conference on Saturday afternoon and urging reporters not to count him out. "I haven't, certainly, foreclosed that option," Mr. Thompson said. But he cautioned reporters not to count him in, either, adding that he will make a decision by Labor Day.
It is said that every politician thinks he or she should be President, and Mr. Thompson is no exception. Delivering what might be the nucleus of a campaign speech, the Governor was not modest in making the case for why his record in three terms on welfare reform, taxes and job creation make him an obvious choice.
"All of the ideas that everybody's talking about are ideas that I've already done," he said. "Wisconsin is a microcosm of what everybody talks about in Washington, except we've done it. And I think that's a message that can resonate across the country." Noting that he has not served in Washington, he said, he would present himself as "the only candidate that's clearly from the outside." And he said he would emphasize economic issues rather than a social agenda.
Nor was Mr. Thompson bashful in recounting how the candidates are all making plays for him. "They all want an endorsement," he said.
The Governor, who is 53, seemed genuinely in a conflict about the Presidential action. One moment he would praise the contenders, and the next he would dismiss them as not matching his achievements. "None of the candidates have the record that I have," he said. "I may want to put that record out there."
But flirting with running for President is usually far more rewarding than actually running for President. Running means raising millions of dollars, putting yourself and your family under even deeper scrutiny and subjecting yourself to nasty attacks from fellow Republicans.
Then, of course, what if you lose? As successful as they may be in their current positions, it could be that Mr. Gingrich's negative ratings and Mr. Thompson's lack of name recognition, among other factors, would sink their candidacies.
Compounding the risk, the candidates who are already running have a head-start in organization and most have raised several million dollars. That is significant because with the compressed schedule of early primaries next year, the race could be over soon after it begins.
That is why some prominent Republicans think that Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Thompson will ultimately stay put. The Speaker, especially, may be positioning himself for a draft movement should the current contenders stumble.
But Mr. Thompson has considered all the angles: Spinning out a scenario of how he might win, he said Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, may not last as the front-runner. Even if Mr. Dole wins the early contests in Iowa and New Hampshire, he said, "The question is: Who comes in second? Who comes in third?" He acknowledged that he could not come close to his rivals' warchests but said that he could raise as much as $4 million by the end of the year.
Turning aside the conventional wisdom, Mr. Thompson said there may be such a divided field that "there's a good chance that this election could be decided on the convention floor, and wouldn't that be exciting?"
For all his plotting, there is someone on the sidelines who may scare Mr. Thompson off: Mr. Gingrich.
"Newt could come in here, and throw this whole election up for grabs," the Governor said. "Newt has an excellent chance to go right to the top."
Is Mr. Thompson maneuvering to be picked for Vice President? Perhaps. Don't count him in for the No. 2 spot, Mr. Thompson said. But, as his Republican fans in Wisconsin warn, don't count him out.

HEADLINE: Miracle in Mexico: A Clean Election

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: VICTORIA, Mexico

 BODY:
In the world that Vicente Fox would save, rivers are running dry, jobs are disappearing, and children's stomachs are hardening from their hunger. It goes almost without saying in the case Mr. Fox makes for his election as Governor of central Guanajuato state that corrupt governing-party politicians are growing fat on the taxpayers' pesos, but he rants about this anyway.
More striking is what Mr. Fox, a strapping, 52-year-old businessman, does not say: In town after town, speech after thundering speech, he never mentions the word "fraud." 
 Not quite four years ago, the protests Mr. Fox led after the state's last gubernatorial race established Guanajuato as a symbol of the anti-democratic ways of the party that has governed Mexico since 1929. In his quest for satisfaction, however, Mr. Fox now finds himself the comfortable frontrunner in what many political analysts say could be the fairest major election held in Mexico in decades.
Surprisingly effective campaign-spending regulations have limited the usual flood of resources to the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI. A new state election law has the opposition virtually discounting the possibility of ballot-stuffing, repeat voting and other once standard practices at the polls.
With a member of Mr. Fox's right-of-center National Action Party serving as Guanajuato's interim Governor, the standard claims of favoritism by the incumbent are being made only by the PRI. "The dirty war" that dominates the headlines of local newspapers refers merely to the mundane business of what Americans know as negative campaigning.
"Things are very different from the last time," Mr. Fox said after a well-attended speech in Victoria, the sort of small farming town where he was all but ignored a few years ago. "I don't think it would be possible for them to get away with a fraud big enough to affect the outcome."
Even aides to President Ernesto Zedillo acknowledge that the conditions for Guanajuato's vote on May 28 remain exceptional. According to federal election officials and a leading election-monitoring group, PRI supporters in the southern state of Yucatan have continued to manipulate the rules and try to coerce the support of voters in another, much closer gubernatorial race there.
Yet the prospect of a clean vote and -- what is far more novel -- fair political competition in Guanajuato suggest that the opposition's growing strength in many states is pushing Mexico toward a more democratic political system even as opposition leaders and aides to Mr. Zedillo haggle over the terms for talks on what he promises will be "definitive" election reforms.
"What we are trying out here is going to be a lesson for the rest of the country," said Hugo Villalobos, 41, a hardware entrepreneur who leads Guanajuato's State Elections Council, an agency now controlled by a council of politically independent local dignitaries. "In Guanajuato, the 'definitive' reform has already taken place."
Six months into the economic crisis that began with Mr. Zedillo's disastrous devaluation of the peso, the brunt of the voters' anger at the PRI is being channeled in Guanajuato and Yucatan not by the leftist opposition that had long criticized the Government's economic policies but by the rightist opposition that had supported most of them.
Both states happen to be relative strongholds of the National Action Party, or PAN, which has governed some of their major cities for years. But the party's track record of relatively efficient, uncorrupt government may now be a lesser part of its candidates' appeal.
Despite leading by almost a two-to-one margin in most opinion polls, Mr. Fox insists that the PAN's interim Governor in Guanajuato, Carlos Medina, is almost as unpopular as the PRI: "He doesn't bring us votes," Mr. Fox said. "He costs us votes."
With many Mexicans growing more nervous about crime and political stability as well as about their jobs, Mr. Fox and his counterpart in Yucatan, Luis Correa, promise gradual change, smaller government, law and order. And in the purest populist tradition, Mr. Fox, especially, tantalizes the crowds with all kinds of things that he knows the next Governor might not have the money to to deliver.
To farmers who have been ruined by drought, he offers dams and canals to irrigate their land. To parents fed up with the decrepit education system, he pledges a computer in every school. Mexican and foreign companies will be wooed to a big, new industrial complex in the poorest reaches of the state, he says, and products will move back and forth on a four-lane highway.
Mr. Fox, a former Coca-Cola executive who makes no secret of his hopes to seek the presidency in the year 2000, also vows to spend only one day out of every seven in the governor's office in the Guanajuato, the colonial state capital. "I am going to hire a governor," he said in an interview, smiling. "I'm going to be a politician."
His talent for political marketing was displayed after the August 1991 contest in which the State Elections Council, then dominated by the PRI, awarded a narrow victory to a candidate from that party's old guard, Ramon Aguirre. The lasting image of the campaign is of Mr. Fox, his eyes open wide, leading angry demonstrations with recovered stolen ballots.
With Carlos Salinas de Gortari, the President then, trying to prove himself a democrat to the United States Congress, which had just begun debating Mexico's possible inclusion in the North American Free Trade Agreement, officials in Mexico City forced Mr. Aguirre to resign before he could take office.
The election was the first of several in which Mr. Salinas quelled opposition protests of fraud in a politically expedient but not particularly democratic way. Mr. Salinas chose Mr. Medina, a rival of Mr. Fox's within the PAN, as interim Governor, then used his control of the federal Congress to push through a law that blocked Mr. Fox from running for President before the year 2000 because one of his parents was born abroad.
Mr. Medina has given Mr. Fox crucial help in presiding over the most advanced state election laws in Mexico.
The citizen-counselors of the State Elections Council quietly proved their independence last December, federal and state officials said, when four of its members threatened to resign in order to force out a fifth member aligned with the PRI.
For the first time in a gubernatorial election, poll workers will be able to compare photographs, signatures and fingerprints on the voter rolls to those on the voters' own identification cards. And though there is no formal auditing of campaign spending, both a study by the elections council and estimates by the PAN have indicated that PRI gubernatorial candidate, Ignacio Vazquez Torres, has so far held to the $2.3 million limit. (Mr. Fox said he had spent slightly less than half the $1.5 million that his PRI opponent was thought to have spent by early May.)
Notwithstanding a scandal last month in which supporters of Mr. Vazquez Torres were implicated in a stolen-car ring, the state elections tribunal has received only about a dozen minor reports reports of campaign malfeasance.
By comparison, reports released on May 18 by the election-monitoring group Civic Alliance documented vote-buying, coercion and a huge advantage in television and newspaper advertising by the PRI candidate for the governorship of Yucatan, Victor Cervera Pacheco, a stalwart of the party's old guard. The evidence was especially troubling, opposition officials said, because Mr. Cervera and his PAN challenger, Mr. Mena, have been neck-and-neck in the latest polls.
"Fraud is much more possible in Yucatan," Mr. Fox said. "I don't think it can really happen here."

HEADLINE: New Schools Seeking Small Miracles

SERIES: Multiple Choice: New York's Alternative Schools -- First article of a series

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON and JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
Once they were New York City's sturdy castles of learning, immense neighborhood high schools with as many as 5,000 students each that dependably churned out graduates to sustain the city and, sometimes, transform the world. Colin L. Powell went to Morris High School in the Bronx, Barbra Streisand and Bobby Fischer to Erasmus Hall in Brooklyn, Lewis Mumford to Stuyvesant in Manhattan.
But many of the city's 125 high schools are aging behemoths, seemingly incapable, as the dinosaurs, of adapting to a changing world. With teachers no longer commanding the authority they once did and with some parents unable to correct unruly or drifting children, too many large schools have become academically barren and violent places. 
 Two years ago, the New York City school system came up with a remedy that some say is its most radical change since its decentralization in 1969. And the initiative has moved forward even as major budget cuts have eliminated sports, art and music from many schools.
Forty-eight experimental small schools -- 46 of them high schools with enrollments of 110 to 600 students -- have been started by an unlikely alliance of neighborhood advocates seeking control of their schools, conservatives promoting school choice, educational pioneers eager to test theories and a teachers' union striving to give its members more say in their work lives.
"Our high schools were just too large, and there were a lot of problems with kids not feeling people even knew who they are," said Joseph A. Fernandez, the former Chancellor who set off the wave of small school development in 1992.
The current Chancellor, Ramon C. Cortines, has also supported the initiative, although his support is more tempered. He has warned that small schools are not a panacea and that the city's support for them must not hurt the large high schools, from Stuyvesant to Midwood, that function well and are still attended by a great majority of children.
Fifty more scaled-down schools, not only high schools but elementary and junior highs as well, will soon be on the drawing boards as a result of a $25 million award from the Annenberg Foundation.
The idea behind the new schools is disarmingly simple: Smaller is better.
Break up the impersonal school factory into intimate, more familial academies. Strip away the assistant principals and other layers of bureaucracy, reducing schools to the essentials: a teacher and a small group of students who can more easily know one another. Build teaching around a captivating theme -- building tunnels and bridges, museums, high finance, the environment, foreign languages, singing.
Similar experiments have been tried elsewhere -- and in New York City, two dozen "alternative" high schools for troubled students have sprouted sporadically since 1968. But nowhere has a city started so many small schools so fast and in such variety.
 
Effectiveness
Innovative? Yes. Better? Maybe.
 The big question, of course, is do these schools work?
That answer is distinctly uncertain. Most experimental schools have been operating for only a year or two, so the Board of Education has little data on academic performance. About all that board officials have concluded is that students attend classes more consistently and that these schools are less violent.
"Some of the small schools are just outstanding," said Mr. Cortines. "Others, there's not much education going on, though they're working to make it happen."
Over the last six months, reporters from The New York Times visited 50 of the new schools and, for contrast, 10 of the older alternative schools. They found that some new schools -- like Kingsborough Academy for the Sciences in Brooklyn -- are blossoming, some are just putting down roots and others have been uprooted repeatedly and are struggling. Many have inexperienced supervisors and teachers who are still grappling with fundamentals, while others have attracted seasoned professional staffs.
Kingsborough Academy has had a robust beginning because it has been paired with Kingsborough Community College in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn, and has access to lectures by the college's science professors as well as its gym and laboratories. Its academically challenging program is so popular that it received 4,000 applications for 180 spots.
Yet Vanguard High School, founded in 1993, camped in four different buildings before moving into a permanent home on the Upper East Side in March. The Leadership School on the Lower East Side shares a building with a junior high where discipline is so bad that students regularly run through halls and occasionally light the bulletin boards on fire. One Bronx school devoted to foreign languages started all its students on Japanese and switched to Russian the next year, only to return to Japanese.
Some critics, including Diane S. Ravitch, a former assistant United States secretary of education, and Hanna Rosin, writing in The New Republic, have voiced concerns that classes at several small schools devoted to the study of social justice can border on indoctrination.
Because of their size, the schools' curriculum is limited -- nothing like the palette of sciences at Midwood High in Brooklyn or the seven languages offered at Edward R. Murrow in Brooklyn -- and many courses seem to be still in development.
Monroe Academy for Business and Law, for instance, has no legal courses yet. For next year, the school has readied a course called Street Law, which the principal, Judith Miller, said would teach students "things you need to know to be a citizen, like how to navigate the legal system, how to go to Small Claims Court, things like that."
Almost everywhere, principals of traditional high schools remain skeptical, pointing out that most of the new schools are not trying to qualify their students for the statewide Regents examinations, as comprehensive high schools must do.
"Smaller schools make it possible for kids and teachers to know each other," said Saul Bruckner, Murrow's principal since 1974. "But it's not easy developing a theme school and still providing the fundamentals."
Yet, at many schools, including those founded and run by teachers, staff members find they relish the chance they now have to discuss teaching and to draw on one another's experiences and perspectives.
"Children do want to learn, they do want to make a difference, and so do teachers," said Maura Malarcher, 33, a former volunteer in Indonesia who teaches at the 129-student Renaissance School in Queens. "But so many teachers walk around with 500-pound weights on their back. They have to file a big request just to make a Xerox of something. Here you finally have a sense of ownership as a teacher."
 
Changes
New Themes And Less Testing
 At these boutique schools, incubating in basements of school buildings, churches and neighborhood centers from the northern Bronx to the Rockaways, the bell does not ring every 43 minutes and students do not have three minutes to get to the next class.
At some schools, classes are two hours long and teachers, blessed with only 14 or 15 students, have time to consider a child's math difficulty or to console an adolescent enduring a family crisis.
In many classrooms, students can eat popcorn or chew gum, listen to music through headphones and call teachers by their first names. At Frederick Douglass Academy in Harlem, though, students in uniforms line up for class in silent rows.
Many are trying exciting, often unorthodox lessons. Students at the Museum School in Manhattan recently surveyed the mammal collection at the American Museum of Natural History and wrote essays on the ethics of collecting specimens. The High School for Economics and Finance, in lower Manhattan, taught a course in capitalist finance: "Welcome to Wall Street." Students at the School for the Physical City, in Chelsea, went 750 feet under Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx to view a water tunnel.
Within many new schools, there has been a radical break with the traditional disciplines. In science, for instance, high school students have for decades been taught in yearlong sequential courses -- earth science, biology, chemistry and physics. Some new schools, like the Science Skills Center High School in downtown Brooklyn, still present this curriculum.
But teachers in the experimental movement felt that subjects taught in isolation were quickly forgotten; instead, they offered courses focused on broad themes and projects. In a course whose theme is water, classes may be taught some biology as they study fish, chemistry as they look at river pollution and a smattering of physics as they examine ocean currents.
Driving these schools is the theory that students learn more by directing their own research than by scribbling lecture notes. Blackboard teaching brought results when America was shaping a labor force for the industrial era, the movement's champions argue, but schools must prepare students differently for the more initiative-driven workplace of the information age.
Students may learn a basic concept of geometry like the Pythagorean theorem only if a teacher decides they need to know how to measure the angles of a triangle to complete an assigned project, like designing a model roller-coaster. Otherwise, a student may never hear of the theorem.
Board of Education officials have no way to monitor what concepts are being taught to which students when. Many experimental school directors criticize traditional tests. Students at only 13 of the 30 new high schools that opened in 1993 took even one state Regents test in 1993-1994.
"I was very unhappy," said Martha R. Sutphen, an English teacher who taught at Manhattan Village Academy on the East Side for a year before returning to a more traditional school. "You'd say, 'Take out your books,' and they'd say: 'Why? You don't give us tests; why should we take out our books?' "
And students at the new schools may be taking even fewer tests: the schools are trying to persuade the State Education Department to grant waivers from Regents competency examinations, which all high school students must pass in order to graduate. Instead, many new schools are developing graduation requirements that involve teacher committees' reviews of students' work.
Some educational leaders are criticizing the abandonment of traditional disciplines and tests. "We find students' access to these disciplinary tools to be an indispensable ingredient of quality education," Howard Gardner, a Harvard University professor, wrote in an article last winter he co-authored with an assistant, Veronica Boix-Mansilla. "Shorn of disciplines we become intellectual barbarians."
These small schools must also confront the reality that some colossal high schools do work, offering a cornucopia of courses in an orderly atmosphere and graduating many students with academically taxing Regents diplomas. At Brooklyn high schools like Midwood or John Dewey or at a Queens school like Benjamin N. Cardozo, a combination of effective principals, a close-knit staff, ambitious students and engaging programs still makes for the kind of schooling most New Yorkers over 50 took for granted.
The new schools, however, have begun to recast a few of the most troubled old ones.
Hoary bastions like James Monroe in the Soundview section of the Bronx and Julia Richman on the Upper East Side in Manhattan have been broken up into six distinct schools. Andrew Jackson in Cambria Heights, Queens, is now four schools.
Although Thomas Jefferson in East New York, Brooklyn, and Bushwick High School still carry on, some of their students are being siphoned off by two new schools run by East Brooklyn Congregations, a clergy and neighborhood group whose forte has been building affordable housing.
A common criticism of the new schools is that they are recruiting the highest-achieving children through interviews. While some student bodies are especially talented, at most new schools the accusation of "creaming" appears to be false. About two dozen new schools act like any other neighborhood school, taking students within a district or zone, first come, first served. Most of their students are very low-achieving. Other schools, like the Choir Academy of Harlem, affiliated with the Harlem Boys Choir, use selective admissions.
A computer study of ethnic composition shows that the schools are about as integrated, ethnically, as the rest of the system. At the most segregated new school, the Choir Academy, 92 percent of the students are black. Eight traditional high schools have a higher concentration of black students.
Anthony Alvarado, who sponsored experimental schools over two decades as a superintendent in East Harlem and in lower Manhattan, said of the movement: "There are warts everywhere -- warts in the pedagogy, warts in the staffing, warts on the leadership." But he added: "The small schools have much to teach the rest of the system about knowing children well, and this isn't just touchy-feely stuff. It creates the potential for much more powerful teaching."
 
Politics
Powerful Support Is Fueled by Hope
 It is violence that set off the experiment. Former Chancellor Fernandez authorized several dozen new schools after a 15-year-old shot two fellow students to death in Thomas Jefferson High in Brooklyn in February 1992. He also used the program to address political pressures to create small community-controlled high schools.
For help in designing safer schools, Mr. Fernandez turned to an odd alliance. It included the Fund for New York City Public Education, a private group that channels corporate funds to public schools; Deborah Meier, who founded an East Harlem school in 1985; the Manhattan Institute, a conservative research group; Acorn, a community organization of low-income residents in three boroughs, and East Brooklyn Congregations.
Besides financing from City Hall and the Board of Education, the Annenberg Foundation donated $25 million in September to a coalition that includes the Fund, the Manhattan Institute, Acorn and Ms. Meier's network, the Center for Collaborative Education. It has become fashionable for corporations and philanthropies to adopt an individual school or a nonprofit organization that has helped found schools.
Teachers' union leaders, hopeful the changes can invigorate not only schools but teachers as well, pioneered contract changes -- new in the nation -- that have allowed the new schools to bypass sacrosanct seniority rules in selecting staff.
So far, the new schools are more expensive than other schools, but this is because each is to receive $800,000 in startup money for desks, computers and other equipment, said John J. Ferrandino, the board's chief superintendent for high schools.
The city has spent more than $120 million to build classrooms in leased offices and factories for 22 new schools, at about $10,000 a seat, said Robert Buxbaum, director of the board's facilities division. By contrast, the most recently built high school, Stuyvesant in Manhattan, cost $54,000 a seat.
After City Hall cut the board's long-term construction budget last fall, Mr. Cortines barred the building of any more small schools. He has urged the recipients of the Annenberg grant to divide troubled large schools into small new ones, keeping them in their own buildings to save money.
Robert Berne, dean of New York University's Robert F. Wagner Jr. School of Public Service, who is studying the new schools' finances, contended that any analysis must consider how many students graduate. And by that criteria, he said, they may prove to be cheaper than large schools.
"Most analyses of school cost look at cost per student," Dr. Berne said. "But the real issue is cost per graduate, because these schools may be more successful at educating students."
By 2000, these schools will seat only 50,000 students -- a tiny fraction of the city's projected 1.3 million schoolchildren. Still, hope is strong that these schools can reverse a long cycle of threadbare results.
"These schools work," said Michelle Fine, a social psychologist at the CUNY Graduate Center. "Violence is down; parent involvement is up. And they are holding on to kids with very troubled histories."
TOMORROW: El Puente Academy for Peace and Freedom teaches social justice, and fights charges of indoctrination.
David Gonzalez and David Firestone contributed to this report.

Mr. Gardner was defending traditional disciplines like science and history. He was not also defending standardized tests; he opposes them.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Obtains a Delay On a Shift in Bond Ratings

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
After an unusual last-minute joint plea from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and leaders of the City Council, a major bond-rating agency agreed yesterday to hold off a possible downgrade of the city's bond rating, at least until after the city and state budgets are settled.
Since late last week, city officials have said that New York City's general obligation bonds were in imminent danger of being downgraded from their current A- level -- an action that would be a major embarrassment for the Mayor -- because of the city's difficulty in closing its $3.1 billion budget gap. 
 But yesterday, Richard Larkin, a managing director of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said the Mayor and other city officials had made a convincing argument to the rating agency that any change in the bond rating should come only after final agreement was reached on the city and state budgets. He said Standard & Poor's would keep the city's bonds on what is called negative credit watch, a warning level that the city received in January.
Mr. Larkin said the negative credit watch demonstrates that the agency continues to have serious concerns about holes in the city budget, and would continue to discuss those concerns with city officials in the weeks to come.
The agency's decision was at least a temporary relief for the Mayor, who ran on a platform of restoring order to the city's fiscal accounts and who has proposed two straight years of drastically reduced budgets. A downgrade, in essence, would be a signal of no confidence in Mr. Giuliani's fiscal policies from financial institutions. A statement by the rating firm that the city's bonds were considered a more risky investment could force the city to pay more interest to sell its bonds on the open market.
The Mayor said yesterday that the decision by Standard & Poor's was a "very helpful, very useful step." He said the administration had finally persuaded the agency that his budget plans would eventually slash the city's structural deficit.
But that view contrasted sharply with the gloomy appraisal that Standard & Poor's officials offered today. They said they were still not convinced that the city was headed in the right direction.
"This is not good news for the city," Mr. Larkin said. "We're only waiting until we've seen the whole puzzle."
To avert the political blow of a downgrade, the Mayor has held three meetings with Standard & Poor's officials in recent weeks, two in the last four days. The final meeting, which took place yesterday morning, was particularly remarkable by City Hall standards because Mr. Giuliani took with him two leaders of the City Council. The Mayor and the Council leadership are frequently at odds over budgetary matters, and the joint presentation underscored the importance to the city of preserving its bond rating.
Joining the Mayor in the hourlong meeting with the rating agency were Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker; Herbert E. Berman, chairman of the Council's Finance Committee, and City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, along with staff members. City officials said that by taking the unusual step of adding Council members to the coalition, the Mayor was trying to demonstrate unanimity on the request, even though the two wings of City Hall are deeply divided on how the budget should be cut.
Mr. Vallone said that if not for yesterday's meeting, the agency would have downgraded the city's credit rating. He said that he strongly urged the agency not to do so and that he remains in disagreement with its decision to continue a negative credit watch.
"I don't think they fully understand how committed everyone is to making sure New York City is not a spendthrift city," he said. "Their only job is to tell people how risky our bonds are. Why would anyone be afraid to buy New York City bonds? They're the safest paper on earth."
Both Mr. Vallone and Mr. Giuliani stressed that they were equally committed to balancing the budget, disagreeing only over which services should be cut.
"Although we have differences in how we allocate reductions," the Mayor said, "we don't have a difference in the scope of the problem."
But now that the rating agency has agreed to wait for a final city budget before taking action, the Mayor and the Council are under even more pressure to close the huge gap without resorting to budget gimmicks used in previous years, techniques that would be likely to produce an immediate downgrade.
Mr. Larkin said Standard & Poor's still had strong doubts about several aspects of the Mayor's plans to close the budget gap. Nearly a billion dollars in the Mayor's program depends on assistance from the state, and leaders in Albany have said the city will be lucky to get even half of its request. The city is also counting on $600 million in labor savings that have yet to be negotiated with municipal unions, along with pension fund changes and agency spending cuts still to be worked out with the City Council.
Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a business group, said a downgrade would have little practical effect on the city's finances because the city's bonds are already trading at a low level, as if they had been downgraded.
The real embarrassment of a downgrade would be in casting the city's credit rating near the lowest levels of major cities. If Standard & Poor's had downgraded, Mr. Larkin said, the rating would probably have fallen to BBB+. That is slightly more favorable than the rating of Philadelphia, now at BBB; of Detroit, now at BBB-, and of Washington, which is the worst in the country, at B.

HEADLINE: Budget Dispute Erupts Over Loans and Grants to Businesses

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 22

 BODY:
A new dispute emerged today in negotiations over the state budget, now 52 days late, over whether the State Commissioner of Economic Development should be given greater discretion in giving out tens of millions of dollars in low-interest loans and grants to businesses.
The issue is more about politics than money. The Commissioner, Charles A. Gargano, was campaign finance chairman last year for Gov. George E. Pataki, directing the drive that raised more than $14 million for the Republican candidate. Democrats now suggest that Mr. Gargano is planning to use his new post to reward loyal Republicans and pressure contributors to finance future Republican candidates. 
 Following a midafternoon negotiating session, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, called Mr. Gargano a "political operative" who controls a $142 million "slush fund." He said Governor Pataki had proposed lifting spending guidelines, reporting requirements and other restrictions traditionally imposed by the Legislature on this money, which is earmarked for business-development projects.
"I'm not giving a political operative of the Governor unfettered discretion as to how to spend a significant amount of money in this state," Mr. Silver said, noting that Mr. Gargano had recently appeared with Republican political officials before groups of potential campaign contributors.
But Mr. Gargano said that Mr. Pataki was only trying to remove costly restrictions that his Democratic predecessor, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, also opposed. He said he had not been involved in political fund raising activity recently.
"Was I a political operative during the campaign? Absolutely," Mr. Gargano said in an interview. "Am I one now? Absolutely not."
This is not the first time Mr. Silver has tried to use Mr. Gargano as an example of cronyism in the Pataki administration. In March, the Speaker criticized Mr. Gargano for planning to move some of his department's offices to a midtown Manhattan office condominium that Mr. Silver described as luxurious and frivolous.
The dispute comes as Mr. Pataki, Mr. Silver and the third member of the Albany power triumvirate, the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, Republican of Rensselaer County, are struggling to complete marathon negotiations over the budget.
Though the three leaders said a final agreement was possible this week, they said they remained apart on key issues including health care, education and criminal justice.
In particular, Mr. Pataki and the leaders were at an impasse over a proposal to soften penalties against nonviolent repeat felons, mostly low-level drug dealers, while also lengthening the sentences of violent offenders.
Though all three sides in the budget debate have agreed in concept to the plan, they have disagreed sharply over alternative programs for the nonviolent repeat offenders. Mr. Pataki and Senate Republicans have recommended converting two state psychiatric centers in upstate communities into drug treatment centers for nonviolent, drug-addicted criminals.
But Mr. Silver suggested that those programs were simply a form of pork-barrel spending for Republican districts and said he would like to see alternative programs in other places, though he would not specify where.
Senator Michael F. Nozzolio, a leading proponent of converting the state psychiatric centers, one of which is in his district, said Mr. Silver is advocating a "lax approach" to drug treatment.
"They are suggesting something that does not have appropriate correctional oversight," Mr. Nozzolio, a Republican from Seneca Falls, said. "They are suggesting something where we would lose control."

HEADLINE: Congress Move on Cuba Irks Canada and Mexico

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: TORONTO, May 22

 BODY:
Canada and Mexico have joined forces to defeat proposed American legislation that would tighten the 33-year-old trade embargo against Cuba.
The extra-territorial reach of the bill, which penalizes countries that have commercial ties with Cuba, has brought the protests of the two North American Free Trade Association partners and their unusual cooperation in Washington. 
 In separate letters to members of Congress, the Canadian Ambassador to the United States, Raymond Chretien, nephew of Prime Minister Jean Chretien, and the Mexican Ambassador, Jesus Silva-Herzog, say the measure seeks to regulate what their countries can and cannot do, and they warn of almost certain retaliation.
Concern is so great in Canada that an all-party delegation of members of Parliament is about to take arguments against the bill directly to the halls of Congress.
"We're going to explain how this bill interferes with our sovereignty," said Paul Zed, chairman of the Standing Committee on Industry of the House of Commons.
"It irks a lot of us in Canada, and we're not going to take it lying down," said Mr. Zed, a New Brunswick Liberal who heads the delegation jointly with Bill Graham, a Toronto Liberal who is chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Commons.
The bill, which has strong backing in both houses of Congress, is sponsored by Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who heads the Foreign Relations Committee, and Representative Dan Burton, the Indiana Republican who heads the the House Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs.
Canada and Mexico mainly object to provisions that ban the import of sugar, syrups and molasses from any country that buys these products from Cuba, prohibit American foreign subsidiaries from having any financial dealings with Cuba, and deny entry into the United States of foreign citizens deemed to have had dealings involving property in Cuba expropriated from Americans.
The Globe and Mail has observed tartly that Canadian executives would enter the same prohibited category as political militants and convicted felons.
Sherritt Inc., a Fort Saskatchewan, Alberta, mining company that recently started producing nickel in Cuba, and Delta Hotels and Resorts, with its nine Cuban properties, are among Canadian companies that could be hit by sanctions in the Helms-Burton bill.
Canada and Mexico say the legislation violates undertakings of the United States under both the free trade agreement and the new World Trade Organization.
Beyond the adverse effects on political, trade and economic relations, Ambassador Chretien grumbled, the bill "would undermine the integrity of an international legal system which serves both our countries."
By trying to force trade partners to squeeze Cuba, the bill sets up a secondary boycott, Canada and Mexico argue. But it has long been illegal in the United States for union members to act against an employer to get it to bring pressure on another company. And in international relations the United States has traditionally opposed secondary boycott situations, like Arab pressure on third countries to isolate Israel.
In the Central American-Caribbean region, Cuba is Canada's second largest trading partner after Puerto Rico. Two-way trade was around $220 million last year, with imports and exports almost in balance. Canada chiefly exports food products and imports nickel and sugar.
Mexico's two-way trade was somewhat smaller at $161 million. Mexico imported only $11 million, mainly rum and tobacco. Exports of $150 million included oil and chemical products and detergents and soap. With its own sugar crop, Mexico has not bought sugar from Cuba since 1990.
But the sugar import prohibition raises serious concerns for Canada, which annually exports $500 million worth of products containing sugar to the United States. Much of this commerce is from American-owned subsidiaries like Kraft Canada Inc., which employs 460 in Cobourg, Ontario, and makes cereals and other packaged foods containing sugar. Canada imports about $400 million of American products containing sugar.
So, Canadian officials point out, trade hostilities over Cuba could erase nearly $1 billion of bilateral trade and the thousands of jobs it generates.
"We're not challenging the right of the U.S. to impose an embargo," said Bruno Picard, an aide to the Canadian Trade Minister, Roy MacLaren. "We share similar goals regarding democracy in Cuba and a market-oriented economy. But we disagree on the means to get there. We favor more engagement and dialogue, rather than a boycott."

HEADLINE: Christopher Urging Clinton to Veto a Bill to Cut Foreign Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that he was urging President Clinton to veto a bill in the House of Representatives that would cut foreign aid and eliminate three foreign affairs agencies.
Mr. Christopher, who has spent much of his time during the last several months trying to persuade Congress to leave the foreign affairs budget and agencies alone, said the bill would undermine American leadership in the world and encroach on the President's authority to make foreign policy. 
 In a speech to the Council of the Americas, an association that promotes United States-Latin American relations, Mr. Christopher sounded exasperated about a bill approved last week by the House International Relations Committee that would cut foreign aid by 15 percent during the next two years and abolish the Agency for International Development, the United States Information Agency and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. The full House is scheduled to vote on the bill this week.
The bill would also reverse the Administration's new policy of sending boat people back to Cuba, would cut off aid to Russia if it sells nuclear reactors to Iran, and would require the appointment of a special envoy to Tibet, a move that would enrage China.
Mr. Christopher, who in the past has pursued a cooperative approach toward Congress, spoke with a harsh tone today, saying the bill "wages an extraordinary assault on the President's constitutional authority to manage foreign policy."
His remarks come after many Administration officials acknowledged that they have done too little and acted too late to blunt the Republican offensive to cut the $15 billion foreign aid budget and to restructure the foreign affairs agencies.
One official said Mr. Christopher's remarks are intended in part to persuade Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who heads the Foreign Relations Committee, to negotiate with the Administration on amending bills he is sponsoring that would also reduce foreign aid and abolish the three agencies.
The aide said Mr. Christopher also hoped that his speech might persuade the full House to amend its State Department authorization bill by raising the levels of foreign aid and deleting provisions that conflict with Administration policy on Cuba and Tibet.
Mr. Christopher has sent President Clinton a letter recommending a veto, and the White House has sent a statement to the House saying that Mr. Christopher, Defense Secretary William Perry and Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin will recommend a veto if the bill is presented to the President.
White House officials said that the President shares Mr. Christopher's concerns, but that he wants to see the final bill before deciding whether to veto it.
"Under the cover of budget-cutting, back-door isolationists on the left and the right want to cut the legs off of our leadership," President Clinton said in a recent speech. "We did not win the cold war to walk away and blow the peace on foolish, penny-wise-pound-foolish budgeting."
The Administration's campaign to save foreign aid has stirred little enthusiasm in Congress, partly because overseas aid is, according to many polls, the least popular part of the $1.5 trillion Federal budget.
Yet foreign aid represents just 1 percent of the budget. In campaigning for the aid, the White House often notes that the United States ranks last among 22 major industrial countries in terms of spending on foreign aid as a percentage of its gross domestic product.
Senator Helms and many other Republicans assert that foreign aid has often been squandered on poor nations that have little to show for it despite receiving millions of dollars. Those Republicans contend that, with balancing the budget a priority, the Government can achieve significant savings by cutting foreign aid and eliminating the three foreign policy agencies.
At his daily news briefing, Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman, criticized both the seven-year budget outline approved by the House and the balanced-budget proposal put forward by the Senate Budget Committee. The two together would reduce foreign aid by more than 35 percent.
"They're simply too low to meet the minimum requirements that this country needs as a global power to meet its interests," Mr. Burns said.
At a Senate hearing last week, Mr. Christopher called those budget bills "irresponsible," saying they would force the United States to close many embassies and abandon its policy of having an embassy in every country.
"We cannot support our nation's foreign policy on the cheap," he said. "We cannot protect our interests as the world's most powerful nation if we do not marshal the resources to stand by our commitments."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Trade Dispute Between U.S. and Japan Moves to Paris

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: PARIS, May 22

 BODY:
The United States and Japan brought their bitter trade dispute to the European Continent today, with senior representatives from both sides accusing each other of using misleading figures on Japanese imports of American autos.
A day before the annual ministerial meeting here of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development -- which brings together the foreign, trade and finance ministers of 25 of the wealthiest nations -- Japan's representative to the European Union, Tomohiko Kobayashi, exchanged strong words at a news conference with the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor. 
 Mr. Kantor said the Japanese were trying to confuse the public with their own numbers and present a distorted picture of the realities of their car market. "You are trying to confuse our friends," he said.
Afterward, Mr. Kobayashi asserted that Washington's threatened trade clash with Japan ran the risk of eroding pro-American sentiment in Tokyo and could lead to worsening relations between the two trade superpowers. "There's a very rapid decrease in sympathy for the U.S.," Mr. Kobayashi said.
The barbed exchange was the latest skirmish to follow the United States' decision nearly a week ago to impose 100 percent tariffs on imported Japanese luxury cars after representatives of the two sides failed to reach agreement in talks to open Japan's markets for American-made cars and parts.
The dispute has placed the O.E.C.D.'s meeting under a cloud, overshadowing its semiannual economic forecast, which showed growth slowing, over all, in its 25 countries.
At the Royal Monceau Hotel here in the stylish 8th arrondissement of Paris, not far down a broad road from the Arc de Triomphe, Japanese officials were setting up their own version of a trade war room. Scores of these officials occupied offices on three floors, for the Trade, Economic and Foreign ministries, giving extensive interviews and having early meetings with their counterparts in the O.E.C.D. The purpose was to make sure that Japan's analysis of its auto market would be widely circulated.
Among the early discussions, Japanese representatives talked with Mexican officials, hoping to win their support and apply pressure on the United States from a member of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
"The Japanese car market is not well understood," said Yoshihiro Sakamoto, a vice minister in the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. "There has been a lack of effort by American car companies to penetrate the Japanese car market."
Mr. Sakamoto said that contrary to assertions by the United States, Japan's market was open and the United States' problem was simply that its auto makers had not done a good job in penetrating the mass market, particularly compact and subcompact cars with engines smaller than 2 liters. He noted that 80 percent of the Japanese car market consisted of such small cars and argued that no Big Three auto maker offering American-made autos in Japan of that size. American officials say they are trying to sell 51 models of such cars in Japan.
The Japanese have come here ready to argue. They have brought the International Trade Ministry's ranking automobile expert, Atsushi Oi, to rebut numbers used by Mr. Kantor and his aides.
Mr. Oi contends that in the big-car market -- cars with engines larger than 3 liters -- the Americans have done well selling to Japanese, capturing 28.4 percent of the market. But that market accounts for less than 3 percent of the 6.5 million cars sold in Japan each year.
Last Tuesday, the United States said it would enforce 100 percent tariffs on 13 luxury cars from Japan with annual import value of $6 billion, unless an agreement on the Japanese auto market could be reached by June 28.
In many previous disputes, Japan has yielded at the 11th hour, but its hard stand in the last few days has made many here doubt that it will accommodate Washington's strong-arm tactics. For example, Japanese officials have repeatedly said they would take part in no more joint talks with Washington on car imports until the United States removed the threat of sanctions. Otherwise, Mr. Sakamoto reiterated today, Tokyo would take its case to the World Trade Organization.
The O.E.C.D. said in its economic report that it had lowered its overall growth forecast because of lower-than-expected growth in Japan.
It estimated the overall increase for its 25 nations at 2.7 percent this year and next, after adjusting for inflation. In December, the group forecast growth at 3 percent in 1995 and 2.9 percent in 1996.
The organization cut its estimate for Japan's growth almost in half, to 1.3 percent from 2.5 percent.
One of the chief reasons for the slowdown was an overly strong Japanese yen, which makes Japanese exports more expensive, reducing demand for them.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Clinton's Aid To Industry Is A G.O.P. Target

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
Buried among the Republicans' sharp cost-cutting proposals to balance the Federal budget is the swift dismantling of two of the Clinton Administration's most prominent economic innovations: the use of the Government to promote exports and the underwriting of new technologies that corporate America considers too risky.
During his Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton briefly called those strategies "industrial policy," until Republicans seized on the phrase as proof that Mr. Clinton wanted the Government to meddle in the workings of the market. Once in office, the White House dropped the terminology but went ahead anyway with an aggressive program, declaring that the United States needed to develop partnerships with industry and use Government pressure to promote exports, two skills that Japan and Germany turned into an art after World War II. 
 The Republican budget proposals would bring many of those efforts to a halt and drastically shrink others, from the Energy Department to the Pentagon. The most sweeping cutback proposal, the "The Department of Commerce Dismantling Act," is scheduled to be introduced on Tuesday by House Republicans. The act would immediately terminate six of the Cabinet department's offices and slice up the organization that provides the skills for trade negotiations with Japan, China and several other nations.
Many functions of the Commerce Department's highest-profile organization, the International Trade Administration, would be carved up or eliminated. It is unclear what would happen to the economic "war room" that calls in ambassadors, Cabinet secretaries and sometimes the President to put pressure on foreign governments to buy American goods.
Curiously, the White House has said almost nothing in public about the attack on the core of its economic strategy, partly for fear that it would detract from its warnings about proposed cuts to Medicare and other popular social programs.
"We've talked through what is the best approach, and the decision was to stay focused on the programs that most people understand," said Hazel R. O'Leary, the Secretary of Energy, whose department's budget would shrink by roughly $7 billion over the next five years.
"It's a little early," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the National Economic Council, an office that was created at the start of the Administration to give economics equal weight with issues of national security. "There should be a good debate about the wisdom of this, but it is still early in the budget process."
It may be early, but it seems clear that most of the trade and technology promotion programs will be sharply reduced, if they survive at all.
As a result, the White House's reticence has not kept the departments themselves from starting all-out survival campaigns. Capitol Hill these days is flooded with under secretaries and assistant secretaries explaining and justifying programs that have never before come under intense scrutiny.
Many of those programs were started under Republican administrations. The theme of the presentations often boils down to one argument: In an age of economic conflict, cutting out political and economic support for industry is the equivalent of unilateral disarmament.
"Our global competitors are laughing at us," Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown said today in a telephone conversation from Paris, where he is attending a meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. "Just at the moment when we've finally learned that there is no way to win without a public-private partnership, without getting the Government involved in promoting a nation's exports, people are incredulous that Congress would be doing this.
"The French are apoplectic that we have been so pro-active and successful," Mr. Brown said, a reference to Washington's role in winning a huge contract in Brazil last year over French competition. "And now they are delighted that we are thinking about not doing it anymore."
The Republican theory is that the Commerce Department has become a brazen example of "corporate welfare," a term coined by one of Mr. Clinton's Cabinet members and close friends, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich. To the White House's horror, the phrase -- which Mr. Reich has not repeated since -- has become a rallying call for the freshman class of Republicans, who do not share their party's traditional closeness or dependence on big business.
"There are 19 different departments in the Government that deal with trade," said Representative Dick Chrysler, the Michigan Republican who drafted the legislation to dismantle the Commerce Department 92 years after its creation. "They could all be reduced to a single Department of Trade."
Another target of Mr. Chrysler's is the department's Advanced Technology Program, which provides backing for technologies that small companies -- and some large ones -- consider promising but too risky to attempt. "This has grown from $10 million in 1990 to $250 million in 1993, and now they want $750 million," Mr. Chrysler said. "This is nothing other than picking winners and losers."
Such arguments underscore the sharp difference in the way technology and trade policy is dealt with in Washington and in the capitals of its major economic competitors, where trade is considered national security and "picking winners and losers" is a phrase with no political resonance.
In Japan and Germany, there is virtually no debate over government programs to provide seed money for risky technologies or to use the influence of top officials to win contracts. It is taken as a given that such roles fall to the central government, along with defending the nation's territory and making foreign policy.
In Japan, for example, officials will freely acknowledge that more than 50 percent of the money committed to new technologies will result in utter failure. But even a 20 percent success rate, they argue, should be considered a success. No one would even attempt such an argument in Washington.
"You can't go up on the Hill and talk about a 40 percent success rate, even if that is a brilliant performance," Ms. O'Leary said last week. "People will say: 'What? We are throwing away 60 percent?"
Instead, Ms. O'Leary's department has been churning out news releases about its industrial breakthroughs in energy conservation. A giant sulfur lamp now hangs over the Energy Department's entrance on Constitution Avenue, a single light that replaces 250 bulbs. "It was developed with $1 million in Government money and much more in private funds," she said. "That is hardly a waste."
On the Hill, though, no one wants to talk about sulfur lamps, unless they are designed to illuminate a balanced budget. "This is the tail-wagging-the-dog syndrome," Mr. Chrysler said. "If it is a good invention, let the private sector invent it."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan's Auto Makers Feel Bite of U.S. Tariff

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, May 23

 BODY:
The high tariff imposed by the Clinton Administration on Japanese luxury cars imported into the United States has begun to bite, forcing Japanese companies to suspend exports and cut production.
The Mazda Motor Corporation and the Honda Motor Company said today that they had temporarily halted exports to the United States of the models that would be subject to the 100 percent tariff. 
 The Nissan Motor Corporation said it was considering cutting its production and exports of the affected cars starting in June.
The Administration imposed the 100 percent tariff on 13 Japanese luxury car models after the United States and Japan failed to reach an agreement aimed at increasing sales of American automobiles and parts in Japan. The tariff, which will affect American-bound exports valued at $5.9 billion annually, will formally take effect on June 28, but it is to be applied retroactively to last Saturday.
Luxury-car exports, while small in number, are very profitable for the Japanese companies. As the yen has risen, auto makers have shifted production of less expensive cars overseas, leaving only expensive cars that can be made profitably in Japan.
The Clinton Administration is counting on the sanctions to break the resistance of the Japanese companies to developing voluntary plans for increasing their purchases of foreign automobile parts.
The companies still say they will not back down, but auto executives are expressing doubts about the hard line taken by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry in the negotiations with the United States.
The companies can ill afford more cutbacks in production because domestic sales and exports have been declining for a few years, leaving a huge overcapacity in Japan.
Because of the high yen, Mazda, which has reported big losses, has already cut in half its exports of all cars to the United States, to about 10,000 vehicles for the quarter from April to June. Its two luxury models subject to the sanctions, the 929 and Millenia, account for about 20 to 25 percent of those exports, or as few as 1,000 cars a month.
Nissan, the second-largest auto company behind the Toyota Motor Corporation, makes 5,000 or so a month of the three Infiniti models subject to the tariff. A spokesman said the company had a 60-day supply in the United States.
Honda said it had stopped exporting its Acura Legend to the United States as of last weekend and was considering reducing production of the vehicle, but had not made a final decision.
Toyota, the largest and financially strongest Japanese auto maker, said it was continuing to ship its Lexus luxury vehicles. A spokesman said the company wanted to keep supporting its American dealers and was hopeful that in the end the sanctions would not be imposed.
Mitsubishi Motors, which is in a somewhat better position, is continuing to ship its Diamante to the United States. The Diamante that is subject to the tariff is in the last stages of its model life. The new model is expected to be produced in Australia, which might allow the company to export to the United States and avoid the tariff.
