HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices for Bonds End Mixed Ahead of Fed Policy Session

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday in thin trading in advance of today's meeting of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee and this week's auctions of new Treasury securities.
The 30-year bond rose 1/32 , to a price of 10829/32for a yield of 6.91 percent, down from 6.92 percent on Friday, while bills of shorter maturity were a bit weaker. Bills with maturities ranging from three months to one year rose as much as 3 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 Though the Open Market Committee is the Fed's policy-making arm, few market participants expect it to make any shift in short-term interest rates at this session. Eric Hamilton, a senior fixed-income analyst with the Technical Data Corporation in Boston, said the market was just plodding along yesterday, with many market participants already looking ahead to the three-day holiday weekend.
With stocks on the rebound yesterday, some investors who retreated to the shelter of credit markets last week may have moved back into equities, he noted. Also, traders said that there was some downward pressure on Treasury securities from the issuance of more corporate debt, which competes with the Treasury market for investor cash, as well as from the $75 billion of new Treasury securities to be sold this week.
"Demand does not show overwhelming retail interest right now, at least not as strong as it normally would be," Mr. Hamilton said, adding, "The low yields we see in the market may very well keep investor interest at the auctions to a minimum."
Mr. Hamilton called yesterday's bill auction "just plain vanilla, with average demand or a little less, given the expensive nature of Treasury securities." The three-month bill was sold at an average discount rate of 5.72 percent, up one basis point from last week; the six-month issue came at the same average rate, 5.72 percent, up 3 basis points from the previous week.
Traders saw some weakness in intermediate-term notes ahead of this week's auctions. Today the Government will sell $17.75 billion in two-year notes.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the new two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.23 percent and the five-year notes at a price to yield 6.46 percent. "Yields have backed up a bit since last week," Mr. Hamilton said.
Tomorrow the Government will sell $11.5 billion of new five-year notes and on Thursday $18.25 billion of one-year bills. Yesterday, the rate for a one-year bill was 5.67 percent. With buyers in no rush to acquire securities that some already consider pricey, dealers have had to sweeten or raise the yields on the new note supply.
In the corporate bond market, where sales have picked up in recent weeks to take advantage of the lower rate environmnent, the AT&T Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday to sell as much as $3 billion of debt to pay for several recent acquisitions and future growth.
With the return between corporate and Treasury debt securities widening, the American General Corporation, an insurer, and Pacificorp, a utility holding company, also plan to sell debt this week.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: 10 Companies Join in Effort to Lower Bids by H.M.O.'s

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
More than 100 health maintenance organizations are bidding this week for a chance to offer standardized health coverage to 240,000 employees of 10 big companies. The bidding is the employers' latest effort to push the H.M.O.'s to lower prices and let employer groups monitor the care provided by doctors and hospitals.
By banding together and offering $1 billion in combined buying power in 27 markets, the 10 employers hope to duplicate the successes of regional employer coalitions in a growing number of metropolitan areas, notably Minneapolis and San Francisco. 
 Michael Sydlaske, a principal with the William M. Mercer consulting firm, said that tomorrow was the deadline for bids from the H.M.O.'s.
The bidding is the first move by a new national health care purchasing coalition. Participants said 10 more big employers were considering joining the original 10 in the buying group.
"It could be as big as we want to make it," LuAnn Cash, a vice president of American Express, said. Still, the organizers said they wanted to stay relatively small to avoid the conflicts that typically plague large coalitions.
In a separate move, some of the same employers are working on plans with other big companies to negotiate with Government-financed Medicare H.M.O.'s to cover their retirees .
The 10 companies are expanding a program begun by American Express and Merrill Lynch & Company, which joined with Macy's in 1993 to negotiate jointly with H.M.O.'s in the New York area, Atlanta, California, Florida and Texas. The participants now include Sears, Roebuck, International Business Machines, the ITT Corporation, Marriott International, Pfizer Inc., and Nabisco Inc., the RJR Nabisco spinoff. Two other companies have asked not to be identified. Macy's dropped out after it was acquired by Federated Department Stores.
Jim Bronson, benefits director of Sears, said the coalition requested bids from the H.M.O.'s on April 26. He said Sears, where about 80,000 of the 115,500 employees and dependents are enrolled in H.M.O.'s in the 27 markets, expected to add to its roster of competing H.M.O.'s. Those already involved include Kaiser Permanente, U.S. Healthcare, United Healthcare, Cigna, Aetna and a number of Blue Cross plans.
Sears is involved in a separate program with the Towers Perrin consulting firm to move retirees into Medicare H.M.O.'s. Mr. Bronson said that some Sears retirees in Florida, California and Arizona had already joined Medicare H.M.O.'s.
Bob Dankmyer, a vice president of Marriott, said the H.M.O. purchasing group was an offshoot of a larger group of employers who provide coverage for 3.5 million people. He said some did not offer H.M.O.'s but they wanted to meld their purchasing power in negotiating for less tightly organized types of managed health care, including physician networks and modified H.M.O.'s that permit enrollees to pick their own doctors if they pay more for doing so.
Sean Sullivan, president of the National Business Coalition of 85 employer groups, said that half did some joint purchasing, often bypassing health insurers and dealing directly with hospitals. "Houston is the latest example," he said. Coalitions in San Francisco and the Minneapolis-St. Paul area were among the first. There are also purchasing groups in Orlando, Fla., Cleveland, Cincinnati and St. Louis.
John Brence, a vice president of Merrill Lynch, said company officials had formed their coalition after discussions with Alain Enthoven, an economist at Stanford University, who advocates competition to make health care more efficient.
Dr. Lonny Reisman, a cardiologist with the William M. Mercer consulting firm, visits the health maintenance organizations and audits their procedures for assuring good quality care. Merrill Lynch and American Express have frozen enrollment in several H.M.O.'s that were judged deficient in the quality monitoring.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up Against Yen on Hope For Reduction in Trade Deficit

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar surged to a seven-week high against the Japanese yen yesterday, bolstered by optimism that Washington's confrontation with Tokyo over automotive trade would help cut the United States trade deficit.
The dollar also received support from a sharp fall in the Japanese stock market. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 351.73 points, or 2.18 percent, dragged down by concerns about weak corporate earnings. The decline prompted currency dealers to sell yen, which increased the demand for dollars. 
 "The dollar has really gained some ground versus the yen," said Michael Faust, a foreign exchange strategist at Bailard, Beihl & Kaiser, a money management concern in San Mateo, Calif. "The sanctions and the stock market plunge helped the dollar stay afloat."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 87.35 yen from 86.74 yen on Friday. The dollar slipped to 1.4410 German marks from 1.4440 marks.
The performance of the dollar elsewhere in the foreign exchange market was mixed, marked by thin trading that may have exaggerated price movements. Trading was light ahead of a meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy makers. While the market has already assumed that the Fed will not raise short-term interest rates at a meeting today, many dealers were exercising caution yesterday.
Also supporting the dollar against the yen yesterday were further comments by American officials that Japan must open its auto market or face sanctions.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said yesterday that the sides were "not even close to agreement" on the auto trade.
Mr. Kantor pledged to follow through with threatened sanctions, which would impose a 100 percent import duty on $6 billion of the most popular Japanese luxury cars. The sanctions will take effect on June 28, but are retroactive to May 20.
The Secretary of Commerce, Ronald H. Brown, also said the United States was serious about the sanctions and "it wasn't just rhetoric."
After those comments, Japan's Ambassador to the European Union in Brussels, Tomohiko Kobayashi, said Washington's moves on trade threatened to erode pro-American sentiment in Japan.
Cars and auto parts account for almost two-thirds of Japan's $66 billion trade surplus with the United States. That imbalance has been seen as an important underlying reason for the dollar's long-term erosion against the yen, because it means Japanese exporters have enormous amounts of dollars that they must sell when repatriating profits.

HEADLINE: Albany's Unsound Tax Cuts

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki and the Democrats in the New York State Legislature have reached agreement on an income tax cut that should help resolve the divisive budget battles of 1995 on terms that both sides can claim as some sort of victory. But their agreement will undermine New York's financial integrity. While scaled back from Mr. Pataki's original proposal, the tax cut is still too drastic to be carried out without further rupturing state services and aid to localities.
Mr. Pataki originally proposed a phased tax cut that would have ballooned in size to nearly $7 billion annually in four years, with no convincing strategy for curbing costs to pay for the revenue loss. He relied on the same wishful premises that have led to record deficits in Washington: that tax cuts would pay for themselves by stimulating economic growth. Some tax relief is needed to help economic development in New York State, but only if instituted carefully and targeted on taxes that dampen the business climate. The state has lost hundreds of thousands of jobs despite steep cuts in the income tax since 1987. 
 The tax cut accord reportedly worked out in Albany will be less costly in terms of revenue loss for the next fiscal year than Mr. Pataki's original proposal. It will grow in four years to only half the size of the Governor's proposal in terms of lost revenues. But there is still no way it can be paid for unless there is a boom in the state's economy, an extraordinary drop in the cost of welfare and Medicaid in the next few years -- and a willingness by state political leaders to carry out cuts rejected this year in education, higher education, mental health programs and other state services.
The Democrats are in a triumphant mood because they have forced Mr. Pataki to make the tax cut more progressive. But the Democrats have also trapped themselves. The tax relief for the wealthy is to be carried out in the first year, leaving relief for the middle- and lower-income groups for the subsequent two years, when it will be hard for Democrats to stomach the spending cuts, especially for the poor, that may be needed to pay for them.
The state should not be locking itself into multi-year tax cuts. Such an approach has attractions for Republicans who argue it is the only way to exact discipline on the spending side. But other Governors, including Christine Todd Whitman in New Jersey, have carried out tax-cut pledges one year at a time. New York, which already has one of the lowest credit ratings of any state, is in no condition to enact tax cuts that will throw its finances into structural imbalance for years to come.

HEADLINE: Crippling American Science

 BODY:
The budget plan passed by the House mounts an assault on scientific research, science training and American research universities that are the envy of the world. Blinded by ideological fury at government, House Republicans seek to abandon a crucial function of government, the provision of public goods like research that are undersupplied by private markets. Private companies will invest in research that is likely to raise their profit, but they are unwilling to invest in research whose benefits leak out to competitors. By abandoning government's irreplaceable role, the House budget would undermine America's technological base.
The magnitude of the House-passed cuts is shocking. Civilian research would fall over five years from about $32 billion to $25 billion, a 35 percent cut after accounting for inflation. Medical research, other than for AIDS, would fall by more than 25 percent. Robert Walker, chairman of the House Science Committee, says the plan would protect basic science. He dissembles. His budget would increase spending on research by the National Science Foundation. But the small increases would not keep pace with inflation, so the number of university-based scholars, graduate students and research projects that the N.S.F. supports would steadily fall. Indeed the plan envisions wiping out support for social science research. 
 The House budget would continue to support the space shuttle and space station, two costly hardware projects with constituencies in key electoral states, but it would provide little money for other aeronautical and space research. It would cut several energy research programs by between 35 and 80 percent -- eliminating thousands of university jobs -- and reduce research on high-speed rail and other transportation projects. Republicans say their cuts eliminate only applied research that business can undertake for itself, but they propose slashing nearly every program in sight.
Not all the research that Washington pays for makes sense. Some university-based research can sound ridiculously abstruse. But there is danger in indiscriminately chopping research and undermining a system that has for decades produced the best scientists and graduate programs in the world. The sectors in which America has led the world -- from computers and software to agriculture and aircraft manufacturing -- can trace their success to heavy Federal support.
Mr. Walker could have performed a valuable service by carefully sifting through Federal programs to weed out those that needlessly subsidize corporations for research and development projects that they would undertake for themselves. But massive cutting just to reach a balanced budget quickly risks damaging important economic assets.
The party that preaches cost-benefit analysis for Federal agencies ought to practice what it preaches. Cutting the science budget will save a few billion dollars a year in a $6 trillion economy. Knocking out innovative research can lead to stagnant productivity and growth. By that calculation, the House plan is an irresponsible gamble.

HEADLINE: How to Save Social Security

BYLINE: By Bob Kerrey and Alan K. Simpson 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Because we belong to opposing parties, the public might presume that we disagree on everything. But there is one critical matter on which we find common ground. We both believe that the time has come to re-examine some of the fundamental premises of the Social Security system. This is Social Security's 60th anniversary year. The needs of retired Americans have changed radically in six decades. Social Security deserves radical change, too.
Last week, we introduced legislation that would transform what is now a consumption-based system into a system that encourages savings and investment. Our bill would allow workers to divert nearly one-third of the employee's share of the Social Security payroll tax into a private I.R.A.-type account or an investment fund modeled after the thrift savings plan offered to Government employees. 
 The plan would also allow one-fourth of the Social Security Trust Fund to be conservatively invested by the fund's managing trustee in equities instead of the Treasury bonds to which they are limited by current law.
When combined with other reforms, this approach would yield at least three major benefits. First, it would give individuals greater control over how they plan for retirement. Second, it would help rescue the Social Security system so that all Americans know with certainty that a promise made is a promise kept. Third, it could increase private savings of 139 million working Americans by nearly $1 trillion over the next decade -- restoring the savings base on which healthy economies are built and maintained.
Last year, an estimated 139 million working Americans and their employers pumped $345 billion into the Social Security system. Under current trends, many of the 139 million have no reasonable expectation of receiving full benefits from the pension fund when they retire. Social Security has hundreds of billions of dollars in unfunded promises it will be unable to pay when the system goes bust in just over three decades.
The main reason is this: Social Security was designed as a consumption-based, not a savings-based, program -- a system under which each generation of workers pays taxes to support the previous generation in return for a promise that the next generation will, in turn, support it.
The system works provided that each generation has enough children to underwrite benefits. The baby-boom generation is producing proportionately fewer children. Today, there are nearly five workers paying taxes to support each retiree; when the baby boomers retire, there will be fewer than three.
The consequences of having a consumption-based system grounded on a 60-year-old demographic assumption that no longer holds true are clear. Without reforms, by the year 2012 every dollar the Government collects in taxes will go directly to spending on entitlements and interest on the national debt. A year later, in 2013, Social Security will begin running a deficit instead of a surplus.
Eighteen years after that, the entire system will be bankrupt -- around the time that workers in their late 20's today retire. Because there will be nothing but the payroll taxes of a small generation of workers available to finance the benefits of the large generation of retirees, our children would be forced to slash benefits dramatically or impose a huge tax increase on themselves.
Fixing this requires going beyond traditional proposals to raise taxes or cut benefits or a combination of the two. The nation must re-examine the consumption-based premise of the program. If it wants to save Social Security, it needs to start putting Social Security into savings.
Our plan includes reforms designed to restore long-term solvency to the system and leave room to begin a shift toward a savings-based approach. One reform would gradually raise the age of full eligibility for Social Security from 67 to 70, a change that reflects the growth in life expectancy since the eligibility age was first set at 65 six decades ago. The change would not affect anyone over the age of 51 today.
In addition, an independent panel would be asked to assess the accuracy of the Consumer Price Index, which is used to determine the size of cost-of-living adjustments. Most economists agree that the index generously overstates the inflation rate. Our bill would also limit cost-of-living adjustments; the top 70 percent would get only partial protection from inflation.
Allowing workers to invest nearly a third of their contributions in alternative investments would bring benefits to the economy. The United States has one of the lowest rates of private savings in the industrialized world, in part because most of the $345 billion pumped each year into Social Security is spent for everyday living expenses by retirees.
 Our international competitors understand the importance of savings; the payoff is clear in the strength of their economies and currencies. Japan, a creditor nation, saves nearly 20 percent of its gross domestic product. Germany, also a net creditor, saves more than 10 percent.
The United States, by contrast, saves less than 5 percent; worse, a big percentage of those savings are consumed by Government borrowing and therefore are not available for the private investment that creates jobs and wealth. Because we consume so much and save so little, America must borrow abroad; this has converted us from a creditor to a debtor nation in less than a generation.
We both believe that diverting part of the payroll tax to private investment plans would radically alter the entire culture of savings. Those who for the first time have large pools of private savings would be likely to see their value and begin to contribute more and more to them. Such a system would allow individuals the substantial benefits of compounding interest, which Social Security, as currently constituted, denies them, and would give the economy the benefits of a new foundation of savings that can restore our status as a creditor nation.
There are a variety of options for repairing Social Security, and both of us are open to suggestions. But one thing is clear. As our society's demography shifts and our population ages, social insurance in which one generation of retirees consumes the next generation's taxes will simply not hold up. Everyone is going to have to start saving more and saving earlier.
Savings has always been a foundation of a healthy economy. In an aging America, it's also an imperative for secure retirement. Making Social Security partly into a savings-based program means that we can build on its successes and strengthen this monumental legislative achievement for future generations and our evolving economy.

GRAPHIC: Cartoon

HEADLINE: Japanese Too Suffer From Trade Barriers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Trading War: No Way Out?" (front page, May 17): 
 There is no doubt that there are trade barriers in Japan against foreign imports.
Many Japanese industry professionals, economists and journalists have been raising their voices vigorously to lift those barriers as soon as possible.
Also, many Japanese consumers would appreciate more foreign products, ranging from gasoline and natural gas to American Jeeps and candies, at lower prices. They know that the costs are too high because of Government regulations, industry practices, and markups by big importers (mostly large corporations) and at each stop in the distribution. They pay all these costs. So, no doubt, Japanese consumers support a more open market policy.
Many economists say, to revitalize the market economy and survive in a globalized economy, it is essential for Japan to "liberate its market" to all countries.
Japan has been missing leadership for this task.
Japanese consumers travel to foreign countries and enjoy shopping where they can buy goods at less expensive prices, even products made in Japan.
However, United States enforcement obligating Japanese automobile companies to buy a defined number of American auto parts is not the appropriate course to persuade the Japanese people who want their markets freer and have been good allies of the Americans.
It only causes feeling of rejection of American power politics.
The Japanese media tend to interpret it as a campaign gimmick by the Clinton Administration to buy votes in Detroit for the 1996 election.
The United States Government must tell the Japanese its true objectives -- open the Japanese market for mutual benefit for both nations, instead of political gain for the Administration.
 
NORIO SATO
New York, May 18, 1995
 
The writer is a consultant to United States and Japanese businesses.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Chief Says Mexican Crisis Has Eased

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
The managing director of the International Monetary Fund said today that the Mexican financial crisis had been reduced to controllable proportions.
"I am confident the crisis has turned into a manageable problem," the top official, Michel Camdessus, told a meeting here of the Council of the Americas. Problems remain, Mr. Camdessus acknowledged, but "Mexico is headed toward recovery," he said, if it sticks with its economic austerity program. 
 He listed a number of encouraging signs that the recovery plan had taken hold. Mexico's trade balance moved from continuing deficits to a surplus in the first quarter of 1995, the peso has recouped some of its losses and domestic interest rates have eased, he said.
Mexico has been struggling to pull out of its worst financial crisis in more than a decade, set off in December by a badly bungled devaluation of the peso.
The Mexico City stock market rose sharply yesterday, with the main index jumping 78.67 points, or 3.91 percent, to 2,090.93.
Last week, though, Mexico's Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, said the Mexican economy was expected to contract sharply in the second and third quarters after a deceivingly mild decline in the first three months of the year. "I think unemployment and economic contraction will get worse before they get better," he said in a speech in Washington.

SECTION: Section C; Page 13; Column 2; Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 2643 words

HEADLINE: Gray Eminence of Classical Music's Stars

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
He wields classical music's biggest baton, conducting conductors, orchestrating orchestras, giving voice to vocalists. But his name is not to be found on concert hall marquees or opera kiosks. When it comes to publicity, Ronald A. Wilford is happy to be Orpheus's silent partner.
As president of Columbia Artists Management Inc., the world's leading classical music booking and talent agency, the silver-haired Mr. Wilford casts a long shadow from the music canyon of West 57th Street to premier concert stages in New York, Philadelphia, Los Angeles, Berlin, Vienna, Tokyo and other music capitals. His many top clients -- who commonly pay commissions of 10 to 20 percent -- include James Levine, Kurt Masur, Seiji Ozawa, Valery Gergiyev, Leontyne Price, Jose Carreras, Marilyn Horne, Kathleen Battle, Yehudi Menuhin and Andre Previn, along with a fair number of the world's leading orchestras. 
 Yet Mr. Wilford remains a cryptic figure who ridicules accounts of his power, even as he uses his vast knowledge of the business to drive hard bargains for his clients. "Publicity does not help me," he said in an alternately grumpy and playful conversation in which he parried most questions and declined to be interviewed at greater length. "I do not run a public institution."
Recent events, however, have focused attention on Columbia Artists -- known throughout the classical world as CAMI -- and the man who has run it unchallenged for 25 years.
Early this year, one of Mr. Wilford's top music managers joined a substantial list of former CAMI executives when he jumped -- or was pushed -- out of the agency. The exit of David Foster, who left CAMI after 22 years to become president of the rival ICM Artists, has raised the question of succession at CAMI, where Mr. Foster, 48, was widely considered a prime candidate to take over for the 67-year-old Mr. Wilford.
In 1993, Peter Gelb, whom Mr. Wilford called his only protege, went with Columbia Artists' classical music video unit when it was bought by Sony. ("He didn't leave," Mr. Wilford quipped. "I sold him.") And several other managers have left amid accounts of feuding among the agency's 18 semi-autonomous divisions.
Besides the threat a stronger ICM presents, CAMI is encountering a growing challenge, especially abroad, from another relative newcomer to the field, I.M.G. Artists, North America, a spinoff of the hugely successful billion-dollar-a-year sports management agency, International Management Group.
Mr. Wilford, for his part, professes indifference to any and all of this.
Why did Mr. Foster leave? "Simple," he said in the brief telephone talk. "We have a contract policy. David Foster was not under contract so he could leave anytime."
Retirement plans? "I'm in retirement."
And finally: "I'm very unimportant."
Mr. Wilford's success has not come on the strength of his musical training; indeed, he has none. Rather, associates say, he has demonstrated near-perfect pitch in recognizing talent and matching music director and orchestra: "picking winners," as one put it.
Others cite his commanding grasp of the industry and all the minutiae of drawing contracts and touring orchestras. "He knows every fact and figure," said Julie Kedersha, who worked at CAMI before opening her own agency. "He can calculate mileage and gas and how much the hotel is. He can go as fast as your calculator."
If you could match his mastery and prove him wrong, she said, "he'd back down." But if not, she said, "he'd eat you alive."
Associates call his nonchalance a cover, a mind-game for someone long enamored of psychotherapy, just, they say, as his oft-proclaimed penchant for privacy seems to invite scrutiny. "He cares very deeply about the artists he represents and his company," said Caroline Smedvig, marketing director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and a longtime friend.
But she said Mr. Wilford saw no client benefit in his being seen as "a nice guy," and was actually amused by his image as "the black knight of 57th Street."
Interviews over recent weeks with dozens of industry figures offer no dispute that Columbia Artists, with headquarters in an Italianate mansion across from Carnegie Hall, remains the giant of classical music, with a current roster of some 800 clients and a total of some 3,000 artists represented over the last 65 years.
It is heir to a management empire built by the redoubtable Arthur Judson. From 1930 to 1935, he managed the Philadelphia and New York Philharmonic Orchestras and the Lewisohn Stadium concerts in Manhattan. He was also was a radio pioneer who became the second-largest stockholder in William S. Paley's Columbia Broadcasting System and the sole owner of Columbia Records, while at the same time running a lucrative concert-management bureau that consolidated with other agencies to become what is now CAMI in 1930. Judson also created a revolutionary unit called Community Concerts, which organized local audiences around the country for lucrative pre-paid bookings featuring the agency's own contract artists.
Mr. Wilford, the son of a Greek janitor and his Mormon wife in Salt Lake City, went into business with another arts manager in New York before striking out on his own. In 1955, he staked his savings on the first American tour of the French mime Marcel Marceau. Mr. Marceau was a smash, and Mr. Wilford, building on that success, mastered the business of touring attractions.
In 1956, he married Janice Roberts, who worked at Columbia Artists. It was Mr. Wilford's second marriage, and three years later he joined the agency as Judson's protege. When Judson left CAMI in 1963 to start a new management venture, Mr. Wilford chose to remain, and succeeded to the presidency in 1970.
 
RELATIONSHIPS
Selecting a Stable Of Favorite Clients
 Not all of Mr. Wilford's relationships with artists have gone smoothly.
A dispute between CAMI and the pianist Andre Watts landed in court in 1990 after a disaffected Mr. Watts sought to reroute commissions through his new agent, I.M.G. Artists. After countersuing for nearly $300,000 and portraying Mr. Watts unflatteringly in court papers as money-driven, CAMI won a judgment in a suburban New York court of nearly $337,000, including interest and costs.
Earlier, in a tangle of professional and personal issues, Mr. Wilford, in his first years at CAMI, took on the pianist Anthony DiBonaventura. Booked on overseas tours, Mr. DiBonaventura found that his wife, with their five children, was leaving him for Mr. Wilford, who was leaving his wife and their adopted son.
The former Mrs. DiBonaventura -- Sara Delano Roosevelt, a granddaughter of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and a stepdaughter of the newspaper publisher, Ambassador and Vanderbilt heir John Hay Whitney -- became Mr. Wilford's third wife. The two divide their time between a Fifth Avenue apartment, vacation trips to the Caribbean and Salzburg, Austria, and a house in West Stockbridge, Mass., near Tanglewood, where Mr. Wilford indulges a passion for gardening and tennis. ("Surprise," said a friend, "he hates to lose.")
Even admirers of Mr. Wilford and CAMI wonder how a star-packed agency can simultaneously advance the careers of dozens of competing artists, especially when, as some say, the managerial divisions are often at odds with each other. In Mr. Wilford's case, associates say, he handles his favorite clients and turns others over to other managers.
"People don't want to hear from John the Baptist," said Jack Mastroanni, an opera manager who left CAMI two years ago, along with his client the mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli. "They want to hear from Jesus Christ."
Mr. Foster, the most recent former apostle, said his decision to leave had less to do with CAMI than with the "wonderful opportunity" to become president of ICM Artists, replacing the long-serving Lee Lamont, who moved up to chairman. Mr. Foster described his departure as amicable and said that although he had offered to leave as soon as he gave notice last fall, Mr. Wilford had encouraged him to spend his final two months there winding up his affairs.
(This was in marked contrast to the departure of the one-time Wilford associate Sheldon Gold, who, before leaving to start ICM Artists in 1976, found himself stripped of his phone and held virtual prisoner by Mr. Wilford in a closetlike office. The Gold captivity has become so ingrained in the lore of the business that Mr. Foster's smooth departure was met with some incredulity. "Ron's lost his edge," one colleague told Mr. Foster.)
An amiable, round-faced man who colleagues say is as "schmoozy" as Mr. Wilford is often inscrutable, Mr. Foster was seen by some as a potential successor to Mr. Wilford. With his departure and others, CAMI "doesn't appear to have that depth of stable that it had in the past," said Thomas W. Morris, executive director of the Cleveland Orchestra.
"From my perspective," he said, "it was a loss for Columbia Artists and a gain for ICM."
One of the most perplexing aspects of Mr. Foster's departure was Mr. Wilford's apparent willingness -- even eagerness, according to some -- to see one of his longest-serving deputies go. Mr. Foster's portfolio, after all, included the Boston Symphony, the New York Philharmonic, the Philadelphia Orchestra and other prize clients. He is barred for a year from taking clients with him.
ICM Artists has a more-than-respectable roster of its own, including Isaac Stern, Midori, Yo-Yo Ma, Emanuel Ax, Wynton Marsalis and the Israel Philharmonic.
Associates who spoke on condition of anonymity said that despite professions of amity, there had been some strain over Mr. Wilford's decision about a year ago to take the job of touring the Vienna Philharmonic, a high-prestige client, out of the Foster division.
Mr. Foster also realized, colleagues said, that he was destined to hit the same glass ceiling as his predecessors at CAMI, that is, Mr. Wilford was not the faintest bit interested in a corporate heir.
If Mr. Wilford shrugged off Mr. Foster's departure, he did not pretend indifference to the loss of Peter Gelb, who, by design, went with CAMI's video division when Mr. Wilford sold it to Sony Music Entertainment in 1993 for a price Mr. Wilford has put at around $6 million.
"I adore Peter," Mr. Wilford said, "but I cannot hold Peter back."
Mr. Gelb, 41, a son of Arthur Gelb, a former managing editor of The New York Times, was similarly effusive, calling Mr. Wilford "the visionary manager."
Mr. Gelb said his introduction to the Wilford style came as press representative for the Boston Symphony when he asked the CAMI president about making Mr. Ozawa, the orchestra's music director, available for press interviews. Mr. Gelb said Mr. Wilford had told him that if Mr. Gelb knew what he was doing, the maestro would cooperate.
Mr. Wilford also taught him, he said, never to enter a meeting carrying a briefcase for fear of looking like a salesman.
"I can't imagine Ronald ever retiring," he said.
While at CAMI, Mr. Gelb produced telecasts at the Metropolitan Opera, an arrangement that Joseph Volpe, who became the Met's general manager in 1990, viewed with suspicion.
"I didn't need an executive producer," the blunt Mr. Volpe said in an interview. "Guess why? I was the executive producer." It ended with Mr. Volpe once reportedly threatening to throw Mr. Gelb across Lincoln Center.
Music professionals close to Mr. Wilford and Mr. Volpe said a degree of tension was inevitable, given the strong management styles of both and the longtime bond between Mr. Wilford and James Levine, the Met's artistic director, which Mr. Volpe was said to regard as an axis.
Some of the tensions burst forth in last year's celebrated firing of the soprano Kathleen Battle, a notoriously difficult Wilford client. Mr. Wilford later complained to associates that the Met management had not provided the right person to smooth things over. But Mr. Levine's position appears secure; he is discussing Met projects into the new millennium.
 
CHALLENGES
Aides Departing As Rival Emerges
 The Foster departure was the most prominent of several. Earlier this year, John Mazzarella, a senior vice president of the Community Concerts unit, left Columbia Artists after 27 years, for reasons he declined to discuss. A deputy to Mr. Foster, Caroline Woodfield, followed her former supervisor to ICM. Yet another executive, Sean T. Bickerton is leaving this month -- amicably, he said -- after more than nine years to open his own agency.
Music managers throughout the industry link some of the discord at CAMI to efforts by Mr. Wilford to tighten control, including trimming expenses, closing the public relations unit and further concentrating the closely held stock, of which he holds a majority share.
In the past, the managers said, Mr. Wilford liked to call the company "employee-owned," allowing division heads to purchase CAMI stock and sell it back to the company at a profit after 10 years under certain circumstances. But recently, the stock policy has become more restrictive, they said. Details remain closely guarded and with the company privately held, there is no outside monitoring of its finances.
Columbia Artists is also facing a rising challenge from an unlikely source: a sports marketing and management giant barely a dozen years in the music business. But many music managers say that I.M.G. Artists, under its director, Edna Landau, now represents a stronger threat to CAMI than does ICM.
Mark H. McCormack, who founded the billion-dollar-a-year company on $500 some 30 years ago and wrote the 1984 best seller "What They Don't Teach You at Harvard Business School," said sports and music struck him as parallel fields.
Like sports, Mr. McCormack said in an interview, music is multinational, a discipline outside language. Money, at least at the high end, is big, leaving star performers, like star athletes, in need of tax and business advice. Corporate sponsorship, too, lends itself to musical events as well as sports. In one way, moreover, music surpasses sports as a marketing and management candidate: musical careers are often many decades long.
The soprano (and golfer) Kiri Te Kanawa, whom Mr. McCormack had met on the greens, smoothed his move into music. "Kiri said, 'I'm going to teach you culture,' " Mr. McCormack recalled. " 'The first thing you have to know is it's intermission, not half-time.' "
Among other recent high-profile catches, I.M.G. Artists signed the soprano Dawn Upshaw, formerly with CAMI. And it signed the teen-aged violinist Leila Josefowicz after Mr. McCormack spotted a writeup in People magazine.
The agency hopes to use both its vast economic resources and its 67 overseas offices to build an international clientele, Mr. McCormack said.
In what is likely to set off a kind of feeding frenzy by both the leading management agencies and the multitude of "boutique" agencies founded by managers who split off from the larger concerns, one of the longtime pillars of the industry, Harold Shaw, announced this week that he would be closing his twin agencies, Shaw Concerts and Shaw Attractions, on June 1, 1996. The action reportedly followed Mr. Shaw's announced intention to retire and the consequent pending departure of a pivotal lieutenant, Bill Capone. Potentially available as a result will be such stars as the soprano Jessye Norman, the pianists Garrick Ohlsson and Mitsuko Uchida, and the guitarist Julian Bream.
Mr. McCormack of I.M.G. said he was flattered to be seen as a major player and would compete hard. "We're aware of changes and a shifting power basis," he said. "We're just staying on our own road. Size is not where it's at."
Characteristically, Mr. Wilford represents himself as profoundly unfazed. "We are what we are," he said.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Humility and Limits In U.S. Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

TEMPTATIONS OF A SUPERPOWER
By Ronald Steel
144 pages. Harvard University Press. $18.95.
In "Pax Americana," his classic 1967 critique of American foreign policy, Ronald Steel looked at the motives behind two decades of United States intervention abroad and at its consequences. He argued that World War II ended decades of American isolationalism by wedding the nation's native idealism to enormous military might, and that the ensuing cold war had nurtured the country's global ambitions. In his view, America's fear of Communism and its moralistic desire to spread its own values to the world at large had had serious repercussions, including an infatuation with global power and influence, a willingness to subordinate rationally assessed national interests to grandiose principles, and "a dangerous gap in our foreign policy between our involvements and our means -- between what we would like to accomplish and what we can reasonably hope to accomplish." 
 The 28 years that have passed since the publication of "Pax Americana" have witnessed enormous changes in the world: the Vietnam War came slouching to a long-awaited end, Communism unraveled as the Soviet Union fractured and fell apart, the Berlin wall came tumbling down and a harsh new brand of nationalism surfaced around the globe. In his latest book, "Temptations of a Superpower," Mr. Steel, a professor of international relations at the University of Southern California, assesses these developments and analyzes America's current foreign policy objectives, habits and imperatives. The resulting book, based on a lecture delivered at the Library of Congress in 1993, is both an impassioned follow-up to "Pax Americana" and a provocative prescription for a new foreign policy based on humility and a recognition of limits, a prescription that is bound to be hotly debated in some circles.
 The opening chapters of "Temptations," which try to sketch in the dynamics of current international relations, will be familiar to the reader: not only do Mr. Steel's musings on the end of the cold war recapitulate his work in "Pax Americana," but his writings on the evolving global situation also retrace ground covered by a host of recent foreign policy books. Like Zbigniew Brzezinski (in "Out of Control: Global Turmoil on the Eve of the 21st Century"), Mr. Steel speaks of the dangers of a newly fragmented world, rebutting the views of Western triumphalists like Francis Fukuyama, who foresee the inevitable victory of liberal democracy around the globe. Like John Lukacs (in "The End of the 20th Century and the End of the Modern Age"), he predicts the waning power of both the superpower and the nation-state in general, as well as the fading of American hegemony. And like William Pfaff (in "Barbarian Sentiments" and "The Wrath of Nations"), he warns of the perils of America's optimism and of its desire to remake the world in its own image.
It is when Mr. Steel turns from a broad overview of global politics to the details of American foreign policy that he most forcefully engages the reader's attention. As he sees it, "We are still hobbled by our cold war ways of looking at the world," even though the world has suddenly and spectacularly become a very different place. He writes that the current military budget of $253 billion "is down fractionally from the previous year" but "is still 85 percent of the average cold war level," which makes "it as large as that of all the other nations of the world combined."
Such expenditures, he continues, have weakened America's ability to compete in the international marketplace, while Japan and Europe, freed from a focus on military concerns by the American security umbrella, have been able to "concentrate on productivity, market penetration, wealth and innovation: the kind of power that matters most in today's world." Instead of worrying so much about the nation's "global responsibilities," he argues, American policy makers might be wiser to focus on the host of domestic problems (from violence in the streets to poverty and a huge national debt) that make the country an upalatable role model to other nations. That policy makers have not done so, he suggests, is partly a reflection of the military bureaucracy's need to perpetuate itself and partly a reflection of the policy elite's own reluctance to abandon the heady notion of American hegemony.
As Mr. Steel sees it, the old American goal of containing Communism has recently given way to the larger (not to mention hubristic) goal of containing "global disorder," even as anti-Communism has been replaced by Wilsonian idealism "as the guiding light of American foreign policy." In his view, the Wilsonian concept of self-determination can lead "to the atomization of human societies," while the Wilsonian concept of collective security threatens to "embroil us in wars everywhere." This latter principle, he observes, was invoked by the United States in three recent situations involving real or threatened military action: in Somalia, in Serbia and in Haiti.
"In not one of these cases," Mr. Steel writes, "could it be argued that a vital American interest was involved. The cold war, for all its irrationalities, was based on real military, economic and political issues. With the cold war behind us, we now engage in conflict for reasons of virtue. However desirable this standard may be for individuals, it is not suited to nations. It can lead either to unending wars for peace in the name of morality or to a reputation for hypocrisy and empty rhetoric."
Under what circumstances should America intervene in the internal affairs of other nations? In Mr. Steel's opinion, justifications come in two categories: morality ("to alleviate extraordinary and severe degrees of human suffering") and self-interest ("to protect vital natural resources; to quell regional disorder in areas vital to American security; to defend the nation's borders"; "to preserve a favorable balance of power in such critical areas as Western Europe, and to prevent nuclear and ecological threats to our national well-being").
Although Mr. Steel lays out these arguments in his usual logical, sharp-edged prose, his discussion of specific examples feels highly perfunctory. In a mere two pages, he argues that the United States should have intervened in Rwanda and Cambodia but was correct not to resort to armed intervention in Bosnia because the death of civilians there "took place in the context of a traditional war over territory, and neither the intention nor the result was the systematic eradication of a people, which is the strict definition of genocide." The human rights abuses in Haiti, he adds, are deplorable but are also part of "the condition under which much of the world lives." Such highly telescoped assessments, laid out almost as an afterthought near the end of the book, feel simplistic, cavalier and coldblooded, and they undermine the more persuasive and carefully considered arguments in Mr. Steel's book.

JUDGE OUSTS EXECUTOR OF DUKE ESTATE
A Manhattan surrogate ruled that the former butler to the late tobacco heiress Doris Duke had used her fortune to finance his own "profligate life style" and as a result was unfit to be executor of her $1.2 billion estate. [Page A1.]
Manhattan Surrogate's Court is the stage upon which many sagas about dying wishes and living desires are played out. [B2.]
 
A BRIDGE FROM HOPE TO SOCIAL ACTION
El Puente Academy for Peace and Justice, one of the city's new small theme-oriented public schools, opened a year and a half ago in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It is a partnership between the Board of Education and El Puente, a youth development group founded on principles of self-help and high achievement. [A1.]

HEADLINE: Mexico Plans Bigger Role For Military Against Drugs

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 22

 BODY:
Faced with a growing threat from narcotics traffickers, President Ernesto Zedillo has ordered the Mexican military to take a greater role in the anti-drug fight, including the use of air force jets to intercept planes loaded with cocaine, Mexican and United States officials say.
The move represents an important shift in policy after years in which successive Mexican administrations, worried about tempting the military with new opportunities for corruption, restricted army involvement in the war against drugs largely to the eradication of marijuana and opium poppy crops. 
 "The determination was made that the situation with drug trafficking was so serious that the army had to be used now," a senior Mexican official said.
Mexican and American officials said that during the last two months, army generals have taken part more extensively in a redesign of the Government's drug-control strategy. Army field commanders have also begun working with federal police officials around the country to coordinate new regional plans to intercept drug shipments.
Most notably, officials said, Mr. Zedillo has responded to the traffickers' use of converted passenger jets to transport huge amounts of cocaine by quietly ordering the military to deploy its F-5 jet fighters and T-33 trainers in pursuit.
The interception program is still in an early phase. Military pilots are being trained to track the traffickers' jets, and it may be months before their effectiveness can even be evaluated. Already, though, several officials said, a significant -- if symbolic -- line had been crossed.
"In the past, there was always a reluctance to allow the military to play a stronger role," a United States official said today. 'But with the Zedillo administration, that mindset has dissolved."
The budget for the military's counter-narcotics campaign, which includes the steady involvement of 7,000 to 12,000 soldiers in the destruction of drug crops, is projected to more than double this year in peso terms. According to Defense Ministry figures, it is to rise from about $27 million last year to $38 million in 1995, adjusted for the prevailing exchange rates.
Officials said the Clinton Administration was expected to provide the Mexican Attorney General's office with about 20 surplus UH-1H Huey helicopters to carry police agents in drug-interdiction operations.
Discussions are also continuing between the two countries about the possibility that the United States might lend or sell as many as several dozen of the far more sophisticated UH-60 Blackhawk transport helicopters for the same purpose.
Mexican officials have made no public announcement of the planned deployment of military jets and helicopters against the old Boeing 727 and Aerospatiale Caravelle passenger jets that have been used by Colombian cocaine traffickers during the last year. Those measures may nonetheless be the most concrete of several steps that the Zedillo administration has pledged to take in response to American pressure for stronger anti-drug efforts.
Following the Clinton Administration's orchestration in February of a $52 billion international rescue package for the Mexican economy, Mexican officials also agreed to a wider exchange of drug-intelligence information, greater cooperation to stop the laundering of drug profits and measures to crack down on leaders of Mexican smuggling organizations.
The Mexican military has played a secondary role in drug-control operations since the establishment of a Government counternarcotics intelligence center in Mexico City in 1992.
In concert with the program run by Mexico and the United States to intercept planes carrying drugs into Mexico, military forces are alerted along with those of the federal police forces when United States Customs Service radar planes deployed over the Caribbean or the Pacific track drug smugglers flying north.
Army troops are sometimes sent to block the traffickers' paths or to back up the federal police, but they leave most law-enforcement tasks to the civilian police. Similarly, the Navy conducts some interdiction operations at sea, but generally does not act on its own initiative.
Even so, the relationship between the Defense Ministry and the Attorney General's office -- which controls the Federal Judicial Police, the drug-intelligence center and the National Institute for the Combat of Drugs -- has often been tense.
Some Mexican law-enforcement officials say the federal police have still not forgotten an episode on Nov. 7, 1991, in which army troops attacked seven federal agents who followed a plane carrying drugs to a clandestine airstrip in the western state of Veracruz. Autopsies suggested that the soldiers -- who appeared to be protecting the shipment and who allowed the traffickers to escape -- beat several of the agents and shot them point-blank.
Some officials said the military's new assertiveness in anti-drug operations was simply part of an effort to perform better duties it already had.
Several Mexican officials said Mr. Zedillo was turning to the military partly out of frustration with the corruption running rampant in the federal police. At the same time, however, the officials played down the danger that such corruption might spread to the army and air force, saying the two forces would generally not plan operations and would continue to turn over criminal suspects to the police.
For the time being, the military has committed six of its Northrop F-5 fighter jets and four aging T-33 Shooting Star trainers to intercept the converted passenger jets, a United States official said. The American official and a Mexican official said the military might deploy more of the F-5's later.
Both military jets are able to fly at speeds comparable to the 500 nautical miles per hour of the passenger jets, although they have smaller fuel tanks and therefore a shorter range.

HEADLINE: 1995 N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;
Horry's Only Basket Puts Rockets Over Top

BYLINE: By TOM FRIEND 

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, May 22

 BODY:
He pump-faked east, west, north and south before taking the shot. The clock read :10, his Houston Rockets trailed by a point, their superstar passed him the ball on a whim and then Robert Horry went into his own personal stall.
He measured, sighed, thought about what he was having for dinner and then heard his entire bench say, "Hurry!" 
 But it was a jump shot worth waiting for because Horry's 18-footer splashed in with 6.5 seconds remaining and made the San Antonio Spurs see red, 94-93.
As is the Rockets' way, they still had to sweat it out until the final buzzer, but Spurs forward Sean Elliott babied a four-foot jump shot.
David Robinson was boxed out by a 38-year-old and could not tip it in.
So, Houston improbably took Game 1 of the four-of-seven-game Western Conference finals, stuck a collective sock in the mouths of 33,337 fans at the Alamodome and made San Antonio's home-court advantage irrelevant.
There are only 10 of them on the bench, but the Rockets have been coming off respirators to win for more than four weeks now.
"This is a crazy team," guard Sam Cassell said. "This team doesn't make sense sometimes. Look around. These characters. I mean, Robert waited 20 seconds to take that shot. He faked three, four times. This team is sick."
At Phoenix over the weekend, an unsung guard named Mario Elie defeated the Suns with a shocking 3-pointer, causing Rockets center Hakeem Olajuwon to say of Elie, "He's a wicked man."
Asked if Horry was the wicked one tonight, Olajuwon said, "He is lucky man."
Considering it was Horry's first basket of the night, that is about right.
"I had no doubts," Horry said. "That's no time to be doubting yourself."
Meanwhile, on most valuable player eve, a relic named Charles Jones turned Robinson into an impostor. With Olajuwon pestered by foul trouble (his fifth came with 8 minutes 10 seconds to play), the 38-year-old Jones was assigned to Robinson. The Spurs center has cleared out space for his m.v.p. trophy -- which he is expected to receive Tuesday -- but he was only 1 of 10 from the field through three quarters and finished with a soft, uninspired 21 points and 7 turnovers.
"I don't think we could've played worse," Robinson said. "This has been our worst game in the playoffs, easily."
In the game's taut moments, Robinson was hounded by Jones, who began the season unemployed in Washington and who was signed only when power forward Carl Herrera dislocated his shoulder.
"Defense is his life," Rockets Coach Rudy Tomjanovich said of Jones.
Jones's brother, Caldwell, played just like him, but when Spurs center Moses Malone was asked to compare the brothers tonight, he said, "Caldwell shot more."
Not anymore. Charles Jones, who had scored one basket all regular season and only one in the playoffs, had 6 points tonight.
"Playoff high?" he said. "That was my career high."
"Old fella came in with a reverse layup tonight," Cassell shouted in the Rocket locker room.
But Clyde Drexler (25 points) and Olajuwon are still the old reliables. Olajuwon, in fact, had 27 points, 8 rebounds and the assist of the night. The score had been tied at 92-92 when Robinson made 1 of 2 free throws with 45.9 seconds left. Olajuwon then did not look in his rearview mirror and allowed Doc Rivers to steal the ball from him, but Elliott missed two free throws with 26.6 seconds left.
That set up the last possession for Houston. Olajuwon was trapped on the baseline and swung the pass to Horry. The 6-foot-10-inch forward seemed to count to 10 before letting it fly.
"Like a free throw," guard Kenny Smith said.

HEADLINE: Partnerships Help Create New Schools

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
Over three decades, New York City educators have opened scores of small public academies, including 46 high schools in the last two years. In the series, all the new high schools are profiled, as well as older ones that served as models and some elementary and middle schools organized according to the same principles. As this listing shows, the founding of the schools has often involved unusual collaborations. A number have been sponsored by educational reformers working with organizations like community groups, colleges, churches and even a labor union.
 
Community Service Schools
 
Benjamin Banneker Academy for Community Development
At Pratt Institute, Steuben Hall, 329 Dekalb Avenue, Fort Greene, Brooklyn. 

IDEA: Learn to build a neighborhood.
OPENED: 1993. (N.V.)
CURRENT ENROLLMENT: 125.
PEAK: 500.
GRADES: 7-10; eventually, 7-12.
Named after the 18th-century black engineer, the academy was founded to teach math, science and technology through internships in building renovation and other urban planning projects. "The changes in science and technology mean increased competitiveness," said Assemblyman Roger Green, who wrote the proposal for the school. "Technological literacy becomes as important as language literacy."
The school's first project director left after a difficult year marred by tensions with officials from Pratt Institute, who seemed to view the school as an unwanted new burden during the Institute's own financial crisis; at one point, Pratt wanted to terminate Banneker's lease. But representatives from both schools attended a retreat, and relations appear to have improved. The Board of Education is constructing permanent classrooms in a leased building at 77 Clinton Avenue at a cost of $11.5 million. DAVID GONZALEZ

HEADLINE: Switching His Tactics, Clinton Begins Preparing Proposal for Balancing the Budget

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
After weeks of refusing to offer specific counterproposals to Republican plans to balance the Federal budget in seven years, the White House has begun to prepare ideas, and President Clinton has explicitly said for the first time that he believes such a goal is achievable.
Asked on Friday in an interview with New Hampshire radio stations whether he was prepared to set a target date for balancing the budget, the President said, "No." But he added, "I think it can be done. Well, it can---- First of all, it can be done in seven years." 
 Mr. Clinton did not specify what he would propose, and, indeed, warned of the risks in trying to balance the budget. But White House aides said his comments were meant to show his determination to continue reducing the deficit and prevent the Republicans from pre-empting him on a popular issue.
"The question is, What is the penalty and what are the tradeoffs," Mr. Clinton said, according to a transcript obtained by The New York Times. "I think it clearly can be done in less than 10 years. I think we can get there by a date certain."
The interview was broadcast on New Hampshire Public Radio stations in Concord, Hanover and Keene.
Mr. Clinton has never opposed the principle of trying to balance the Federal budget, and Vice President Al Gore and other Administration officials have variously suggested that 2002 was a reasonable goal.
But for weeks, most of Mr. Clinton's top advisers, from his chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, down, have denounced Republican efforts to meet such a deadline as unrealistic efforts to fulfill an "arbitrary campaign promise." They have also warned that proposed cuts in the growth of spending on Medicare and other programs would harm the elderly.
The President's chief economic policy adviser, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, went so far as to say that locking the Government into the goal of balancing the budget by the turn of the century could risk worsening any economic downturn that might occur in the meantime.
But now, in the words of one senior economic adviser, "the President wants to move the debate from whether or not you can balance the budget at a time certain to a debate over how you get there, what are the tradeoffs and what are the priorities, and even what the best time path is."
To that end, White House budget aides have been reviewing potential alternatives to the Republicans' plans, though aides emphasize that Mr. Clinton has not softened any of his three main conditions for negotiations: That the Republicans drop their proposed tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans, agree to protect educational programs and curtail the growth of Medicare only as part of a broader overhaul of the health care system.
"It's not like they're preparing a balanced budget of their own to be sent up," a senior White House aide said of his Administration colleagues. "But I'd be dishonest if I didn't say this is a reflection of the President's interests and his unwillingness to let the debate be diverted."
House Republicans have already passed a broad outline of how they would balance the budget, and Mr. Clinton said he wanted to wait to evaluate the Senate's proposals, and see how differences were reconciled.
"Then I have to do what I promised them," he added. "I promised them that if they would adopt a budget, that I would negotiate with them in good faith, and that I would propose a counterbudget.
"That's what I---- I have given them my word I'd do it, and I will do it. I owe that to them, and I owe it to the American people."
One of Mr. Clinton's greatest frustrations is that he has not won more political credit for his willingness to reduce the deficit in the five-year economic plan that passed Congress in 1993 without a single Republican vote. After last year's electoral rout by Republicans, the White House decided against deeper deficit reduction in favor of reviving Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign promise of tax relief for the middle class, which he set aside on taking office.
Since then, the President has often struggled to be heard above the Republicans' own promises of bigger tax cuts and bigger spending cuts in an effort to put the budget on a path to balance by 2002.
In recent weeks, as the scope -- and potential pain -- of the Republicans' plans became clear, the White House rallied traditionally powerful political constituencies like the elderly by warning of the dire consequences, while refusing to provide specific budget-cutting proposals of its own. That has led Republicans to accuse Mr. Clinton of ducking the tough choices of leadership.
The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, sought today to portray the President's comments in the New Hampshire interview as a natural evolution.
"He has said all along we want to reduce the deficit and move toward a balanced budget," Mr. McCurry said, "and he's prepared to lead the way forward. We are going to engage at some point in the process, and probably sooner rather than later."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Tax Cuts Rejected In Senate Budget Plan
 The Senate voted 69 to 31 to reject a proposal to include deep tax cuts in its budget framework, one of the few times this year that Republicans were split, with 23 Republicans joining all 46 Democrats to vote no. 
 The proposal, by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, would have put into the Senate budget most tax cuts contained in the House budget that was passed last week. The budget measure now before the Senate would allow no tax cuts right away. [Page A1.]
 
Lloyd's Offers Deal to Investors
 Lloyd's of London proposed a reorganization intended to pare the insurance losses of its hard-hit individual investors, offering them an aid package valued at $4.4 billion to help cover $9.3 billion they still owe. [D4.]
 
Fed Keeps Rates Steady
 With the statement, "The F.O.M.C. meeting ended at 12:15 P.M.; there is no further announcement," the Federal Reserve, as expected, left interest rates unchanged. [D2.]
 
Boeing Plans to Cut More Jobs
 Boeing now expects to eliminate an additional 5,000 jobs this year, bringing the total job cuts to about 12,000. [D3.]
 
House Panel Backs B-2
 House Republicans moved toward canceling a Seawolf nuclear submarine, which would jeopardize thousands of jobs at the Electric Board division of General Dynamics, and buying two more B-2 Stealth bombers, which would save jobs at Northrop-Grumman. [B8.]
 
Firm's Founder Settles With S.E.C.
 David J. Askin, whose investment fund collapsed after bond prices plunged last year, settled S.E.C. charges that he had misled investors. Mr. Askin agreed to be barred from the securities industry for two years and to pay $50,000 to repay former clients. [D8.]
 
United Rubber Workers End Strike
 The United Rubber Workers ended a 10-month strike at Bridgestone-Firestone, agreeing to return to work without a contract. The company need not rehire all strikers. [A17.]
 
Court Takes Up Perelman Deal
 Oral arguments began before the Delaware Supreme Court in a case involving the deal that formed the foundation of Ronald O. Perelman's fortune, his 1982 acquisition of Technicolor. It is the third time the deal has come before the Delaware court, and the case could revise takeover ground rules. [D3.]
 
Bradlees Suspends Dividend
 Bradlees suspended its 15-cent quarterly dividend and predicted a loss of $2.25 to $2.75 a share for its first quarter. [D3.]
 
Omnicom to Buy Ross Roy
 Ross Roy Communications agreed to be acquired by the Omnicom Group for an estimated $50 million to $52 million. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 
Travelers Can Reclaim Taxes
 Americans who go to Europe on business can partly counter the decline of the dollar there by reclaiming part of the value-added taxes they incur. Business Travel. [D5.]
 
Hewlett to Introduce Mobile Unit
 Hewlett-Packard is expected to introduce a wireless mobile unit today that would let doctors see patients' electrocardiograms and vital signs for remote diagnosis in an emergency. A physician who has tested the system said it might already have saved a life. [D3.]
 
Seat Belts in Voluntary Recall
 Nine car manufacturers agreed to repair or replace Japanese-made seat belts on more than eight million cars because of concerns that the buckles can sometimes jam. [A17.]

HEADLINE: Fed Policy Makers Decide To Leave Rates Unchanged

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
Faced with slowing growth in the American economy and a strengthening dollar, the Federal Reserve left short-term interest rates unchanged at a meeting today.
The Fed's interest rate policy group, the Federal Open Market Committee, signaled its decision with a brief statement. "The F.O.M.C. meeting ended at 12:15 P.M.; there is no further announcement," said Joseph R. Coyne, the Fed's chief spokesman. 
 The phrasing of the announcement matched almost exactly the wording of statements from previous meetings at which the Fed left interest rates unchanged.
Few economists were surprised by the Federal Reserve's announcement. The central bank doubled short-term interest rates in the 12 months that ended on Feb. 1 in response to a burst of economic growth that appeared likely to produce some increase in inflation.
A wide range of economic indicators since then has pointed to slower growth, while inflation has barely risen. Producer prices and consumer prices did creep up in April. But last year's sharp increases in prices for raw materials like wheat and for semiprocessed goods like steel have not yet produced the run-up in finished good prices that many Wall Street economists and some Fed officials feared last year.
In the bond market, longer-term interest rates have been sliding this spring as Treasury prices rallied in reaction to the dwindling inflationary pressures. Today, the yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond fell to 6.86 percent, from 6.91 percent.
The economy's slowing growth led some economists to speculate today that the Fed might ease monetary policy and push down interest rates later this year. "There is a chance of easing in July and a bit greater chance in August, but I don't see any chance of tightening in 1995," said Lawrence Chimerine, an economist at the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington research group.
Other experts say there is just as much chance of another interest rate increase this year as a rate cut, depending on whether the economy grows too fast or too slow. "We're right on the razor's edge of that, and I think that's where the Fed is now," said Darwin L. Beck, an economist with the First Boston Corporation.
The Federal Open Market Committee is scheduled to meet next on July 5 and 6, and again on Aug. 22.
The Fed still faces risks that the economy will grow too fast or too slow, most likely as a result of fluctuations in consumer spending. The last two months have produced signs of weak consumer spending, notably a slowness in auto sales.
But some Fed officials also thought in June of last year that consumer spending was slowing and the economy with it, only to find that shoppers soon returned in force to stores. That experience may have left Fed officials cautious.
Falling interest rates in recent weeks have produced a surge in new mortgages and in mortgage refinancings, as consumers try to lock in lower rates. Many economists say lower rates will produce a recovery in home building and in sales of appliances like washers and dryers.
But many refinancings involve homeowners trading adjustable-rate mortgages for fixed-rate mortgages at about the same rates. Because these homeowners' paymentsremain roughly the same each month, they may not have much added cash to spend on goods and services, said Sung W. Sohn, a senior vice president and chief economist at the Norwest Corporation, a bank holding company in Minneapolis.
The weakness of the dollar earlier this year had put some pressure on the Fed to push up interest rates to make American financial investments more attractive.
