HEADLINE: Giuliani Is Hopeful After Going to Albany in Quest of Money

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 23

 BODY:
With the state budget headed toward completion, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made a last-minute sojourn to Albany in search of cash today and said he thought New York City would fare better than Albany leaders have previously suggested.
But it was far from clear yet whether he was right. 
 At the same time today, two of the city's fiscal monitors, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi and State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, both Democrats, warned that the city may face sizable budget shortfalls, even if the Republican Mayor gets all of the money he wants from Albany, because much in his budget plan relies on risky assumptions.
Also today, Democratic Assembly officials said they had acceded to Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to cut $58 million in Metropolitan Transportation Authority funds that pay for free transit passes for about 350,000 students in New York City. Because the M.T.A. already faces a $150 million budget gap this year, the cut could increase the likelihood of a fare increase.
"Our belief is there was no way to guarantee how that money would be used, and we might be throwing it away," said one Assembly official, speaking on condition of anonymity.
On his rounds of the Capitol, Mr. Giuliani received some good news from Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, who predicted that anticipated state budget cuts in welfare, Medicaid and other entitlement programs would save the city between $550 million and $600 million of the $700 million sought by the Mayor.
Tonight, Mr. Pataki said that estimate was "within the range of what we think is possible." State officials had predicted previously that Mr. Giuliani would receive far less, opening a large gap in the city budget for the fiscal year that begins on July 1.
Mr. Giuliani sounded markedly upbeat as he assessed the continuing state-budget negotiations, which seem to be moving slowly but steadily toward completion. "From what I know of the compromise that's been reached, it gets us a very, very large percentage of the savings that we need," he said.
Mr. Giuliani focused his lobbying efforts today on several priority measures that would drive additional cash to the city. One priority, he said, is for the state to keep a commitment it made last year to pick up a greater share of the cost of pre-kindergarten programs for handicapped youngsters, a $78 million saving for the city. Another request was for the state to keep last year's commitment to raise revenue sharing for local governments, worth $31 million to the city.
Mr. Giuliani also pleaded for the state to pay a larger share of the cost of managed-care programs for Medicaid recipients, worth $22 million. And he asked the Governor and the Legislature to grant him a waiver from a state requirement that forces the city to spend the same amount as the state on the City University. The waiver is necessary to enact Mr. Giuliani's proposal to cut $38 million from the CUNY budget.
The Mayor's total request for state aid, which combines cash assistance with entitlement cuts, is valued at $950 million.
Mr. Giuliani raced through the Capitol from one half-hour meeting to the next, with news conferences after each. Along the way, he received encouragement at each stop. None of the leaders dismissed his requests on philosophical grounds, although none expressed any certainty the money would be found.
Mr. Pataki and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, both Republicans, used Mr. Giuliani's request to apply pressure to the Assembly Democrats to make deeper cuts in social programs.
"I think in the context of the entire budget, what the Mayor has requested today is not unachievable," Mr. Pataki said. "That's not to say it won't be difficult because it requires additional cuts in entitlement programs that thus far the Assembly's resisted."
Handing a double dose of criticism to the Mayor, Mr. Hevesi and Mr. McCall questioned the viability of several of Mr. Giuliani's budget proposals.
They both said the budget relied heavily on actions of others -- including the Federal and state governments and the city's municipal labor unions -- that the city is by no means certain to achieve.
Both of them also criticized the Mayor's estimates on tax revenues and pension contributions and expressed doubt about the city's ability to find $130 million in new revenues for leasing the city's two airports to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
The largest uncertainty involves the assistance from the state that Mr. Giuliani lobbied for today. Mr. Hevesi and Mr. McCall both estimated that the city would receive only $400 million to $500 million of the $950 million the Mayor has sought.
The Mayor's budget also calls for other legislative changes that would save the city millions of dollars beyond the $950 million, but there is no assurance they will be approved. Those include changes in special-education requirements that would save $155 million, legislative changes in the city's legal liability to save $45 million and a waiver to allow the city to cut its contribution to the City University.
In all, Mr. Hevesi said $1.4 billion to nearly $2 billion of the Mayor's gap-closing proposals were "substantial risks" that could fail to become reality. Mr. McCall, who recently has feuded with Mr. Giuliani, took a softer tone but still said the Mayor's budget included $948 million in risky or uncertain proposals.
Mr. Giuliani defended his budget proposals. He said the city had made a significant "downpayment" toward ending its recurring budget gaps in the last year and would continue to do so with the new budget.
"This budget, assuming that it goes through in the form in which we've proposed it, will make even more of a downpayment on it," he said, speaking to reporters at the Capitol. "We're working our way out of, really, 40 or 50 years of consistently spending more money, with maybe one or two exceptions, than the rate of growth in the economy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver walks with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani from the Speaker's office after conferring yesterday in Albany. (David Jennings for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "LEDGER: Soft Spots in the Mayor's Budget"
Mayor Giuliani's proposed budget relies on several sources of income, or savings, for the city that are not assured because they rely on actions by the Federal or state governments, or others. Yesterday both the city and the state comprollers published reports showing how much money is involved.
 The state Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, estimated that the Mayor's budget includes $948 million that the city might never actually get, while the city's Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, warned that the total could be between $1.4 billion and $2.1 billion.
These are some of the proposed sources of income, or savings:
 
Savings from state cuts in welfare and Medicaid, and new state aid -- up to $500 million
 
Proposed state waiver to allow city to cut CUNY's budget -- $38 million
 
Proposed state legal reforms -- $45 million
 
Proposed additional aid to come from the new Federal budget -- $50 million
 
Savings to come from negotiations with labor unions -- $600 million
 
Proposal to renegotiate airport leases with the Port Authority -- $130 million
 
Over-estimation of tax revenues -- $93 million
 
Unbudgeted, projected overtime costs -- $81 million
 
Unbudgeted additional pension-fund contributions -- up to $100 million

HEADLINE: Bradlees Halts Dividend, With Big Loss Foreseen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: BRAINTREE, Mass., May 23

 BODY:
Bradlees Inc. suspended its 15-cent quarterly dividend today and predicted a fiscal first-quarter loss about twice as large as had been expected.
The struggling regional discount department store, which has been hurt by the expansion of national chains, also said it would not develop new stores in 1996. 
"Bradlees is a turnaround company in its first stage of transition," said its chief executive, Mark A. Cohen. "It is unfortunate that we are living through one of the worst retail periods in memory, but then we have no control over the general economy."
The Braintree-based Bradlees, which was spun off from the Shop and Shop Companies in 1992, said it expected to report a loss of $2.25 to $2.75 a share for the quarter that ended last month.
Four analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research had been projecting an average loss of $1.38. Bradlees said it is scheduled to release the earnings in mid-June.
The announcement came after Bradlees stock closed today off 12.5 cents, at $7.50, on the News York Stock Exchange.
Earlier today, the Standard & Poor's Corporation placed its ratings of the Bradlees debt on Creditwatch, with negative implications.
The ratings agency said it was concerned about the company's liquidity under its current credit arrangement, "given expected continuing weak operating and financial performance."
Same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year, fell 6 percent in the quarter ended April 29. The retailer said today that it intended to replace its credit agreement with a larger, more flexible asset-based facility in the middle of this year.
"We believe that the elimination of the $6.8 million dividend is in the best interests of Bradlees and its shareholders," Mr. Cohen said.
Bradlees operates 136 stores in Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Rhode Island, Pennsylvania and Virginia.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Wilmington, Del., gets a shot in the arm from office construction for two big banking companies.

BYLINE: By Maureen Milford 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del.

 BODY:
TWO big banking companies are generating a small burst of office construction in downtown Wilmington. Both plan to relocate operations from the suburbs.
One of the companies, the MBNA America Bank, a big issuer of Visa and Mastercard credit cards, has nearly completed the first of two towers on 11th Street, the main boulevard into the city from Interstate 95. The tower is in Rodney Square, a prestigious office location. 
 The other institution, the Wilmington Trust Company, has architects at work on a design for a 10-story building to supplement its headquarters on Rodney Square.
Both banks are responding to the vigorous courting of Mayor James H. Sills Jr., who was joined in his efforts by Wilmington 2000, an economic development group made up of business leaders. The city offered a variety of tax breaks, and has worked to smooth the path to the approvals required for new development.
Until the MBNA America Bank agreed to consider the city for its new headquarters, the site on Rodney Square had been an embarrassing and unsightly hole left over from a failed real estate project of the 1980's.
Now the final touches are being put on a nine-story neoclassical building of 350,000 square feet designed by Heery International Inc. of Washington. It will serve as offices for MBNA's executive staff and business development functions.
The building shares the square with E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the Hotel du Pont, Wilmington Trust and the Delaware Chancery Court, where many of the country's prominent takeover battles have been fought.
When the work on the MBNA building is completed in July, the bank will shift workers from its sprawling suburban complex in Newark, a town near the Maryland line 11 miles southwest of Wilmington.
The bank has grown in its 13-year existence to become the state's second-largest private employer, with 5,800 employees. Du Pont is the largest, with 16,300 employees in Delaware.
The bank's physical growth has been equally rapid. No sooner had it begun work on the new headquarters than it was scouting properties on neighboring city blocks. In March MBNA said it would begin work on a companion to the Rodney Square building. It had quietly bought two neighboring properties for $2.7 million for the project.
The second building, which will house the bank's telemarketing, computer processing and training operations, will be smaller, at 225,000 square feet. It will be connected to the Rodney Square building by an elevated walkway.
As a result of the moves, MBNA will have as many as 2,000 more workers in downtown Wilmington, a boon to the retail district and wage tax base.
The planned Wilmington Trust building, which will be three blocks west of Rodney Square on 11th Street, will be the first of possibly two buildings to be built by the bank in the next decade.
The bank will shift about 650 people to the building when it is completed in 1997, more than half of whom will come from the bank's suburban building near New Castle.
When the move is complete, Wilmington Trust will put its 13-acre suburban campus and 85,000-square-foot building up for sale, saying the downtown offices will meet its space requirements through 2015.
While there is still a large inventory of space here that is less than prime, most office users are looking at new construction because of the smaller floor sizes of older buildings. Today companies want at least 40,000 square feet of space for the best use of office furniture systems, said Daniel R. Reeder, vice president of CB Commercial Real Estate Group Inc. in Wilmington.
Some are worried that land in the most desirable areas will be spoken for. The state Committee for the Delaware Justice Center, which is working to consolidate all the state's courts in Wilmington into one new building, had its eye on the site that MBNA chose for its headquarters.
The committee is now looking at other sites in the city. One proposal for the justice center called for the construction of a tower behind the existing classical facade of the Daniel L. Herrmann Courthouse on Rodney Square, the building in which the Chancery Court is situated.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Recovers From Weakness In Europe and Ends Up vs. Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar was steady against most leading currencies yesterday after recovering from a bout of weakness in Europe, where dealers were drawn to German marks because of fears about the new French Government's economic agenda.
The dollar traded within a tight range. A decision by Federal Reserve policy makers to leave interest rates unchanged had little effect on the market. Currency dealers had expected the Fed to take no action at the meeting of its Federal Open Market Committee yesterday. 
 The Fed has raised short-term interest rates seven times since February 1994 to stem inflation and slow the economy. Higher rates tend to attract investors to dollar-denominated assets.
"There was just no economic news to get this market going," said Christopher Iggo, an international economist at the Chase Manhattan Bank.
In late New York trading, the dollar settled at 1.4436 German marks, up from 1.4410 on Monday. The dollar slipped to 87.10 Japanese yen from 87.35.
The dollar weakened against the mark at the start of New York trading after the new Prime Minister of France, Alain Juppe, outlined his Government's budget plans.
He reiterated many of the measures that were announced during the campaign of President Jacques Chirac in early May. Those included employment incentives and tax breaks on real estate investments.
But he also added that the minimum wage would be "raised significantly," which worried some investors, sending them selling French francs and buying marks. That indirectly hurt the dollar.
"The mark is considered the safe-haven currency," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign-exchange dealer at the Bank Leumi Trust Company in New York. "Many investors are worrying how the French are going to go through with all of this."
The strengthening of the mark against the dollar was only temporary and the dollar recovered after European trading concluded.
The dollar was weighed down against the yen amid uncertainty of what would happen with the American trade sanctions against Japan.
The United States has imposed an import duty of 100 percent on $6 billion of Japan's most popular luxury cars in an attempt to press Japan to open its auto market. Washington said it rescind the duty if an agreement was reached with Tokyo by June 28.
"The market is starting to wonder what will happen with the sanctions and whether they will help" lower the bulging United States trade deficit, Mr. Waxman said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Fledgling World Trade Arbiter Listens to the War Cry of Giants

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: PARIS, May 23

 BODY:
At the annual meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development here, one of the major players turned out to be not a member of this select club of 25 rich nations but an invited guest.
As Renato Ruggiero, the Director General of the new World Trade Organization, went from meeting to meeting, he had to fight his way through the crush of television cameras. 
 Mr. Ruggiero's high visibility only underscored one of the biggest worries here -- whether a brewing trade war between the United States and Japan over car imports will undermine, even negate, the very agency created to settle international trade disputes.
"The threatened United States sanctions against Japan could sabotage the entire concept of the W.T.O.," a European trade official said. "I don't know why the Americans did this just five months after the thing was started. The timing is just bad."
The World Trade Organization, which came into being on Jan. 1 in Geneva, replaces the headquarters organization of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. GATT saw plenty of disputes, but none with the magnitude of this one facing its successor -- the hot new round of argument over access to the Japanese market of 6.5 million cars each year and the American threat to impose 100 percent tariffs on luxury Japanese cars.
Today, as Japanese and American representatives tried desperately to convince fellow O.E.C.D. members of the correctness of their positions, the question many were asking was: Can the agency under Mr. Ruggiero -- whose candidacy had been opposed by both Washington and Tokyo until it was clear there was no real alternative -- bring the two warring sides together?
When GATT went out of existence at the end of last year, after more than 100 countries had signed the Uruguay Round agreement liberalizing world trade by eliminating or slashing tariffs, many experts saw the World Trade Organization as the arbiter and protector of the new free trade.
They predicted that it could become the most important international economic agency in the 21st century, possibly eclipsing the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
These experts envisioned the agency's dispute settlement board, which will have the final word on trade disputes, as the forum for resolving the myriad of bigger and smaller such arguments every year. It would aim to prevent its members from backsliding into protectionism.
Many of the Government ministers here today were highly critical of Washington's threatened sanctions against the Japanese. Most agreed that Japan needed to open its markets, but nearly everyone condemned sanctions. In part, Europeans see such sanctions as a political tool to bolster President Clinton's re-election prospects next year.
They also fear side effects of strong-arm tactics. One possibility is that the United States will use sanctions against them. Another is that if a settlement is reached, it will be one primarily involving the United States and Japan, effectively excluding European auto makers. Finally, Europeans -- particularly the Germans -- argue that their auto makers have heavily invested in building car distributorships in Japan and are now seeing the first results. They note that European car sales in Japan are almost twice the level of American sales.
"Our companies have invested a lot and made the effort to penetrate the market," said Gunter Rexrodt, Germany's Economics Minister. "We are not interested in the United States companies earning a cheap dollar by forcing a managed market."
Trying to calm the troubled waters, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, promised today that Washington would abide by any ruling the World Trade Organization made. Mr. Kantor also tried to drive home the point that any opening of the Japanese market would benefit not only American workers, but Europeans and even Japanese.
In an interview, he said that the dispute with Japan "is not going to overwhelm the W.T.O," adding: "We have gone to the W.T.O. We'll abide by the W.T.O."
But he criticized his European colleagues for not being tougher on the Japanese. Alluding to the threat of sanctions, he said: "What you're hearing here is a little bit of, 'We'd rather you not do this. We want you to be successful. We'd just rather you not proceed in this manner because we're a little frightened you will use it against us.' "
Still, it is Washington's threat of sanctions that leads many to say that the United States has weakened the W.T.O.'s position in world trade disputes. If the world's largest economic power sees no problem imposing a trade action, even though it simultaneously seeks a settlement through the W.T.O., doesn't that send a signal to small countries that such an approach is acceptable?
Several European Government officials pointed out that perhaps what the Japanese feared most was that even though the United States had agreed to abide by any W.T.O. decision, the complex review and appeals process could take as long as two years.
In the meantime, if an agreement with Japan is not reached by June 28, Washington will impose tariffs that could total more than $6 billion a year, effective May 20 -- money that the United States would not necessarily be obliged to repay Japan and its auto makers for lost sales, even if it lost the case.
For his part, Mr. Ruggiero said he was sure that the World Trade Organization would rise to the challenge of taking on this dispute between economic giants.
"I do not want to overdramatize this," he said. "It arrived at the beginning of its life, and we will handle it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Renato Ruggiero, left, the head of the World Trade Organization, answering questions from Japanese reporters yesterday at the O.E.C.D. meeting in Paris. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: No Question of Fed Nominee's Pro-Tax Views

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Peter Passell's defense of Alicia H. Munnell's candidacy for a Federal Reserve slot (Economic Scene, May 18) employs newspeak, which illustrates exactly why Republican opposition to Ms. Munnell is growing. 
 Mr. Passell refers to "members of Congress who have never met a tax expenditure they didn't like." "Tax expenditure" is newspeak for any of that portion of wealth individuals are permitted to keep: Mr. Passell is referring to members of Congress who have never met a tax they do like.
In that light, opposition to Ms. Munnell's position by those who oppose new taxes becomes clearer.
Mr. Passell then equates the absence of a putative new tax on accrued income in pension plans with an "adverse impact on income distribution."
This assumes that income distribution is a desirable yet incomplete role of government.
Again, it should be no surprise that those who do not agree with this position oppose Ms. Munnell's appointment. When someone employs newspeak in an influential forum, watch your wallet.
 
PAUL A. BURMEISTER
Concord, Mass., May 18, 1995

HEADLINE: Turkey Beats Kurds With an Old Stick

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman (column, May 17) writes in awestruck tones of Turkey's "bad neighborhood," as if it were something truly new and the main source of the country's serious difficulties -- which it is not. He barely mentions Turkey's most urgent problem -- that is, its Kurdish insurgency and the Ciller Government's refusal to deal with the issues it raises other than by force. 
 Mr. Friedman describes the Kurdistan Workers Party, or P.K.K., which leads the armed revolt, as a Marxist organization that aspires to carve a separate Kurdish state out of southeastern Turkey. That is the Turkish (and United States Government) line. On the chance that the P.K.K. itself might have something to say about this, I recently sent a list of questions to its General Secretary, Abdullah Ocalan. Here, in part, is what Mr. Ocalan replied in regard to the allegation of Marxism:
"We are dedicated to a philosophy that is based on democracy and pluralism, not on the power of the state. We favor a synthesis of capitalism and socialism, an economic structure in which individuals will freely develop to their fullest potential."
And about breaking off from Turkey: "It is unrealistic for the P.K.K. to insist upon a separate state. . . . We hereby explicitly declare that we do not insist on a separate state of our own. . . . We want a Spanish or American type federalism."
Those who uncritically echo the charge that the P.K.K. is Marxist and separatist (and "terrorist") should understand that the purpose of the charge is to justify Ankara's policy of military repression of ethnic Kurdish aspirations. That policy worked in decades past when governments were considered free to do as they pleased with people within their borders.
Today it guarantees a Turkey consumed by civil war, economic misery and a rising tide of Islamic fundamentalism, far too unstable to play the role of regional bulwark that the United States and other NATO allies would assign it.
 
DAVID A. KORN
Washington, May 17, 1995
The writer is a retired Foreign Service Officer.

HEADLINE: Argentines Voted For Continued Change

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The election results in Argentina are a good sign of a maturing democratic society. President Carlos Saul Menem won a second term with nearly 50 percent of the vote. The Radical Party received only 19 percent of the votes for president, coming in third. 
 In Congress, the vote was 42 percent for the Peronists and 22 percent for the Radicals, making them the second party in Congress. In certain provinces, like Cordoba, the Radical Party won the gubernatorial race by a greater margin than Mr. Menem won as President. In Buenos Aires, he lost to a third party. So the political process is working.
I do not think the results give anyone a blank check, but rather show that Argentines want to continue the process of change that is now going on both economically and socially, and they believe that the credibility of the Government must continue to maintain stability.
Argentina faces the task of restructuring a nearly bankrupt banking system and bankrupt provinces and creating a method of handling the huge unemployment in a country that tends to think foreign investment is the savior, when it will be development of products for export and Argentine investment that will remake the country.
The Argentines will have to learn that because you have the technology for first-world stock exchanges, that in itself does not remake a country.
The President and his Economy Minister, Domingo Cavallo, who was a force in Mr. Menem's victory, deserve credit.
 
LAURENCE W. LEVINE
New York, May 18, 1995
The writer was a member of the Argentine American Chamber of Commerce, 1958-94.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Toyota Considers Suit Against U.S. Sanctions

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 23

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation is considering filing suit against the United States Government in an effort to remove or reduce the impending sanctions on luxury vehicles, company officials said today.
"If there is legal ground to act, we have to explore the possibility," Toshiaki Taguchi, a Toyota director in charge of North American sales and public affairs, said today. 
But he and a company spokesman said the company had not made a decision. If action is taken, they said, it would not occur until sanctions are actually imposed on June 28.
Toyota also warned today that earnings would suffer if the United States imposed 100 percent tariffs on 13 models of Japanese luxury cars. The 13 include all five Lexus models made by the company. Toyota, Japan's largest auto maker, warned about the tariffs' impact while reporting strong earnings.
Besides Toyota, other auto makers and American dealers of Japanese luxury cars were believed to be exploring court action to stave off the tariffs.
"Such an idea is widely talked about among Toyota and other manufacturers," Eiji Hirabayashi, the spokesman for Toyota in Tokyo, said.
Another company official said the Washington law firm of Hogan & Hartson, which represents Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A., the company's American sales arm, had prepared a memo outlining the possible legal approaches but cautioning against proceeding.
A lawsuit would have to be filed by Toyota's American subsidiary. Since a case that might take years to resolve would be of little help, a company filing a lawsuit would no doubt seek an injunction to stop the tariffs from being imposed.
It was difficult to predict how successful such a lawsuit might be. The proposed tariffs fall under Section 301 of United States trade law, which has never been challenged in court.
The tariffs would formally go into effect on June 28 but would be retroactive to cars that entered the United States as of last Saturday.
Mr. Hirabayashi said the company was particularly considering a lawsuit that would contend it was illegal for the Government to make the sanctions retroactive.
Toyota is concerned about this because it is continuing to export Lexus cars to the United States. If the tariffs were applied retroactively, the company would face a huge payment on luxury cars that entered the United States after last Saturday. Mazda and Honda have already stopped exporting cars that would be subject to the tariffs.
Mr. Hirabayashi said companies in the industry were exploring broader attacks on the sanctions as a whole. One approach would be to argue that United States law requires the Government to go to the World Trade Organization to resolve a dispute before imposing sanctions.
A likely place for filing such a case would be the Court of International Trade in New York, where Government decisions to impose duties can be appealed.
That is the court in which the Nissan Motor Corporation won a suit in 1993 against the Government over the tariff on imports of its Pathfinder sport-utility vehicle. The ruling was upheld by a Federal appeals court in 1994.
While sanctions could hurt sales and earnings, Toyota posted a healthy gain for the nine months that ended March 31. The company earned 131.95 million yen, or $1.48 billion. The reporting period was for nine months because Toyota changed the end of its fiscal year to March from June to put it in line with the accounting practices of most large Japanese companies. Toyota did not provide figures for the corresponding period a year earlier.
Still, the results were well above the 125.81 billion yen in earnings reported by Toyota for the 12 months that ended June 1994.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Rally Sends Rates Downward

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bonds rallied yesterday, sending interest rates to their lowest levels in nearly a week on speculation that the Fed would cut short-term interest rates soon.
The policy-making Federal Open Market Committee met without changing the Fed's monetary policy. After the meeting, the Fed's spokesman simply said, "There is no further announcement." 
 William Shea, senior vice president-head government trading at Nikko Securities Company International, said that Treasuries received a lift from a report in The Washington Post yesterday that suggested Fed officials would lower the overnight bank loan rates, better known as the Federal funds rate, sometime this year. The article said that the central bank could cut short-term rates as much as 1.50 percentage points this year, if growth slowed to a 2.5 percent pace.
Analysts said that since the economy was widely predicted to grow at less than that rate in the first quarter of this year, the newspaper article effectively presented a case for an easing of rates in the near term.
Other market watchers attributed some of the market's rise to a 1.1 percent drop in the Mitsubishi/ Werthein Schroder weekly sales report, saying that the bond market yesterday was driven by technicals.
Some analysts noted that dealers who tried to set shorts ahead of the auctions, could not because the market failed to give ground, forcing them instead to cover quickly. A short occurs when a market participant sells borrowed securities, hoping to buy them back later at lower prices, thereby pocketing the difference. However, if prices are rising instead of falling, shorts need to cover, that is buy back the securities in order to limit their losses.
According to some trading desks, the two-year note auction went well, with the average yield coming in at 6.15 percent, down sharply from the April auction when the yield was 6.52 percent, and the lowest since June 21, 1994, when the yield was 6.04 percent.
Today the Treasury will auction $11.5 billion in five-year notes, and in when-issued trading they were offered at a price to yield 6.37 percent.
Mr. Shea said he thought that the market was working on breaking out from a consolidation phase and resuming its upward path. In fact, he said, seasonally and technically he likes the market. "This is one of the best times of the year to buy," he said, adding that the yield on the long bond might get to 6 3/8 to 6 5/8 percent in the near term before a substantial correction in the market.
In a technical analysis, Mr. Shea notes, bond price changes have developed a chart formation that is characteristic of fast market moves. This suggests that the market is in the late stages of a bull move, he said.
Eric Hamilton, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said, "There are still concerns that investors are not fully prepared to take on any further supply, and the five-year and one-year auctions today and Thursday may have a harder time finding investor favor" than did the two-year note.
In the Johnson Redbook weekly retail sales report released yesterday sales were up three-tenths of 1 percent for the first three weeks of May versus April. This was down slightly from the four-tenths of 1 percent gain reported last week and was slightly lower than some economists had expected.
Elsewhere, municipals rose in step with the rally in Government bonds, as investors concentrated on yesterday's $1 billion in new debt securities.
In the day's largest scheduled competitive sale, Connecticut sold $125 million in special tax obligation bonds in an offering awarded to Chemical Securities Inc.
The bonds were priced to yield from 4 percent for an issue due in 1996 to 5.75 percent in 2014 and 2015. And because the bonds were insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company they are rated triple-A by the major rating agencies.

LENGTH: 413 words

HEADLINE: Boeing to Cut 5,000 More Jobs Than Originally Expected

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company said yesterday that it expected to eliminate 5,000 more jobs this year than it originally anticipated, bringing the total number of cuts to 12,000. The company said its new forecast resulted from actions taken to reduce costs to stay competitive.
The additional job cuts would occur at a time when the airline industry has returned to profitability after four years of losses. But Boeing officials said the duration of the recession raised doubts about how soon airlines would be ready to order new airplanes. They also said that to remain competitive with the European Airbus Industrie consortium and other aircraft manufacturers, Boeing had to continue reducing costs. 
 Boeing shares closed at $57 yesterday, up 75 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said the increased number of job cuts were not surprising in light of the early retirement program Boeing announced last month, and were more reflective of increased manufacturing efficiency than of pessimism.
"What the company is saying is that the ability to lower employment this month is really the result of efficiencies they've achieved, and not another production-rate cut," William B. Whitlow, an analyst with Pacific Crest Securities in Seattle, said. "The company is really making a lot of headway in increasing productivity."
Boeing said a significant portion of this year's job reduction would result from the one-time special retirement-incentive program offered to employees last month. The 13,000 employees eligible have until June 16 to decide whether to take part in the program. So far, more than 6,000 have said they would do so. Job cuts for the year so far totaled 3,600, leaving 2,400 that must be cut by layoffs or attrition to meet the revised goal of 12,000, a Boeing spokesman said.
"We're pursuing aggressive efforts to reduce costs so that we can maintain and expand our leadership position in the market," Frank Shrontz, Boeing's chairman, said in a statement. "These additional job reductions are the result of efforts to trim the size of our nonmanufacturing work force and improved processes to design and build aerospace products more efficiently."
Most of the added 5,000 job cuts were expected to occur at Boeing plants in the Seattle area. Boeing currently employs 113,900, down from 117,300 at the beginning of the year. As a result of the special retirement program, the company may have to hire new workers in some divisions, Boeing said.

HEADLINE: GRAMM PROPOSAL FOR DEEP TAX CUT KILLED BY SENATE;
Clinton Draws Line on Vetoes On 2 Subjects

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
Confronting the Republican Congress on several major fronts, a combative Clinton Administration today threatened to veto foreign aid legislation the President denounced as "isolationist," as well as any welfare bill that would turn the Federal food stamp program over to the states.
At the same time, the President backed away from his remarks to New Hampshire radio stations on Friday, suggesting that he was preparing his own counterproposal to Republican plans to balance the budget over seven years. 
 After saying that he believed such a goal was achievable, Mr. Clinton returned instead today to themes sounded by his own advisers, calling the seven-year goal "an arbitrary period" that would require "massive tax increases or massive budget cuts," which would hurt the nation's standard of living.
The veto threats, delivered personally by Mr. Clinton and by the Agriculture Secretary, Dan Glickman, continued White House efforts to put the Republicans on the defensive and draw sharp distinctions between the President and the Congress.
And while the White House has insisted that Mr. Clinton's comments in New Hampshire reflected only a marginal shift in his tone and thinking, it was clear from his remarks today that he and his top aides were concerned that the remarks would be interpreted as a significant shift in strategy and draw him into negotiations before he is ready.
Indeed, Senate Republican leaders leapt to deride Mr. Clinton for what they called his "secret plan" to balance the budget, noting that he had endorsed the balanced budget in a key primary state known for its anti-tax mood. "It's strange that only people in New Hampshire have heard about this plan," said the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, who is the front-runner for the Republican nomination to challenge Mr. Clinton.
For the first time today, Mr. Clinton said he would veto legislation under consideration in the Republican Congress that would cut foreign aid and eliminate the Agency for International Development, the United States Information Agency and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.
As the House began debating a measure to cut foreign aid by 15 percent over the next two years and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee worked on its own bill, Mr. Clinton spoke at a news conference in the Rose Garden and assailed the legislation as "the most isolationist proposals to come before the United States Congress in the last 50 years."
Singling out the House proposal, Mr. Clinton said it would compromise efforts to stop North Korea's nuclear program, endanger the Administration's policy toward Russia and restrict the President's ability to fight illegal immigration. "Taken together, these constraints represent nothing less than a frontal assault on the authority of the President to conduct the foreign policy of the United States and on our nation's ability to respond rapidly and effectively to threats to our security."
It was at a hearing of the Senate Agriculture Committee today that Mr. Glickman made it clear that Mr. Clinton would veto any attempt to turn the food stamp program over to the states.
Mr. Glickman said that wrapping food stamps into block grants for the states would do away with a valuable feature of the food stamp and school lunch programs, which as entitlement programs automatically expand to meet increased need in a recession.
But the chairman of the committee, Senator Richard G. Lugar, said that despite the veto threat he was considering suggestions by Republican governors to give each state a lump sum of Federal money to run its own food assistance program.
Mr. Lugar, an Indiana Republican, said he had not decided whether to recommend such changes and added that he had heard nothing on the question from Mr. Dole.
On the question of balancing the budget, when Mr. Clinton was asked if he was prepared to set a target date, he said: "No, but I can say this, I think it can be done -- well, it can -- first of all, it can be done in seven years. The question is what is the penalty and what are the tradeoffs. I think it clearly can be done in less than 10 years."
Today Mr. Clinton emphasized the pain involved in balancing the budget by the year 2002, saying "that would require massive tax increases or massive budget cuts, which would be unfair to our long-term objective to stabilize the incomes and the way of living of the American people."
Seeking to explain the change in emphasis, White House officials later said that since Friday Mr. Clinton had asked for detailed figures on the kinds of cuts needed to balance the budget in seven years and had rejected them as untenable. They also said he was irritated that news accounts of his New Hampshire remarks had interpreted them as signaling a shift in policy.
The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, also suggested that the President had signaled a willingness to negotiate too early, because House and Senate negotiators have not agreed on their own outline for balancing the budget by 2002 and have not indicated if they are willing to compromise with the White House.
Asked if the President's change in tone was designed to keep the emphasis on the Republicans, Mr. McCurry said, "Bingo!"
"The Republicans are still wrestling with their own resolution, and there's a huge internal contradiction in their two versions of a budget resolution," he said. "And the President has made it clear that they've got to reconcile that."
Asked if the President would offer specific full-scale budget alternative, Mr. McCurry said: "It depends. And it depends on what type of posture the Congress will be in at that point.
Mr. Clinton repeated his three longstanding conditions for negotiations with the Republicans: that they drop tax cuts for the wealthy, protect education programs and curtail the growth in Medicare only in the context of overhauling the health care system. He also added a fourth, that Republicans back off from their plan to repeal the scheduled expansion of tax credits for low-income working families with children, which were enacted after Mr. Clinton made them a central feature of his 1993 economic plan.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At a Rose Garden news conference, President Clinton said the seven years that Republicans had set to achieve a balanced budget was "an arbitrary period" that would hurt the nation's standard of living. (David Scull/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.N. Links G.O.P. to Boat People's Riots

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 23

 BODY:
United Nations officials asserted today that a Republican-sponsored proposal to offer asylum in the United States to thousands of Vietnamese boat people set off riots last weekend that left more than 200 injured in Hong Kong.
They also warned that the bill could lead to a new exodus from Vietnam. 
 Refugee officials say the riots last Saturday began when 1,500 Vietnamese, many of them carrying handmade metal spears, refused to be transferred from one detention camp in Hong Kong to another in preparation for their deportation to Vietnam. It was the most violent clash in years between the boat people and the Hong Kong police.
The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which oversees the detention camps in Hong Kong, said the Vietnamese were emboldened to riot by the recent move by Republicans in the House of Representatives to offer asylum to as many as half of the 40,000 Vietnamese still held in detention camps in Asia.
"Absolutely," said Jahanshah Assadi, head of mission for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, when asked if there was a connection between the legislation and the riots. During the riots, he said, "you saw U.S. flags all over the place, you saw portraits of President Clinton all over the place."
At least 180 Hong Kong fire, police and corrections officers were hurt in the clashes on Saturday in the Whitehead detention center, the largest of the Hong Kong camps used to detain the Vietnamese. Dozens of Vietnamese were also hurt in battles in which the camp was blanketed by thick clouds of tear gas.
Representative Chris H. Smith, a New Jersey Republican who is a sponsor of the legislation, said in a statement today in Washington that there was no evidence of a connection between the legislation and the violence in Hong Kong. It is "grossly unfair to blame resistance to forced repatriation on the very people who are trying to come up with a peaceful and gentle solution to the problem of these refugees," he declared.
Mr. Smith has said that many of the Vietnamese residents of the camps, including Buddhist monks and former soldiers of the American-backed South Vietnamese Government, are legitimate political refugees who could be persecuted by Vietnam's Communist Government if sent home.
While the Republican-drafted legislation is opposed by the Clinton Administration and faces an uncertain fate in Congress, word of the Republican plan is already circulating in the camps in Hong Kong, where nearly 21,000 Vietnamese are now detained. Mr. Assadi said in a telephone interview that the Vietnamese who joined in the riots "have the false hope of going to the United States."
Even if the bill is defeated in Congress or vetoed by President Clinton, he said, "the damage has been done," since many Vietnamese now believe that they can resist deportation because "they have strong support from influential members of Congress."
Mr. Assadi said the American asylum proposal could also lead to a new exodus of Vietnamese, taking to rickety boats and pushing off into the dangerous waters of the South China Sea in the hope of becoming one of the lucky 20,000 who might be offered resettlement in the United States.
"That risk is definitely there now," he said. The $30 million asylum plan is part of a foreign affairs appropriations bill now before the full House of Representatives. The bill has already been approved by the House International Relations Committee.
While some Vietnamese rioters waved photographs of President Clinton last weekend, the Administration is in fact a strong advocate of a United Nations-backed plan to return virtually all of them to Vietnam.
While the United States granted asylum to most of the more than one million Vietnamese who fled their homeland after the Vietnam War, sympathy for the boat people has mostly run out. The State Department says that virtually all Vietnamese who remain in Asian detention camps are economic migrants who have no legitimate fear of persecution in Vietnam and are not entitled to asylum.
The deportation program, known as the Comprehensive Plan of Action, was supposed to empty most of the detention camps around Asia -- there are also large camps in Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand -- by the end of the year.
The Hong Kong Government is clearly outraged that the moves in Congress may have contributed to the violence in the camps.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Rebuke by White House
 WASHINGTON, May 23 (By The New York Times) -- Administration officials said today that they had predicted that the proposed Republican measure would encourage thousands of boat people who were not qualified for refugee status to refuse to be returned to Vietnam.
"We are opposed to the proposed legislation which, at the 11th hour, seeks to abrogate an international undertaking," said one State Department official. "The proposed legislation would reopen large-scale screening of those already found to be ineligible for refugee status."
Administration officials predicted that the bill would encourage further riots like the one that occurred on Saturday in Hong Kong.
"The proposed legislation will end voluntary return to Vietnam and create new levels of false hope and result in further disturbances," a State Department official said.
Administration officials assert that the $30 million the bill would set aside to handle the Vietnamese migrants would result in less money being available to handle those found to be legitimate refugees from Vietnam, Cuba, Bosnia and Russia.

HEADLINE: Focus on Federal Power

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
The surprise in the Supreme Court's decision on term limits on Monday was not the result; ever since the Court agreed last June to decide the case, it had been widely assumed that the Justices would find state-imposed limits on Congressional terms to be unconstitutional.
Nor did the surprise lie in the divided vote. The case, argued last November, was the oldest undecided one on the Court's docket, suggesting that a struggle of some dimension was under way that would be unlikely to produce a unanimous ruling. 
 Rather, the startling aspect of the 5-to-4 decision in U.S. Term Limits v. Thornton was how close the Court came to rewriting the script of modern constitutional law and of long-dominant political thought.
Justice Clarence Thomas's dissenting opinion, signed also by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia, would have deposed the Federal Government from its primary role in the constitutional system and resurrected the states as the authentic organs of democratic government.
Taking the opinion at face value, and recognizing that the Court would not actually go so far in the crucible of a real case, it is only a slight exaggeration to say that the dissent brought the Court a single vote shy of reinstalling the Articles of Confederation, the affiliation of sovereign states that the Constitution replaced with the Federal system in 1789.
"It is hard to overstate the importance of how close they came to something radically different from the modern understanding of the Constitution," Prof. Laurence H. Tribe of Harvard Law School said in an interview.
Furthermore, it is barely a month since the same four Justices, joined then by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy to make a 5-to-4 majority, ruled in United States v. Lopez that the authority of Congress to regulate interstate commerce did not reach as far as it had been generally assumed for nearly 60 years. The Court held in that case that Congress did not have the power to make it a Federal crime to possess a gun near a school.
The two events -- what the Court accomplished in the Lopez decision and what the dissenters nearly achieved this week -- have together put in play for the first time in a half-century fundamental questions about the essential nature of the Federal Government. While the dissenters fell short this week, they framed the terms of the debate, retrieving it from the scholarly journals and think tanks to which it had long been relegated and placing it center stage at the Supreme Court.
"The Court is reaching the question at the heart of it all: Did we authorize all this government?" said Roger Pilon, an enthusiastic supporter of the Court's new focus who runs the Center for Constitutional Studies at the Cato Institute, an influential libertarian research organization here.
Cheerfully conceding in an interview today that the underlying question was one of the legitimacy of the national government, Mr. Pilon said: "When you ask the question 'by what authority?' you are asking the most fundamental question in law and in politics. And it's absolutely consistent with the mood of the country that wants to get Washington off our backs."
Justice John Paul Stevens, the 75-year-old liberal Republican who wrote the majority opinion striking down state-imposed term limits, is really the Court's "most reactionary member," Mr. Pilon said, because "he is defending the ancien regime" of centralized Federal power that is enshrined in the Court's modern precedents. He added that Justice Thomas, at the age of 47 the Court's youngest member, was "speaking for the future" in his states' rights dissent.
Whether that is an accurate forecast of the Court's balance of power depends in part on where Justice Kennedy casts his vote as the debate continues to unfold and, more saliently as the 1996 Presidential election approaches, on future appointments to the Court.
It is a measure of how unexpected has been the emergence of the Court's debate over Federal power that no recent Supreme Court nominee has been asked more than a passing question about the issue during the confirmation process.
Confirmation hearings that have examined in excruciating detail constitutional questions ranging from the right to privacy to the authority of the President to deploy troops have understandably skipped issues that have appeared firmly settled since the New Deal, like the scope of Federal authority over the economy.
But the last few weeks at the Court have virtually guaranteed that this omission will not continue. The next "litmus test" for judicial confirmation could easily be the vigor with which a nominee endorses the dissenting Justices' statements in the term-limits case that "the Federal Government's powers are limited and enumerated" and that "the ultimate source of the Constitution's authority is the consent of the people of each individual state, not the consent of the undifferentiated people of the nation as a whole."
"This is a Court that is reopening first principles," Prof. Paul Gewirtz of Yale Law School said in an interview. Both Chief Justice Rehnquist's majority opinion in the Lopez case and Justice Thomas's dissent on Monday used the phrase "first principles," Professor Gewirtz noted.
What those first principles are, in fact, is the heart of the debate. "Some of what Justice Thomas thinks of as first principles were actually the first principles of those who opposed ratification of the Constitution," Professor Gewirtz said. He noted that Patrick Henry, an opponent of ratification who once declared, "I am not really an American, I am a Virginian," demanded at the Virginia ratifying convention in 1788, "Who authorizes the gentlemen to speak the language of 'we the people' instead of 'we the states?' "
"We the people of the United States" is, of course, the opening phrase of the preamble of the Constitution. Justice Stevens, in his majority opinion in the term-limits case, cited the preamble for another of its famous phrases, "a more perfect union."
But the Court is so divided on the basic question of national structure and identity that even the Constitution's preamble, a paragraph so familiar as to strike modern readers as platitudinous, provided no common ground between the majority and the dissent.
Justice Thomas noted in a footnote to his dissenting opinion that as originally drafted at the Philadelphia convention, the opening phrase was "We the people of the states of New Hampshire, Massachusetts" and so on, and that the phrase "the United States" is used throughout the Constitution "consistently as a plural noun."

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 297 words

HEADLINE: Making It Easier to Get Justice in America

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Make Haste Slowly" (column, May 15): Imagine our surprise when we found something on which we could agree with Anthony Lewis. While we are not in accord on all civil justice reform issues, he makes a very strong point about lowering the costs of litigation by curbing some abuses of plaintiffs' lawyers. 
 When we introduced our civil justice reform legislation this year, we included a limitation on attorneys' contingent fees that Mr. Lewis praised. That bill is pending before the Senate Judiciary Committee. The fee limit, which has the endorsement of legal scholars from Norman Dorsen to Robert Bork, is one sure way of putting more money in the hands of injured victims.
Studies show that the injured receive too few of the dollars spent in the liability system. Most of the money goes to the system and to the lawyers on both sides, who profit from the status quo.
We also propose an early-offer, rapid-recovery mechanism that would enable injured parties to recover a specified amount that would include all of their economic losses, both past and future, without a legal battle.
Both of these reforms change the incentive structure of the legal system, which too often rewards the most contentious and protracted litigation. Defendants must be encouraged to make fair and reasonable offers at an early stage; plaintiffs need incentives to accept them. These proposals do just that.
The Senate has just completed action on much-needed product liability reform legislation. We anticipate further legal reforms in the 104th Congress and look forward to Mr. Lewis's continued support of our efforts to put more money faster into the hands of injured persons.
 
(Senator) MITCH McCONNELL
(Senator) SPENCER ABRAHAM
Washington, May 19, 1995

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
In My Next Column

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I've been keeping my eye on Mexico lately, watching the economic indicators there so I can be the first columnist to write that America's $20 billion bailout of Mexico -- which I favored -- has worked.
This is not that column. This is the column just before that column -- the one that says there are a lot of positive indications the Mexican bailout is working, but that it's too soon for a definitive judgment. 
 Am I a chicken, or what? Not really. Because there is something definitive that can be said right now about the Mexico bailout. It always had two objectives. One was to save the Mexican economy from melting down; the other was to save the system from melting down -- the system of developing countries adopting free-market models, privatizing their state-owned industries and financing their growth with domestic savings and private capital from developed countries.
While it's still unclear whether the bailout will bail out Mexico, it is clear that it has preserved the system, by giving time for the other developing countries that were being dragged down with Mexico to get their balance sheets in order and disengage from Mexico's fate. In other words, Mexico's fate is still in doubt, but it's now much less important.
At the peak of Mexico's crisis a lot of investors called their brokers and screamed in panic: "Get me out of all emerging markets" -- without distinguishing. That's why Mexico's financial collapse threatened to set off a domino effect. What the U.S.-led bailout of Mexico did was buy time for the next two dominos in line, Brazil and Argentina, to fortify themselves and to persuade investors that their stories were different from Mexico's.
Argentina just overwhelmingly re-elected President Carlos Menem, who ran on a platform of continued free-market reforms, combined with tight fiscal and monetary policies that will hurt many Argentine workers but promise long-term stability. In other words, Argentine voters looked at Mexico and instead of saying let's try a different model, said let's stick with the same model only do it right. Other dominos rattled by Mexico, like Peru, India and South Africa, have done the same, and foreign investors are now flocking back to all of them.
As for Mexico itself, the peso has stabilized at around 6 to the dollar, from near 8 at the height of the crisis. Interest rates are down from 100 percent to 60 percent. In the first quarter of this year Mexico ran a $165 million trade surplus, versus a $4.3 billion deficit the same period a year ago. Its exports were up 33 percent -- all signs that the Government's new policies are working.
But that's also Mexico's problem. The rescue plan is working. It is putting the Mexican people through a brutal recession, like wiring someone's jaw shut to lose weight. With 500,000 newly unemployed, the potential for a social explosion remains very high. On the finance side, the main problems are banks, banks, banks. There are a lot of Mexicans with variable-rate mortgages who cannot repay at the current high rates, so the banks are carrying huge amounts of bad loans. The potential for bank runs, or for the Government to have to prop up banks with cash and create more inflation, is still real. Until foreigners are assured that Mexico's inflation is under control, it is unlikely they will return in large numbers and the Government will still need to draw bailout funds.
Still, President Clinton's decision to rescue Mexico was the largest non-military international commitment by America since the Marshall Plan. It was done without Congressional or public support, because it meant bailing out some U.S. speculators as well. But what Mr. Clinton understood was that it was important to rescue Mexico -- not because a few big American investors would be helped by it, but despite the fact that a few big American investors would be helped by it. Because the issue was never just Mexico, but the stability of the global system.
Of course, some reckless populists like Senator Al D'Amato advocated doing nothing. But as bankers will tell you, it was that sort of shortsighted thinking that made the Great Depression "Great."
No, if this works, the Mexico bailout could go down as the least popular, least understood, but most important foreign policy decision of the Clinton Presidency.
But this is not that column. This is the column just before that column.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Dole and Gramm: At Play in the Field of Budgets

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
At a passing glance, it may appear that the Senate's 100 members have spent most of the week debating a plan to balance the Federal budget. In fact, maybe 46 of them have. The other 54 -- that is to say, the Republicans -- have been watching a race for President.
The contestants are Senators Bob Dole of Kansas and Phil Gramm of Texas, the early leaders among Republican Presidential aspirants, and their field of battle has been that chestnut of Republican political issues, cutting taxes. Mr. Dole, the front-runner, says he wants to. Mr. Gramm, playing catch-up, says he wants to more, much more. Mr. Dole says he wants to just as much as Mr. Gramm. And so on. 
 This dance for political advantage has played on and off the Senate floor all week, elbowing aside an eye-glazing budget debate whose outcome was long preordained anyway. The blunt truth is that the Dole-Gramm jousting is the main event by default, but it is still worth watching.
A week of back-and-forth over the tax-cut issue has cast in relief the personalities and political skills and flaws of the two men: Mr. Dole, the cagey, tight-lipped tactician; Mr. Gramm, the battering ram who disdains tactics for the brute force of argument.
As if it were needed, it has also underscored the clout of the those on the Republican new right, the Gingrich wing of the party for whom tax cuts are not just a platform plank, but the foundation.
Mr. Gramm has their hearts, but needs to persuade them that he can outpoint Mr. Dole and win the party's 1996 nomination for President. Mr. Dole looks like a winner, but needs to persuade them that he has their interests at heart.
For Mr. Dole, this is no easy task. For one thing, he is majority leader in a Senate whose Republicans are, by and large, far less radical than the Gingrich acolytes, and he cannot appease the right without risking the loss of his colleagues' support in legislative battles to come. For another, he has a record of Republican-style moderation that he cannot shed without appearing to the nation at large to be unprincipled.
Mr. Gramm, on the other hand, has little to lose by courting the activist conservatives who are a real force in the early months of a Presidential campaign.
"Phil Gramm is playing to the Republican primary voter," Kenneth M. Duberstein, former chief of staff to the patriarch of tax-cutters, President Ronald Reagan, said the other day. "He's not worrying about the general election. Bob Dole is worrying about both."
The field for this contest has been the Senate's budget blueprint, the document in which Republicans have shown in rough terms how they intend to move the nation to fiscal balance in seven years. The House version of this document makes additional reductions in spending to accommodate a raft of tax breaks, for businesses and individuals, that is expected to total $350 billion by 2002.
The Senate version, drafted by Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the Budget Committee chairman and Mr. Dole's close ally, held out the prospect of a tax cut -- but only later, after a balanced budget is locked into law. And it suggested that any cut should be limited to $170 billion, the amount some economists say the Government could save if a balanced budget led to lower interest rates and lower finance charges for Federal borrowing.
Perhaps sensing a chance to highlight his ideological differences with Mr. Dole, Mr. Gramm decided weeks ago to make the tax issue a battleground. He made it known that he would try to attach a House-sized tax package to the Senate budget proposal, paid for with deeper savings in Federal programs like Medicaid.
In Green Bay, Wis., last weekend, he told Midwest Republicans that Mr. Dole showed no commitment to lower taxes despite a promise by the Senate's Republicans in last fall's campaign. "We have some Republicans who have one foot firmly implanted in the dramatic change we committed to," Mr. Gramm said, mentioning no one by name, "and they have the other foot firmly implanted in business as usual in Washington. This week, they are going to have to pick one of those feet up."
Mr. Gramm's plan, which he proposed on Monday, cut taxes for families, retirees, small businesses and others by $300 billion, omitting only a few of the breaks in the House tax proposal. In truth, it stood no chance of passing the cautious Senate, where a body of Republicans opposes cutting taxes at all until the budget is on the way to balance.
But an effect of it was to put Mr. Dole on the hook, and, for a long while, he seemed to wiggle between the Republican right and the moderates he represents as majority leader.
Mr. Dole repeatedly promised that the Senate's final budget would include a tax cut, but he did not say how large it would be, whom it would benefit or when it might be enacted. Asked outright whether he supported Mr. Domenici's no-tax-cut-now stance, he said drily, "I haven't talked to Mr. Domenici about that."
There were rumors, then sightings, of Republicans closeted in Mr. Dole's office, trying to hash out a compromise tax plan that would appease both Mr. Gramm and the majority leader.
Mr. Dole refused to confirm such sightings. "If they want to see me, they know where to find me," he said of the negotiators.
Mr. Gramm, in a speech on the Senate floor, rejected bargaining. "I know there are others talking about cutting deals, compromising," he said caustically, again mentioning no names.
If the United States is to take a new course, he said, "we've got to stop cutting deals in Washington."
On Thursday, the moment of truth arrived, and Mr. Gramm's proposal came to a vote. It lost by an unexpectedly large margin, 31 to 69. Twenty-three of the 54 Republicans opposed it.
Mr. Dole voted for it.
"I think it has possibilities," he said, without elaboration.
On record in support of Mr. Gramm's plan, but unencumbered by it, Mr. Dole now appears ready to support an alternative filed late today by one of the negotiators, Senator Rod Grams of Minnesota. The plan would effectively follow Mr. Domenici's dictates, allotting $170 billion for tax relief over seven years. But first, the Congressional Budget Office would have to certify that that $170 billion was actually materializing.
Republican aides said Mr. Dole would speak on the Senate floor on Friday, advocating that the money be devoted to a $500-per-child tax credit for most families, lower capital-gains and estate taxes and a new individual retirement account for spouses.
"Dole came out of this fine," one Republican senator said today. "He covered his rear."
Mr. Gramm begged to differ. A "cut-a-deal, kiss-your-sister kind of compromise," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Europe Warns of Trade Suits On Car Quotas

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: PARIS, May 24

 BODY:
Fearing they might be cut out of a deal on auto imports, European officials warned Japan and the United States today that they would sue both countries if the Japanese agreed to demands to set numerical targets for increased imports of American cars.
It was the most aggressive step to date by the Europeans, who have condemned the plan by the Clinton Administration to impose punitive tariffs of 100 percent on 13 Japanese luxury cars as a violation of world trade rules. 
 The warning came as the American Secretary of Commerce, Ronald H. Brown, acknowledged that the United States was unsure of its legal standing in such threats of trade retaliation. Mr. Brown said at a briefing with reporters here that Government lawyers had given mixed opinions to the Administration on whether its intention to increase tariffs on Japanese cars was legal under the new world trade agreement adopted last year.
The Clinton Administration has demanded that Japan force open its automotive markets and set a figure for increased American auto sales by June 28 or it will impose the sanctions, effective last Saturday.
Some trade experts noted that the world trade agreement set tariff levels for automobile imports and said that any increase would blatantly violate the accord.
"We believe such numerically denominated imports amount to managed trade and would violate international trade rules," Sir Leon Brittan, the European Union's chief trade official, said today. "And we would give very serious consideration to taking action against such an agreement" at the World Trade Organization, he said.
Sir Leon's warnings, delivered to Japan on behalf of the 15 countries of the European Union, came on the second of a tense two-day meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development here.
The American plan to impose $6.5 billion in new tariffs on Japanese luxury cars in retaliation for Japan's closed-market system has overshadowed other debate at the meeting.
The threat by European officials places them in the middle of the auto trade debate. It underlines the level of European frustration with tactics that amount to a threat of a trade war, just a few months after 124 nations had signed an agreement meant to settle such disputes through a system centered at the World Trade Organization in Geneva.
Japan welcomed today's statement by the European Union, its officials said, as it amounted to support for its position against the United States in their increasingly heated trade dispute.
Though there was little disagreement that Japan's markets were not fully open to foreign competition, almost every member of the O.E.C.D., an organization of 25 of the world's richest nations, was visibly upset over plans by the United States to take action on its own against Japan and not let the matter rest with the World Trade Organization.
Clinton Administration officials asserted that after two days of talks with fellow O.E.C.D. members, they had gained support. But others here said no other country was willing to support the use of sanctions against Tokyo.
Japan pushed hard to include language that explicitly condemned the use of unilateral trade actions in the meeting's final statement, and officials here said that all the O.E.C.D.'s nations supported the Japanese position except the United States.
But it was the United States' threat that it would not agree to the final communique, and Japan's willingness to avoid outright confrontation, that kept the language out of the document, officials said.
Numerical targets are hardly a new concept in Japanese-American trade relations. Indeed, during the Bush Administration, an agreement was reached that set target levels on imports of American-made auto parts. But since the new round of negotiations with the Clinton Administration began two years ago, Japan has been resisting that idea.
"We cannot force Japanese auto dealers to sell American cars," said Atsushi Oi, director of the automobile industry division of the Japanese trade ministry, the top-ranking Government specialist brought here to persuade Europeans that Japan had tried to open its markets to American cars and that the problem was that American auto makers had made only paltry efforts to gain a greater share of the Japanese market. "We cannot do any more."
In the end, much of the wrangling centered on the interpretation of numbers. Japanese trade officials, for instance, said that American auto makers were selling only two cars with steering wheels on the right side -- the standard in Japan -- so how could the Big Three expect to sell more cars.
American officials said such arguments were bunk, that Detroit had 10-right hand drive models but could not get the cars into Japan.
"If you don't have dealerships and can't get the cars into the country, how can you sell cars," a senior American official said.

HEADLINE: Gerry Adams and Briton Discuss Ulster Peace in Washington

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
Gerry Adams, the political leader of the Irish Republican Army, and Sir Patrick Mayhew, the British Secretary for Northern Ireland, met for the first time today to discuss the peace effort in Northern Ireland.
The meeting lasted 30 minutes in Sir Patrick's sixth-floor suite at the Sheraton Washington Hotel. Mr. Adams said the meeting was "very useful, frank and friendly and positive." He added, "We understand each other's position." 
 Asked if he could "do business" with Sir Patrick, Mr. Adams answered, "Absolutely." The two men shook hands, but not in sight of photographers. Mr. Adams added that the meeting had "moved the full situation forward."
Sir Patrick was less sanguine about the meeting, which he described as "civil." He said he had urged Sinn Fein to try again to persuade the I.R.A. to begin decommissioning its arsenal, but said he did not get a positive response from Mr. Adams. "I won't negotiate with a party associated with a paramilitary organization that won't give up its arms," Sir Patrick said.
Officials and experts said this meant that there was still a long way to go before the British Government would allow Sinn Fein to take part in full-fledged peace talks.
The meeting was expected to clear one of several obstructions to the peace moves that have been advancing sporadically since the I.R.A. declared a cease-fire last Aug. 31. Mr. Adams had been demanding a meeting with Sir Patrick for months, arguing that the Secretary, the ranking official in the British province of Ulster, was in contact with other parties involved, including Protestant unionists, mainstream Roman Catholics and the Irish Government.
Sir Patrick had delayed contact with Mr. Adams because he wants assurances from him that Sinn Fein is ready to discuss ways to decommission the I.R.A. arsenal, estimated at 100 tons of weapons.
The meeting came at the start of a White House-sponsored conference on trade and investment in Ireland, which President Clinton promised last year as part of his attempt to foster peace in Northern Ireland.
The talks at the Sheraton Washington upstaged the economic aspects of the conference, which Mr. Clinton, Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and a number of American business executives are scheduled to address on Thursday.
"For the first time representatives of all Ireland, not only political but from the community, are meeting under the same roof," said John Hume, the leader of the Social Democratic and Labor Party in Northern Ireland, whose secret talks with Mr. Adams two years ago led to the revival and acceleration of the peace effort. "Given that we're all prepared to sit down and talk about jobs, it shouldn't be too hard to sit down to talk about lives."
He said that Sir Patrick, having met with Mr. Adams, should now agree to permit Sinn Fein to take part in full-fledged peace talks, including all the Protestant and Catholic parties and the British and Irish Governments. Such talks are Sinn Fein's main demand. But officials and independent experts say that there will be no all-party talks until the arms issue is resolved.
The meeting today gave Sinn Fein the important recognition it wanted, showing that political negotiations, as distinguished from the I.R.A. campaign of violence, had attained for Mr. Adams a meeting of equals with Sir Patrick.
Some Irish and British officials said the meeting was pressed on the British by the White House, which wants the peace negotiations to move faster.
