HEADLINE: Long War Turns Liberia Into Core of a Spreading Blight

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia

 BODY:
Nearly every street of this city bears the marks of the five-year-old conflict in Liberia. Medical clinics have been stripped of their roofs. Government ministries, dark and looted shells, are crowded homes to squatters.
In the countryside, instead of merely being the theater of constant small-scale skirmishes between poorly armed peasants, one village after another has been leveled and inhabitants slaughtered by the heavy firepower of tribally based militias that mark their territory with the skulls of their victims. 
 If regions can be likened to neighborhoods, few would dispute that Liberia has been the eyesore of West Africa. While many countries in the region have made unparalleled strides toward democracy and economic reform in the last few years, the blight of Liberia's crisis has also spread.
"There are ever more cross-border incidents in the Ivory Coast," a Western diplomat said here. "You've got a major refugee crisis in Guinea, and as far away as Mali now we are seeing a wave of armed robberies using Liberian weapons."
Of all the countries in the region, however, none has been more affected than Liberia's western neighbor, Sierra Leone. Shortly after the Liberian rebel leader Charles Taylor invaded his country from the Ivory Coast in 1989, he helped spawn a copycat movement next door.
Now, after an increasingly intense yearlong drive that has resembled a scorched-earth campaign, Sierra Leone's rebels, led by a shadowy former army photographer named Foday Sankoh, are camped on the doorstep of the capital, Freetown, and stand far closer to their goal of power than does Mr. Taylor.
In both cases, experts on this region readily identify the factors behind the political decay. First, in Liberia, as in Sierra Leone, years of misrule and economic hardship created a desperate yearning for change. Next, neighbors began to take advantage of each country's weakness, exploiting resources in exchange for cash and arms.
"Had our neighbors not permitted their borders to be used for the arms trade, we would never have had this problem," said David Kpormankpor, chairman of the Council of State, Liberia's governing body.
Additionally, analysts say, the failure of the West to respond adequately has encouraged others to meddle. Diplomats say Libya and its leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, have been the most active and puzzling troublemakers.
"In the 1980's, Qaddafi began looking for interesting characters in the region, helped them get set up and has maintained contact with them," a Western diplomat said. "This provided him with a way to take a slap at the Americans, a slap at the French and a slap at the British, without really leaving fingerprints."
Recently, diplomats say, Colonel Qaddafi has received visits from Mr. Taylor and Burkina Faso's President, Blaise Compaore. For years, diplomats have complained that Mr. Compaore has funneled arms and logistical support to Mr. Taylor, and, many now suspect, to Mr. Sankoh of Sierra Leone. These leaders share military tactics or pasts, and a vague leftist or nationalist oratory.
Some of the fighters in Mr. Sankoh's group, the Revolutionary United Front, are known to have received training in Libya, and diplomats say Mr. Sankoh maintains contact with Colonel Qaddafi.
"What we are seeing is a Libyan move to extend its influence throughout West Africa by reaching out to young, ambitious leaders who have been frozen out by the West or otherwise frustrated," a European analyst said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Pressing China Hard to Maintain Democracy in Hong Kong

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, May 24

 BODY:
Signaling heightened interest in Hong Kong's future, American officials have issued their boldest warnings yet to China over its future treatment of the British colony when it reverts to Chinese sovereignty in two years.
The warnings have provoked a wave of denunciations from Beijing-controlled newspapers here. 
 In a blunt statement by the United States Consul General and in comments by Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia, Washington has expressed its apprehensions over excessive control of Hong Kong's economic and social freedoms.
"What we're saying," Mr. Lord said during a brief visit to Hong Kong over the weekend, "is, we have a strong interest in the prosperity and stability of Hong Kong."
The strengthening of attitudes on Hong Kong comes at a time of growing concern here over how China will govern the territory. The local press is full of articles about the future of the legal system, threats to freedom of the press and the outlook for democratic politics.
This toughening also comes as the Clinton Administration has decided to grant a visa to Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, a decision that Beijing greeted with a barrage of hostile pronouncements.
In setting forth Washington's objectives in Hong Kong, the Consul General, Richard Mueller, emphasized that the United States wants a continuation of Hong Kong's autonomy, the flourishing of its free-market economy, a firm commitment to the rule of law, the protection of human rights and the development of democratic institutions.
Mr. Mueller emphasized the continuation of Hong Kong's autonomy, which is set forth in the Basic Law, a Beijing document that stipulates China's policies toward Hong Kong.
"The continuation of this promised high degree of autonomy is a key factor in the future of Hong Kong's international position, and in the future of U.S.-Hong Kong relations specifically." Mr. Mueller said. "U.S. interests focus particularly on the rule of law and the protection of civil liberties."
China and Britain, whose lease on Hong Kong expires in 1997, are deeply divided over setting up a Court of Final Appeal, which is to be the highest court. The impasse has become increasingly worrying for businesses seeking protection of contract and property rights.
Mr. Mueller's remarks, earlier this month, drew an immediate and stinging retort from Beijing-controlled newspapers, which accused him of interfering in the British-Chinese talks and of collaborating with the British Governor, Chris Patten, who is routinely demonized in the pro-China press.
"It is inappropriate for a U.S. Consul General in Hong Kong to utter the above mentioned remarks," Wen Wei Po declared in an editorial, "quoting out of context and siding with Chris Patten in his policy to confront China and stir up trouble in Hong Kong."
Increasingly throughout the year, Beijing has attacked American statements on Hong Kong.
A State Department report in April surveyed American interests in Hong Kong and firmly supported efforts by Mr. Patten to expand democratic institutions, especially the legislature. China has said it will abolish any democratic structures created before 1997.
A Foreign Ministry spokesman in Beijing, Chen Jian, described the report as "irresponsible" and "interference" in China's internal affairs. "The Chinese side would like to express our strong displeasure," he said.

HEADLINE: Brazil's Former President Can't Seem to Make Up His Mind

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 17

 BODY:
As President of Brazil until last December, Itamar Franco displayed an indecisiveness that was the despair of the nation. Out of office, his dithering over a plush diplomatic post has become mass entertainment.
In Bolivia, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela, former Presidents are battling lawsuits or court trials. Here, in Latin America's largest country, Mr. Franco has been agonizing over what most consider a soft landing -- his appointment by his successor, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, as Ambassador to Portugal, Brazil's former colonial power. 
 When he was in office, the soft-spoken Mr. Franco was a reluctant President, often offering to resign. But since his diplomatic appointment, he seems to have been looking for excuses to avoid leaving the bright lights of Brasilia, the capital.
"Perhaps nostalgic for the spotlight, he insists on remaining on the stage," Mauricio Dias, a newspaper columnist, wrote recently.
Although sending political rivals into golden exile as ambassadors is a longstanding Latin American custom, Mr. Franco seemed a curious choice for an ambassador because of his limited diplomatic skills. As President, he routinely ducked official receptions and dinners by staying in his hotel room. Averse to overseas travel, he offended the Portuguese by canceling official visits to Lisbon twice at the last minute.
Mr. Franco took three months to accept the ambassadorship. When he did, Brazil's Senate responded with unusual speed, unanimously approving the nomination in March without debate.
He sent his clothes and butler on to Lisbon, but since then has jumped at every opportunity to avoid following.
First, Mr. Franco made it known that he had taken offense when Brazil's Foreign Minister, Luiz Felipe Lampreia, failed to greet his former boss at the door of the Foreign Ministry when he came to discuss his appointment. Then Mr. Franco's girlfriend, June Drummond, announced that she would not go to Lisbon with him unless he married her. Initially, he seemed inclined to do that, and the Supreme Court completed in record time its ratification of Ms. Drummond's 1994 divorce in the United States.
Then it appeared that the 63-year-old politician had cold feet about marrying Ms. Drummond, a teacher half his age. No wedding date has been set.
As he has lingered in Brazil, the former President has repeatedly broken a vow of political silence he took when his term ended.
When a federal judge criticized a labor accord reached by Mr. Franco while President, he called the judge "an ignoramus." But the harshest outburst came when Clovis Carvalho, Mr. Cardoso's chief of staff, charged that Mr. Franco had derailed a privatization program.
"Let's hope that this citizen understands historical and political facts better and that he shuts his mouth," Mr. Franco wrote recently in a telegram sent first to President Cardoso and then to newspapers.
Referring to the plan to reduce inflation that went into effect during his presidency and that was based on a new unit of currency, the real, he added, "One day history will show my participation in your presidential candidacy -- approving, endorsing, and supporting the Real Plan."
In response, Antonio Carlos Magalhaes, a conservative Senator and former ally, belittled the former President. "To this day, the ex-President doesn't understand the Real Plan," he said. "He did everything so that the plan would not work."
After this broadside, Mr. Franco kept silent. Through friends, he hinted that he might fly to Lisbon after all.

HEADLINE: Charitable Giving Rose 3.6% in 1994, Philanthropy Trust Says

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Charitable giving in the United States rose by 3.6 percent last year to $130 billion, just slightly ahead of inflation, according to figures made public yesterday by the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel's Trust for Philanthropy. After inflation, the gain amounted to six-tenths of 1 percent.
At a time when Speaker Newt Gingrich and other government officials are calling for charity to replace government aid in some functions, these figures provide little evidence of any surge in charitable giving, either by individuals or corporations. 
 "There is a big question about how much our nonprofit sector can absorb," said Ann E. Kaplan, research director for the association, which gathers these figures annually.
Giving by individuals, which accounts for about 80 cents out of every dollar given to charity in the United States, was up by eight-tenths of 1 percent after inflation, or slightly more than giving over all. Giving by foundations, which accounts for almost 8 cents of every dollar given to charity, was also up slightly after inflation. But giving by corporations, which accounts for just under 5 cents of every charitable dollar, fell by 2 percent after inflation.
Officials of the philanthropy trust said, however, that they believe corporations are contributing in other ways that do not necessarily get counted.
Ms. Kaplan said the increase in giving last year probably grew out of the improving economy and in people's confidence in their own future.
Not all areas of giving showed gains, however. Giving to human services and to arts, culture and humanities, two sectors that are expected to be hit hardest by local, state and Federal budget cuts, declined on a real basis last year, after inflation.
Charitable donations in all other areas of giving showed an increase after inflation, including donations to religious causes (up 1.4 percent), education (up 5.3 percent) and health institutions (up 3.3 percent).
International affairs, a relatively small area of giving by Americans, showed the biggest gain, to $2.2 billion, for an increase of 15.3 percent after inflation. That is up sharply from the $900 million given for international affairs in 1987, the year the association began to track that type of giving as a separate category.
Environmental and wildlife groups and public benefit organizations like those involved in civil rights and community development also showed gains of nearly 8 percent after inflation last year.
One question in philanthropic circles now is whether the problems stemming from the bankruptcy of the Foundation for New Era Philanthropy will discourage giving by other potential donors.
Helmer Ekstrom, president of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel, an association of consultants to charitable groups, said the New Era situation could lead some potential donors to raise questions about whether charities were handling their donations responsibly. But he added that he believed most charities would be able to convince their donors that "they are minding the store and taking good care of the gifts they get."
Members of the association were also optimistic that the New Era problems would have only a minor impact on giving.
"The Aramony-United Way affair was quite damaging to giving," said J. Patrick Ryan, the association's chairman. "Some nonprofit groups made some mistakes, but they were in good company. This is not a matter of malfeasance by executives running the nonprofits, except for bad judgment."

HEADLINE: China Takes Its Own Way in World Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
William Safire's "China's 'Four Fears' " (column, May 22) contains four errors: 
 (1) Inflation in China is declining. April inflation fell to 18 percent, the sixth consecutive monthly decline. It did not rise to 20 percent, as Mr. Safire implies. The "average Chinese" may have many economic worries, but a fear that "half of what he saves disappears after four years" because of inflation is not one of them. His savings account receives an "interest rate subsidy" on top of the normally earned interest, calculated to compensate for increase in the price level.
It is questionable whether China's gradual lifting of its prices to world price levels can be called "inflation." The national currency has been steadily appreciating against the United States dollar in the last 15 months, and the income of wage and salary earners is growing faster than prices rise. Last year, the national savings rate topped 50 percent of gross domestic product.
(2) There is no such thing as "workers' fear of underemployment" in China. There is fear among "underemployed workers" in archaic sectors of the economy that they may lose their patronage appointments to more productive competitors. Many among those who "migrate eastward" do so by abandoning dead-end employment in order to seek more productive and rewarding opportunities.
Moreover, in the last half-year, large-scale migration of investment capital inland has been spreading these opportunities beyond the "prosperous coast."
(3) Farmers' land is not "encroached on by industrialization." Farmers themselves are selling their appreciated land for profit and are going into business. Farmers do not "now prefer" to sell to local entities and black markets. They have always preferred to do so, and this preference was unfettered by Deng Xiaoping's reforms in 1978 and constituted the backbone of China's free-market reforms.
(4) What dominates in Beijing these days is not fear of "some expression of the people's disgust at pervasive corruption." What dominates is the tactic of the reformers, centered around an effort to impose congressional supervision over party and government, thereby channeling "the people's disgust at pervasive corruption" into successful campaigns against party hacks who impede free-market reforms.
Mr. Safire's charge that the economic chief, Zhu Rongji, has reverted to "regulation" and "central control" is misleading.
His most notable measure of "central control" in the last year has been to introduce central banking and a unified financial market against the opposition of corrupt provincial political machines.
It will do us no good to misread what 1.2 billion people are up to. Nor will it do us any good to try and alter their course by "using our market muscle to encourage freer enterprise." China's reformers started encouraging freer enterprise for their own national strategic reasons some 17 years ago -- before anyone in the West had any inkling that such a thing was possible.
China's largest trading partner is not the United States, and some 85 percent of all foreign investments into the country come from wealthy overseas Chinese. Japan, the largest among the non-Chinese foreign investors, is also China's largest trading partner.
 
CRITON M. ZOAKOS
Newton, N.J., May 23, 1995
 
The writer heads LETO Research, which invests in Burma and China.

HEADLINE: Letter Grades Flunk The Evaluation Test

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "A's Aren't That Easy" (Op-Ed, May 17): 
 It has always been my impression that grade inflation had already begun by the early 1970's. Thus, I am not surprised there has been little change since then. It would be more useful to compare today's grades with those from 30 years ago, when C's and D's were allegedly more common than today.
I hope that widespread attention to this phenomenon reflects an emerging appreciation of the inadequacy of letter grades as a system of academic evaluation. In the last two decades I have had experience with both letter-grade and narrative evaluation systems, as undergraduate and graduate student, college professor, employer and, now, mother of a school-age child.
From all these perspectives, I have found letter grades deceptive and uninformative.
Narrative evaluations provide the rigorous and useful details that parents, admissions committees, employers and the students themselves need: the strengths and weaknesses of all aspects of student work, including exams, papers and research projects, oral and written skills, creativity, mastery of the subject, consistency of performance.
Narrative evaluation systems have been sustained at colleges and universities (notably the University of California at Santa Cruz), and are becoming widespread in private and public schools.
 
MARY BETH SAFFO
Associate Professor, Life Sciences
Arizona State University West
Phoenix, May 17, 1995

HEADLINE: Raytheon Can't Complain About Electric Rates

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Corporate dissembling reached a new level in the declaration by a senior executive of the Raytheon Company, likening his Massachusetts-based company to helpless sheep because regulations compel it to buy costly power from in-state utilities (Business Day, May 18). 
 Raytheon itself may be the biggest single cause of its high electric rates. A Raytheon subsidiary, United Engineers & Constructors, designed the $6 billion Seabrook nuclear plant, collecting $1 billion in engineering fees, much of it from Massachusetts utilities that own a large chunk of the grossly expensive plant. United Engineers & Constructors was also a prime cheerleader for Seabrook, declaring it essential to the regional economy, and for nuclear power in general, trumpeting its illusory cost-effectiveness in a dozen government-paid studies over two decades. By all means, let Raytheon shop around for cheap power, but let it first make reasonable reparations for helping to create the predicament it now decries.
 
CHARLES KOMANOFF
New York, May 22, 1995
 
The writer is an independent energy economist.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Bonds Rise and Yields Drop On New Signs of Slowdown
Bond prices surged and their yields fell sharply after a Government report showed a drop of 4 percent in orders in April, convincing some investors that the Fed's next move would be to lower interest rates.
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond dropped to 6.74 percent, its lowest level in nearly 15 months. [Page D20.] 

Stocks closed mixed after drifting for much of the day. The Dow industrials edged higher to 4,438.16, up 1.72 points. [D10.]
 
Europeans Threaten Trade Suit If Japan Accepts U.S. Car Quotas
European officials, fearful of being cut out of any deal on auto imports, warned Japan and the U.S. that they would sue both countries if the Japanese agreed to set numerical targets for increased imports of American cars. The aggressive step followed European condemnations of American tariffs. [A1.]
 
Salomon's Loss, Merrill's Gain
Sheldon Epstein, who invented the indexed-amortizing swap, is leaving Salomon after less than a month to rejoin Merrill Lynch. [D2.]
 
Sprint Alliance Hits Snag
Sprint's attempt to form an alliance with France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom hit another obstacle when the European Union's commissioner for competitiveness criticized the $4.2 billion deal's joint venture. [D3.]
 
Insiders Work on Securities Bill
The Senate Banking Committee is to begin work on securities legislation today that could save businesses and securities firms billions of dollars by making it harder for investors to sue. Critics contend the firms had too much say in crafting the bill. Two top Senate aides who worked on it have accepted jobs in the industry. [A1.]
 
California to Seek Low-Cost Power
The California Public Utilities Commission recommended the creation of an agency to buy power for the state's utility customers from the lowest-cost producers. [D4.]
 
Voting Begins on Phone Bill
The House Commerce Committee began voting on provisions of a bill to overhaul the nation's communications laws, but put off the most volatile issues until today.[D3.]
 
One Orange County Case Dismissed
The bankruptcy judge handling the Orange County, Calif., fund collapse ordered a dismissal of the investment pool's bankruptcy case, but not that of the county itself. [D2.]
 
Bogus Parts Used for Aircraft
The F.A.A. told a Senate subcommittee that bogus parts were common on airliners because of greed by suppliers and weak Government oversight. Several witnesses said inspectors were lax. [A18.]
 
Matsushita Warns of Loss
Matsushita Electric said its earnings more than tripled, to 90.5 billion yen, or $1.02 billion, for the last fiscal year, but the Japanese company warned that it would lose about $730 million next year because of its $1.9 billion loss on the sale of MCA to Seagram. Matsushita said that on a pretax basis, it would still remain profitable. [D6.]
 
Chairman Quits Embattled Ayer
A battle for control of N. W. Ayer erupted publicly with the unexpected announcement that Steve Dworin, the agency's chief was leaving after only 13 months. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D8.]
 
Computer Use Among Blacks
A Census Bureau study found that 25 percent of blacks were using computers, compared with 37.5 percent of whites, confirming what black people in the computer industry have suspected: that many blacks are not embracing them as necessary tools. [C1.]

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Skid: A Harder Landing?

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
Evidence mounted today that the economy was cooling faster than the Federal Reserve intended when it doubled short-term interest rates from February 1994 to February 1995.
Orders for long-lasting manufactured goods skidded 4 percent in April, the third consecutive decline, the Commerce Department reported. The drop was the steepest since December 1991 and worse than analysts had expected. Moreover, no big category of durable goods was spared. 
 "Today's report confirms that what little momentum was left in the industrial sector has all but disappeared," said Laurence H. Meyer, a consultant in St. Louis.
Still, analysts generally continued to avoid predicting that the sharp deceleration of the economy would lead to a recession, even though the annual growth rate had probably become slower than the pace of 2.5 percent or so that was widely thought to be the quickest the economy could grow without increasing inflation.
"The picture of a soft landing is still coherent," said David C. Munro, economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm in New York. "It's not time to call for the crash truck."
The report today was the latest in a nearly unbroken string of statistics depicting an economy that was slowing sharply from the breakneck pace of late 1994 that the Fed, fearing resurgent inflation, had already begun to counter.
Bond prices surged and long-term interest rates fell to their lowest point in nearly 15 months as the report today reassured investors that any inflationary pressures were abating. The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond fell to 6.74 percent from 6.86 percent. [Page D20.]
But stocks gave up almost all their early gains as new concerns emerged about corporate profits. [Page D10.]
The Commerce Department's report on durable goods also showed that shipments of durable goods fell 2.1 percent last month, the first decline since October, while backlogs of unfilled orders declined, by four-tenths of 1 percent, for the first time since August.
Though orders for durable goods are volatile, today's statistics tend to increase the chances that the next move by the Fed will be to cut interest rates, but analysts said it remained unlikely that would come as soon as its next scheduled policy meeting in early July. The meeting on Tuesday of the Federal Open Market Committee, which convenes eight times a year to plot monetary policy, produced no change.
With exports booming, long-term interest rates reduced enough to stabilize the housing sector and payrolls still expanding, the economy may accelerate again after currently swollen inventories are worked off, analysts said.
Still, the figures on durable goods reinforce other evidence of an increasing slowdown. Retail sales and industrial production both fell in April, the latter for the second consecutive month, and gross domestic product slackened in the first quarter, to an annual pace of 2.8 percent, from 5.1 percent in the final three months of last year.
Orders for durable goods -- goods designed to last at least three years -- tumbled $6.5 billion last month, to $156.5 billion, and the Commerce Department revised orders for March to show a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent instead of the advance of five-tenths of 1 percent it had first estimated.
Transportation equipment was the weakest sector in April, down 9.3 percent on slumps in motor vehicles and parts, along with aircraft and aircraft parts. That followed a decline of 2.9 percent in March and was the third fall so far in 1995.
Industrial machinery and equipment tumbled 4.2 percent, its first decline since December, electronic equipment fell 3.4 percent and primary metals were lower by 1.8 percent, the fourth consecutive monthly decline.
Perhaps most sobering, some analysts said, was the fact that capital goods, one of the few areas of persistent vigor this year, reversed course and fell 8 percent over all, 5.2 percent when military items are excluded and 4.9 percent without military goods or civilian aircraft.
Orders for military equipment alone plunged 24.6 percent, more than wiping out the combined gains of February and March.
"This is the third consecutive monthly decline in orders and it suggests that the second quarter will be quite weak, probably showing a growth rate of 2 percent," Gordon Richards, economist at the National Association of Manufacturers, said in a statement. "Clearly, the Federal Reserve did the right thing by not raising interest rates yesterday."
For the latest 12 months, orders for durables are now up only 6.2 percent, compared with 11 percent in March and 13.5 percent for the year through April 1994, the report also showed.
The widespread decline in shipments of durables was also paced by transportation equipment, down 4.1 percent, the third consecutive fall. And unfilled orders of transportation equipment have now declined nearly every month since reaching a peak in March 1991, the department said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
First luxury cars, now bicycles get the trade once-over.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IF Tokyo does not bend, say goodbye to all those sleek Japanese luxury cars. But look on the bright side: You can always buy a bicycle.
Don't bet on it. In what may be interpreted as an effort to cover all bases on the transportation front, the Commerce Department is investigating charges by the American bicycle industry that China is "dumping" bicycles in the United States. If the domestic makers prevail -- and precedent suggests they will -- the prices of all bicycles are likely to go up in time for Christmas. Worse, there will be serious shortages of the high-end bicycles that are the lifeblood of thousands of specialized bike shops. 
 Three American manufacturers (Huffy, Murray and Roadmaster) dominate the domestic industry. And three giant retailers (Kmart, Wal-Mart and Sears, Roebuck), which sell more than a quarter of all bicycles in this country, stock only American-made bikes. But the two other big chains (Toys "R" Us and the Target unit of Dayton Hudson) sell imported bicycles as well as domestic brands.
Imports sometimes cost the retailers less than competitive domestic models in spite of tariffs ranging from 5 to 14 percent. Much of the incentive for selling imports, however, is variety: Toys "R" Us, for example, stocks five times as many models as the price leaders.
All low-price imports come from Asia, which until a few years ago meant Taiwan and South Korea. Rising wages along the industrial Asian rim, however, have led producers to relocate their factories to the Chinese mainland, where the large bicycle industry is fast becoming both a cost and technology leader.
Imports have held a fairly steady 40 percent share of the American market because China's export gains have largely come at Taiwan's expense. Indeed, the indirect cause of the new war on imports is apparently the intense, profit-sapping struggle for market share among the American makers in the wake of Roadmaster's decision to expand production capacity.
But the legal threshold for establishing a "reasonable indication of material injury" from imports is, as a matter of precedent, very low. Hence no jaws dropped last week when the United States International Trade Commission, a Federal agency with close ties to Congress, forwarded the domestic bicycle makers' complaint to the Commerce Department to measure the degree of dumping.
"Dumping" is legally defined as selling below "fair market value," which is usually interpreted as less than cost. Just why private companies would invest in new factories in China in order to sell below cost is a bit of a mystery. Jim Pollock, the bicycle buyer for Toys "R" Us, states flatly that suppliers are "in business to make money." But judging from previous dumping cases, such logic carries no weight at Commerce.
When foreign producers in capitalist countries are accused of dumping, the Commerce Department reconstructs their costs from internal accounting data. But in earlier cases, the department decided, China is a "nonmarket economy," and it is thus likely to use the method of measuring cost preferred by the domestic bicycle makers -- namely, the cost of making similar products in a third country.
To make the Government's job easier, domestic producers have already calculated what it would cost to make Chinese bikes in Indonesia. And -- no surprise -- they find that merely to break even, the Chinese would have to raise prices by 51 to 98 percent, depending on the model.
Mass market retailers are not about to say how they would respond to the imposition of steep punitive tariffs. But industry analysts expect a combination of higher prices, limited selection and spot shortages by Christmas.
The fate of independent bike stores and their customers would be far worse. Specialty stores sell 95 percent of the $200-plus bicycles, most of which are now made in China. Thus, while virtually none of the bikes sold by independents compete with Huffy, Murray and Roadmaster, punitive tariffs "would be devastating to a good number of the 6,500 independent dealers," said Jay Townley, a consultant to manufacturers and retailers of high-end bicycles.
The Commerce Department could still surprise everyone by deciding that Chinese bicycle makers operate in what the law defines as a "bubble of capitalism," and are thus not subject to the most biased methods of calculating punitive tariffs. And even if the department sets very high tariffs, the International Trade Commission could carve out a sanctuary for high-end bicycle makers and their independent retailers, who cannot possibly be injuring the domestic mass-market manufacturers.
But even if Chinese bicycles slip through the cracks in the protectionist wall, the antidumping law will remain an inviting alternative to just about any domestic manufacturer who would rather hire lawyers than cut costs. America's trade laws are written for the benefit of producers and consumers. Stay tuned: you have nothing to lose but your living standard.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
D'Amato Leads Attack on Mexican Aid Package

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and a string of Capitol Hill witnesses argued today that the $20 billion rescue package for Mexico was a failure that was being covered up by unrealistic official reports.
"The Mexican Government is taking the American Government for a ride," said Javier Livas, a Mexican businessman and political opponent of President Ernesto Zedillo. "The bailout package has not helped the real economy." 
 Mr. Livas testified before the Senate Banking Committee, which is headed by Senator D'Amato, a leading critic of the Clinton Administration's loan package to Mexico.
Senator D'Amato, the New York Republican, said Mexico's "economy is in shambles" and optimistic accounts of a recovery were misleading. "The financial alchemy is concealing a massive hole in Mexico's banking system," he said.
Economists, business leaders, members of Mexico's political opposition and college professors supported Senator D'Amato's assessment.
A banking committee aide said there were no plans to call Clinton Administration witnesses and it was uncertain if additional hearings would be held.
The Administration insists Mexico's economic crisis is easing, with a sharp reduction in its short-term debt and tough austerity measures.
The United States approved the latest $2 billion installment in loans last week, bringing the total provided Mexico to $10 billion. The money is being used to pay off short-term, dollar-denominated debts.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has said "it is too soon to declare victory" but that Mexico is putting major budget-cutting and revenue-raising measures into effect.
Senator D'Amato disputed the Administration's optimistic assessment, saying Mexico's economy appeared on the verge of collapse because the loans from the United States were only helping wealthy investors redeem their securities.

HEADLINE: Stocks End Mixed, With the Dow Gaining 1.72, to 4,438.16

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stocks closed mixed yesterday, as stock traders wondered whether the latest evidence of an economic slowdown was good news or bad.
After drifting for much of the day and then falling as much as 30 points, the Dow Jones industrial average edged higher to a record 4,438.16, up 1.72 points. And the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 0.02 point, to 528.61, also a record, while the Nasdaq composite index, rich in the technology stocks that have recently led the market, dropped 1.66 points, to 877.98. 
 Stocks rose for the first 15 minutes of the day in reaction to a Commerce Department report that seemed to reinforce the market's consensus that the economy is slowing, inflation poses little or no threat, and the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates flat or even cut them later in the year.
But the Commerce Department report pointed to such a sharp economic slowdown that some traders began puzzling whether corporate profits would be depressed, meaning they should start selling stocks.
Because of the uncertainty, high-technology stocks, for the first time in weeks, actually dropped sharply, although many rebounded by the end of the day. "In a slowing economy, it becomes harder and harder to make money," thus hurting equities, said Tim Grazioso, manager of Nasdaq trading at Cantor Fitzgerald & Company. When high-tech stocks fell, other stock groups fell, too, Mr. Grazioso said.
The Commerce Department said factory orders for aircraft, cars and what economists call durable goods, declined 4 percent in April. It was the largest drop in more than three years and the third monthly decline in a row.
Wall Street had expected a drop of only half a percentage point, which would have been more in line with March's drop of two-tenths of 1 percent and February's drop of seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Durable goods orders have "declined quite sharply, much more than I thought they would," said Joseph Liro, chief economist for S. G. Warburg & Company.
The drop in American exports to Mexico, caused by the peso crisis, and a big drop in April car sales, Mr. Liro said, mean that the gross domestic product will probably grow only 1 percent or so in the second quarter, compared with growth of 3 percent or more in the first quarter.
Because of the slowing economy, the bond market is betting on a Fed rate cut, bidding down bond yields, lowering borrowing costs and thus deflecting some money to stocks.
Indeed, shorter-term bills, ranging from three months to two years, are now trading below 6 percent, the level of the Federal funds rate that the Fed left unchanged on Tuesday. It is a clear indication that bond traders are anticipating a rate cut later this year.
But unlike other economists, Mr. Liro sees a pickup in the economy in the second half, removing any urgency for the Fed to cut interest rates. "This market has the Fed moving to cut rates no later than the August meeting" of the Fed's policy-making committee, he said. "The Fed is going to be slower on the trigger than that."
Mr. Liro sees stock money staying put, as the bond market underperforms because of the misperception of the Fed's willingness to cut rates. But later this year, he sees more foreign investors moving to buy American stocks, in which they are underinvested in comparison with other assets.
The dollar has stabilized recently, so foreign investors, especially Europeans, are not penalized so much by buying dollar-denominated stocks as they were. The Dow, for example, has risen 15.74 percent in dollars so far this year, 15.02 percent in British pounds and 15.74 percent in French francs, but only 7.47 percent in German marks.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.18 point, to 283.98, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,213 to 1,040. The American Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.09 point, to 491.77.
Among advancing stocks, United Counties Bancorporation rose 19 1/2, to 147, after Meridian Bancorp agreed to acquire it for $360 million. American International Group, an insurance company, rose 3 3/8, to 116 7/8, after it declared a 3-for-2 stock split and raised its quarterly dividend.
Among declining stocks was Michaels Stores, a home-decorating retailer, which dropped 7 1/2, to 24 3/4, after it warned of lower profits in its second fiscal quarter. The American depository receipts of CBT Group, a software developer in Ireland, fell 5, to 38, after an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons downgraded his assessment from "strong buy" to "buy."
The most active stock, at nearly 9 million shares, was Oracle Systems, a software developer, after a Goldman, Sachs analyst said it might be undervalued.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slips as Durables Report Stirs Interest-Rate Speculation

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against most leading currencies yesterday after a large decline in American durable goods stirred speculation that the Federal Reserve might cut interest rates.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that factory orders for durable goods, manufactured items from air-conditioners to aircraft, fell 4 percent last month, the biggest drop since December 1991. Orders have fallen three months in a row. 
 "The fact that the durable goods report was so bad deterred some dollar buyers," said Betsy Reetz, head of institutional sales at National Westminster Bank in New York.
Also weighing on the dollar was talk that European central banks were selling dollars for marks as part of normal reserve adjustments, currency traders said. Foreign central banks bought dollars on several occasions this year in coordinated efforts to support the value of the dollar, and are now seeking to sell, traders said.
"We heard there were a lot of orders by foreign central banks to sell dollars at the 1.4450 level," said Dave Glowacki, senior currency trader at NBD Bank in Detroit. "That had a major impact on the dollar."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar slipped to 1.4385 marks from 1.4436 marks on Tuesday. The dollar edged up to 87.18 Japanese yen from 87.10 yen.
The durable goods report yesterday, together with other signs of slowing in the United States economy, reinforced the view that the seven rate increases by the Fed since February 1994 had cooled growth enough to keep inflation in check. Some traders have suggested the Fed could lower rates later this year. Lower rates typically hurt the dollar by making deposits denominated in it less attractive.
"The Fed is on hold with a bias toward easing, and the easing could come sooner rather than later," said Karl Halligan, vice president of strategic trading at CIC Bank New York.
The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged after a meeting of its policy-making committee on Tuesday.
A strong rally in the Treasury market, however, muted the negative effects of the durable goods report on the dollar, traders and analysts said. Demand for American stocks and bonds usually bolsters the dollar because foreign investors must buy dollars to buy the securities.
"The report was worse than expected, but dollar fallout is being stifled by the bond market rally," said Kevin Lawrie, manager of foreign exchange trading at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.

HEADLINE: Dole Abandons His Plan For Significant Tax Cut

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, today abandoned any notion that the Senate's budget plan could allow for a substantial tax cut right away.
But the budget plan that comes out of a House-Senate conference committee is almost certain to include a tax cut in some form. So the Senate will have another chance to vote on the issue next month. 
 The final vote on the Senate plan was delayed until Thursday, as Democrats offered dozens of amendments meant mostly for political consumption and demanded votes on all of them.
Most of these amendments were rejected on party-line votes. But the Democrats, joined by 10 Republicans, did succeed in blocking a Republican scheme to abolish taxpayer financing of Presidential election campaigns.
On Tuesday, the Senate voted, 69 to 31, to reject a proposal by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas to include tax cuts of more than $300 billion in its overall plan that is supposed to balance the budget within seven years.
Republicans were split on the issue. Twenty-three of them voted with all the Democrats against the tax cut, including Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Budget Committee, and Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, chairman of the Finance Committee.
Mr. Dole and Mr. Gramm are rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination next year. Mr. Dole voted in favor of the Gramm tax proposal, presumably hoping to cancel any political advantage Mr. Gramm might get for his effort. Mr. Dole has promised all year that the Senate would vote for a tax cut, but he expended no effort to get the Gramm amendment passed.
Looking for solid political footing, Mr. Dole, who normally offers an opinion on every issue in the legislative galaxy, has kept quiet this week about the tax matter. On Tuesday night and again today, he met with Republican colleagues in search of some kind of compromise.
What they decided on was an amendment, to be voted on Thursday, that would require that any money the balanced-budget plan saves the Government in lower interest rates on Government bonds be used for tax cuts.
During the debate, Mr. Dole is expected to enter into an exchange with Mr. Packwood in which they pledge that such tax cuts would involve lower taxes for families with children, a tax break for capital gains and several other items on Mr. Gramm's list.
The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that if a balanced budget plan is adopted and adhered to for seven years, the Government will save $170 billion because of lower interest rates. The budget plan now before the Senate would permit this money to be used for tax cuts and would not allow any of it to be spent, but it would not require that taxes be lowered.
In any event, almost none of the money would be available in the first year or two, and the bulk of it could not be used until after the turn of the century.
The scene in the Senate today represented legislative sausage-making at its worst.
By early afternoon, the 50 hours of debate allotted by the budget law had expired. But dozens of amendments had not been voted on. So the Senate took one vote after another without any debate or explanation of what the amendments entailed.
The proposal to block Republicans from stopping Government financing of Presidential campaigns beginning with the election in the year 2000 was approved, 56 to 44. Ten Republicans joined all 46 Democrats in supporting the proposal. All those in favor of scrapping public financing were Republicans. The measure to drop the financing system was put into the budget resolution earlier this month by the Republican majority on the Budget Committee.
The Republican Senators running for President next year were split on the issue. Mr. Dole and Mr. Gramm voted to cancel Federal financing. Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania voted to retain it.
Under one of the campaign finance laws enacted in the aftermath of the Watergate scandal, the Federal Government partly finances Presidential primary races and fully finances general election campaigns.
In return for the Government money, candidates can accept only limited private contributions in the primaries and no private donations at all in the general election campaign.
To pay for this, taxpayers can voluntarily check a box on their tax returns that results in $3 going to the campaign fund. It does not increase their taxes, but it reduces the amount of money the Government has available for other purposes.
Scrapping this system has become a pet project of Republicans in recent years. The main reason this has become a partisan issue is that Republicans generally have an easier time raising private contributions than do Democrats.
In next year's campaigns, the Government is expected to spend $60 million to $80 million for primary races, $12 million for each major party's nominating convention and an additional $60 million for each party.

HEADLINE: Government Is Urged to Act Quickly in Protecting Habitats

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
An expert panel convened by the National Academy of Sciences today called on the Government to act more swiftly to protect the habitats of plant and animal species that are found to be in danger of extinction.
When a species is listed under the Endangered Species Act, the group of scientists said, the Government should act on an emergency basis to protect enough of the habitat to stabilize the species' population and guarantee its survival for about 25 years, taking protective steps no matter what the economic consequences. 
 That recommendation flies in the face of critics who are recommending that Congress change the law to give more consideration, not less, to economic factors when writing environmental regulations.
The critics also contend that the law is not being scientifically applied, for example, by trying to protect distinct populations that closely resemble one another. But the report's main conclusion was that the current law was "based on sound scientific principles."
Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, who supervises the law's enforcement, said many of the report's conclusions supported "exactly what we've been doing for the past two and a half years."
But Henson Moore, head of the American Forest and Paper Association, an industry group, said the report was neither a total endorsement of the law nor a repudiation of an industry-supported bill to revise the law.
The panel, convened in 1992 by the scientific advisory council at the request of Congress, included 17 experts from various disciplines. It was headed by Michael T. Clegg, a geneticist who is dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at the University of California at Riverside.
Calling preservation of habitat the major factor in saving species, the report noted that nearly 80 percent of all the species listed as endangered have not been provided with protected habitat. "Survival habitat" should be provided immediately, it said.
When long-term plans for the recovery of endangered species are drawn up, it said, enough habitat must be set aside to let populations grow to sustainable levels, though in these long-term plans, economic costs may be taken into consideration.
"Because habitat plays such an important biological role in endangered species' survival," the report said, "some core amount of essential habitat should be designated for protection at the time of listing a species as endangered, as an emergency, stop-gap measure. It should be identified without reference to economic impact."
The panel said its conclusions and recommendations were based on purely scientific grounds. It said that subspecies, or distinct populations, like the runs of salmon that migrate along a single stream generation after generation, should be protected because of the genetic diversity they provide.
More fundamentally, the report endorsed the widely held scientific view that human activities have recently brought on a "major episode of biological extinction" comparable to the great extinction 65 million years ago that wiped out the dinosaurs and most other reptiles. The best-known example, it said, is the destruction of tropical rain forests, which harbor enormous biological diversity.
"To sustain a viable future for our descendants," the report said, "we must find ways to preserve both species and ecosystems. The Endangered Species Act is a critically important part of our efforts."
But the panel said this law alone could provide no more than a safety net for maintaining biological diversity. Other measures, such as tax incentives for private conservation, are also needed.
"Any coherent, successful program to prevent species' extinctions and to protect the nation's biological diversity is going to require more enlightened commitments on the part of all major parties to achieve success," the report said.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Whitman Gets to Hear Fans' Plea: Don't Let the Devils Go!

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 24

 BODY:
Midway through the first period of tonight's Devil-Penguins playoff game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, a fan held up a sign that said:
"KEEP DEVILS. SEND NASHVILLE THE YANKEES." 
 Between periods, the door of a luxury suite opened onto a jammed, stifling concourse and New Jersey Gov. Christine Todd Whitman stepped out.
"Keep the Devils, Christie!" one fan shouted hoarsely.
"Don't let 'em go!!" screamed another.
"I'm trying," the Governor said, over and over, to fans who had clustered around her, making various pleas to make the Devils happy enough in current lease renegotiations to scotch a potential move to Nashville.
Whitman, whose husband last week brought together officials of the Devils and its landlord at the arena, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, insists that the Devils can be saved from moving.
"All you have to do is look at the crowd tonight," she said. "I've witnessed a continual growth in support of this team. I wouldn't have thought so five years ago or even two years ago."
Although the arena was not sold out, a common problem for the Devils, even during the playoffs, Whitman said, "This is a pretty darned good crowd."
Yet the failure to sell out Byrne Arena is symptomatic of the Devils' existence in New Jersey. Thirteen years after emigrating from Colorado, the Devils, two victories from the Stanley Cup semifinals, are one of the best teams in the National Hockey League. But the team has not captured a significant enough fan base or snared a large enough chunk of the New York market's heart.
It is hockey's local stepchild to the Rangers, the defending Stanley Cup champions, in terms of attendance, attention and corporate cache.
Whereas Rangers fans know tickets at Madison Square Garden are scarce because 15,000 of the 18,200 seats are in the hands of season-ticket holders, those going to Devils games know there will almost always be tickets available because the team has only 10,000 season ticket owners.
And, it's difficult to lure walk-up traffic to Byrne Arena.
The Rangers sold out all 24 home games this year, the Devils sold out six. The Rangers are capable of charging up to $125 for playoff tickets, the Devils charge a high of $60. The Devils have 29 luxury suites, the Rangers 88. The Rangers have sold out their three playoff games, the Devils one of three.
"I'm surprised when they don't sell out the playoffs, but they did when they played the Rangers last year because their fans bought up the tickets," said Laura Steers of Hackettstown, N.J., a 26-year-old veterinarian's assistant.
The Devils admit that they exist within the Rangers' shadow from the east, and compete for some South Jersey hearts with the Philadelphia Flyers. It comes down to whether there really are enough Devils devotees.
"We feel there aren't," said Mike McCall, the Devils' head of marketing and sales. "We have a base of fans. But we think we can grow more."
And McCall admitted that the Devils had for years mistakenly marketed the team as a New York club, not aggressively targeting home-grown fans.
"Dr. McMullen said he felt he was buying a team in the Big Apple," he said, referring to the team's owner, John McMullen. "That's proved not to be the case. North Central Jersey is our primary area."
The Devils have significantly less business support than the Rangers, and the team has not succeeded as well as the basketball Nets, their Byrne co-tenants, in aggressively selling corporate sponsorships.
The Devils are hamstrung as the local area's third team, after the Rangers and Islanders, and even a fourth, the Flyers.
"We're the No. 4 sport, and even Nos. 1, 2 and 3 haven't put three teams in this market," said the N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman. "If I were confronted with putting a third team in this market, I would not have recommended it."
Governor Whitman, who has said she won't go overboard financially to satisfy the Devils, insisted there is a supportive market for the Devil.
"But I don't think the N.H.L. wants three teams," she said.
Whitman's job is to persuade the authority to satisfy McMullen, who believes he has been mistreated financially. Besides believing that the terms of his lease are grossly inadequate, McMullen feels the authority has not always paid everything the team is owed.
McMullen's long-term displeasure with the authority and its president, Bob Mulcahy, has made quite alluring Nashville's offer, which is a virtual giveaway of gate, luxury suite, advertising and concession revenues.
Despite a small rapproachment last week at Whitman's behest, the team and the authority squabbled again this week over a revelation that the authority temporarily suspended the team's lease last December during the N.H.L. lockout. Persons familiar with the situation said the team viewed a letter sent by Mulcahy as unnecessarily provocative and may have meant the possible withholding of revenues, including those from luxury suites.
No other arena owner in the N.H.L. is believed to have done the same thing.
John Samerjan, a spokesman for the authority, said the letter had informed the team that it would reap no revenues for unplayed games. It was rendered moot when the lockout ended. "It was legal necessity," he said. "It was routine and non-threatening." He said no revenues had been withheld.
The Devils have an inadequate lease by the standards of today's sports economics. The team reaps about 35 percent of key luxury suite, concession and parking revenues, well below Nashville's sweetheart offer.
"I'm sick they might move," said Jean Sagarese, 42, a government worker from Mendham, N.J. "I hope it's a bluff."
"The Devils had better stay," said Joe Yander, 40, of Morganville, N.J., who owns a sports novelties business. "It's a con job by the N.H.L."

HEADLINE: 1 State-Federal Tax Collector Is Better Than 2, I.R.S. Says

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
Relief is coming soon for small businesses that fall behind in turning over income, Social Security and other taxes withheld from their employees' paychecks, an Internal Revenue Service official said today.
 Small businesses owing such taxes must typically contend with the competing claims of Federal and state tax collectors, either of whom can file a lien. That can cause an enterprise that is temporarily cash-starved to collapse. 
The I.R.S. now believes, however, that it can increase tax collections and reduce collection costs by coordinating efforts with state tax agencies. Within two years small businesses would need to deal with only one tax collector, who would have authority to negotiate on behalf of both the Federal and state governments.
 To induce states to cooperate, the I.R.S. would forgo its supremacy in collecting the back taxes, and it would split any collections with the states.
 Beverly P. Monaco, the I.R.S. official in charge of relations with state tax agencies, told the I.R.S. Commissioner's Advisory Group at its quarterly meeting here, that a pilot program in San Jose, Calif., involving 200 businesses that were chronically late in submitting Federal and state unemployment insurance taxes had produced dramatic results.
 Businesses default on 50 percent to 75 percent of such agreements, she said, but there have been no defaults in San Jose.
 "The business people involved are very happy," Mrs. Monaco said in an interview. "Business people who had been running from us, and from the State of California, are now coming in, saying they understand they can work out an agreement with both of us."
 The agreements require the businesses to keep all taxes current and to make agreed-upon payments to reduce the back taxes, she said. The payment schedules are tailored to fit the cash flow of each business, she said.
 Mrs. Monaco said that "easily within two years" she expected the I.R.S. to authorize its regional and district offices to sign contracts with state tax agencies to coordinate collection of overdue payroll taxes.
 "We expect tax collections to increase, even though we will split the money with the states, and we expect the expense of collection to go down," Mrs. Monaco said.
 Mary Craig, a former Montana state revenue commissioner who serves on the advisory group, said the I.R.S. was also exploring joint training of Federal and state tax auditors, examiners and collectors. She said the first such training would begin soon in Montana, probably to be followed by joint training in Indiana.
 In another development, a document from an advisory group committee disclosed that the I.R.S. was considering increased record-keeping requirements for all small businesses, even part-time enterprises run from a kitchen table, to reduce the need for tax audits.
 Among the options being discussed, the document showed, are requiring small businesses to keep separate business and family checking accounts and requiring that an annual cash flow statement be submitted to the I.R.S. Mrs. Monaco said that she was surprised to find the disclosure in the document, adding the I.R.S. had not intended to make the proposals public yet.

HEADLINE: A Generation Gap in Venture Capital

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN 

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 24

 BODY:
In his 11 years in the venture capital business, Jonathan Flint found himself becoming more and more frustrated at other people getting rich from all his work. Sure, he earned a six-figure salary, lived in a stylish suburb of Boston and was respected by his peers. But after steering his firm, Burr, Egan, Deleage & Company, through a series of stellar software start-ups -- including a $105 million payback on a $3 million investment in the Powersoft Corporation -- he wanted more.
So, along with two like-minded partners, Mr. Flint is taking a radical step that reflects the new order that is beginning to reshape the clubby world of venture capital. Rather than waiting for the three founding partners of Burr, Egan to hand over the reins and share more of the profits, Mr. Flint is betting that he and his colleagues, Stephen D. Arnold and Terrance McGuire, can do better for themselves by splitting off and seeking investors for a new firm, Polaris Ventures. 
 "This is an old bulls versus young bulls situation," said Mr. Flint, who is 44. "The founders think they are leaving too much money on the table, while the next generation thinks they are taking too much off."
For Burr, Egan, Mr. Flint's exodus represents the end of an era. While the firm, one of the great investment success stories of the last two decades, will not disappear, it has decided not to raise any new funds or invest in new ventures. It will split into three new firms, but members of the former team, including Mr. Flint, will maintain their roles overseeing the firm's earlier investments.
Burr, Egan is not alone. From Sand Hill Road in Menlo Park, Calif., home to many of the venture capital partnerships that helped build Silicon Valley, to downtown Boston, where the first venture capitalists got their start after World War II, the business is molting in an unprecedented fashion.
Several blue-chip partnerships are closing as a spate of new operations emerge to carry on the traditional business of venture capital: raising money for young entrepreneurs with great promise and helping shepherd them along until they can sell shares in their companies to the public. And while more venture capital money than ever is now available, several longstanding firms -- Interven Partners in Santa Monica, Calif. is just one -- have decided not to seek new funds. Venture groups within Alex. Brown, the Wall Street investment house, and the Hambros Bank in London, are also retreating. In their place, some veterans of those operations are starting new partnerships like North Bridge Venture Partners in Waltham, Mass.
"There's more turmoil right now with venture partnerships than I've ever seen," said Gib Myers, a general partner at the Mayfield Fund in Menlo Park, who has 25 years of experience in the field.
All this upheaval worries entrepreneurs and the investors who put their money on the line for them.
"This makes our lives very difficult," said Gary Bridge of Horsely, Bridge Partners, an adviser to corporate pension funds and the insurance companies that have increasingly replaced wealthy individuals as the prime sources of risk capital for privately held companies. "This is a people business. The people may not be new to the business but they may be new to working with each other. You never know how the chemistry will be."
Bill Egan, 50,, who presided over the uneasy breakup of the firm he helped start in 1979, acknowledges the risk of abandoning the general-purpose approach of Burr, Egan in favor of the three new organizations with untested leaders at the helm. "We're either going to be real visionaries," he said, "or real idiots who killed the goose that laid the golden eggs."
Much of the turmoil revolves around sharing the rewards of sponsoring successful new ventures.
"There's a younger generation of partners who want theirs and aren't getting it," said Steven P. Galante, editor of Private Equity Analyst, an industry newsletter in Wellesley, Mass.
A survey by the Hay Group, a consulting firm based in Jersey City, found that the average compensation last year for a founding partner in a large venture capital firm was $1.24 million. Senior partners took home an average $770,000, while intermediate partners received $366,000.
But unlike law firms, where younger partners can expect to reap steadily greater rewards as their tenure and status rise within the firm, or Wall Street investment firms, where the best producers tend to receive the greatest compensation, many venture capital partnerships are so closely identified with their founders that they are stumbling over questions of succession and pay.
In Silicon Valley, Merrill Pickard Anderson & Eyre is undergoing a metamorphosis similar to that at Burr, Egan. Steven Merrill, a founding partner, said the structure of most venture capital firms was "not optimal for the normal kinds of promotions and successions." By helping to spin off the firm's younger partners into new funds while they continue to manage Merrill Pickard's existing investments, he said, the elder statesmen might satisfy the Young Turks and still come out ahead.
But others say Mr. Merrill and the other founders brought the breakup upon themselves. "If Merrill Pickard had divided the rewards more equitably, they wouldn't have split up," said one person with knowledge of the industry.
Some founders, critics say, are clinging to the past, when they arranged every deal personally and assumed much of the risk. With younger partners taking lead roles today in many deals, they say, these founders are overreaching by continuing to reap so many of the rewards themselves.
"Today the power is much more distributed," said Robert Kagle, 39, a partner at Technology Venture Investors in Silicon Valley. He is leaving to start Benchmark Partners. "Nobody can claim they are making all the money for the firm."
Not everybody is caught up in the turbulence. Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers in Menlo Park, which has invested in companies ranging from Compaq Computer to the biotech pioneer Genentech, has successfully navigated the transition from one generation of venture capitalists to the next. Its track record is unmatched: the companies in which it has invested now generate a total of $30 billion in annual revenue and employ 30,000 people. The continuity of the firm is a testimony to the lessons that one of its founders, Eugene Kleiner, learned from his experiences at the Hewlett-Packard Company, the Silicon Valley trailblazer that has become a global heavyweight in computers and printers and is now in its third generation of leadership.
As early as 1986, Mr. Kleiner and Thomas Perkins, the other chief founder, set in motion a plan to hand over leadership of the firm to L. John Doerr, a younger partner.
"What it takes is, first, a decision that you want to sustain and build a franchise, which I'm not sure others have made," Mr. Doerr said. "And second, let the best idea win around the table. Hierarchical structures don't work in a stable, healthy partnership. Plus, you generously share the profits."
By going off on their own, though, the up-and-comers of the business are running big risks for themselves and their original firms. The powerful advantage of stability is the reassurance it provides to limited partners, who generally invest for a decade or more in a venture fund. Many have come to expect that the same people will be there to safeguard their investments.
"One of the reasons people make investments is that they know who they are investing with," said Arthur Rock, a venture capital pioneer who now lives in San Francisco. "New faces mean more anxiety."
Many younger partners are tempted to go out on their own in part because the venture capital business is flush with cash these days. According to Private Equity Analyst, $4.3 billion was raised last year, up from $2.9 billion in 1993.
With so much money on hand, funds at the blue-chip firms are oversubscribed, analysts say, leading them to concentrate on the bigger deals available at later stages of financing rather than true start-ups, which are smaller and riskier.
That should provide an opening for the new firms. But T. Bondurant French, a partner at Brinson Partners, an institutional money management firm in Chicago, said he was wary because of the generational upheaval roiling the business. Like many others, Mr. French appears to be sticking with the tried-and-true venture capital outfits, at least for now. "There are certain firms where we have decided not to invest in their latest fund because some of the most talented senior and junior people were leaving," he said.
For now, more money is ending up in fewer hands, leaving the growing number of new firms to fight over the remainder. According to Jesse Reyes, director of Venture Economics Information Services in Boston, 75 percent of the investment money is now controlled by just 40 percent of the venture capital firms. In 1980, that share was spread across 55 percent of the firms.
Indeed, for all the potential rewards, many younger partners are deciding it is safer to stay where they are. Many are handcuffed by existing commitments to companies they helped get off the ground. Others are not ready to walk away from steady incomes and potential future payoffs when their companies go public.
Still, in a business tied so tightly to the entrepreneurial spirit, the lure of starting over is strong. Mr. Flint of Polaris Ventures said the difference between his generation of venture capitalists and the prior one was that he and his peers were much closer to the newer technologies, like the convergence between medicine and software, that will dominate the investment opportunities of the next decade. But he also acknowledged that his group, like the earlier generation that built the business from scratch, was motivated by the same desires for fame and fortune.
"At the end of the day, all we want is to go out and do what those guys did," he said. "We're high on the yearning curve."
 Because of an editing error, the article misstated the total employment of companies in which Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers has made investments. Those companies now employ 100,000 people, not 30,000.

HEADLINE: Investors Still Put Cash Into Stock Funds

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Mutual funds that buy American stocks are continuing to attract a lot of cash from investors, although May's cash flows have been down from April's extraordinarily high levels, fund managers said yesterday.
In April, such funds took in a net $8.6 billion, the highest flow for domestic funds since January 1994, but the cash did not stay in the funds for long. Instead, almost all of it was invested immediately in stocks, according to figures released by the Investment Company Institute, a trade group. 
 The figures showed that domestic mutual stock funds had just 6.8 percent of their assets in cash at the end of April, down from 7 percent in March and the lowest since 1978.
While the money is pouring into stock funds, bond funds are breaking even, at best, in terms of money flow. In April, a net $1.4 billion was withdrawn from bond funds, with most of that coming from funds that invest in municipal bonds.
"In 1994, we had the worst bond market in history, and that is a wound that has not healed yet," said Jack Sharry, a managing director of Putnam Investments. "People have a greater comfort with equities."
At Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund group and a unit of the FMR Corporation, domestic equity funds took in about $1.3 billion this month, a spokeswoman, Marilyn Morrison, said. That was down from $2.5 billion in April, when cash flows were inflated by the deadline for many retirement fund contributions.
April also saw a rebound in cash flow for international stock funds, which invest only outside the United States, and global stock funds, which can invest anywhere in the world. They took in a net $2 billion between them, the best performance since October.
The most extraordinary figures for any class were chalked up by growth funds -- the medium-risk class among diversified funds. Such funds took in $2.8 billion in cash during the month, up from $2 billion in March and the highest for any month since January 1993.
Moreover, the managers of growth funds ended the month with just 6.9 percent of their assets in cash, down from 7.2 percent in March and 10 percent as recently as November. That is lower than in any month for which comparable figures are available, stretching back to 1984.
Mutual funds keep cash on hand to handle redemptions and to guard against declining prices. With money pouring in month after month and stock prices hitting new highs, neither need now seems to be much of a risk.
Among bond funds, junk bond funds have been the only bright spot in attracting money. "People are either expressing confidence about the economy or trying to hold on to yield," said Steve Norwitz, a spokesman for the T. Rowe Price group of funds. In April, such funds took in a net $760 million, raising their total for the first four months of 1995 to $3 billion.
Over the same stretch, municipal bond funds saw outflows of $2.2 billion, government bond funds lost $3.6 billion and mortgage-backed funds had outflows of $2.9 billion.
All cash-flow figures include sales and redemptions as well as transfers among funds in the same family. But they exclude reinvested dividends.
