HEADLINE: Cortines Is Conspicuous by His Absence

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

 BODY:
It was billed as a rally to stand up for New York City's schoolchildren and to protest school budget cuts. The teachers' union -- showing a toughened stance against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- bused thousands of teachers to City Hall. Some school board members walked across the Brooklyn Bridge with many of the school system's top leaders, a few hundred parents, students and more teachers -- everyone except Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines.
The Chancellor stayed away after issuing statement that said, "I was led to understand that my presence would be interpreted as meaning the rally was against someone or something -- City Hall, or the City Council, or state leaders or whomever or whatever." 
 Although Mr. Cortines did not say so in his statement, his decision to stay away followed a conversation with Deputy Mayor Ninfa Segarra in which she told the Chancellor that the Mayor would consider his participation an affront. Mayor Giuliani said at a news conference that he had not asked her to convey that message.
"We have worked long and hard to forge better working relationships with all our partners in government and I want to preserve that relationship," the Chancellor's statement said.
About 10,000 people attended the rally.
Mr. Cortines's decision to stay away, and his curious explanation of it, illustrated how uneasy his relationship with the Mayor, which has followed a tumultuous two-year course, continues to be. During a confrontation with Mr. Giuliani over budget cuts 13 months ago, Mr. Cortines resigned briefly and then rescinded the decision. Several of the educational leaders who attended the rally said they were puzzled by the Chancellor's decision.
Carol A. Gresser, the Board of Education president who hired Mr. Cortines and is his closest political ally, said she first heard of his decision not to take part when she read the Chancellor's statement yesterday. She expressed some irritation with Mr. Cortines's posture.
"I would have preferred that he join us because I think that we have an important message to deliver," Mrs. Gresser said in an interview at the rally. "I want the Mayor to hear our message, and I'm not tiptoeing around about it."
Sandra Feldman, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, said she was "really disappointed" about the Chancellor's decision.
"This is not a rally against anybody," Ms. Feldman said. "This is not an anti-Giuliani rally. This is a rally to show that there is a large constituency for public education in this city. I think it's appropriate for the leadership of the school system, the Chancellor, the board president, to come out and say to the Mayor and the City Council, 'We want you to make education a priority in your budget.' "
Donald Singer, the principals' union president, said of Mr. Cortines: "I'm disappointed that he's not here since he's the leader of the school system, but we're not leaderless -- we have most of the rest of the city's educators here."
The teachers' union hired 185 buses to transport teachers and parents from the outer boroughs to City Hall for the rally, said Susan Amlung, a union spokesman. Both the teachers' union, which represents 90,000 teachers, guidance counselors and other school employees, and the principals' union, which represents more than 3,000 assistant principals, principals and other supervisors, bought radio time to criticize City Hall's proposed school budget cuts and to urge the rank and file to attend the rally.
Mr. Giuliani, and to a lesser extent Gov. George E. Pataki, were the targets of the rally, although almost none of the speakers mentioned either man by name. Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, whose locals represent cafeteria workers, school aides and other school employees, was one of the few.
"We're saying to Mayor Giuliani and to Governor Pataki that when you take away money from the school system, you kill people, you hurt people," Mr. Hill said.
If most of the rally's speakers seemed reticent to target Mr. Giuliani by name, few of those who marched, chanting slogans and waving placards, showed the same hesitation.
"Gov. Pataki and Mayor Giuliani Hate the Children of New York!" screamed a placard carried by Ann Walter, an unemployed mother of a second-grade student who attends Public School 230 in the Kensington section of Brooklyn.
Two teachers from George Washington High School in Manhattan carried a banner, stretched between two poles, which portrayed a menacing Mr. Giuliani wearing an "I Love NY" T-shirt, but swinging an ax.
"The mayor is a target of a lot of unrest in this city," said Luis Espinoza, a social studies teacher at George Washington High School in Manhattan who helped paint the banner. "People trusted him because he says that he loves the city, but he has cut it apart."
Seeking to close the city's budget gap, City Hall has proposed that the Board of Education's operating budget, which was $8.4 billion during the current fiscal year, be reduced to $8.1 billion for the fiscal year that begins July 1. Because enrollments are rising and there are other increases in operating costs, board officials say City Hall is cutting the budget by $1 billion. City Hall says that it is seeking to cut the budget by only $220 million.
Mr. Giuliani, appearing after the rally on a WCBS radio talk show, took a call from a teacher at John F. Kennedy High School in the Bronx who complained that the city's schools are insufficiently funded. Mr. Giuliani reacted with an angry lecture about waste in the schools.
"Those are the things the teachers should have been out there demonstrating about today," he said. "We have got to be more accountable in spending the first $8 billion. There is no more money in New York City to put in the school system or anywhere else."

HEADLINE: McCall, Citing Pension Fund Payments, Blocks Budget Plan

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 25

 BODY:
The Democratic State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, erected a new roadblock on the path to a budget agreement today by rejecting a plan to save money by lowering the state's scheduled payments to its pension system.
Gov. George E. Pataki said that the rejection represented "a minor setback," and that another plan under consideration to produce the $110 million in savings might not require Mr. McCall's approval. But budget negotiations that had seemed headed for a possible conclusion by this weekend were sidetracked while legislative leaders focused on the pension issue. The budget is now 55 days late. 
 Also today, state officials said that Mr. Pataki had reached tentative agreement with Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, and the Senate Republican leader, Joseph L. Bruno of Rensselaer County, on providing financing for 19 stadium projects.
The projects, worth a total of $110.6 million, had been approved as part of the 1994 election-year budget, but many had been recommended for elimination by Mr. Pataki, who questioned their value to economic development. The projects include construction of a deluxe $24 million swimming center in Nassau County for the 1998 Goodwill Games, renovations to Buffalo's hockey arena and construction of minor-league baseball parks around the state.
The agreement would also provide money for new projects in and around Mr. Bruno's district costing $14 million, including improvements at the Albany County Airport and the Saratoga Performing Arts Center.
The state officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said today that the leaders had agreed to pay for the stadium projects and the projects in Mr. Bruno's district by selling Urban Development Corporation bonds rather than using cash from the state's general fund.
The cost of paying off the bonds this year is estimated at $15 million. Of the projects approved last year, only construction of a soccer stadium in Mitchell Park in Nassau County was dropped.
The agreement, which remains subject to negotiations on the larger budget, would also restore $62 million for school construction projects that was appropriated last year, including $42 million for projects in New York City. Mr. Pataki had proposed eliminating that spending, but Mr. Silver made it a priority to restore the money.
As for a larger budget agreement, prospects foundered after Mr. McCall issued his objection today.
Mr. McCall, the sole trustee of the state's $60 billion retirement system, defended his decision by calling the plan a gimmick. He said it "would be a violation of my fiduciary responsibility" to allow the leaders to "adjust the pension fund or its contribution level for the purpose of balancing the budget."
The Comptroller's announcement also raised political questions. Mr. McCall is considered a potential gubernatorial candidate in 1998, in which he could compete against two authors of the pension plan: Mr. Silver in a Democratic primary, and then Mr. Pataki in the general election.
"I'm worried about Carl," Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's spokeswoman, said. "He's either got a bad case of amnesia or a blind case of political ambition. He probably doesn't know whether to see a doctor or a pollster."
The plan devised by Mr. Pataki and the legislative leaders would have produced savings for the state and for local governments, by stretching out repayments to the pension plan that were ordered by the State Court of Appeals in 1993.
Ruling in a lawsuit filed by unions of state workers, the court found that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Legislature had acted illegally in 1990 when they changed pension actuarial methods. The change allowed the state and local governments to make huge reductions in their annual contributions to the pension system and helped the state fill a large budget gap.
In response to the court decision, Mr. McCall devised a schedule for state and local governments to repay the more than $4 billion lost to the pension system, with interest. The Comptroller estimated that it would take at least 12 years to make the system whole.
Republicans criticized him at the time for allowing a very small repayment in 1994, an election year in which his Democratic ticket mate, Mr. Cuomo, would be running for re-election.
The repayment schedule for this year requires the state to pay $110 million, and for local governments that use the state retirement system to pay a total of $120 million. Mr. Pataki proposed in his original budget this year to make those payments by using money that had accumulated in a $360 million fund intended to make supplemental pension payments to retirees.
But on Wednesday, Mr. Pataki and the legislative leaders announced that they would not disturb the supplemental fund and would try to use that money to increase pensions for retirees, as originally intended. Instead, they asked Mr. McCall to stretch out his previous repayment schedule to save money for the state and local governments. The proposal was to eliminate the payments by the state and by local governments in this fiscal year, and would have greatly reduced them in the subsequent five years.
Mr. Pataki argued today that Mr. McCall's original repayment schedule had been arbitrary and that nothing prevented him from changing it.
The Governor also said that at Mr. Silver's behest, he had dropped his proposal to eliminate the State Division of Cemeteries.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Rally Is Cut Short by Profit Taking

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
What appeared to be the making of another strong bond rally was cut short yesterday by a sharp decline in the dollar and profit taking.
Prices surged in morning trading after new economic reports on housing and the job market indicated that economic growth would be weaker than expected in the second quarter. The data raised expectations that the Federal Reserve might reduce interest rates later this year. 
 Carroll J. Delaney, managing director of Stires, O'Donnell & Company, a New York securities firm, said yesterday that while the data were of the "minor variety," the fact that the market was at such lofty levels meant "almost any nuance could initiate a profit-taking spree."
Still, bond prices ended higher, but off the highs of the day. The price of the 30-year bond rose 10/32 , to 11119/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.72 percent, from 6.74 percent on Wednesday.
Also yesterday, the Treasury sold $18.25 billion of one-year bills at an average yield of 5.88 percent, down slightly from 5.90 percent last month and the lowest since Sept. 15, 1994, when it was 5.38 percent. Traders said the sale of the one-year bills went as well as could be expected. The high and low bids were further apart than usually seen at the auction, suggesting that investors were hesitant to buy.
The market first gained after the Labor Department reported initial jobless claims for the week that ended May 20 were at 380,000, higher than forecasts for a drop to 362,000. The week before the figure was 364,000.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, yesterday put the four-week moving average of unemployment claims above an important level of 370,000, to 371,000 -- the first time the level has been briefly breached since the first two weeks of February 1994.
A second report yesterday, on sales of existing homes, was also weaker than economists' forecasts. The National Association of Realtors, a trade group, said that sales of previously owned single-family homes fell 6.4 percent in April to a seasonally adjusted 3.39 million annual rate, the lowest rate since 3.36 million in June 1992. Housing data, Mr. Chan said, continue to defy expectations despite a decline in mortgage rates. Althouth there are signs that housing will bounce back -- as seen, for example, in the home buyers index rleased by the National Association of Home Builders -- "bond traders are trading positions based on today's data, which does not really see a bounce-back," he said.
The advance in bonds, however, quickly gave way to profit taking. Also weighing on the market yesterday was a sharp decline in the dollar. The prospect of the Fed's cutting short-term interest rates to prevent a slowdown from becoming a recession caused alarm on foreign-exchange markets.
The message to the Fed on cutting rates, Mr. Chan of Banc One said, is "clearly don't do it, because if you do, no amount of government intervention is going to prevent the market from heading lower, which will only fuel the flames of inflationary pressures."
Lower interest rates would hurt the dollar by making deposits denominated in it less attractive. And a prolonged slide in the dollar would hurt bonds by diminishing their appeal to foreign investors.
"In short, the decline of the dollar was an early warning signal to the Fed, and provide an easy excuse for many credit market players to take profits," he said.
The market will have an abbreviated session today going into the Memorial Day weekened. The futures market will close at 1 P.M., and the Public Securities Association, a trade group, has recommended that the cash market close at 2 P.M. today.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new one-year bills:

HEADLINE: Powell on Politics: Still Cagily Noncommittal

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
From the viewpoint of some who want to make him President, Colin L. Powell is playing his cards too close to his vest. Either he gives a hint of interest soon, one of his main backers said last week, or people at the grass roots will dismiss him as "too coy."
From his own perspective, his friends say, General Powell has no option except to allow the political drama to unfold. One of them put it this way: "Suppose, just suppose, he wants the job. He has nothing to gain by running after it months ahead of time. That makes him look like everyone else." 
 "I want to keep my options open," the general himself said cagily. "I'm going to do something to try to help make this an even greater country than it is now. Just keep watching. I'll be out there somewhere."
He has certainly done nothing to chide those who have spoken favorably of his potential as a candidate, such as Ken Duberstein, a former White House chief of staff under Ronald Reagan, or former Senators Paul E. Tsongas, a Massachusetts Democrat, and John C. Danforth, a Missouri Republican. Nor has the general tried to head off a Citizens for Powell movement in New Hampshire or a small but persistent national draft-Powell effort. To all who ask, he replies with a smile, "I'm flattered."
As in the Persian Gulf war, he is cautious in assessing potential adversaries and determined, friends say, to follow a strategy that has "the highest potential for success and entails the least possible risk." He still refuses to say whether he is a Republican, a Democrat or neither.
Col. William Smullen, General Powell's spokesman, spends his days knocking down rumors that never stop coming, like a cook swatting flies in midsummer. No, the general has not decided against running. No, he has not signed on to advise Senator Bob Dole's campaign; the two just had a friendly talk. No, he has not been offered the Vice-Presidential nomination by anyone.
It is a high-stakes game. The odds are that it will come to nothing, and it would be easy to dismiss the whole thing. But many professionals do not, because neither President Clinton nor any of the Republican candidates seems to have captured the public imagination yet.
Also, in a time of public disgust with politics and politicians, General Powell, for all his years in Washington, has a reputation for probity, patriotism and independence. He is seen by many as the very archetype of the leader.
Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, acknowledged as much this week, telling a group of Washington reporters, "If he were to decide to run, he starts off with a well-deserved reputation and huge stature in this country."
 
Transition Made By Other Generals
General Powell is, of course, untested in the political arena. That could work against him if he proved unable to withstand media scrutiny or to articulate detailed policies. But it could also work for him if he were able to rise above the clamor of the campaign, like some Jimmy Stewart character -- or like Dwight D. Eisenhower.
It is said that if General Powell were obliged to take positions on such divisive issues as abortion or the capital gains tax, his appeal would vanish. The most popular sketch in this year's Gridiron show, staged by Washington journalists, showed him losing his halo every time he removed his officer's cap.
But other war heroes, from George Washington to Andrew Jackson, from U. S. Grant to Eisenhower, have successfully made the transition to Presidential candidacy.
Still doggedly Delphic, General Powell has begun to drop a few hints about his political ideas. A week ago, in a speech to mutual funds executives, he even allowed himself to say a bit about partisanship: "I don't find yet that I fit neatly into either party. I have very strong Republican leanings on economic matters and international affairs matters, but I'm still a New Deal kid from Harlem and the South Bronx. Franklin Roosevelt's picture was in my home."
What about Newt Gingrich's Contract With America? someone asked. The general answered: "Some parts I find a little too hard, a little too harsh, a little too unkind. We do not yet have a level playing field in our society."
They could have been the answers of a moderate Republican, a conservative Democrat or an independent, which is probably precisely the kind of ambiguity that General Powell wanted to convey, and which drives his backers nuts.
 
Three Have Links To Eisenhower
Not coincidentally, the three leaders of the draft-Powell movement, who see him as the perfect Republican nominee for next year, all have links of some kind to General Eisenhower. Two helped to put together the draft-Ike movement in 1952, which sent the World War II hero to the White House for two terms; the third wrote acclaimed biographies of Eisenhower and his Vice President, Richard M. Nixon.
Their goal is to convince General Powell that he would far better serve himself and his country by emulating General Eisenhower rather than George C. Marshall, whom he has long considered his hero, and running for elective office rather than settling for a high appointive position as General Marshall did.
Tex McCrary, the New York publicist, raconteur, wartime bomber pilot and onetime talk-show host, is one of the three draft-Powell leaders. Now 84 years old and ailing, Mr. McCrary remains a formidable advocate. He has thrown himself into this campaign-without-a-candidate with enviable zest; every week he writes to the general, often enclosing what he calls "an attention-grabber," such as a bayonet that former President Francois Mitterrand of France gave him.
The general replies politely, often charmingly, always noncommittally. Recently he wrote, "Tex, you are a piece of work." Not much to go on, but Mr. McCrary keeps at it.
Stephen E. Ambrose, the historian and biographer, has just retired as director of the Eisenhower Center at the University of New Orleans. He scarcely knows General Powell, but the Powell bug has bit him, too. Like Eisenhower and unlike contemporary politicians, the usually low-key Mr. Ambrose said: "General Powell is defined by the word 'trust.' He proves by his life that the American dream is still alive. Ike had that quality, too."
Mr. Ambrose plans to spend full time in the coming months as a volunteer in a political army that does not yet exist, working faxes and phones from his ranch in Montana. He described himself recently as "head over heels on this, determined to do nothing else unless he makes a Sherman-like statement."
Less well known is the third man, Charles J. Kelly Jr., but he was the one who got the whole thing started. Mr. Kelly concedes that General Powell has given him no encouragement, but he says the general "has done nothing to discourage me, which is enough."
 
Can a Centrist Shift the G.O.P.?
Mr. Kelly is not without connections. A retired Wall Street investment banker who was something of a protege of the late Clifford Roberts, one of General Eisenhower's original promoters and best friends, he worked in the Eisenhower White House. He rents the smaller house on the Georgetown property of Ben Bradlee, the former editor of The Washington Post.
Mr. Kelly, too, is busy seeking commitments, building networks, writing letters and taking reporters to lunch at the Metropolitan Club, one of the temples of the Washington establishment.
The three dismiss the idea of an independent candidacy, arguing, among other things, that General Powell is too much of a traditionalist to relish a third-party bid. But they have no ready answer to an obvious question: In an era when conservatives in the mold of Speaker Gingrich dominate the Republican Party, how does a dedicated centrist like the general win the nomination?
When Myrlie Evers-Williams was sworn in this month to head the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, for example, General Powell was there to help celebrate the occasion. News photographs showed him in the company of Jesse Jackson and Betty Shabazz, the widow of Malcolm X -- people who are considered well beyond the pale by Republican right-wingers.
Mr. Kelly, for one, thinks General Powell has the capacity to "realign the Republican Party to the center," but not many political experts agree with him.
By the time of the New Hampshire primary in 1952, Mr. McCrary recalls, General Eisenhower was nowhere in the polls. He still won the nomination. But in 1952, with television in its infancy, campaigns were less expensive and money was easier to raise in the absence of stringent Federal regulations.
A poll taken in March for Time magazine and CNN showed that General Powell is potentially the second most popular Republican candidate without having lifted a finger; Senator Dole ranked first, with 37 percent, in a hypothetical race and General Powell next, with 27 percent. No one else pulled more than 7 percent.
 
Powell Springboard In New Hampshire
Other polls are equally enticing for Powell-boosters. A New York Times/CBS News Poll produced stunning favorability ratings for the general, whose Gulf war achievements have evidently not faded from the public mind. He scored 67 percent among Republicans, 61 percent among Democrats and 52 percent among independents. Other national and state polls have shown that, as a third-party nominee in the 1996 general election, he would pull about a quarter of the vote against Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole.
In a memorandum two weeks ago, Mr. Kelly argued that "New Hampshire is almost ideally positioned to initiate a Powell primary campaign" because "its voters are famously independent-minded and sensitive to candidates' personal character and principles." Registered independents, who make up 31 percent of the state's electorate, are eligible to vote in the Republican primary.
General Powell, who is 58, has almost finished his memoir, which is to be published this fall. It has been bought by Time magazine, which plans to run excerpts and perhaps to put his picture on the cover. The general is committed to a five-week international book tour covering 22 cities and starting in mid-September, which should keep him in the limelight all fall.
To qualify for the New Hampshire ballot, he would not have to make a public declaration until Dec. 22, the filing deadline. That would give him time to finish his tour, take political soundings, authorize trial balloons, start a publicity buildup and then make his announcement.
But Senator Dole might have things clinched by then.
The troika wants the reluctant dragon to say something publicly -- not to declare his candidacy, but to say something at least nominally political, something that they can use to keep the pot boiling -- no later than the 51st anniversary of D-Day, June 6. That would underline the Eisenhower connection, but Colonel Smullen says nothing will be forthcoming until the tour has ended.

HEADLINE: SENATE APPROVES PROPOSAL TO BALANCE BUDGET BY 2002; TALKS WITH HOUSE ARE NEXT

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
In what could be a first step toward a revolutionary change in Government economic policy, the Senate today approved a Republican road map that is supposed to put the Government on the course to a balanced Federal budget in seven years.
After a week of highly partisan debate and votes on more than 50 amendments, most of them generally along party lines, the proposed budget calling for nearly $1 trillion in savings by 2002 was approved 57 to 42. The House endorsed a similar blueprint last week. All Republicans and three Democrats -- Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, Sam Nunn of Georgia and Charles S. Robb of Virginia -- voted for the measure today. The remaining Democrats voted "no." 
 In the closing debate, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, said the vote would "make history."
In one respect, the vote is a milestone. It marks what seems to be the serious intention of a majority of the Senate to control spending on popular Government programs, saving enough money to balance the budget.
But in other respects, this is no more than the beginning of an arduous journey with land mines all along the way. Over the next few months, lawmakers will feel the heat as they go beyond the principle of saving money and decide exactly who will pay the price and how much they will pay.
The next step is for a conference committee to work out the differences between the Senate budget resolution and the one passed by the House.
Final remarks in today's debate offered a preview of arguments to come as Democrats contended that Republicans would protect the privileged at the expense of the needy and Mr. Dole countered that their complaints amounted to "the same old liberal rhetoric."
Senator Jim Exon of Nebraska, the top Democrat on the Budget Committee, declared, "It's a budget that takes away unfairly from our seniors, children and least fortunate, but disproportionately and unfairly lines the pockets of the wealthiest among us."
But Mr. Dole asserted that Democrats in control of Congress for a generation had piled up the nation's debt.
"In 1994," he said, "we had a political revolution, an earthquake."
And Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the chairman of the Budget Committee who has devoted his career to the sometimes quixotic goal of cutting the deficit, said that from now on, "we're going to pay our own bills."
Settling the differences between the two versions of the proposed budget will not be easy because the House made a $350 billion tax cut the centerpiece of its plan, and the Senate on Tuesday rejected such a tax reduction by a margin of more than 2 to 1.
The really heavy political lifting will come after a single budget resolution is approved. Such a resolution only sets spending limits for broad areas of Government programs like the military, transportation and education. To actually balance the budget, Congress must decide on the policy changes that will allow it to wring the billions in savings it has specified out of hundreds of Government programs.
It is one thing to say, as the Senate measure does, that a quarter of a trillion dollars will be saved in Medicare over the next seven years. It is another matter to show exactly how these savings will be accomplished and to explain to retirees how their medical benefits would be reduced.
In addition, before the year is out, Republicans must compromise with President Clinton, who vigorously contests the way the Senate and House found most of their savings in the Government's domestic policy activities.
The budget resolution is not subject to a Presidential veto. But the measures to implement it are subject to veto. The Republican majorities in the Senate and House are probably not sufficient to override vetoes on such important matters.
Furthermore, while the Republican Congress seems to be showing more resolve this year about balancing the budget than Congress ever did when it was in Democratic hands, the laws that were passed this year can always be changed in the future.
Congress has promised tough measures to balance the budget many times before, the most prominent being the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings laws of the mid-1980's. But each time these laws started to pinch, they were relaxed.
Still, the importance of today's vote should not be underestimated. Congress is now on record with promises to take deep bites out of popular Government programs like Medicare and education and to force the states to bear a larger burden of programs for the poor like Medicaid and public assistance or trim the benefits.
While most of the week was spent in partisan warfare, Republican Presidential politics provided a sideshow. Mr. Dole found himself struggling to meet conservative markers laid down by a rival for the Republican nomination, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas.
Today, to prove his conservative bona fides, Mr. Dole engineered an amendment that committed the Senate to using for tax reductions any new money that the Congressional Budget Office finds is the result of an improved economy growing out of a balanced budget.
"Make no mistake about it," Mr. Dole said. "In the final analysis, we intend to provide tax relief."
The budget office has estimated that if a balanced budget is adhered to for seven years, the savings in lower interest rates on Government bonds would amount to $170 billion.
But there is less to this than meets the eye. Only $3 billion would be available next year, the budget office found, and $123 billion of the benefits would not accrue until after the turn of the century.
Republican senators say that their budget does not really lower Government spending but merely reduces the rate of growth of spending. That is literally true. But in many areas, reducing the rate at which spending grows would have the effect of cutting back Government services, especially in health care.
Without a change in the law, spending for Medicare, the Government health insurance program for the elderly and disabled, is expected to grow by about 10 percent a year. This is not because the program is being expanded but because inflation in overall medical costs and an increase in the number of beneficiaries each year requires additional spending just to maintain the current level of services.
Over the next seven years, compared with what the budget office believes would be the Government's expenditures without changes in the law, the Senate measure would reduce spending for Medicare by $256 billion and spending for Medicaid, which provides coverage for the poor, by $175 billion.
Republicans say that the trust fund that pays part of Medicare costs will run out of money by 2002 without changes. Still, the cuts anticipated by the Senate resolution are far greater than what would be needed to make the program solvent.
The Senate resolution would cut other Government benefits, including welfare, food stamps and Government pensions, by $209 billion, but Social Security benefits would basically be untouched.
The resolution would allow military spending to rise by about $25 billion over a seven-year period, the same amount favored by the Clinton Administration. But other domestic discretionary spending -- ranging as widely as education and transportation, paper clips and space shuttles -- would be reduced by $390 billion below what would otherwise be spent if the programs rose at the rate of inflation.
The Senate budget resolution proposes but does not require that these levels be met through steps like these: shutting down the Commerce Department; paring the operating budgets of the National Park Service, the Forest Service and the Wildlife Service; abolishing subsidies for Amtrak and municipal mass transit systems, and lowering allotments for scientific research.
One of the most controversial proposals in the Senate resolution is to reduce outlays for the earned-income tax credit, a program that gives tax breaks and, in some instances, direct payments to low-income working families.
One threatened cut was restored today. The Senate voted to rearrange allotments so that the Government's interest subsidy on student loans would not have to be cut.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senators Bill Frist, left, and Christopher S. Bond applauding their Republican colleague Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, during a news conference after yesterday's Senate vote on the budget. The scale Mr. Dole is holding is meant to represent a balanced budget. (David Scull/The New York Times) (pg. A18)
 
Chart: "Compare and Contrast: Budget Proposals - The House and Senate Versions"
 Following are areas of significant difference between the House and Senate budget proposals: Yesterday the Senate passed its budget resolution, a broad outline in fiscal 1996. The House passed its version last week.
 
Total Deficit Reduction
 House: $1.04 trillion over seven years, when measured against the same "baseline," or starting point, used by the Senate.
 Senate: $961 billion over seven years.
 
Tax Cuts
 House: $353 billion over seven years.
 Senate: $170 billion over seven years, if the Congressional Budget Office certifies that this much money can be saved in lower interest payments on Government bonds.
 
Medicare
 House: $288 billion in savings over seven years, achieved by reducing the growth rate of the program to 5.4 percent a year from 10 percent.
 Senate: $256 billion in savings over seven years, achieved by reducing the growth rate to 7.1 percent a year from 10 percent.
 
Medicaid
 House: $187 billion in suggested savings over seven years, achieved by converting the federal share of the program to a block grant and transferring it to the states and by gradually reducing growth to 4 percent a year from nearly 10 percent.
 Senate: $175 billion in suggested savings over seven years, achieved by means similar to those in the House budget.
 
Welfare
 House: $101 billion in savings over seven years by converting major welfare programs into block grants to the states.
 Senate: $80 billion in savings over seven years, block grants.
 
Military Spending
 House: $67.9 billion increase in spending over seven years above the Senate budget and the Clinton administration's proposal, which called for increasing spending by $25 billion over seven years.
 Senate: $25 billion increase, like the Clinton proposal, which would keep defense spending at or below a "hard" freeze - unadjusted for inflation.
 
Non-Military Discretionary Spending
 House: $192 billion in savings over seven years, measured against a freeze at the 1995 enacted level.
 Senate: $190 billion in savings over seven years, measured against a freeze at the 1995 enacted level.
 
Agriculture
 House: $17 billion in savings over seven years in agricultural production programs.
 Senate: $12 billion over seven years.
 
Departments Abolished
 House: Departments of Commerce, Education and Energy.
 Senate: Department of Commerce
 
(Source: Congressional Quarterly; Congressional budget documents) (pg. A18)

HEADLINE: In New Sign of Slow Economy, Home Resales Plunge by 6.4%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
More signs emerged today that the economy was heading toward a sharp slowdown. Sales of existing homes fell 6.4 percent in April to the lowest level in almost three years, despite declining mortgage rates.
The decline in home resales last month, to 3.39 million at an annual rate, was the third decrease in four months, the National Association of Realtors said. In March, sales rose at an unrevised rate of 5.8 percent. 
 "Housing sales are a leading indicator of the economy," said Peter Kretzmer, an economist at Nationsbank in New York. "The overall decline in the economy may be sharper than most people perceive."
A separate report from the Labor Department underscored that point. First-time jobless claims rose 13,000 last week to 380,000, putting them at the highest level since last July, the agency reported. Additionally, the less volatile four-week average for claims rose to a two-and-a-half-year high.
The new evidence of weakness follows Wednesday's report that orders for durable goods fell a steep 4 percent in April and reports earlier this month showing declines in retail sales and industrial production.
The slowdown stems from the Federal Reserve's moves to increase short-term interest rates seven times from February 1994 to February 1995 to cool a rapidly growing economy and keep inflationary pressure in check.
The level of home resales was the lowest since June 1992, when it was also 3.39 million, said Trisha Morris, a spokeswoman for the realtors association. Before that, the low was 3.27 million in January 1992, she said. Before today's housing report, analysts expected a decline of three-tenths of a percent in home resales during April.
For all of 1995, the realty group is projecting that existing-home sales will fall 7 percent from last year's 3.728 million rate, which the group said was the second-best annual showing on record.
By region, April home resales fell 8.1 percent in the South to an annual rate of 1.240 million, declined 6.6 percent, to 710,000, in the West and fell 6.3 percent in the Midwest to 900,000. Sales were unchanged in the Northeast at 550,000.
The realty group said the average price for a home rose five-tenths of a percent, to $108,400 in April from $107,900 in March.
The report showed that even though 30-year mortgage rates have been heading down, many consumers were still leery about committing to home purchases. Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.85 percent this week, up a bit from 7.83 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today.
In April, the rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage averaged 8.32 percent, down from 8.46 percent in March and 8.77 percent in February. That put the average monthly payment on a $100,000 loan at $756.19 in April. When rates were 6.74 percent in mid-October 1993, the monthly payment stood at $647.93.

LENGTH: 385 words

HEADLINE: 1995 N.H.L. Playoffs;
Nordiques Off to Denver After $75 Million Deal

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
The Quebec Nordiques surrendered to the economics of playing in a small market yesterday and were acquired for $75 million by the same entertainment company that purchased the Denver Nuggets in 1989.
COMSAT Entertainment Group follows the sports-as-entertainment lead of the Walt Disney Co., which owns the Anaheim Mighty Ducks, and Wayne Huizenga, the former chairman of Blockbuster Entertainment, who owns the Florida Panthers. 
 The sale price exceeds the $50 million expansion fees paid by the Anaheim, Miami, San Jose, Tampa Bay and Ottawa teams. In 1984, the Hartford Whalers sold for $47.5 million. Of the $1 billion paid for Madison Square Garden by ITT and Cablevision this year, the Rangers probably accounted for about $100 million.
The Nordiques were valued at $49 million by Financial World, but their value was hampered by playing in the small-market Quebec and in an inadequate arena, le Colisee, which holds 15,399.
The team will be worth much more in a larger market, where a new arena, the Pepsi Center, is scheduled to open for the 1997-98 season. The team will share McNichols Arena with the Nuggets for two seasons.
"The N.H.L. is very clear about not seeing this team play in McNichols beyond two years," said Charlie Lyons, the president of COMSAT Entertainment."
In moving, the team transfers from a market with 396,000 TV households to one with 1.1 million.
COMSAT's entertainment interests include film and TV production, hotel TV programming and communications systems.
Lyons met Marcel Aubut, the head of the Nordiques' ownership group, in December. Aubut has been working with the provincial government on financing to keep the Nordiques from moving and to build a modern arena. COMSAT's talks to buy the team got serious in the past week.
COMSAT will retain the services of Marc Crawford, the Nordiques coach, and Pierre Lacroix, the general manager.
The Nordiques' shift to Denver means the return of the National Hockey League to a market that lost its team, the Colorado Rockies, when John McMullen acquired them in 1982 and turned them into the New Jersey Devils.
Lyons said the Rockies "had a marketing problem, not a market problem then." He said there were some doubts, since erased, that major league baseball and pro basketball would work in Denver.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber Prices Lower on Report Showing Weakness in Housing

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Lumber prices fell the daily limit yesterday after a disappointing housing report reinforced fears of a glut in lumber caused by a weak housing market.
On other commodity markets, cotton prices surged. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities fell 0.95 point, to 235.30. 
 Lumber prices fell on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after the National Association of Realtors said sales of previously owned single-family homes fell 6.4 percent in April to the lowest level in nearly three years.
"Those numbers were just miserable -- there's no other word for it," said Michael Young, an analyst with the Pacific Futures Trading Company. "It's continued evidence of sluggishness in the new-home market as well."
Lumber for July delivery fell $10, to $251.10 for 1,000 board feet, and November lumber fell to a three-week low of $267.20 for 1,000 board feet.
Cash lumber prices have been at their lowest levels in years amid a glut of cut wood and dampened enthusiasm about the economy. Futures prices are beginning to fall in accord, analysts said.
Lumber prices have fallen for months as housing starts have fallen to new lows and inventory has backed up.
Some traders attributed the stockpile in inventory to the continued cutting in Canada, where prices of wood byproducts like newspaper pulp are soaring to all-time highs. That has encouraged more lumber companies to cut trees for pulping, depressing the price of wood.
"It's gone from bad to worse lately," said Neil Schmaedick, an analyst with Smith Barney Inc. in Eugene, Ore. "Until we see a break in paper and pulp prices, we're not going to see a rally."
The July cotton contract neared a return to Civil War highs on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, as buying was tied to fears of a shortage before the new crop becomes available.
July cotton rose the limit, 2 cents, to $1.12 a pound, while new-crop contracts fell amid improved weather conditions in some growing areas and lower mill consumption figures.
The Census Bureau said seasonally adjusted daily average cotton consumption fell to 41,686 bales in April from 43,007 in March. The National Cotton Council reported that textile mills consumed less cotton because of high prices.
Cotton prices reached $1.172 a pound on April 24, the highest since the Civil War, on strong worldwide demand for the American crop and fears that the supplies would run out before August, when the new crop is to be harvested.

HEADLINE: House Foes Talking on Foreign Aid Bill

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
With the vote on the delicate foreign aid bill postponed until June, House Republicans are negotiating with Democrats in hopes of making the bill more palatable to Democrats, according to some of those involved.
But the negotiations are tricky because raising the amount of foreign aid, to appeal to Democrats, could cost Republican votes. And the central sticking point is less the money than whether three agencies are retained or melded into the State Department. 
 Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, Republican of New York and chairman of the Rules Committee, said today that the Democrats wanted an extra half-billion dollars restored to the bill, which cuts foreign aid from $17.4 billion in 1995 to $16.5 billion in 1996 and $15.4 billion in 1997.
In addition to the reduction in money, the bill, the first foreign aid package designed by Congressional Republicans since the Truman Administration, would also eliminate three agencies -- the Agency for International Development, the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and the United States Information Agency -- that Democrats hold dear. It also would attempt to influence American policy toward other countries by restricting ways in which American aid could be spent, which prompted President Clinton to threaten to veto the bill, calling it a "frontal assault" on Presidential authority.
"If this whole bill goes down, there could be further cuts," Mr. Solomon said. "If Democrats aren't going to support it, and we didn't have the votes, then there will be further cuts. It's a fragile ball that's out there."
Republicans yanked the bill off the House floor Wednesday night, with Democrats asserting that the new majority did not have the votes to pass it. Republicans said today that they could have passed the bill without Democrats, but that they were in danger of losing several hard-core conservative Republicans if those members did not have a chance to offer their own amendments.
There were 100 amendments to the bill and the vote in the House was scheduled for today. But by the end of Wednesday, the House had debated only nine of them. House leaders then stopped the debate and postponed the vote to June 7.
Democrats said Republicans came to them on the floor to discuss a compromise, which the Democrats rejected because it still cut the agencies. "We had very strong indications that they didn't have the votes," said one Democratic aide.
Mr. Solomon said that between now and the vote on June 7, the negotiations would continue and he expected heavy lobbying by organizations such as the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, to help persuade Democrats, who are the natural allies of foreign aid bills, to come on board. "Aipac is putting pressure on some of those Democrats to vote for it," Mr. Solomon said. "That's what will happen over the next eight days. If they don't vote for it, there's apt to be other trouble down the road" in the form of more drastic cuts.
Still, Mr. Solomon said he was "confident" that his party could gather enough Republicans, "if we had to," to vote for the bill despite their lifelong antipathy toward foreign aid.
House Speaker Newt Gingrich said the same thing today. "We have the votes," he told reporters. "I'm not worried about passage." In private meetings with Republicans, he pressed for passage, saying, according to one Republican, that the bill amounts to "the projection of American power and presence around the globe in a nonmilitary way at a cost of one cent on the federal dollar."
Tony Blankley, Mr. Gingrich's spokesman, said of the negotiations with Democrats that the goal was a bipartisan foreign policy. The Republican party, he said, "is reorienting as a majority governing party, and there are old instincts that when you are in the minority, there are certain things you don't vote for." He added: "Those things are reversed in this case for both parties. So we're in that process.
"But on something as unpopular as foreign aid, that we were in single digits on possible no votes was a good sign. And we're not convinced we won't get Democrats. After all, there is Israeli aid, and that's a component in any foreign aid package."
While the Republican bill would slash aid to other regions, including Russia and Africa, it would continue the current $3 billion per year commitment to Israel.
Democratic aides said that the party was unified against the bill and that the party's caucus today revealed that only about four members might vote with the Republicans. But Mr. Solomon said that he believed about a dozen Democrats might defect, but if they did not, the Republicans would fall in line.
"We are cohesive enough, we can provide our own votes, because you've got people like me," Mr. Solomon said. "I've never voted for a foreign aid bill. I'm with the conservative hard core, the people who are not of the internationalist group. But we are going to support it and we'll give them the votes they need. You may have 8 or 10 Republicans who don't want to vote for it, and if we get no Democrats, then we just have to ask our people to vote for it."

HEADLINE: German Accuses Tourist Office of Prejudice

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, May 25

 BODY:
An official of Germany's Government-financed tourism office in New York City said tonight that he had been dismissed after uncovering a directive from his head office in Frankfurt saying "Jews, blacks, Hispanics and Asiatics" should be discouraged from visiting Germany.
Government officials here sought to distance themselves from the directive as a statement of German policy and said they could not explain how it came to be in the files of the New York City office. 
 The New York German tourism office is already embroiled in several racial and sexual harassment suits and recently dismissed one of its employees who was involved in translating an article that sought to deny the Holocaust.
Fred Gross, the acting head of the New York tourism office, said on German television tonight that he was suing his employers, a Frankfurt-based office supposed to promote tourism in Germany. The office receives around 85 percent of its funds, which total over $30 million a year, from the Government in Bonn.
Mr. Gross said the document had not been formally withdrawn even after he drew the attention of his superiors to it.
German television showed an excerpt from the document referring specifically to "Jews, blacks, Hispanics and Asiatics" as people who should not be enocouraged to visit Germany.
Ulrich Geisendorf, an official of the Economics Ministry, which finances the tourism agency, described the document as "worthless." He said it dated to 1984 and did not reflect the practices of German tourism. It was not known who wrote the document.
In fact, Mr. Geisendorf said, American Jews had been encouraged to visit his country.
The existence of the document, however, is a major embarrassment for the Bonn Government, particularly since the tourism office has acquired a reputation for controversy and impropriety.
This week, the office's assets were attached by a New York State court in connection with a $3.5 million sexual harassment suit brought last year by an employee, Monique Schlein. Another employee, Christa Willibald, has brought a $1 million racial discrimination suit.
This month, Elke Berg, another employee at the office, was dismissed for translating an article by her husband calling the Holocaust an "absurd story."
At that time, Gunter Colonius, the head of the tourism agency in Frankfurt, said the tourism office "tolerates neither anti-Semitic statements nor the dissemination of the Auschwitz lie," a phrase by which Germans refer to attempts to discount the Holocaust.
A former director of the New York office, Henning Schreiber, was recalled to Frankfurt following the complaints of racial and sexual harassment. The monetary lawsuits outstanding against the German office now total some $15 million.

HEADLINE: Clinton Urges Investment In Ulster

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
President Clinton urged American companies today to invest in Northern Ireland, saying jobs created by new factories and businesses there would "lift the despair that breeds violence" and help turn a nine-month-old cease-fire into a permanent peace.
"We must make hope real," Mr. Clinton said, addressing 300 business and political leaders at a conference here on trade and investment in Ireland and Northern Ireland. 
 "I urge American businesses and all others to consider investing in Northern Ireland and the border counties," the President said, referring to border counties of the Republic of Ireland.
Mr. Clinton also vowed to battle for more American aid for Ireland despite the Republican onslaught on his budget proposals in Congress. He said he would seek a roughly 60 percent increase -- to $60 million over the next two years -- in the American contribution to the International Fund for Ireland. The fund channels some $50 million a year in economic assistance to Ireland from the United States, Europe, Canada, Australia and New Zealand.
"Some want to cut these programs which support peace," the President said, acknowledging Congressional opposition to the increase. He called such resistance "a grave error."
Saying economic development would also depend on disarmament, he urged the Irish Republican Army and Protestant paramilitary forces in Northern Ireland to start turning in weapons, so both sides could "get rid of the guns and bombs for good."
The call seems to increase the pressure on the I.R.A. at least to make a gesture by surrendering some weapons -- the price Britain is demanding for including the group's political wing, Sinn Fein, in all-party talks on a permanent settlement for the British-ruled province.
The White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said afterward that Mr. Clinton was hoping to visit Ireland and Britain in the late fall or early winter.
In a rare meeting here on Wednesday, Britain's chief official for Northern Ireland, Sir Patrick Mayhew, urged Sinn Fein's president, Gerry Adams, to start the process of "decommissioning" the I.R.A.'s weapons, saying that would be the most effective way of giving businesses enough confidence to invest.
The premise of the business conference here and another held in Belfast in December is that much of the sectarian violence in Northern Ireland over the last 25 years reflects frustration and extremism bred by high levels of unemployment on both sides of the border.
That has led the Clinton Administration to develop a strategy that Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown today called "commercial diplomacy," or seeking to strengthen the cease-fire by increasing employment and economic development.
"People have a right to expect that risks for peace will bring opportunities and growth," Mr. Brown said.
The Administration has adopted a similar approach toward Israel's agreement with the P.L.O. on extending Palestinian self-rule in the occupied territories. Last fall the United States helped organize a business conference in Morocco on investing in the Middle East.
The most important reason American companies should set up in Northern Ireland and the border countries of the Irish Republic, Mr. Brown said, would be to gain tariff-free access to the 15-nation European Union market.
Investors would also be drawing on a "large pool of educated, motivated and English-speaking workers" earning an average hourly wage that is 36 percent lower than that paid in the United States, he said.
Finally, Mr. Brown said, both Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland offer tax and other incentives that have helped American companies investing there earn a healthy 25.8 percent annual return, the highest average in Europe.
Paradoxically, the short-term effect of peace in Northern Ireland will be a dampening of economic activity, as the British Army pulls out and police and other security services are reduced to normal levels.
"There is a down side to peace," Baroness Denton, the under secretary of state for the economy in Northern Ireland, said in an interview, while emphasizing that the British Government would gradually "recycle" the security savings back into the province's economy. By the end of the century, Britain hopes to create 60,000 more jobs in the province, she said.

HEADLINE: Myer Rashish, 70, Economist and Aide

 BODY:
Myer Rashish, a Harvard-trained economist who served as Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs in 1981, died Tuesday in Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 70 and had lived in Washington since 1952.
His son, Peter, said his father had been under treatment for lung cancer. 
 Mr. Rashish was particularly interested in economic relations with European countries. As an assistant on trade policy to President John F. Kennedy, Mr. Rashish drafted and then lobbied successfully in Congress for the passage of the 1962 Trade Expansion Act. The legislation paved the way for lowering tariffs betwen the United States and the then European Common Market.
Myer Rashish was born Nov. 10, 1924, in Cambridge, Mass. He received a bachelor's degree in 1944 and a master's in economics in 1947 from Harvard.
He taught economics in the 1940's at M.I.T., Williams College, Tufts College and Bowdoin College.
His marriage to Bernice Rashish ended in divorce.
Survivors in addition to his son of Washington include two daughters, Alisa and Andrea, both of New York, and a sister, Shulamith Wilion, of Brookline, Mass.

HEADLINE: Reducing Debt Has a Depressing History

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Forever in Debt?" (Op-Ed, May 21), the British historian Paul Johnson uses at least three misleading or incorrect statements that the best government is one with no outstanding debt: 
 (1) While it is true that the United States national debt was virtually eliminated in 1835 and 1836, it is also true that a serious economic depression began in 1837. Every sustained period of debt reduction in United States history has been immediately followed by a depression. There have been six such periods, preceding the economic collapses of 1819, 1837, 1857, 1873, 1893 and 1929. For whatever reasons, systematic debt reduction has never led to prosperity.
(2) Mr. Johnson's claim that the national debt "was cut by half" between 1946 and 1975 is false. There has been no systematic debt reduction since World War II. Coincidentally or otherwise, there has been no serious depression since then.
(3) There have been no "huge increases" in Federal Government employees since 1975. There were 2.9 million Federal civilian employees in that year, and 3.1 million in 1992.
 
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Pittsburgh, May 22, 1995
The writer retired as professor of public and international affairs at the University of Pittsburgh.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

HEADLINE: How the Government Could Aid Job-Seekers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Katherine S. Newman's May 20 Op-Ed article "What Inner-City Jobs for Welfare Moms?" suggests that the chief job-search obstacle faced by recipients of Aid to Families with Dependent Children in the ghettos is unique to them. On the contrary, middle-class Americans have periodically faced a lack of local job opportunity and have been required to adjust. 
 Given the staggering unemployment statistics -- 18 percent plus -- in neighborhoods such as central Harlem, it seems an exercise in futility to continue the job search there. The history of immigrant and middle-class families speaks eloquently of the necessity of relocating where work is to be found.
Jobs do not, in a free society, move to meet the job-seekers; it's the other way around.
Even a leaner Federal Government could provide an essential service: a central data base matching job-seeker qualifications with constantly updated work openings in the private sector across the country. Problems in housing and training could be met locally with tax incentives and private philanthropy. Is this not the public-private cooperation our employment figures cry out for?
 
KATHLEEN E. WHEELOCK
New York, May 20, 1995

HEADLINE: In Book, Simpson Friend Takes a Skeptical Tone

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 25

 BODY:
On the day after Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman were killed, O. J. Simpson boasted to friends and to Brian (Kato) Kaelin that Mr. Kaelin could provide him with an alibi, according to a new book based on extensive interviews that Mr. Kaelin gave before taking the stand in March.
But the book, by a freelance writer, Marc Eliot, says Mr. Kaelin knew he could not account for Mr. Simpson's whereabouts throughout the evening of June 12. Indeed, on several occasions, Mr. Eliot writes, Mr. Kaelin told him that he believed that Mr. Simpson was a murderer. 
 The book, "Kato Kaelin: The Whole Truth," built around 16 hours of taped interviews, contains few other revelations or dramatic deviations from Mr. Kaelin's testimony. But in it the aspiring actor, who lived for a time with both Mr. and Mrs. Simpson, appears far less protective and far more skeptical of Mr. Simpson, a man he has vowed to help in any way he can. Prosectors may want to explore Mr. Kaelin's elaborations further under oath.
After the interviews, Mr. Kaelin and Mr. Eliot had a falling-out, and the $545,000 that the publisher, HarperCollins, paid for the book went to Mr. Eliot alone. Mr. Kaelin, who has gone from unemployment and a jalopy to fame and a Mercedes since the killings, is expected to seek part of that advance, though his lawyer, Michael Plotkin of Los Angeles, declined to comment today.
Meantime, prosecutors are weighing whether to recall Mr. Kaelin to the witness stand.
His published recollections include an account of the morning of June 13, when he joined friends and relatives of Mr. Simpson in his home at 360 North Rockingham Avenue. Mr. Simpson, he recalled, sat glued to the television set, watching news reports of the killings. When a reporter stated that Mr. Simpson could not account for his whereabouts at the time of the killings, Mr. Kaelin said Mr. Simpson declared: "That's not true. Kato knows where I was! Kato knows my alibi! Kato went to McDonald's with me. And Kato knows I went back into the house after."
Mr. Eliot said Mr. Kaelin then related: "In my head I went, 'No, I never saw you go in the house after McDonald's.' And I didn't. The last thing I remembered seeing before going into my room was O. J. standing by the driver's side of his Bentley."
Mr. Kaelin also recalled the evening of June 12, just before the killings, when he saw Mr. Simpson several times. But unlike the bland and disjointed version he offered on the witness stand -- which, Mr. Eliot contends, was an act designed to protect Mr. Simpson -- the book version is characterized by a persistent sense of disquiet.
After hearing Mr. Simpson describe both the dance recital he attended with his family early that evening and after accompanying Mr. Simpson to McDonald's, Mr. Kaelin said he felt something was amiss. "I don't know why, but the entire night, I kept having the feeling that something was not right," he said.
He felt the same way around 11 P.M., he said, when he spotted a duffle bag -- still unaccounted for -- on the driveway of Mr. Simpson's house, while the rest of the luggage that Mr. Simpson was taking to Chicago sat yards away by the limousine that took him to the airport.
"I didn't remember seeing it before, and couldn't understand why it was there since O. J.'s luggage usually is where the golf clubs had been," he said. "This made no sense, I told myself."
The Mr. Simpson he saw the day after the killings was strangely, disconcertingly detached, Mr. Kaelin says in the book, and the tearful Mr. Simpson he saw at Mrs. Simpson's wake was just as odd. "I thought it was possible he was crying just crocodile tears," Mr. Kaelin said. "The impact of sadness on his part just wasn't there."
Under oath last March, Mr. Kaelin testified that the Simpsons had a good relationship the entire time he knew them. But in the book, he said that Mrs. Simpson told him that she suspected Mr. Simpson both videotaped her in bed with other men and was tapping her phone. She told Mr. Kaelin, as she had others, that Mr. Simpson's jealousy would lead him to kill her but that he would go unpunished because of his celebrity.
Mr. Eliot, whose other books include biographies of Bruce Springsteen and Walt Disney, described his former collaborator as a "master opportunist." He said that his resolve to go forward with the project grew as he watched Mr. Kaelin "fandango his way through six days of testimony."
Like various other Simpson case authors, Mr. Eliot has pledged to donate a portion of the book's proceeds to the Simpsons' two young children, Justin and Sydney. Like his fellow writers, he has not specified the amount.

HEADLINE: Senate Welfare Plan Cuts $41 Billion Over 7 Years

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
The Congressional Budget Office said today that welfare legislation proposed by leading Senate Republicans would cut projected spending by more than $41 billion over the next seven years, a saving of at least 10 percent.
But the budget office said the proposal's work requirements were so stringent that most states could not meet them. And if states did comply, it suggested, they would have to spend most of their Federal welfare money on job training, child care and related services, rather than on direct assistance to poor people. 
 The bill, scheduled to be considered Friday by the Senate Finance Committee, was drafted by the chairman of the panel, Bob Packwood of Oregon, working closely with Bob Dole, the Republican leader.
Like a bill approved by the House in March, the Senate plan would eliminate the Federal guarantee of cash assistance for millions of poor families that meet eligibility criteria set by Federal and state law. Instead, each state would receive a lump sum, or block grant, equal to the amount of Federal welfare spending in the state in 1994.
Under Mr. Packwood's bill, the block grants would total $16.8 billion a year from 1996 to 2000, without any adjustment for inflation or population growth. The grants would not necessarily increase if hard times led more people to seek aid.
Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, has criticized many features of the Senate bill. But at a meeting with Administration officials on Wednesday, Democratic members of the Finance Committee chided the Administration for what they said was President Clinton's failure to lead an aggressive attack on Mr. Packwood's bill.
People who were at the meeting said Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, Democrat of Illinois, held up a copy of a report by the Department of Health and Human Services estimating that four million children would lose Federal welfare benefits because the bill would set a five-year limit on payments to any family.
White House officials responded then that the Senate bill was less harsh than the House bill. Several Senate Democrats said they left the meeting with a clear impression that President Clinton would not veto Mr. Packwood's bill, and some Administration officials said they had reached the same conclusion.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who has studied welfare policy for several decades, said he was disappointed that the Administration was not fighting to preserve welfare as an entitlement, available to all who meet the eligibility criteria.
Administration officials have said that Mr. Clinton will veto any bill replacing food stamps with block grants. But they have not made such threats about the main cash welfare program for poor children.
Mr. Packwood's bill would continue a work program established under the last major welfare law, the Family Support Act of 1988, but the requirements would be more stringent. Half of all the adults on welfare in each state would have to be enrolled in work or training programs by 2001. States failing to meet these requirements could lose 5 percent of their Federal welfare money grants.
The Department of Health and Human Services said that to comply with these requirements, states would have to spend $12.7 billion a year, or three-fourths of the block grant money, on jobs, training, education and child care. That would leave only one-fourth of the money for actual welfare benefits. The department, like the Congressional Budget Office, concluded that many states would simply pay the financial penalties rather than comply.
Republicans say that states can cope with the block grant restrictions because they can run welfare programs more efficiently than the Federal Government and will move many people from welfare to work.

HEADLINE: Long Beach Journal;
From Cambodia to Doughnut Shops

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: LONG BEACH, Calif., May 21

 BODY:
The first English words that Ly Yiv learned 15 years ago after fleeing the slaughter in Cambodia were the names of doughnuts: twist, glazed and jelly, chocolate, buttermilk and old-fashioned.
His first impressions of the United States remain crystal clear. "I came here to California at 2 o'clock in the afternoon," said Mr. Yiv, now 45, "and at midnight I went to learn how to bake doughnuts with my friend. I had coffee and ate hot dogs -- a lot of hot dogs -- and I stayed all night." 
 Ever since, he has been earning his living making doughnuts.
Cambodian refugees and doughnuts, which got their distinctive shape in 19th-century America, may seem an odd match, but the oddest thing is that Mr. Yiv's story is typical. Over the past decade and a half, Cambodian refugees have, with little fanfare, virtually taken over the doughnut business in California, making it their primary route into the local economy.
Building on the inspiration of a refugee named Ted Ngoy, and by extending credit to one another, Cambodian immigrants have opened one small shop after another, cutting deeply into the business of large chains like Winchell's Donut Houses, which once dominated the California market. Today, industry analysts say Cambodians own about 80 percent of the doughnut shops in the state.
These refugees, survivors of the Khmer Rouge government that caused the deaths of a million people in the late 1970's, brought with them memories of one of the century's great horrors. About 200,000 Cambodians reached the United States, with close to half settling in Southern California, particularly in the Little Phnom Penh section of Long Beach, where they began their doughnut boom in the 1980's.
Mr. Ngoy, who trained at Winchell's in the late 1970's, became rich by opening small doughnut shops and selling them to newer arrivals. He has since returned to a less chaotic Cambodia to enter politics, leaving behind a refugee community forever altered by doughnuts.
"In my computer, I have 2,400 Cambodian doughnut shops in California," said Ning Yen, 39, who started with a small shop and now owns an $8 million business distributing doughnut-making equipment.
"I think it's already too many now," said Mr. Yen, a disciple of Mr. Ngoy, "and people are fighting each other for business. They just kept opening doughnut shops, and there is not enough demand for them all."
Nancy Parker, president of Winchell's, said her company was now down to 120 outlets in California. Before the Cambodian influx, Winchell's had more than 1,000 outlets in the western United States, mostly in California.
"Where we had one Winchell's shop, they now have three or four Cambodian shops," Ms. Parker said. "They were very happy with a much lesser volume."
Defying California's health-food trend, she said, the number of doughnut shops in the state grew by 55 percent from 1985 to 1993, even as consumption fell by nearly 10 percent. In Los Angeles, for example, there is 1 doughnut shop for every 7,500 people, compared with 1 per 30,000 more common elsewhere in the country.
Scott Thov, an associate of Mr. Ngoy, said it takes about $80,000 to open a small shop, adding that a family of three to five people can manage a business alone, pulling themselves up from the poverty that still affects many of the refugees.
At Good Time Donuts in Diamond Bar, near here, Mr. Yiv, who was a landowner in Cambodia, said that while doughnuts were little known there, the business here had been a haven for refugees in an alien culture.
"Some people can't write and can't tell the name," he said, "but they can smell the flour and they can make the doughnut. This is a good business for people who don't speak too much English. They can say, 'Good morning' and 'How are you?' and count the money."
Mr. Yiv said Cambodians preferred doughnut shops to liquor stores or gas stations because they were not as susceptible to robbery, but Mr. Thov said many doughnut shops had been cutting back nighttime hours because of a rising fear of crime.
Sun's Donuts in Westminster remains open around the clock, with family members working in shifts. When one of the family's three children, Naun Sinn, was married last year, the family enlisted a friend to keep the shop open during the wedding.
Now Mr. Sinn, 26, whose father was a teacher before the Khmer Rouge takeover, starts in the afternoon and works until 10 P.M. and studies management at California State University at Fullerton. His wife, Sophan Chea, 23, who is studying to become a teacher, does her homework at a table in the back of the shop.
With the California market saturated, but with the refugees' entrepreneurial appetite far from sated, Mr. Yen said, some shop owners are looking to expand beyond California.
Perhaps back in Cambodia, an untapped market? "Too small," Mr. Yen said. "Only six million people -- less than Los Angeles.
"We are looking to go to China."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I came here to California at 2 o'clock in the afternoon," says Ly Yiv, now 45, "and at midnight I went to learn how to bake doughnuts with my friend." Mr. Yiv is the owner of Good Time Donuts in Diamond Bar. (Seth Mydans/The New York Times)
