HEADLINE: SENATE APPROVES PROPOSAL TO BALANCE BUDGET BY 2002; TALKS WITH HOUSE ARE NEXT;
Fight Now Turns Intraparty, And Battleground Is Taxes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
Republicans in Congress have been fighting Democrats for five months over how to balance the Federal budget. Now they start fighting each other.
With broad-brush proposals to reach fiscal balance now approved by both the House and the Senate, the Republican majorities in the two chambers will begin haggling on Friday to reach a compromise plan that both ends of the Capitol can support. And they immediately confront a yawning split over the most divisive issue of the entire budget process: tax relief. 
 "It's the crux of the issue," Richard May, the staff director of the House Budget Committee, said today. "Everything else revolves around tax cuts. The longer this thing hangs out there, the bigger problem it becomes."
Already it is immense enough. The budget plan that the Senate approved today omits any guarantee of a tax cut, in large part because Republican moderates refused to go along with one until the deficit is on a proven path toward zero. The plan does reserve up to $170 billion for tax relief later, but only if lower deficits strengthen the economy and create a Government windfall from lower interest rates and greater tax revenue.
By contrast, the House would slash taxes by $350 billion over seven years, half of that for $500-a-child credits to taxpaying families earning $200,000 a year or less. Most of the rest would go toward tax breaks for capital gains, estates, small businesses, well-off Social Security recipients and married couples.
Although budget negotiations are legendary for puffery and posturing, Republicans in the House appear adamant about preserving tax breaks, which many place at the core of their ideological revolution. Today some 80 Republicans sent Speaker Newt Gingrich a letter in which they pledged to vote against any compromise "that fails to balance the budget or significantly diminishes the tax relief passed by the House."
"We're going to insist on capital gains," said Representative David L. Hobson, Republican of Ohio. "We're going to want fairness for senior citizens. We're going to go after the tax difference for marriages."
One House concession, said Mr. Hobson, who advises the chairman of the Budget Committee, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, might involve the scope of the family tax credit, which he predicted would be limited to households with annual earnings below $95,000, or even less. But lowering the earnings ceiling would save a scant amount, because the bulk of families who would benefit from the tax break earn less than $95,000 a year anyway.
The Senate, meanwhile, has made clear that a bone of a few score billion is not enough. Only this week, Republicans joined Democrats to deliver a 69-to-31 thumping to a virtual clone of the House proposal, a $300 billion tax cut offered by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas.
The Senate's chief bargainer, Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, is as firmly opposed to tax cuts as Mr. Kasich is for them. Mr. Domenici was silent on the issue today, saying he did not conduct negotiations through newspapers. But the Budget Committee's No. 2 Republican, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, said he believed that the Senate would demand that the House scale back its tax-cut package by at least half -- to $170 billion, say.
"When you're out there in grass-roots America and asking questions, people want to balance the budget by a 2 to 1 margin over tax decreases," he said. Proposing a big tax reduction now, he said, wounds Congress's already bloodied credibility.
But Mr. May, the House committee's staff director, said, "I don't think the guys on our side are going to be happy with $170 billion."
That said, none of those experts appeared to believe today that the tax fracas would destroy the negotiations, as have budget disputes between the House and the Senate in some past years. Mr. Gingrich's spokesman, Tony Blankley, predicted that the party would arrive at a united stance on taxes, and he cast the letter from Republican conservatives as a gesture of support for negotiators, not a threat.
An aide to the House leadership put it another way: "This is typical pre-conference posturing on both sides, which is helpful to the process. Each side stakes out its turf. I think we all recognize the number's going to be somewhere between zero and $350 billion."
The negotiators face additional differences, but Mr. May and others predicted that these would fall like dominoes once the tax question was resolved. They include the following:
MILITARY The House would spend $1.9 trillion on the military through 2002, while the Senate would spend some $70 billion less. Mr. Grassley said he leaned toward the lower figure but predicted that the Senate would give up some of its cuts to satisfy Congress's hawks.
MEDICARE The House would reduce projected spending by $288 billion over seven years, the Senate by $256 billion. Logic, and the powerful lobby of the elderly, suggest that the Senate's figure will carry more weight, experts said.
CRIME The House would reduce contributions to the Violent Crime Trust Fund, established in last year's anti-crime legislation, by $7.8 billion over seven years. The Senate would reallocate to law-enforcement agencies $2.7 billion of those contributions.
HOUSING AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT The House proposal would shave projected spending by $37 billion through 2002, cutting tenant subsidies, deregulating public housing and turning many programs into block grants. The Senate envisions considerably less paring, $12.2 billion, by cutting some existing block grants and consolidating other programs into new ones.
VETERANS PROGRAMS The House would save some $7.1 billion over seven years by reducing construction of new hospitals and making other changes in medical programs. The Senate would save $9.7 billion by freezing new construction and, like the House, changing medical programs.

GRAPHIC: Chart shows the differences between the House and Senate proposals for tax cuts and deficit reduction over seven years (pg. A1)

HEADLINE: $25 and Under

BYLINE: By Eric Asimov 

 BODY:
The burrito proliferation has leveled off. Two years ago, new places specializing in gargantuan burritos were opening all over Manhattan, and established restaurants were opening branches with abandon. But a consolidation seems to have taken place, with the weaker restaurants closing and fewer new ones opening.
Nonetheless, burritos remain huge, in size at least, and economical. A single burrito -- a soft flour tortilla more than a foot in diameter, stuffed with rice, beans, cheese, guacamole, and meat or shrimp or anything else you can think of -- can be an entire meal, usually for less than $6. What's more, almost every place offers vegetarian burritos, and most even offer nondairy burritos, made with tofu instead of cheese and sour cream. Some also offer alternatives like brown rice and whole-wheat tortillas, although such choices will hardly lower the calorie and fat count of a burrito also laden with sour cream, cheese and guacamole. 
 Here are three burrito specialists in Manhattan.
BERTHA'S. This uptown outpost of the two Benny's Burritos downtown, which has a peace sign etched into the entrance wall, exudes northern California cool. With its big plate glass windows opening onto the Upper West Side, its comfortable couches in front of a carved wood bar and its butcher block tables, high ceiling and white brick wall, this is one of the more pleasant burrito restaurants in New York City, although the noise level can rise when the bar is hopping.
Chips ($2.25) are homemade, puffy and sprinkled with cayenne. They come with a lively, chunky tomato-and-onion salsa. The Bay burrito ($5.95) is fresh and almost impossible to finish, packed with chunks of beef or chicken, beans, rice and the rest. The barbecued pork burrito ($5.95) is less successful. An overly sweet barbecue sauce makes the whole package too moist.
The staff is mellow and alert, offering free refills of the tart homemade lemonade.
CALIFORNIA TACQUERIA. At this branch of a chain that began in Brooklyn, dining is self-service, the amenities are few and the focus is strictly on the food.
That is good news because the East L.A. burrito ($4.75) exudes freshness and flavor, stuffed with yellow rice, a choice of pinto or black beans, and delicious chunks of beef. The tortilla's texture and elasticity are just right, but flimsy plastic utensils can't properly saw through the behemoth burrito. Chips ($1) are thick and homemade, served with fresh salsa.
The pastel-green walls of the dining room are covered with colorful murals, and the ceiling is shiny silver. A display of hubcaps on one wall is a particularly nice California touch.
FLYING BURRITOS. Most of what you need to know about Flying Burritos is on the back of the menu: the restaurant serves 24 kinds of tequila, ranging from $3.50 to $8.50 a shot, and 34 kinds of margaritas, $4.50 to $9.25.
Yes, Flying Burritos is as much bar as restaurant. The dark square room is a study in head-shop kitsch, with black-light portraits of Elvis and Hendrix, a lamp covered in zebra skin and other dormitory favorites of an earlier era. Burritos here are more notable for their mass than for their quality. The Stomping Burrito ($5.95), stuffed with beef, guacamole, rice, beans and cheese, stretches over the ends of a plate but overall is rather insipid.
The margaritas are delicious, though.
 
Burrito Specialists
BERTHA'S, 2160 Broadway, at 76th Street, (212) 362-4955. 11 A.M. to 11:30 P.M. Sundays through Thursdays, until 12:30 A.M. Fridays and Saturdays; cash only; entrance and dining room on one level; restrooms a flight down.
CALIFORNIA TACQUERIA, 355 Avenue of the Americas, near West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 229-0999. Noon to midnight daily; cash only; everything is on one level.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Bill Would Overhaul Communications Industry
In a 38-to-5 vote approving an overhaul of communications regulation, the House Commerce Committee voted to kill most cable TV price limits and to lift scores of restrictions on how many television, radio and other media properties a company can own.
The bill would also let local telephone companies enter the long-distance and cable industries while forcing them to open up their own markets. [Page A1.]
 
Senate Approves Plan To Balance Budget
The Senate approved a Republican road map that is supposed to balance the Federal budget in seven years. The budget plan calls for nearly $1 trillion in savings. The House endorsed a similar plan last week. [A1.]
 
House and Senate Republicans must now devise a compromise budget that confronts the incendiary issue of tax relief. [A1.]
 
Judge Clears Suit Against Prodigy
A New York judge ruled that Prodigy can be held liable for comments posted electronically by a user, clearing the way for a $200 million libel suit against the online service. [D4.]
 
Bill on Securities Suits Gains
The Senate Banking Committee approved a bill that would make it harder to bring lawsuits against publicly traded companies when stock prices drop sharply. [D2.]
 
A California Republican has led an effort to overhaul Federal securities laws, making it tougher to sue executives for fraud. [A19.]
 
Radio Host Indicted in Fraud
Sonny Bloch, radio host of a popular financial call-in program, was charged with fraud by Federal prosecutors and the S.E.C., which said Mr. Bloch and his associates had bilked hundreds of investors of more than $21 million by using his broadcasts to promote fraudulent wireless cable and radio schemes. A Federal grand jury indicted Mr. Bloch and four other men on 35 counts of fraud. [D3.]
 
Home Sales Fall 6.4 Percent
Sales of existing homes fell 6.4 percent in April, to an annual rate of 3.39 million, the lowest level in almost three years. Separately, the Labor Department said first-time jobless claims rose 13,000 last week, to 380,000, the highest level since July. [D6.]
 
Phar-Mor's Ex-President Convicted
Michael Monus, the ousted president of Phar-Mor, was found guilty of Federal felony charges for his role in a $1 billion fraud that plunged the company into bankruptcy. The verdict came as Phar-Mor said its reorganization plan had been approved by major creditors. [D3.]
 
Shell to Develop Gulf Gas Field
Shell Oil plans to develop a gas field about a mile deep in the Gulf of Mexico that is expected to contain an estimated 720 billion cubic feet of natural gas. [D18.]
 
Questions at Solomon-Page
Shares of Solomon-Page Group have more than tripled in value since March, despite the company's widening loss. Market Place. [D6.]
 
Ovitz in Talks to Head MCA
Michael Ovitz, chairman of the Creative Artists Agency, has been negotiating with Edgar Bronfman Jr., Seagram's chief executive, about becoming head of MCA, people familiar with the talks said. [D4.]
 
Money Keeps Flowing Into Funds
Mutual funds that buy American stocks took in a net $8.6 billion in April, the highest flow for domestic funds since January 1994. The funds had just 6.8 percent of their assets in cash, the lowest level since 1978. [D5.]
 
Evening Sun to Close
The Evening Sun of Baltimore, the newspaper of H. L. Mencken, will be closed in September by Times Mirror. [D4.]
 
Haagen-Dazs Tries a New Image
In a $10 million campaign for the summer selling season, Haagen-Dazs will assert that its superpremium products are not rich treats only intended for special occasions. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Slowdown Signs Hurt the Dollar, And Stocks Fall

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Fresh news suggesting an economic slowdown -- this time in housing and unemployment --hit the dollar hard and divided stock and bond traders yesterday.
The bond market, which is more fearful of inflation than recession, continued to rise. But stocks fell as the new data led traders to question their assumption that the economy was, in the words of Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, in a "Goldilocks expansion": not too hot to set inflation ablaze yet not cool enough to stop the growth of corporate profits. This view helped lift the blue-chip indexes by more than 15 percent this year. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 25.93 points, to 4,412.23, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 0.02 point, to 528.59. The Nasdaq composite index, rich in the technology stocks that have recently led the market, nonetheless dropped 0.66 point, to 877.32.
The value of the dollar, which had stabilized for the last few weeks, posted its biggest one-day loss against the German mark since the autumn of 1992, signaling more currency turmoil to come. The dollar dropped sharply against the Japanese yen as well.
Because of the dollar, the value of American stocks held by foreigners plummeted overnight. It was only Wednesday that the Dow rose 15.74 percent in dollars so far this year and 7.47 percent in German marks. Yesterday, the Dow's rise was 15.07 percent in dollars and only 3.88 percent in marks.
While there were one-time factors behind some of the market moves, especially in the currency market, analysts say the markets as a whole may be at a crossroads.
"My feeling, at the very least, is that the stock market is peaking before our eyes," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist for Oppenheimer & Company.
Next week, when more economic reports are due, will carry either more news of economic strength, which will reduce the chances of a Federal Reserve cut in interest rates and could hurt stocks and bonds, or news of more economic weakness, which could also hurt stocks and bonds.
"There is no good news from here on out," Mr. Metz said.
Only a few weeks ago, stocks and bonds marched upward in an almost unbroken advance. The dollar was steady against the mark and Japanese yen, encouraging foreign investors to buy dollar-denominated assets.
Now, some analysts say the economy is slowing too much and possibly hurting corporate profits. More and more traders are heading into next week primed to sell off stocks.
In addition, said Byron Wien, United States investment strategist for Morgan Stanley, "this correction was overdue because the market has gone too far too fast."
The immediate catalysts for yesterday's turbulent markets was a Labor Department report that the four-week average for initial jobless claims had reached its highest level in more than two and a half years. Also, the National Association of Realtors said that sales of existing homes in April dropped to their lowest levels in nearly three years.
These figures, which were far weaker than Wall Street analysts expected, followed Wednesday's report that durable goods orders had fallen more than expected.
Up to this point, the currency markets had largely ignored doubts about a soft landing for the economy. "The foreign exchange market had got sucked into believing that a bottom to the dollar had formed," said David De Rosa, a director of foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation.
Kevin Lawrie, manager of foreign exchange for the Mellon Bank, said, "To pay attention, we really had to be hit over the head with a hammer like the numbers in the durable goods orders and today's numbers."
Moreover, rumors about Mexico and Japan affected the currency markets. "When we walked in this morning, we immediately started hearing rumors about Mexico defaulting on its debt and a middle-tier Mexican bank that was on the skids," said Ramon Bauza, a vice president for foreign exchange for the Bank of Boston. Both rumors proved groundless.
Also, there were rumors that Japan was somehow going to retaliate against the United States in the continuing trade tensions between the two countries and that a German company was selling millions of dollars after an American acquisition had gone sour.
The rumors were especially effective because important European markets, including those of Frankfurt and Paris, were closed for Ascension Thursday. With fewer traders, there was less likelihood of someone buying dollars and thus supporting the price.
In New York, the dollar fell to 1.3969 marks from 1.4385 and to 84.71 yen from 87.18.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.05 point, to 283.93, with advancing stocks lagging declining stocks by 1,048 to 1,149. The American Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.14 point to 491.63.
Among advancing stocks was Legent, a software developer, which rose 13, to 44 1/4, after Computer Associates agreed to acquire Legent for nearly $2 billion. Computer Associates rose 5 7/8, to 71 1/2.
Stocks sensitive to economic downturns dropped as a group. For example, 11 of 12 paper and forest products stocks in the S.& P. 500 fell, led by Louisiana-Pacific, which dropped 4, to 22 3/4. The company said it might be indicted for violations of environmental regulations.
Among declining stocks was System Software, another software developer, which dropped 3515/16 , to 257/16 . Ideon Group, a credit card registration company formerly called Safecard Services, dropped 1 7/8, to 13 3/4. All of the price drop occurred before it announced, after a halt in trading, that it would report lower-than-expected earnings.
The most active stock, at 17.9 million shares, was Novell, a software developer, which dropped 2, to 20 5/8, after the company said sales of a major product, Netware, had fallen.

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1130 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Reporter's Notebook;
The Lonely Americans, Isolated in a Trade War

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: PARIS, May 25

 BODY:
It's not a nice feeling to be alone. And if you were an American trade official in Paris this week, you may have felt remarkably isolated.
The reason was simple. Fellow members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the economic research and policy forum here of 25 of the world's rich nations, do not like the big stick Washington is swinging around as it threatens Japan with trade sanctions -- 100 percent punitive tariffs on 13 luxury-car models -- unless the Japanese open their auto markets. 
 Europeans, conditioned by two world wars fought on their territory, do not like direct confrontation or brinksmanship and are trying to work out a system in which consensus -- or multilateralism, in world trade argot -- solves problems.
They also say that the Americans do not have the force of law on their side, arguing that automotive tariffs are covered by the recently approved world trade accord. And beyond the letter of the agreement, they say, its spirit should discourage one nation from taking action on its own against another.
For their part, the Japanese are tired of American ultimatums on trade issues and do not feel like yielding again.
So the in-your-face American style -- the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, calls himself a "bureaucratic thug" -- does not go over well here -- indeed, it is almost certain to alienate.
The United States position is that the world trade accord does not cover auto distribution and parts purchasing systems, and that anything not covered by the world agreement allows each nation to pursue its interests, according to its own laws.
Thus, as Americans and Japanese tried over the last couple of days to elicit support from their O.E.C.D. colleagues for their respective positions on opening Japan's markets, Clinton Administration officials did not seem to understand why they were being told privately, "Good luck, we wish you well," as Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown said, and then hearing that the same people were criticizing them to other audiences.
That was particularly true between Mr. Kantor and the European Union's trade commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan. Sir Leon became the chief antagonist of the Americans, holding friendly, public chats with Japanese officials while bitterly criticizing Mr. Kantor's threatened sanctions. Many here feared that the auto dispute would now dominate the meeting in Halifax, Nova Scotia, starting June 15, of heads of government of the Group of Seven industrial nations.
Staff members here repeatedly complained this week that the Japanese-American trade battle had overshadowed the intended substance of the meeting. And that was indeed the case as several major initiatives and studies seemed to vanish into the ether.
One was a report on the effects of growing third world economies on the West. Some people have expressed fear that if emerging markets like those in Chile, Argentina and India modernize too much, they will become a serious competitive threat to established Western economies, draining manufacturing and high-tech jobs. This is certainly the case already with South Korea, Taiwan and Singapore.
But the O.E.C.D.'s report found that the benefits far outweigh the negatives because of the enormous consumer buying power that will be unleashed for Western goods and services over the next 15 years.
Look at the combined markets of China, India and Indonesia, three nations with a combined population of 2.25 billion and a combined middle class now of 100 million. The middle class is always at the core of broad economic growth. Given current growth rates, that 100 million will become 700 million by 2010, creating an enormous market for the West.
So what to do? The O.E.C.D. says its members should promote continued economic liberalization in these countries and encourage them to become more and more linked to the international marketplace.
Some of the talk here this week seemed, on the surface, remarkably esoteric -- but important nonetheless. The O.E.C.D. recognizes that while total world trade -- imports and exports -- is significant, the amount of business done by companies that set up plants in other countries -- direct foreign investment -- is more important. Such direct investment in the 1980's increased at a 30 percent annual rate, more than three times the growth rate of world exports and four times as great as overall world economic growth.
Primarily because of agreements like the recent world trade pact and regional trade accords like the North American Free Trade Agreement, trade rules are being standardized and barriers are coming down.
But there are no standards on direct foreign investment that make it easy for one company to set up a plant in another country. Standardize the procedures, get governments to agree on transparent methods of investment, and companies will set up more overseas plants.
The O.E.C.D. has begun a study on a standard direct investment regimen. Sir Leon -- who evidently enjoyed the publicity he got this week -- is insisting that this has to go beyond the exclusive club of the O.E.C.D. and include many of the developing countries.
Thus, it was agreed here that the World Trade Organization, the successor of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, with 124 members, will work on a parallel study in hopes that there will be little difference, in terms of Government red tape, between setting up, say, a glassmaking plant in Mannheim, Germany, and one in Santiago, Chile.
Also lost in the auto battle was a remarkably strong signal sent by Mr. Kantor to the Europeans on Monday, when he spoke to the American Chamber of Commerce in Brussels.
Talk has circulated in Europe for months about starting negotiations on a North Atlantic Free Trade Agreement. The Europeans provide the United States' largest trading region outside North America. There is neither a big deficit nor a big surplus between the two powers, and Europe is the only area of the world where wages are higher than those in the United States.
The Clinton Administration has been slow to focus on this matter, paying primary attention to free-trade initiatives with South American and Pacific Basin countries.
But Mr. Kantor sent the first official signal that the President likes the idea and that the United States sees a free-trade relationship with Europe as essential glue in holding the allies together, with the threat of Communism gone.
The Japanese left the talks on Wednesday relieved at the support they had gotten from the Europeans. But they were not quite celebrating. Although the Americans had been reproved for threatening sanctions, the Europeans had made it clear that Japan needed to do more to open its markets.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

Philip Morris Recalls 8 Billion Cigarettes
Philip Morris is recalling more than eight billion cigarettes, including its Marlboro, Virginia Slims and Benson & Hedges brands, because of a defect in their filters that could cause "temporary discomfort" from an irritant that is similar to a commercial pesticide.
 Since there is no way to identify the defective cigarettes by their boxes or cartons, the company asked all smokers of 36 of its cigarette brands to return them to retailers immediately. [Page 6.]
 
Fed Open Market Committee Was Unanimous on Steady Rates
The Fed was unanimous in deciding to hold interest rates steady at the March 28 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, minutes showed. But panel members expressed some willingness to raise the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans if needed to combat any signs of accelerating inflation. [38.]
 
BBA Group Bids for Paper Maker
BBA Group of Britain offered 443 million Swiss francs, or $390 million, for the Swiss paper maker Holvis Holzstoff, topping a hostile bid of 387 million francs from International Paper. BBA's friendly bid followed the withdrawal Tuesday of a takeover offer by Intertech Group. Both BBA and International Paper particularly want Holvis's nonwoven product used in making diapers, medical gowns and similar products. [36.]
 
Conseco Drops Bid for Bankers
Conseco withdrew its offer to acquire all the publicly traded shares of Bankers Life for $22 a share. Conseco's board had approved buying up to 10 million shares on the open market, where the cost could be lower. The company owns 63.2 percent of Bankers' 52.8 million shares. [39.]
 
Dollar Tumbles on Economic Fear
The dollar tumbled against the Japanese yen and the German mark on fear the American economy was slowing too much. [34.]
 
Oil prices fell 57 cents, to $18.69 a gallon, after a report indicated that a Brazilian oil workers' strike would soon end. [34.]
 
Treasury securities were mixed, weighed down by the falling dollar. Traders moved to cash ahead of the holiday weekend. [38.]
 
Awards for Business Ethics Planned
The Clinton Administration will offer annual awards to companies judged to be complying the best with a voluntary code of ethical practices it issued earlier this year for American corporations doing business overseas. The Model Business Principles urge employers to provide a safe and healthy workplace, avoid discrimination, avoid using child or forced labor and promote free expression. [36.]
 
Nissan Posts a Huge Loss
Nissan reported a group net loss of 166.1 billion yen, or $1.86 billion, almost double its loss of a year earlier. Mazda posted a net loss, for the Japanese parent company only, of 35.8 billion yen, or $400.6 million, but Mitsubishi's net income doubled because of its strong position in Japan's expanding recreational vehicle market. Other Japanese auto makers have also reported gains. [36.]
 
Detroit Considers Downtown Casino
In an effort to revitalize its downtown, Detroit is considering creating an Indian reservation in the heart of the city solely to establish casino gambling there. If approved, it would be the first casino run by Indians anywhere away from their main lands. [6.]
 
Electric Car Sets Distance Record
A four-passenger electric car has set a record for the distance traveled by a battery-powered vehicle without recharging: 238 miles in mixed city-highway driving. The car, the Sunrise, built by Solectria, set the record in the course of the American Tour de Sol, an annual five-day road rally for electric vehicles. [38.]

HEADLINE: Samuel Tamposi, 70, Real Estate Developer, Dies

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Samuel A. Tamposi, who rose from modest beginnings as a farmer and vacuum cleaner salesman to become New Hampshire's largest commercial real estate developer, died at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston on Thursday. He was 70 and lived in Nashua, N.H., and Hernando, Fla.
 The cause of death was lymphoma, said his son, Samuel A. Tamposi Jr. 
 The son of Romanian immigrants, Mr. Tamposi was born in Nashua and raised on the family farm.
 After graduating from high school, he began his career selling Electrolux vacuum cleaners door to door. After several years as a salesman, he began buying up vacant Nashua mill buildings, factories and farmland, including some parcels that sold for as little as $7 an acre.
 Those purchases were the foundation of a real estate empire that at his death stretched from New Hampshire to Florida.
 "He was a man who grew up very poor and had a great love of the land," said former Senator Warren B. Rudman, one of many New Hampshire Republicans to whom Mr. Tamposi contributed during his lifetime. "He loved to build things, things that would be of value."
 Mr. Tamposi made his fortune buying and selling land and persuading Fortune 500 companies like Anheuser-Busch, Digital Equipment and Raytheon to build plants in New Hampshire.
 Mr. Rudman said yesterday that Mr. Tamposi "brought more jobs to New Hampshire than all of the economic authorities in all of the state's cities and townships put together."
 Mr. Tamposi's other great interest was baseball. He was a limited partner in the Boston Red Sox, rarely missing a home game and occasionally traveling with the team.
 In the late 1960's Mr. Tamposi enlisted the help of Ted Williams, the Red Sox star, in the development of Citrus Hills in Florida, a 15,000-acre tract about 75 miles north of Tampa.
 The project was little more than watermelon fields and thick forest when Mr. Tamposi and a partner acquired it in 1968, but now it has two golf courses designed by Arnold Palmer and more than 2,500 houses.
 In addition to Mr. Rudman, the list of Republicans Mr. Tamposi backed includes former President George Bush and John H. Sununu, who was New Hampshire's Governor before joining the Bush Administration in 1989 as White House chief of staff.
 During the Bush Administration, Mr. Tamposi's daughter, Elizabeth M. Tamposi, was head of the State Department's Bureau of Consular Affairs, which issues passports and visas. During the 1992 Presidential campaign, Ms. Tamposi supervised a search of the passport records of Bill Clinton, an action that generated considerable controversy and led to her dismissal.
 In addition to his children Elizabeth and Samuel, who live in Nashua, Mr. Tamposi is survived by his wife, the former Eileen Maloney; four other children, Michael A., of Nashua, Nicholas E., of West Palm Beach, Fla., Celina Tamposi Griffin of Bedford, N.H., and Stephen A., of Hernando, Fla.; three stepchildren and 19 grandchildren.
 The stepchildren are Richard M. Doyle, Jr. of Boston; Charles R. Doyle of San Francisco and Katharine S. Doyle of Nashua.
 Mr. Tamposi's first marriage, to the former Barbara St. Pierre of Nashua and Palm Beach, Fla., ended in divorce in 1986.

HEADLINE: 10-Minute Clock Keeps Shots Low At G.M. Meeting

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., May 26

 BODY:
When the chairman of the General Motors Corporation muzzled a nun, any shareholder's hopes that G.M. might bend its new rules to limit their speaking time at its annual meeting here surely began to melt away.
 When he did it again, all hopes must have vanished. 
 "Again, Sister, your minute is up," said the chairman, John G. Smale, in his weary, growling baritone.
 Like basketball shot clocks, two digital signs, in glaring red, ticked off the seconds racked up by each outspoken shareholder. Each was held to a total of 10 minutes, in 1- or 3-minute increments.
 Those who overshot found themselves squawking into a dead microphone, as Mr. Smale briskly summoned the next speaker. Control of the mikes gave Mr. Smale a clear victory today in what became a grudge match against a tag team comprising the three most belligerent, loquacious shareholders.
 "I'm not done!" hollered one of the trio, George Sitka of Bristol, Conn., as his 10 minutes elapsed.
 "Well," said Mr. Smale, in a grim tone worthy of Dirty Harry, "yes, you are."
 Closely watched by other companies, G.M. is trying to discipline its historically raucous shareholder meetings, an often flammable blend of business forum, town meeting and cage-match wrestling. In addition to limiting speaking and keeping the entire meeting to two and a half hours, G.M. offered no plant tour to shareholders as it has in the past, and did not even display its vehicles in the Holiday Inn ballroom here. G.M.'s meetings are generally held each year in different cities where the company has assembly plants; the company, the nation's No. 1 auto maker, has a plant in Wilmington.
 "We're moving in the right direction," Harry J. Pearce, an executive vice president, said after the meeting, G.M.'s 87th. "This is a very important part of what corporate governance ought to be in the future."
 Mr. Pearce said G.M. spent only $150,000 on the meeting this year, compared with $1.2 million in 1994. But turnout this year, at 137 people, was the lowest since at least 1948.
 Despite the lower attendance, Mr. Pearce insisted that the new forum allowed G.M. to hear from more shareholders. "We can't allow two or three people to dominate the meeting," he said. He said G.M. hoped to emphasize less formal regional meetings with investors. It intends to hold 12 such meetings this year; some 6,000 shareholders have attended 26 regional meetings since 1993.
 At the meeting, executives were peppered with queries on such matters as how G.M. was protecting shareholders from the Ebola virus, and whether Dr. Jack Kevorkian was damaging the image of the industry by helping people kill themselves in a van. (Mr. Smale said he thought the van was a Chrysler product, although it is actually a Volkswagen.) One gentleman requested a seat on the board; Mr. Sitka requested the resignations of Mr. Smale and John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s president and chief executive, as he had last year.
 Nevertheless, a few interesting details emerged.
In a speech to shareholders, Mr. Smith said G.M. made a contribution of $1.5 billion to its United States pension fund last week, bringing the total of contributions since the beginning of 1994 to $17.2 billion. Based purely on those contributions, G.M.'s unfinanced pension liability would be as low as $3 billion, but lower interest rates and higher pension costs have raised it above that level.
 After the meeting, Mr. Smith also said that G.M. had for the first time reduced its forecast for sales in 1995 to 15.3 million cars and light and heavy trucks, down from 15.6 million. Ford and Chrysler had already cut their much more optimistic estimates several times to reach similar levels.
 And in response to shareholders' questions, executives said G.M. spent $220.6 million on recalls during 1994, and $300 million on fees for outside legal counsel.
 In addition, a group of nuns engaged Mr. Smith and Mr. Smale in a serious discussion of G.M.'s military sales abroad, and whether the company was paying its Mexican workers enough. Mr. Smith said G.M. had raised wages in Mexico by 15 to 30 percent since the devalutation of the peso in December. But the Mexican and United States Governments were discouraging increases, he said, because they could be inflationary in Mexico.
 A more typical, and less illuminating, exchange ensued when Evelyn Y. Davis, a notorious gadfly, asked how much Heidi Kunz, G.M.'s treasurer, and other female executives spent on first-class travel. (Earlier, Mrs. Davis said she was concerned that G.M. was promoting too many women, although only 4 of its 64 officers are women. "What chance does a man have for promotions at General Motors?" she asked, to widespread chortles.)
 Mr. Pearce said G.M. reimbursed executives only for coach fare. But Mrs. Davis's question about Ms. Kunz prompted another shareholder, Joan Cockerton of Michigan, to approach the mike.
 First, Mrs. Cockerton apologized for removing her shoes, saying that her feet hurt. Then she asked, "Who is Heidi Fleiss?"
 Mr. Smale gently explained that she was mixing up names. Mrs. Cockerton then said she was glad to discover that Mr. Smale was not a stuffed shirt.
 "It's hard to be a stuffed shirt in this situation," Mr. Smale said.
 The new rules did not delight all shareholders. Sister Barbara Glendon, an Ursuline nun from New York, told Mr. Smale that she understood there was a "creative tension" between allowing shareholders a voice and running an efficient meeting.
 But "if we have to be a little off-balance on one of them," she said, G.M. should err on the side of letting people speak. "It could be done in a better way," she said.

HEADLINE: An Indian Reservation? Right in Detroit?

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 21

 BODY:
Detroit has tried for decades to revitalize its moribund downtown, but never before with so novel an approach as a proposal now on Gov. John Engler's desk: to create an Indian reservation in the heart of the city solely to establish casino gambling there.
Michigan law prohibits casino gambling, but Federal law provides an exemption: states that permit any form of organized gambling, like Michigan's lottery, must permit gaming operations run by Indians on sovereign Indian lands, as opposed to private or commercial land owned by Indians. If approved, Federal officials say, the casino here will be the first casino gambling enterprise run by Indians anywhere away from their main lands. 
 Detroiters, frustrated by decades of decay, unemployment and a dwindling tax base but leery of gambling's harmful trappings, have mixed feelings. The voters rejected gambling initiatives four times. But after casinos opened last year in nearby Windsor, Ontario, and began drawing 25,000 people a day across the Detroit River, the voters had a change of heart.
By a two-thirds majority in a referendum last August, they approved a proposal, which had the backing of Mayor Dennis Archer and the City Council, to transfer land in the Greektown area downtown to a Chippewa tribe for the purpose of establishing an Indian-run casino there. The voters also approved a riverboat casino, but state law would have to be changed before that could be allowed.
The Rev. Jim Holley, pastor of the Little Rock Missionary Baptist Church near downtown, who opposed the ballot initiatives, said pragmatism had won out over principle.
"When you've got a million dollars a day going over to Windsor, which is a few blocks of water away," Mr. Holley said, "the people saw it as something that was already here, but the city wasn't benefiting from it." Mr. Holley served on an 11-member commission, appointed by Governor Engler, that concluded that Indian-run casinos would benefit the city. "They figured that they already had gamblers in Detroit," he said. "They just didn't have gambling in Detroit."
The willingness to risk for economic good the social ills that critics warn accompany gambling districts is a measure of the desperation many people feel about the longtime plight of Detroit's derelict city center. The city's unemployment rate is 15 percent, and an estimated third of its population of one million live at or below the poverty level. The Greektown proposal promises 4,400 jobs reserved for Detroiters, $25 million a year to city coffers and additional millions for economic development projects.
The exodus of department stores and business offices from Detroit began with the marriage of cars to new freeways in the 1950's and accelerated after the riots of the 1960's. Each decade since has had its own ambitious plan to bring people and prosperity back, none of them successful.
In the 1970's, it was Henry Ford 2d's Renaissance Center, the soaring, cylindrical twin hotel and office towers. But the "Ren-Cen" keeps its visitors indoors, and nearly two decades later the nighttime streets around it are as empty as before.
In the 1980's, it was the People Mover, several miles of elevated tramway subsidized by Washington to encourage visitors to tour downtown. But by then there were few places worth visiting, and riders gazing at eye level into the empty upper floors of the relics of pre-World War II Detroit commerce were left with the impression that this was a city that had moved out of town.
Now gambling is being heralded as the catalyst for renewal. So far, three competing groups, including the one whose specific plans were approved at referendum last August, are vying for the right to deed various parcels of downtown land to the Chippewa for a casino.
While the investors would not own, operate or directly profit from a casino, they would expect to reap the spinoff profits from the casino crowds and the hotels, restaurants and shops on adjacent land they owned. And, despite awareness that casinos in Atlantic City have not delivered broad prosperity, voters here are evidently counting on the promoters' scenario to reverse decades of decay and provide much-needed jobs.
John Kelly, a lawyer and former Democratic State Senator who opposed gambling when he was in the Legislature but is now working with one of the investor groups, said the presence of Canadian casinos across the river had been persuasive to him and many other Detroiters. Since gambling is, in effect, already here, the rationale goes, Detroit ought to reap some profit from it rather than watch its people -- and their money -- cross the border.
Still, the odor that surrounds gambling dictates that political leaders speak reluctantly of the proposal as a last resort, though even among opponents the betting is that Governor Engler, a Republican, will not stop the project when he makes his decision, perhaps by the end of June, on whether to accept in trust for the Chippewa 135,000 square feet of Greektown land offered by two developers for a casino. He is also weighing other proposals, though it is expected he would not sanction them without another referendum.
"The Governor is not necessarily enamored of gambling and doesn't consider this a panacea for Detroit's problems," said John Truscott, Mr. Engler's spokesman. "But he is certainly willing to consider it as an option."
Detroit draws substantial financial aid from the state, and so improving the city's economy, Mr. Kelly said, could make Mr. Engler's budget-balancing much easier.
So far, the two developers from the near east side's Greektown area, Jim Pappas and Ted Gatzeros, appear furthest along in their plans, with the Sault Ste. Marie tribe of Chippewa as partners. It was this proposal that the voters approved last August, and it has the blessing of the United States Department of the Interior, whose agreement, along with that of a state governor, is required before land can be placed in trust for an Indian tribe. The two developers have already transformed several old warehouses in Greektown into a lively nightspot, with a hotel, several restaurants and a small design center.
Another group -- known as the Foxtown group, for a development in the old theater district farther from the river -- is working on a proposal to offer other Michigan Indians land in Foxtown. They are following the lead of Mike Ilitch, the owner of the Detroit Tigers baseball team and the Detroit Red Wings hockey team. He has invested millions to refurbish the Fox Theater as the headquarters of his Little Caesar's Pizza empire and wants to have a new stadium for his baseball team built nearby.
The leagues in which Mr. Ilitch's professional sports enterprises compete forbid owners to be associated with a casino project. But his investment in the area would leave him in a position to profit from the spinoff traffic.
The third initiative is that of Mr. Kelly and his partners, who want to transform the former Hudson's Department Store building into a two-million-square-foot multilevel wedding cake of gambling, shopping, dining and a hotel.
"This is what the city needs," said Jim Butsikaris, owner of the Lindell Athletic Club, a sports bar that lies between Hudson's and Foxtown. "If we don't get people down here in the evening, we won't survive."
A spokesman for the Chippewa, John Hatch, described Detroit as one of the biggest untapped gaming markets in North America. "And," he said, "it is the only urban market that has passed a referendum on casino gaming."
But dissenters remain wary.
"In Detroit, we always get it backwards," said Fred Rashid, an English professor at Marygrove College and the president of a group, Fans of Tiger Stadium, that is trying to block Mr. Ilitch from moving his baseball team. "We always think that the big project is the one thing that's going to do the job. We have paid dearly for the absence of careful planning."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In past decades, Detroit tried an elevated tramway and the Renaissance Center, the cylindrical structure in the distance, as projects that would lead the way out of decay. Neither succeeded. Now a gambling casino is envisioned, on an Indian reservation that would be created in the heart of downtown. (Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
It was unlike any other event associated with the White House Conference on Trade and Investment in Ireland: A diminutive, rosy-faced Irish Archbishop and a bearded Presbyterian official joined in a conversation that veered wildly from the nuts and bolts of fair employment practices and investment opportunities to abstruse talk of "ontological individualism" and Trinitarian theology.
But in a world where religion so often opens wounds, one can hardly overlook religious leaders striving to close them. 
 "If we could find solutions" in Northern Ireland, said Cahal Cardinal Daly, Archbishop of Armagh, Primate of the Roman Catholic Church for all of Ireland, "it would have important lessons, I think, for the rest of Europe." He was addressing a news briefing on Wednesday with the Rev. John Dunlop, a former moderator of the Presbyterian Church in Ireland, at the National Press Club in Washington.
In January 1994, Cardinal Daly and Dr. Dunlop issued a joint call for strong fair employment measures and more investment in Northern Ireland. In some ways the joint call foreshadowed the Washington conference. Also signed by Irish Methodist and Anglican leaders, the joint call linked peace with economics and brought together leaders from contending factions.
More importantly, the call yoked what had been viewed as rival approaches. Catholics and nationalists had focused on job discrimination while Protestants and unionists had treated investment as the issue.
Both Cardinal Daly and Dr. Dunlop have faced opposition within their own churches. In an interview after the briefing, the Cardinal recalled how his denunciations of nationalist violence had provoked "a great deal of what you call hate mail," especially from those "who regarded me a betraying my own people.
"That's the interesting phrase -- 'my own people' -- and they are not my people," he said. The letter writers "just couldn't understand why I would be concerned about the rights of Protestants," he said.
Religious leaders have "to preach the Gospel in season or out of season, welcome or unwelcome," Cardinal Daly said, although "that can pose real pastoral problems."
Dr. Dunlop interjected: "It's sometimes described as a tension between the prophetic element of preaching and the pastoral element. You musn't lose contact with your base, but you musn't lose your integrity to maintain contact with your base. Neat trick."
Yet Cardinal Daly and Dr. Dunlop finally spoke less of bold preaching than of sensitive listening as the key to peacemaking. Each of the two communities in Northern Ireland, they explained, had distinct identities -- Protestant and unionist, Catholic and nationalist -- shaped by different stories.
"They are stories about suffering and about pain," Dr. Dunlop said at the news briefing. "And of course if you can establish the fact that your community alone is the only community that suffers, then you occupy the moral high ground, and there is an enormous amount of political capital that comes from that occupation.
"But whenever the Cardinal and I talk to one another, and whenever our two communities start to tell one another's stories, we begin to understand that the pain is not exclusively the domain of one community."
The challenge for the churches, he said, is "to create the opportunity for these stories to be told" and to enable their people to tell their stories in a way that others can hear "because if you tell a story in order to win an argument, a counter-story will be told against you, and the conflict will intensify."
If Ireland had long harbored two communities divided by a common faith, won't the rapid secularization it is undergoing end that? "That might create more psychic space for my community," Dr. Dunlop said. "If Ireland is understood ideologically as a homogeneous Catholic nationalist state, there's not an awful lot of room in it for somebody like me."
"And yet the Catch-22 is that secularization is not good for any kind of faith," he continued. "With regard to the young people in my congregation, none of them have ever become Catholics in my time, but a great many of them have stopped practicing the Christian faith altogether.
"So if I go around in Ireland thinking that Cardinal Daly's Christian community is the main threat to my existence, then I'm looking in the wrong direction."
And what about "ontological individualism?" Dr. Dunlop borrowed the phrase from the American sociologist Robert Bellah to contrast the idea of an isolated individual prior to all social relationships with the idea of an individual "made in the image of a God who is Trinitarian, Father, Son and Holy Spirit."
The concept of a person made in the image of a God "who has existed in unity and community from the very beginning" implied "a society which is interested in relationships," he said, "not a society which is dominated by power and by coercion."
The representative of the American National Conference of Catholic Bishops, which had helped organize the briefing, looked amused at this heavy serving of theology. He promised a free lunch, he said, to any journalists getting "ontological individualism" into their lead paragraph.

HEADLINE: U.S. Provides First Details Of Its Business Ethics Code

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today disclosed its plans for encouraging American and foreign companies to respect the voluntary code of ethical practices it issued earlier this year for American corporations doing business overseas.
 The Commerce Department said it would offer annual awards to American companies judged to be complying the best with these guidelines. The first award will be made early next year and the search for the winning companies will start in September. The Commerce Department did not say what form the awards would take. 
 The Model Business Principles, as the voluntary business ethics code is called, urges employers to provide a safe and healthy workplace, avoid discrimination on race, religion or sex, avoid the use of child labor or forced labor and promote free expression.
 But it is vague about urging companies to respect a worker's right to organize and stops short of asking companies to encourage such activity.
 In addition to the Administration's statement, a San Francisco organization called Business for Social Responsibility plans to create a privately financed clearinghouse for information about other codes of business conduct. The clearinghouse will provide information and advice to companies planning to develop their own codes of conduct.
 The Administration will also work with Business for Social Responsibility to organize conferences and seminars at which business leaders will be instructed in the Clinton Administration's code and encouraged to draw up their own guidelines based on its principles.
 The Administration also plans to encourage foreign governments to draw up similar guidelines for their own companies and will seek international support for its code in such bodies as the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and the International Labor Organization in Geneva.
 The Administration will also seek support for its ethics code from the President's Export Council, a group of chief executive officers who advise the President on issues affecting foreign trade.
 In an effort to show that American business is coming to accept the new code after expressing strong reservations in the past, the Commerce Department today issued a list of the companies that it said supported the code "as a useful reference point for framing the codes of conduct of individual businesses."
 These companies include the Boeing Company, Honeywell Inc., the General Electric Company, the Westinghouse Electric Company, the Eastman Kodak Company, the Rockwell International Corporation and the Loral Corporation.
 President Clinton first promised such a voluntary code of conduct last year in an attempt to meet the complaints of human rights activists' angry over his decision to renew China's most-favored-nation trade status despite criticism of Beijing's human rights record.
 To avoid seeming to be singling out China, however, the Administration decided to make the code applicable to American companies' business dealings with all countries.
 Today human rights activists welcomed the Administration's plans as "a useful first step toward encouraging U.S.-based businesses to adopt voluntary codes of conduct governing their activities abroad."
But the statement by Amnesty International USA, the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights and the Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Center for Human Rights regretted the lack of governmental involvement in the proposed clearinghouse and said the Administration "has not taken sufficient steps to press for the protection of human rights in China."

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Tumble for A Second Day

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market extended its losses for a second consecutive session yesterday, setting off the so-called circuit-breaker rules of the New York Stock Exchange twice in one session. But leading stock indexes still managed to finish ahead for the week.
 Contributing to the drop in prices yesterday were declines in bonds and the dollar, prompting a small rush to gold, whose price is the fever chart of market anxiety. 
 Moreover, traders seem to continue believing that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates later this year. Such a cut could send the dollar plummeting further because it would pay less interest to foreign investors. "The dollar could prevent the Fed from easing," said Jay Goldinger, market strategist for Capital Insight in Beverly Hills, Calif.
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 43.23 points yesterday, to 4,369.00, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 4.94 points, to 523.65. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 5.45 points, to 871.87.
 For the week, the Dow climbed 27.67 points, while the S.& P. 500 was up 4.46 points and the Nasdaq, 7.3 points.
 Next week will be a test for the financial markets, analysts said. At least five major economic reports are due: a preliminary revision of the first-quarter gross domestic product, April new-home sales and May consumer confidence, chain-store sales and employment data.
 It was difficult to draw many conclusions from the movements of the financial markets this week. As was the case last week, when stock trading was distorted by the quarterly expiration of options, one-time factors seemed to be at work.
 Thin trading also tended to magnify price movements. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange, for example, was a light 291.2 million shares yesterday, the bulk of it before 1 P.M. The long Memorial Day weekend as well as a wildcat railroad strike in New York prompted an early exit from Wall Street. "People were just getting out of the way of a three-day weekend," said David Holt, vice president for research and strategy at Wedbush Morgan Securities in Los Angeles.
 After rising for four consecutive sessions, bond prices fell, pushing up yields and helping attract money away from stocks. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.75 percent from 6.72 percent.
 The dollar fell to 82.94 Japanese yen from 84.71 yen and to 1.3787 German marks from 1.3969 marks. Gold settled at $386.60 an ounce, up from $383.10 at the beginning of the week.
 Despite the decline in stocks, most surveys of market sentiment still show investors unusually bullish, said Todd Clark, managing director for equity trading at Rodman & Renshaw.
 Stocks may have risen too far, he said, which means there would have to be more of a correction before new money will come into the market and move prices higher. "We could still use some work on the down side," he said.
 Such concerns may have prompted the Dow to fall as much as 56.38 points by 3:30 P.M. The Dow was down more than 50 points at 11 A.M. setting off the Big Board's circuit- breaker rules, which are intended to slow high-speed computer-guided trading. The rules took effect again at 2:58 P.M.
 The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 2.35 points, to 281.58, with advancing stocks lagging behind declining stocks by 849 to 1,356. The American Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.89 point, to 490.74.
 Among the advancing stocks was Applied Innovation, a telecommunications equipment maker, which rose 4 1/4, to 38 1/4. On Thursday, Wheat First Butcher Singer recommended it as a buy.
 The American depository receipts of Kubota, the heavy-equipment maker, rose 7, to 142, after it reported higher earnings.
 Among the declining stocks was Chipcom, a computer-equipment maker, which dropped 11 7/8, to 20 1/8, after it said lower shipments of its products by I.B.M. would hurt profits. Chipcom was also the most active stock, at 10.2 million shares.
 Ideon Group, a credit-card registration company, fell 4 5/8, to 9 1/8. Ideon, which changed its name from Safecard Services on May 1, said it expected to report lower 1995 earnings.
 In Japan, stocks ended slightly higher. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 114.81 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, at 15,694.25.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Japan Inc.'s Dying Bit Players;
Rising Yen Is Wreaking Havoc on Small Factories

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 26

 BODY:
Tomohiro Koseki is one of the unsung heroes of this nation's industrial miracle. A journeyman metal worker, Mr. Koseki can craft a turbine blade or a shaft to a precision of less than the thickness of a human hair. He has also written books celebrating the Japanese metal-working artisan. But Mr. Koseki, 62, said such craftsmen were now a dying breed.
In this city's Ota Ward, where he works, many of the small metal-working factories are falling victim to hard times and the soaring yen, leaving a feeling of helplessness, "like a carp on a cutting board." His own employer has only eight workers left, down from 20 a few years ago. 
 For all the focus on how the rising yen is hurting powerful exporters like Honda and Hitachi, the impact is far worse on the small, anonymous manufacturers supplying the parts to the brand-name giants. The small factories either cut the prices of their parts to help the big companies maintain their profits or they lose business when the bigger companies relocate factories offshore.
 Yet these small factories have been instrumental in making Japan Inc. what it is -- an efficient producer of high-quality goods. And as their numbers keep on dropping, there is growing fear that Japan is losing some of its fundamental manufacturing know-how and possibly its ability to produce new products in the future.
 National and local officials, as well as the companies themselves, are devising countermeasures. The Ministry of International Trade and Industry is offering loans as well as advice to small factories.
 In Ota Ward, the local government formed a special task force to come up with ways to preserve the factories. Tadao Kamiya, a ward official, said the goal was not to keep all the factories but rather a "manufacturing minimum" -- enough to insure that know-how gets passed to the next generation. One plan is for the ward to give loans to factories to help master craftsmen train younger workers.
 The ebbing of the manufacturing culture in Japan is being played out in Ota Ward, an area in southern Tokyo that is home to more than 7,000 small, mostly metal-working factories, 80 percent of them with fewer than 10 employees. These are not the direct suppliers to the big companies, but second- or third-tier ones.
 In the last decade, more than 2,000 factories have vanished from Ota Ward, driven out of business, or at least out of Tokyo, by land prices, recession, difficulties in recruiting workers and the rise of the yen.
 In one sense, Ota Ward is to metal working in Japan what Silicon Valley is to electronics in the United States. Just as Silicon Valley has the engineers, programmers and financiers who can join to create electronic products, so Ota Ward has a network of specialized workers to supply virtually any metal part, often quickly and in lots as small as one.
 The factories can share jobs, allowing them to accept bigger and more complex orders than any one shop could handle by itself.
 "The high level of technology arises because these small factories complement one another," said Atsuhiko Takeuchi, a professor of geography at the Nippon Institute of Technology, near Tokyo. "In that regard, this is the only place where such a concentration exists."
 Kuwashi Otomo, who owns a small grinding shop in Ota Ward, cited an instance of such industrial networking -- a complex valve that is part of a machine used to make computer chips in South Korea. Eight companies in Mr. Otomo's neighborhood teamed up to make the valve, with one doing the specialized welding, another the screw, and so on.
 Mr. Otomo said the valve could not yet be made in South Korea or other Asian nations with lower wages. The same is true, experts said, of many high-precision parts used in aviation, electric power generation and electronics equipment.
 But run-of-the-mill parts, like pins and screws, can be made offshore, and such work is leaving Japan. Mitsuhiro Seki, a professor at Senshu University, said that Japan was losing its "full set" industrial structure, in which it made virtually all components by itself, and would be more fully integrated with the economies of other Asian nations.
 American parts suppliers could also benefit as the big Japanese companies move more of their manufacturing -- of cars, machine tools and electronics -- to the United States.
 The Ricoh Company, the office equipment maker, is now importing 10 percent of its parts, from China and elsewhere, up from 2 percent a few years ago, although the heart of a copier machine, a specially coated aluminum cylinder, can still be made only in Japan. The company has urged its 350 local suppliers, one- tenth of whom are in Ota Ward, to adopt more sophisticated technology or face losing business.
 Takahide Kaneko, general manager of Ricoh's purchasing division, noted that salaries in China are one-tenth or one-fifteenth of those in Japan. Senior craftsmen in Ota Ward can make more than 5 million yen a year. In the last four months, the dollar equivalent of that has risen to $60,000 from $50,000.
 The pressures on small companies are heightened because many of them borrowed heavily during Japan's speculative boom of the late 1980's to buy new computerized machine tools, which can cost $100,000 apiece.
 "At the peak I was boasting to people that debt is a barometer of your power -- it shows how creditworthy you are," said Norihide Fujita, 50, a factory owner.
 Mr. Fujita's company makes metal molds for one customer, Fujikura Ltd., which uses the molds to stamp out printed circuit boards. The boards are sold to another company making speedometers for Nissan cars.
 But in 1989 Fujikura moved part of its operations to Thailand, even studying Mr. Fujita's shop to set up its own metal mold operation there.
 Mr. Fujita's sales have dropped to 80 million yen, or about $1 million, from 140 million yen a few years ago. Since January, he said, four of his eight workers had quit. And these days Mr. Fujita can afford to pay only interest, not the principal, on his loans.
 "Actually, we want to quit but we cannot because of the debt," Mr. Fujita said. "Probably most of the factories in Ota Ward are in that situation."
 The constant pressure to cut costs has strained what is supposed to be a harmonious, long-term relationship between the big companies and their suppliers.
 Manufacturers are forcing the small companies to bid against one another, and suppliers who cannot meet demands for price reductions are losing business. Mr. Otomo, the grinding shop owner, said the big companies often unilaterally cut prices or changed the terms of an agreement.
 "They say orally that an order will continue for a year," he said. "It never continues for a year."
 Recruiting is another problem. In Ota Ward's heyday -- during Japan's high-growth years of the 1950's through the 1970's -- 15-year-old junior high school graduates known as "golden eggs" would arrive in Tokyo from the hinterlands and find work in metal shops. After they became skilled craftsmen, many would go into business for themselves.
 But nowadays, affluent and well-educated Japanese young people shun factory work. At Mr. Koseki's factory, the eight remaining employees are all more than 50 years old. Teiichi Matsuda, the factory owner, said he had given up trying to find young blood. So it is a matter of time before the factory shuts down.
 The real estate boom in the late 1980's created more problems. It forced some factories to move to outlying areas with cheaper rents. Some owners converted their factories to more lucrative apartments. (There are few zoning restrictions in Japan.) Since Ota Ward is in the middle of a big metropolis, defunct factories quickly give way to office buildings or shops. So the area has avoided the fate of Bridgeport, Conn., which turned into an urban basket case when its factories shut down.
 Masahito Ohma now manages an apartment house built on the site of the factory he closed in 1990. The factory, started by Mr. Ohma's father in 1951, made lenses and other camera parts but suffered as Japanese camera makers began buying parts from Taiwan and Southeast Asia. The company, which had 150 employees, could not meet the camera makers' demands to cut its prices 40 percent.
 "When we said we could not cut prices further, orders stopped coming," Mr. Ohma said. "At our peak we were making 5,000 lenses a month but it dropped to the 1,000 to 2,000 level. The most difficult thing in making the decision was that we felt so bad toward our workers."
 To survive, some companies are looking for products they can sell themselves, rather than continue solely as parts suppliers. Here, the networks in Ota Ward come in handy. Mr. Fujita's company and 10 others recently teamed up to develop a nozzle that when attached to a vacuum cleaner sucks the air out of plastic soft-drink bottles for recycling.
 Mr. Fujita said Ota Ward should try to advertise itself as a parts supplier to the world, not just Japan. "It's so sad to just sit here and see the town losing factories," he said. "We have to move."

HEADLINE: Fed Panel Was Unanimous For Steady Rates in March

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers were unanimous at their March 28 meeting in deciding to hold interest rates steady, according to the minutes of the session that were released today.
 But the policy makers, members of the Federal Open Market Committee, did express a willingness to raise the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans if needed to combat any signs of accelerating inflation, the minutes show. 
 "There remained a risk that higher inflation could emerge if the expansion did not moderate sufficiently," the minutes said. "On the whole, the economy appeared to retain considerable forward momentum."
 Still, the panel left the Federal funds rate unchanged, as it did at its most recent meeting, on Tuesday.
 The last time the panel voted for a rate increase was at its meeting on Jan. 31 and Feb. 1.
 The policy-making committee normally meets eight times a year. Its deliberations are held in secret, and the minutes of the meeting are released several weeks later -- after the subsequent meeting of the committee.
 The committee next meets July 5 and 6. A growing number of economists say Fed officials may be prompted to lower rates at that session because the economy could be teetering on the edge of recession.
 At the March meeting, committee members expressed concern about the decline of the dollar and whether that "would add to inflationary pressures in the economy," the minutes said.
 "In these circumstances, the members generally concluded that some increase in inflation was likely in the coming months," the minutes said.
 And though Fed officials remained concerned about the weakness of the dollar against other leading currencies, "they believed that policy should not be directed toward the achievement of a specific level for the dollar but rather toward the implementation of an effective anti-inflationary monetary policy," the minutes reported.

HEADLINE: 3 Convicted In Mob Plot To Cheat U.S. Of Gas Taxes

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 26

 BODY:
Three men, including an associate of John Gotti, were convicted today of defrauding the Government of more than $100 million in gasoline taxes in a huge scheme that provided new evidence of the growing ties between the Italian Mafia and emerging Russian organized-crime groups.
 In a five-month trial, jurors were taken into a world of tribute money paid to New York's largest Mafia families, threats of violence and arson, and a sting operation set up by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Internal Revenue Service. 
 Mob members provided protection to the black-market companies, helped control competition and handled price-fixing, witnesses testified. The Government maintained that the Gambino, Genovese, Colombo and Lucchese families split proceeds from bootleg gasoline transactions.
 In an undercover operation, F.B.I. and I.R.S. agents set up a company, Packer Petroleum in Ewing Township, to compete with the bootleg oil dealers. The undercover agents were pressured by the black-market operators to team up with the bootleg organization -- in which case they would receive $165,000 -- or go out of business, said an Assistant United States Attorney, Robert G. Stahl.
 The undercover company burned down in February 1992 in a fire of suspicious origin.
 The Government charged that phantom companies were set up for a few months at a time with forged I.R.S. registration forms, indicating that they were entitled to sell fuel without paying taxes. To hide the origin of the transactions, fuel was sold from company to company in a chain. Since the illegal companies saved 20 to 37 cents a gallon on tax, they were able to manipulate the market price and make large profits.
 The three defendants -- Gregory Federico, Anthony Morelli and Igor Roizman -- were found guilty in United States District Court here of racketeering acts and extortion, United States Attorney Faith S. Hochberg said. She said the companies avoided paying taxes on hundred of millions of gallons of gasoline and diesel fuel and laundered $48 million.
 Videotapes played in court showed Mr. Morelli speaking with John Gotti, the boss of the Gambino crime family, at the Ravenite Social Club in Little Italy.
 The Government maintained that Mr. Morelli collected tribute money from motor fuel bootleggers for the Gambino crime family. Mr. Morelli was convicted today of racketeering, extortion, money laundering, mail fraud and wire fraud.
 Mr. Federico, who owned and operated Capital Fuel Service in Cranford, N.J., was accused of supplying diesel fuel to the black-market oil companies. He was convicted of racketeering, money laundering, mail and wire fraud, tax evasion and extortion.

HEADLINE: BBA Group Bids $390 Million To Acquire Swiss Paper Maker

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: BASEL, Switzerland, May 26

 BODY:
The BBA Group P.L.C. of Britain bid 443 million Swiss francs ($390 million) today for the Swiss paper maker Holvis Holzstoff A.G., topping a hostile offer of 387 million francs from the International Paper Company.
 BBA's friendly bid followed the withdrawal Tuesday of an offer by the Intertech Group Inc. for Holvis, which has been seeking other suitors since International Paper made its offer on April 24. 
 Both International Paper and BBA are after Holvis's paper-fiber business. The product, known as nonwoven, is used in disposable diapers, surgical gowns and other medical products.
 "Babies need diapers irrespective of economic cycles," said Roberto Quarta, BBA's chief executive.
 Holvis endorsed the BBA proposal, valued at 500 francs a share, and 15 percent above the 435-franc-a-share hostile offer by International Paper, the world's largest forest-products company.
 International Paper said it would not respond until it had a chance to study BBA's offer in detail. International Paper's offer expires on Tuesday. The company has already acquired 25 percent of Holvis at 435 francs a share and has an option on 6 percent more.
 If International Paper chooses not to make a higher bid, it could exercise its option and sell BBA nearly a third of the outstanding shares at a profit of 65 francs each, or 14 million francs.
 Holvis said that shareholders who might have already tendered or sold shares to International Paper had the right under Swiss takeover law to revoke their decisions once BBA had publicized its formal offer, on Monday at the latest. The deadline to revoke tendered shares is noon the following day.
 BBA shares closed up 17.5 pence, at 235.5 pence, and Holvis shares closed up 47 francs, at 492 francs. International Paper stock closed down 25 cents, to $78.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 "It looks to be a very good acquisition for BBA," said David Buxton, an analyst at Henry Cooke, Lumsden P.L.C. in Manchester. "They will get direct commercial benefits."
 Holvis's Fiberweb unit posted an operating profit of 17.1 million francs in 1994 on revenue of 306 million francs. Muehlebach earned 13.7 million francs on 379 million francs in sales. BBA said it would merge Fiberweb with its Reemay nonwovens business, based in Nashville.
 Fiberweb's profit margins are about 6 percent, and BBA can raise those to "double digit range," Mr. Quarta said.

HEADLINE: Conseco Goes to Open Market To Acquire Bankers Life Shares

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Conseco Inc. said yesterday that it had withdrawn its offer to acquire all the publicly traded shares of the Bankers Life Holding Corporation for $22 a share but that its board had approved buying up to 10 million shares on the open market.
 Conseco, which is based in Carmel, Ind., and provides finacial services to life insurance companies, already owns 63.2 percent of the 52.8 million shares outstanding in Bankers, which sells mostly health insurance. 
 The balance of Bankers' stock, about 19.5 million shares, is publicly traded. The shares fell 87.25 cents, to $20.50, before trading was halted on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Thus, Conseco may be able to buy some of the shares more cheaply on the open market.
 Conseco shares fell 75 cents, to $44.62; trading was also halted in its shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
 James Rosensteele, the vice president of investor relations, said that buying 10 million more shares would give Conseco more than 80 percent of Bankers Life and that there were tax benefits at that ownership level.
 Stephen J. Hilbert, the chairman of Conseco, said that after meeting with the independent committee and Bankers' financial advisers it beame evident that Bankers was not going to approve the proposal to buy the rest of the stock at $22 a share.
 "Under the circumstances, it didn't make sense for us to continue our discussions," he said.
 "We continue to believe that the price we offered represented full and fair value to the public shareholders of B.L.H."
 Conseco, which has grown rapidly through acquisitions, can buy large blocks of existing life insurance policies more cheaply than it can generate internally. It also owns 42 percent of CCP Insurance Inc.
 In November, Conseco terminated a $2.96 billion takeover bid for the Kemper Corporation after a rise in interest rates increased the cost of financing the takeover attempt, and some shareholders opposed the move.
