HEADLINE: Pre-Holiday Caution Weighs on Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended mixed yesterday in a shortened session ahead of the Memorial Day holiday weekend.
 The market was weighed down for a second day by a falling dollar, which makes securities less attractive to foreign investors. Traders said the market was also vulnerable to weakness because of the normal unwinding of positions before a long weekend. Most market participants prefer to hold large amounts of cash going into long weekends. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 13/32 , to 1115/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.75 percent, from 6.72 percent on Thursday. For the week, the yield was down 17 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 Trading was light yesterday as the futures market closed at 1 P.M. and the cash market closed at 2 P.M.
 Bond prices were hurt by a report that suggested a pickup in inflation. The Labor Department said yesterday that import prices rose 1.2 percent in April, the sharpest increase since October 1990. Prices rose a revised five-tenths of 1 percent in March.
 The increase in import prices, said James Hale, fixed-income analyst with MMS International in San Francisco, is "particularly worrisome because it suggests that the weak dollar is already causing inflation in imported goods, which could feed into the U.S. economy as a whole."
 Other data released yesterday had less of an impact on the market. The University of Michigan released its consumer sentiment index, which came in as expected, at 89.8 for May, up from a preliminary reading of 88.4, according to traders who saw the report. The April index was 92.5. And the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia released a survey of regional activity that suggested a slight rise in consumer prices over the next five quarters.
 Mr. Hale of MMS International said the recent rally in Treasury securities seemed to run out of fuel yesterday as portfolio managers began taking profits.
 "This corrective, or negative, atmosphere in bonds has been encouraged by the sharp dollar declines of the past two days," he said. "Shorter-maturity Treasuries were less affected by the weak dollar, though, because the inflationary implications were offset by the prospect for central bank buying of notes and bills with the proceeds of foreign exchange intervention."
 The dollar fell 2 percent against the Japanese yen yesterday and 1 percent against the German mark.
 In the municipal market, bonds were little changed as demand from investors in tax-exempt bond funds continued to decline. Traders said many investors had been reluctant to buy bonds as yields lingered near their lowest level in more than a year. The yield on 10-year insured revenue bonds rose 2 basis points, to 5.22 percent, according to the PSA/Bloomberg municipal bond yield table, which measures yields on insured revenue bonds. That was just above the 13-month low in yields seen during the last two weeks.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Takes Another Big Fall On Worry About U.S. Economy

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against the Japanese yen and the German mark for a second day yesterday as concerns grew that a slowing United States economy could prompt the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates.
 And the weakness in the dollar widened yesterday, with the currency posting declines of more than 1.5 percent against the Swiss franc, more than 2 percent against the French franc and more than 4 percent against the Dutch guilder. 
 "The dollar's looking pretty sick," said Andrew Hodge, vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert in New York. The fall was prompted by "increasing thoughts of a weak U.S. economy, plus Europeans getting nervous about the possibility of Fed interest-rate cuts," he said.
 The dollar fell as low as 82.45 yen, its lowest since April 26, before settling in New York trading at 82.94 yen, down from 84.71 yen on Thursday. The dollar fell to 1.3787 marks from 1.3969 marks. The dollar also fell to 4.8553 French francs from 4.9664 francs; to 1.1359 Swiss francs from 1.1557 francs, and to 1.5404 Dutch guilders from 1.6095 guilders.
 The decline in the dollar began after a report on Thursday showed a bigger-than-expected decline in orders for durable goods, suggesting that the economy might be weakening to a point where the Fed would have to cut short-term interest rates. Lower rates often hurt the dollar by making deposits denominated in it less attractive.
 Still, the dollar had rallied in recent weeks, with currency dealers encouraged by efforts in Congress to cut the budget deficit and the Clinton Administration's confrontation with Japan over automotive trade. But the rapid reversal of the dollar in the last two days has soured currency dealers.
 "We've completely wiped out any good will toward the dollar that might have built up with the rally," said Michael Faust, international portfolio manager at Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser in San Mateo, Calif.
 Support for the dollar has also been eroded by changing views of the Clinton Administration plan to impose punitive tariffs on imports of Japanese luxury cars.
 Traders had viewed the sanctions as good for the dollar on the ground that the United States would not have to rely on a weak dollar to pry open Japanese auto and auto parts markets.
 But strong European criticism of the United States decision has cast doubt on the effectiveness of the strategy, dealers and analysts said.

HEADLINE: Albany's Painful Budget Accord

 BODY:
It is not a pretty sight to watch Gov. George Pataki and New York State's Legislature stumble toward the finish line in their budget negotiations. Nearly two months late, they have reached agreement on the most punishing cuts in years in programs serving the poor, the sick, the elderly, the mentally disabled and the young. They have also resorted to fiscal gimmicks that are certain to create new budget problems next year. The best that can be said is that Republicans and Democrats have faced up to the difficult job of crawling out of a financial hole while mitigating some of the worst cutbacks demanded by Mr. Pataki.
The Governor's first budget was destined to be extremely tough. The state's economic decline has eroded the tax base, the cost of Medicaid is growing faster than anyone can find resources to pay for it, and the two parties stuffed last year's election-year budget with popular tax cuts and spending initiatives financed by revenue windfalls that did not recur. This year Mr. Pataki compounded his problem by insisting that he would deliver on his campaign pledge to enact even more tax cuts for which there was no money to pay. 
 In the end, Democrats and Republicans alike balked at the deep spending cuts Mr. Pataki wanted. They have sensibly restored money for the State University and City University to head off disturbingly steep tuition hikes and to minimize cuts in tuition assistance programs. They are allowing for a modest increase in aid to school districts, although it is too soon to tell how much will be available for New York City. They have saved home care for the elderly from elimination, and there will be no cuts in welfare benefit levels or time limits for those on welfare rolls.
But the agreed-upon cuts in mental health, child welfare and Medicaid, while less harsh than originally proposed, pose a severe threat to New York's tradition of caring for the most defenseless parts of the population. The budget imposes deep cuts on nursing homes, hospitals and agencies that care for the mentally ill and children in troubled or violent families. The Republican mantra in all these areas is that the cuts will force providers of medical and social services to curb waste and mismanagement. But the scale of the cuts looks as if it exceeds any waste. The state must be prepared to reverse course if serious suffering results.
Mr. Pataki has made good on his pledge to stop the growth of government spending in New York. But his achievement would have been more impressive if the budget had brought genuine structural balance to the state's finances. Instead, the ill-considered tax cut that is about to be passed will open up another budget hole growing to at least $3.6 billion in three years. In addition, this year's budget contains $1 billion in one-shot revenues that will disappear next year, deepening future deficits still further. It almost seems as if the Republicans want a deficit next year so they can propose still more welfare cuts before the elections, when the Democrats may have more trouble resisting them.
With the near-completion of the state budget, the painful fiscal drama for residents of New York City switches to Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and the City Council. The state budget leaves the city with the need to cut perhaps a half-billion dollars in spending beyond those reductions already announced. That will reduce services to the middle class and poor alike as the city struggles to emerge from its worst fiscal crisis in a generation.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Research Repays Time and Costs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Scientists at the Los Alamos National Laboratory recently announced the development of a superconducting tape capable of conducting a million amperes per square centimeter and yet supple enough to be wound into electrical cable. 
 What was lost in the excitement was the long, deliberate path that led to this moment and the long-term investment, or patient money, that supported it along the way -- from private industry, universities and the Federal Government, the three pillars that have traditionally supported basic research.
Today the Federal Government is looking to cut its science and technology budget (front page, May 22), and universities are facing declining research support. At the same time, American industry is cutting costs, with research and development shifting from fundamental science to applied engineering. Competition, Wall Street, survival -- the reasons are economic.
It was long, patient research that brought us the transistor, the silicon chip, wonder drugs and an electrical supply system we take for granted. Superconductive materials have been with us for more than 80 years, but it was only 10 years ago that we finally saw the potential of "high-temperature" superconductivity.
There is no sure way to know which of the many sciences now under investigation will raise the quality of life and help solve the environmental, economic and health concerns of tomorrow. Unfortunately, as both the public and private sectors, out of immediate financial pressure, turn inward, we eliminate possibilities.
It is imperative that we maintain our commitment to science and technology. One approach, which has served us well in the past and deserves more attention, is the coordinated pooling of funds and expertise among government, industry and universities. Such efficiency not only amplifies and accelerates payoffs, but also helps sustain the critical expertise needed to maintain the long-term health of this nation's economy and betterment of the human condition.
 
RICHARD E. BALZHISER
President
Electric Power Research Institute
Palo Alto, Calif., May 23, 1995

HEADLINE: Senate Committee Approves A Vast Overhaul of Welfare

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
The Senate Finance Committee approved a momentous shift in social policy today, voting to cancel the Federal guarantee of a subsistence income for poor children while giving states vast new power to design their own welfare programs without Federal standards.
By a vote of 12 to 8, the committee approved a sweeping welfare bill generally similar to one passed by the House in March. The committee chairman, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the bill's sponsor, said it would reach the Senate floor next month, and he predicted that more than 60 of the 100 senators would vote for it. 
 The White House, while criticizing many features of the bill, avoided any veto threat. Administration officials predicted that President Clinton would eventually sign a measure like the Senate bill, which would fulfill his campaign promise to "end welfare as we know it," though in ways far different from what he envisioned. Mr. Clinton never proposed ending the Federal guarantee of some minimal support for poor children, and his proposal would have spent more than would the Senate bill on programs to put welfare recipients to work.
Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said: "I am pleased that the legislation eliminates some of the extreme and punitive provisions in the bill passed by the House of Representatives. But it still has a long way to go on what should be the centerpiece of welfare reform -- helping people earn a paycheck, not a welfare check."
Today's vote followed party lines with one exception. Senator Max Baucus of Montana, a Democrat who is up for re-election next year and is considered vulnerable, voted for the bill. He said that it would be good for Montana and that he trusted state officials to take care of poor people in the absence of Federal standards.
The handling of welfare legislation illustrates how the Republican revolution that swept through the House in the first 100 days of the new Congress is moving at a more measured pace in the Senate. But the results are similar.
The Senate bill omits House provisions that would require states to deny cash assistance to unmarried teen-age mothers, most legal aliens and additional children born to families already receiving welfare. While it would not require those restrictions, however, it would allow the states to impose them.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a New York Democrat who has studied welfare policy for decades, described today's vote as "a constitutional moment" in which the committee was eliminating a safety net for dependent children that was established by the Social Security Act of 1935.
Democrats said state officials would sometimes be unable or unwilling to care for their poor. Senator Carol Moseley-Braun of Illinois said the Federal Government had a duty to make sure children "will not go homeless or hungry, die from deprivation" or sleep on top of one another like street urchins.
But Republicans rejected that argument. Senator John H. Chafee, a moderate Republican from Rhode Island, said: "When I was Governor, one of the most sensitive issues I had before me was taking proper care of children. Governors are going to be extremely conscious of taking care of children. The fears of Senator Moseley-Braun are not justified."
The Department of Health and Human Services estimated that four million children would lose welfare benefits under a provision of the bill that would bar payments to any family for more than five years. The House bill also includes a five-year limit, and so that provision appears likely to become law.
The Senate bill, like the House bill, would eliminate any requirement for states to spend their own money as a condition of getting Federal money for cash assistance to poor people. States now contribute 43 percent of the money spent on the main welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children: $10 billion of $23 billion this year.
The Senate bill would also sharply restrict Supplemental Security Income benefits for disabled children. The cutbacks in the House bill are somewhat deeper.
Under Senator Packwood's bill, each state would receive a lump sum, or block grant, equal to the amount of Federal welfare spending in the state in 1994. The block grants would total $16.8 billion a year from 1996 through 2000, without any adjustment for inflation or population growth. States would have to put at least half of their adult welfare recipients into jobs, training or education programs by 2001, and their Federal welfare money could be cut 5 percent if they failed to do so.
John W. Tapogna, a welfare analyst at the Congressional Budget Office, told the committee that only six states could meet the work requirements; he did not name them. To comply with the requirements, he said, states would need to spend 60 percent of their block grants, $10 billion of the $16.8 billion, on job training, education and child care. Mr. Tapogna said that 44 states would accept financial penalties rather than invest so much of their Federal money in job programs.
As a result, said Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, the work requirements in Mr. Packwood's bill are hollow. Deborah V. Weinstein of the Children's Defense Fund said the study by the Congressional Budget Office "shows that the work requirements are an exercise in posturing."
Mr. Packwood said he was surprised to hear that 44 states could not meet the work requirements, and he said he would re-examine this part of his bill.
Unlike the House measure, the Senate bill does not make any substantial change in food stamps or the school lunch program. But on the floor next month Republican senators may propose amendments to revamp those programs too.
Administration officials said this week that President Clinton would veto any bill that replaced food stamps with block grants. But the White House has not made such threats with respect to Aid to Families With Dependent Children.
An Administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said, "A.F.D.C. is the bone that the Clinton White House can throw to the hounds at the door, the people who want to make radical changes in the welfare state." The official said the White House had not made a major effort to preserve poor people's entitlement to welfare benefits because such an effort would have been "more trouble than it's worth" in political terms.
Senators from fast-growing states like Florida, Texas and Arizona expressed concern because Mr. Packwood's bill would freeze allocations of Federal money, with no allowance for changes in population. Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, sent a letter to Mr. Packwood saying the proposed formula for dividing up Federal money "would produce devastating results over a five-year period."
The letter was signed by 29 other senators from Sun Belt states, many Republicans among them.

HEADLINE: Clothing Company Is Common Link in 3 Killings

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
One victim was an immigrant from Soviet Armenia shot to death two and a half years ago outside a prospering suburban sewing factory. Another garment industry executive, at his job less than a year, was slain in December while waiting at a stoplight in Los Angeles's inner city. Just three weeks ago, a longtime apparel industry executive was shot to death in his car.
 The only apparent link among these three killings is Carole Little, a Los Angeles-based women's apparel company that employed the two executives and contracted for sewing from the other victim. Investigators are trying to determine whether the slayings, as well as assaults on two other Carole Little associates, are connected. 
 "It's baffling," said Fred Miller, a Los Angeles Police Department detective.
 John P. Gill, an intelligence analyst for the Long Beach Police Department, said, "Nothing has been ruled out and there is no definitive connection."
 One theory suggested to explain the spate of violence is the rise of Russian organized crime, which law-enforcement officials say is taking root in the United States as the immigrant population swells; with the influx from what was once Soviet Armenia, the Los Angeles suburb of Glendale has in less than a decade seen Armenians become almost a majority of its population. Investigators are also exploring whether the attacks are an attempt to cover up financial irregularities.
 Another possible explanation comes from tensions between big manufacturers and the tiny contract shops that sew many of their garments. The relationship has been especially strained since the Clinton Administration began an aggressive crackdown on violations of labor law in garment centers like Los Angeles.
 Facing the threat that regulators will hold up their shipments, manufacturers like Carole Little have been trying to police their sewing-shop operators for what are suspected to be widespread violations of minimum wage and overtime rules. In Los Angeles, hundreds of family-controlled contracting shops cut fabric and sew clothing, operating on razor-thin profit margins with fewer than 50 employees, many of them recent immigrants.
 In response to Labor Department pressure, Carole Little has reduced its contracting network from 90 domestic shops to 30 since 1993 and has opened an internal compliance department to check payroll records of its contractors.
 "There were some strained relations with contractors who didn't feel we had the right to audit their records," said Leonard Rabinowitz, who co-founded the company in 1974 with his wife, Carole Little, a clothing designer. "That put us in a funny spot."
 But no other apparel producers, including Levi Strauss and Rampage Clothing, which are known in the industry for vigorously weeding out illegal contractors, have had the problems with violence that Carole Little has had, police and industry executives say. Indeed, industry executives are skeptical that Carole Little's move to consolidate its business among fewer contractors would lead to such deadly reprisals.
 "No one believes that," said Maurice B. Newman, president and chief executive of the California Mart, which houses 1,500 manufacturers. "Every manufacturer is very careful to make sure their contractors abide by the law. If you don't like it, you can put your production overseas."
 For his part, "I am bewildered," said Mr. Rabinowitz of Carole Little. The company has offered a $100,000 reward for information leading to any convictions.
 In December, Kenneth Martin, a Carole Little executive responsible for domestic and foreign contractors, was shot while at a stoplight. Then on May 4, Rolando Ramirez, the company's controller, who had been at Carole Little for 17 years, was killed. He was responsible for the company's finances, including making payments to sewing contractors, fabric finishers and textile suppliers. An internal audit that had already been planned is being speeded up as part of the police inquiry.
 "Embezzlement is one hypothesis being investigated," Mr. Rabinowitz said. But so far, investigators have not found any financial irregularities and have not made a connection between Mr. Ramirez's death and his business, Mr. Rabinowitz said.
 "Any objective person would have to wonder if there wasn't a connection," said Ellen J. Aragon, a Los Angeles County deputy district attorney. She is prosecuting Karapet N. Demirdzhyan, 35, of Los Angeles, on first-degree murder charges in the November 1993 killing of Hakop Antonyan, the Carole Little sewing contractor.
 Mr. Demirdzhyan entered a not guilty plea last August. At that hearing, a Glendale police detective testified that Carole Little had made cutbacks among some of its sewing contractors and that as a result Mr. Antonyan's business had surged.
 Prosecutors did not discuss what they thought was Mr. Demirdzhyan's motive, said his lawyer, James Sussman of Pasadena. "The whole focus has changed because of the subsequent killings," he said, declining to comment further.
 Garnik Antonyan, 47, is certain there is a link between his brother's slaying and Gaha Inc., the sewing business he and his brother started in 1987. "My brother didn't have personal enemies," Mr. Antonyan said. "Whatever happened to my brother is business related. That's 100 percent certain, but why and how I don't know."
 One week after the anniversary of his brother's death, Garnik Antonyan and his wife, Diana, 45, were wounded in an attack outside Gaha. The gunman fled when Mr. Antonyan returned fire with a weapon he began carrying after his brother was killed.
 Karin Wong-Holzinger, a former Carole Little employee responsible for trimming the company's contractor network, survived two bombing attempts at her Long Beach home and a freeway shooting in Compton, Calif., in 1993. She said she had taken a leave of absence to recuperate and was dismissed while on leave; Mr. Rabinowitz says the dismissal was tied to her job performance. She contends in a wrongful-termination suit that she was attacked as a result of the company's efforts to sever ties with some sewing contractors. The company denies any wrongdoing in her dismissal.
 During the California recession, the garment industry has been one of the growth sectors in Los Angeles and now supports nearly 110,000 jobs, making it the region's No. 2 manufacturing employer, after the high-technology and aerospace industry. Carole Little, a private company that had revenue of $375 million last year, is probably the third-largest apparel maker in the region, after Bugle Boy and Guess Inc., said Jack Kyser, president of the Los Angeles Economic Development Corporation, a private association that tries to help create jobs.
 Carole Little's reputation as a maker of career clothes at affordable prices has earned it prominent floor space at its largest customers -- Dillard Department Stores, R. H. Macy and May Department Stores.
 The company has benefited from the economic beating taken by big department stores as apparel sales have fallen. In an effort to increase efficiency, retailers have curbed the number of manufacturers they buy from. Carole Little's sales were only $204 million in 1992, slightly more than half last year's level.

HEADLINE: Club Med Comes of Age

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO; JOSEPH SIANO is assistant to the editor of the Travel section.

 BODY:
CLUB MED, which once advertised that it had an antidote for civilization, is now trying to provide a cocktail mixer for it. The resort chain turned 45 this year, and is watching many of its regular customers reach their 50's and 60's, which explains why one of its newest outposts, Columbus Isle on San Salvador, doesn't seem to belong in a Club originally founded on communal dining tables and guest rooms with no door locks. Age has turned Club Med soft.
In the interest of added comfort and service, Columbus Isle -- which opened in December 1992 on the island that is believed to have been Columbus's first landfall in North America -- has all the civilized appurtenances that the Club once spurned: Its rooms are equipped with locks, safes, cable television and civilization's rudest intruder of all, a telephone with a message light. 
 But as my wife, Marsha, and I found out on a five-day visit in February, the technology turned out to be unobtrusive. The songbirds' wake-up calls sufficed; the flowers, palms and the sea beyond -- a view that filled one full wall of our room -- far outdid the cable TV.
With some of the highest rates of any Club Med village (in high season $210 a person a night, double occupancy, including all meals and most activities), Columbus Isle has to do more than provide the Club basics -- and it does, starting with a staff that one of my fellow guests described semi-incredulously as "happy and peppy and bursting with love" -- even without tips.
I could appreciate the difficulty of the task. As a long-ago veteran of two traditional Club Meds, I spent the weeks before our trip trying to prepare my wife, explaining why she would enjoy eating every meal at a table with six strangers, and staying in an unlocked room. I wasn't making much headway.
We arrived on Sunday via the Miami-Nassau-San Salvador connection (a pair of one-hour flights) on Bahamasair. Minutes after the 50-passenger turboprop had touched down on the airstrip carved out of the island's rocky terrain, a Club Med van deposited us at the lobby entrance, where the standard gantlet of smiling, clapping staff members awaited us and the 20 other guests on our flight.
I was smiling, too; then again, I hadn't yet learned that the half-mile, three-minute ride from airport to resort cost $10 a person round trip, making New York cab fares seem low.
If there were added costs along the way (as we were to find out often during our stay), there were also added courtesies. Sophie, one of the resort staff, personally walked us to our room, stopping to point out the high spots on a mural depicting the resort "village" that would be our home for the next five days. We also passed the small booth where we could get fresh beach towels the moment the ones we were using became even slightly damp.
Our room, which was on the ground floor of one of the two-story four-unit guest cottages, was at least twice as big as the accommodations at the Clubs I had visited, and was devoid of the dormitory feel I remembered. The walk-in closet had ample shelf space, and the roomy, brightly illuminated bathroom had a stall shower, makeup table and chair, hair dryer and mini-refrigerator. Furnishings included a queen-size bed, a daybed with a reading lamp, a wooden writing table and a padded chair and ottoman made out of a plastic rattan. The white ceramic-tile floors and walls gave the room a bright, spacious, airy feel. The room was spotless, though we did find a large but harmless bug in our room the last night.
On one wall was a feathered mask from an Amazon tribe; on the other, framed propeller-shaped pages from a Burmese bible. Six floor-to-ceiling wooden panels folded back to expose a large sliding glass door that led onto a small porch facing the sea, which was visible beyond a lawn studded with short palms. Outside, flowering plants surrounded walkways and climbed trellises.
Statues, carvings and folk art from around the world adorned the public spaces and rooms, as if a treasure hunter had shipwrecked here and decided to settle in and decorate. The pieces were, in fact, collected from more than 35 countries by Gisela Trigano, whose husband, Serge, is Club Med's chairman. As I walked through ornately carved wooden doorways from Indian palaces or sat beside a happily grinning buddha, I never saw any markers indicating the origin of these pieces; as a result, their impact was emotional rather than intellectual.
THE first night of our stay, our small group got the orientation talk, a combination pep rally and staff introduction that soft-pedaled the pep. When Chris, the head of the sports staff, covered the weekly picnic cruise, for example, he noted that this wasn't "like some of the other Club Med picnics you may have heard about." He assured us that there wouldn't be the traditional bathing-suit swap. Our fellow guests, most of whom were 40 and older, did not look disappointed.
Columbus Isle's tone was definitely modulated. I realized it was unlikely I would hear Chris announce over the public address system, as his counterpart at another Club did 10 years ago, that the village nurse was sunbathing topless beside the pool. Although the Club has the requisite discotheque, the late-night social scene was centered more around the Club's indoor bar and an adjacent large parlor filled with cushy sofas. A live band played selections worthy of VH-1 rather than MTV, and staff members staged small, informal skits (most of which involved cross-dressing, with mixed results).
The nightly stage shows were presented in an open-air amphitheater where the only unpleasantness was the odor of bug spray that came wafting in each evening around sunset (guests may still need their own insect repellent). The shows themselves were like most at Club Med, amicably amateurish with some professional touches. I might have been a harsher critic if the performers weren't staff members who had already worked a full day.
Besides, if you want to criticize, the Club obliges with a few targets. Like a can of Budweiser for $4.80, or sunscreen for $11. If the latter could be excused as the price for arriving unprepared, this cannot: The least costly alternative to the processed tap water, unpalatable even after being filtered and chilled, was a 1.5-liter bottle of water for $2.40. The Club includes unlimited wine and beer with meals, so why not tasty water?
We hadn't made reservations in either of the village's two specialty restaurants the first night, so we ate in the main dining room. It was buffet style, and the meats, fish, salads, cheeses and breads were fresh and varied. The high-ceilinged room was warmly lighted, and the noise never became intrusive -- perhaps because the village, which can accommodate up to 522 guests, had only about 240 that week. We had our choice of the regular eight-seat group tables or more intimate tables just for the two of us. (The specialty restaurants emphasize the latter.)
Every meal offered a few well-prepared entrees, and only once did we see any fruits or salads that had lost the blush of youth. But the low-fat selections were unimaginative -- plain poultry or fish -- and the items that usually suffer the worst in buffets (grilled meat and fish) fared no better here.
On our third night, we tried the Italian restaurant, Dona Isabel. Large bouquets of rice-paper flowers, found throughout the village, added touches of color to the softly lighted second-floor room. Although the food was served buffet style, as in the main dining room, it was a step up in style, with a slightly dressier dress code -- no shorts or tank tops.
A rich, peppery minestrone and delicious marinated eggplant were memorable starters; the prosciutto was too salty, though, and mussels were served lukewarm. The veal dishes, pizza hot out of the oven and fresh breadsticks were successes. One caloric warning: There were no limits on the tiramisu.
The next night brought our favorite dinner. The Club's grill restaurant, Media Luna, offers regular menu service with the accent on steaks and fish. My wife's grilled salmon was in that ideal state of balance between doneness and tenderness, swimming in a translucent butter sauce. My New York strip steak (exactly medium well) had met its match in a shimmering bearnaise.
In the spirit of Christopher Columbus, who is said to have arrived a few miles up the beach, we decided not to limit our horizons to the Club grounds. So on our first morning there, for $25 apiece, we took the half-day island sightseeing tour.
Our driver and guide was the Rev. Livingston Williams, a Zion Baptist minister who has spent most of his life on the island. Mr. Williams was a great advertisement for island living; he said he was 76 years old, but looked closer to 60.
About 750 people now live on San Salvador, he said as we navigated the island's paved and not-so-paved main road. Mr. Williams tends both crops and his flock; he pointed out his small farm and showed us the new church he is building (the minister's price wasn't all-inclusive; he politely solicited a donation to the building fund).
The island, 13 miles long and 5 miles wide, is not a stunner geographically -- with low scrub covering rocky terrain, and lakes in the middle; one of Columbus's supposed landing sites is at Long Bay, marked by a tall white crucifix and a few other monuments. It is scuba diving that provides the essential sightseeing experience at Columbus Isle; San Salvador is surrounded by coral reefs, and the resort has three custom-built dive boats capable of carrying 50 divers each.
By the end of the club's two-afternoon course ($25, including equipment), I had plumbed the deepest regions of the Club's pool, boldly leaped off the end of the boat pier and felt comfortable exploring one of the dive sites the next afternoon.
MEANWHILE, Marsha happily worked out in the village's exercise room. Classes in stretching, step aerobics and in-pool exercises were also provided for no extra charge. Columbus Isle also indulged her love of beaches, with a two-mile-long stretch of sand washed by a mild surf and amply supplied with simple lounge chairs and umbrellas -- and with plenty of fine white sand between each guest, there was never a claustrophobic feeling. To protect the delicate-looking dune vegetation bordering the beach, access from the village is via elevated footbridges.
One challenge remained, and I -- along with four other novice divers and a staff expert as our guide -- would face it on my final afternoon at the Club. I signed up for a dive to one of the coral walls not far off the beach ($35, including equipment), and as the boat approached the dive site, I could tell I was heading into a different depth. The water's color changed from a benign turquoise to an ominous deep violet, marking the sudden drop in the ocean floor at the coral wall.
Don, the staff member who was guiding us, used a series of hand signals to point out the rays and other sea life swimming by. We never did meet the friendly grouper that has a penchant for swimming right up to divers and nibbling on their hair, but the multihued fish and the spidery coral had me enraptured.
About 20 minutes into our dive, the spell broke. It turned out I was a regular bubble machine, probably because I was concentrating too hard on breathing. And with my tank low on air, I started floating inexorably to the surface, regretfully watching the fish and coral fade into the distance. "When you go out tomorrow," Don told me later, "just don't breathe so much."
Don's advice came too late for me; we would be leaving the next afternoon. In a resort with unlimited beer, wine, tiramisu, sunshine and visual delights, it was just my luck to find the one place where the air was rationed.
 
 
 
For sand, surf and cushy sofas
The Resort
 Although Columbus Isle is not a couples-only resort, singles are much more likely to have a good time if they are avid scuba divers or accomplished snorkelers. And there is little to entertain young children.
Columbus Isle is as dressed-down most of the time as other Club Med villages, but T-shirts, sneakers, tank tops and jeans or shorts are out of place in the evening in the Club's two specialty restaurants.
For reservations, call (800) 258-2633.
 
Getting There
For those not taking the Club Med charter flights, Bahamasair operates flights Wednesday through Sunday to San Salvador from Nassau on 50-passenger turboprops. From Miami, the five-day advance-purchase fare is $254.95 round trip; the unrestricted fare is $300.95. For $376 round trip to San Salvador, Delta offers service to Nassau from La Guardia on Fridays, with a connection on Bahamasair to San Salvador; the return flights are on Mondays only. A Club Med van provides round-trip service to and from the airport for $10 (the trip is free for those on the Club Med charter flights).
 
Rates
From April 29 to Dec. 9 (low season), weekly rates are $1,050 a person and daily rates $150 a person (ages 12 and up), based on double occupancy and without transportation. Weekly rates including round-trip air fare from Miami are $1,420; from New York, $1,650 (a special rate of $1,470 from New York is being offered from June 24 to Sept. 2). Add 30 percent to the weekly rate for single occupancy of a standard room.
"Economy singles" rooms with shared baths (for a 30 percent discount off standard rates) have the amenities of the regular rooms, but are only about a third the size. Some overlook the well-tended lawns and flowers behind the main guest cottages, but others face the rather sparse vegetation behind the village. None have ocean views or picture windows.
Club Med also charges all guests an initiation fee of $30 a family and annual membership fees of $50 a person, $20 for those under 12. Certain Clubs, such as this one, are geared to couples and singles (material for Columbus Isle says that children from age 12 are welcome). In such cases, families with children under the suggested age must sign a waiver informing them that there are no facilities for children and that parents are responsible for them.
 
What's Included
All meals; beer and table wine at meals; instruction and use of equipment for windsurfing, sailing, kayaking, waterskiing, snorkeling (including boat trips to coral reefs), tennis (10 Har-Tru courts, 3 lighted), bicycling, volleyball, basketball, boccie and aerobics and exercise classes. The smallish exercise room has one stationary bike, two programmable stair machines and treadmills, dumbbells, a circuit weight machine and aerobic steps. There is a weekly picnic cruise to a secluded beach.
 
What's Not
Scuba diving: $100 for a six-day package that includes all equipment (you pay even if you bring your own), two dives a day, one night dive and a fruit plate after each dive. For beginners, the program includes one day of lessons and five daytime dives. Per-day programs are $25. Advanced certification courses, $195.
Bar drinks: cappuccino ($1.60), Coke ($2), Perrier ($3.20), mixed-drink specials ($4), most beers ($4.80 a can) and hard liquor ($3.20 to $5.80). Fancier dinner wines cost $20 to $60 a bottle. Soft-drink machines dispense sodas for $1.
Sightseeing: Sunset cruise, $10; half-day island van tour, $25; three-hour deep-sea fishing, $160; day trip to Nassau, $280.
The spa: from $25 for a manicure to $65 for a major-overhaul facial.

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
ATHENA, by John Banville. (Knopf, $22.) In this wickedly mannerist novel, a murderer turned "art expert" runs smack into his own past when he has to catalogue a batch of stolen Old Masters.
 
GOD: A Biography, by Jack Miles. (Knopf, $27.50.) Not a joke but a scholarly, entertaining literary inquiry into the character called God as His multiple personalities have been rendered through the ages in the Hebrew Bible.
 
THE HAUNTED LAND: Facing Europe's Ghosts After Communism, by Tina Rosenberg. (Random House, $25.) A moral, political and psychological investigation, by a wise journalist, of four post-Soviet societies struggling with their conduct under the old regimes.
 
THE INFORMATION, by Martin Amis. (Harmony, $24.) Mr. Amis's cool and brilliant novel is sustained throughout by the corroding, corrupting envy of an unsuccessful novelist for a successful novelist who is also his best friend.
 
THE MAN WITHOUT QUALITIES, by Robert Musil. Translated by Sophie Wilkins and Burton Pike. (Knopf, two volumes, boxed, $60.) A magnificent new version of the unfinished and unfinishable novel by an Austrian contemporary of Proust and Joyce whose acknowledged greatness has always exceeded his acknowledged readership.
 
ONE BY ONE FROM THE INSIDE OUT: Essays and Reviews on Race and Responsibility in America, by Glenn C. Loury. (Free Press, $25.) An African-American economist tackles race and poverty in a collection of biting pieces that emphasize black self-help while also calling on the Government to aid the nation's poor.
 
OSWALD'S TALE: An American Mystery, by Norman Mailer. (Random House, $30.) Stoked by a passion to believe J.F.K.'s death was more than a meaningless absurdity, Mr. Mailer pursues and delivers the assassin's very slightly significant soul, using his own research and that of others.
 
POPE JOHN PAUL II: The Biography, by Tad Szulc. (Lisa Drew/Scribner, $27.50.) Mr. Szulc, a seasoned reporter of Polish birth, inquires into the special circumstances of Polish Catholicism and the special stresses of fascist and Communist domination that formed the present Pope.
 
A RIVER TOWN, by Thomas Keneally. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $24.) It's 1899 in Mr. Keneally's impassioned 21st novel, and Tim Shea, an outsider in an Australia with no insiders, inexorably digs himself into deeper and deeper trouble by always trying to do the right thing.
 
RULE OF THE BONE, by Russell Banks. (HarperCollins, $22.) A novel that reinvigorates the Huck Finn myth in the person of Chappie, a mall rat from upstate New York who lights out for Jamaica with a runaway farm worker.
 
WALT WHITMAN'S AMERICA: A Cultural Biography, by David S. Reynolds. (Knopf, $35.) An intensive historical excavation, aiming to show how Whitman, an enthusiast for almost everything, transmuted into his poetry images from all aspects of American culture.

LENGTH: 900 words

HEADLINE: Bad Art, Bad Politics

BYLINE: By Martha Bayles; Martha Bayles is the author of "Hole in Our Soul: The Loss of Beauty and Meaning in American Popular Music."

 BODY:

ART LESSONS
Learning From the Rise and Fall
of Public Arts Funding.
By Alice Goldfarb Marquis.
304 pp. New York: Basic Books. $25. 
WHENEVER Flannery O'Connor was asked whether universities stifled creative writers, she used to say, "They don't stifle enough of them." Given the pious tone of most contemporary discourse about the arts, such crankiness is downright refreshing. Fortunately, there is plenty of it in Alice Goldfarb Marquis's "Art Lessons: Learning From the Rise and Fall of Public Arts Funding."
Ms. Marquis, a visiting scholar in history at the University of California, San Diego, and the author of "Alfred H. Barr Jr.: Missionary for the Modern," has written a lively, detailed history of public arts funding that doesn't shy away from either the hard facts or most of the hard questions.
Consider her discussion of the current battle to cut or abolish the National Endowment for the Arts. While critics worry that such measures might reduce the number of artists in America, Ms. Marquis reminds us that artists are not exactly an endangered species. "Between 1965 and 1984," she writes, "the number of professional arts organizations had grown by 700 percent." And from a base year of 1986, she projects that by the year 2000 "total civilian employment is expected to grow by 19 percent, while the number of artists will swell by 31 percent."
Ms. Marquis also dares to suggest that quantity drives out quality: "Art is not a product like soybeans, but rather the outcome of imaginative endeavor by talented people, of whom there is always a limited supply. When grants prop up artists unable to attract audiences, individuals with limited abilities persist, crowding out superior talents."
Equally refreshing is Ms. Marquis's matter-of-fact approach to the "politicization" of the endowment. About Congressional reauthorization of the N.E.A. (which now occurs every two years), she writes, "The agency must, like a Siberian sled dashing through a pack of ravening wolves, liberally toss out chunks of goodies that key committee members can carry home to their districts." This fund-renewal process has always served to politicize the arts agency.
The distribution of such goodies, combined with the prestige that politicians gain when they associate themselves with the arts, explains why, for the first 20 years of the endowment, it was good politics for both Republicans and Democrats to support it. Only in the 1980's did such support become bad politics. The question is: Why?
To her credit, Ms. Marquis does not simply blame the Republicans -- indeed, she recalls that money for the arts continued to rise steeply under President Richard M. Nixon. Rather, she observes that during the Reagan years "a self-styled avant-garde" began "thrusting itself into media attention with strident political and sexual 'art.' "
"No expression, no matter how tasteless, depraved or insulting, could get the slightest rise out of art patrons," Ms. Marquis notes. But these strident gestures did get a rise out of Congress. Before you could say Mapplethorpe, she writes, "500 rampant bourgeois politicians with access to 500 microphones rewarded the new provocateurs with a thundering outrage not seen in the artistic world for many a decade."
Was this blowup inevitable? Would it have happened without public arts funding? On these thorny matters, Ms. Marquis is somewhat less clear. She chides every chief of the endowment from Nancy Hanks to Jane Alexander for failing to exercise artistic leadership. Yet she also asserts repeatedly that such leadership has no place in a democracy, and that the will of the people is better expressed in the marketplace.
About the marketplace, however, Ms. Marquis is ambivalent. On the one hand, she mocks the tendency of arts organizations to prefer hemorrhaging money to besmirching themselves with profit. On the other, she derides the way fund-raisers for the arts praise theaters and museums in the language of economic boosterism. This ambivalence extends to the private sector. Taking her cue from the historian Lawrence W. Levine, Ms. Marquis dismisses the great 19th-century philanthropists as philistine social climbers intent upon "sacralizing" art. Yet she admires John D. Rockefeller 3d and Dorothy Chandler, "neither of them passionate or at all knowledgeable about culture," for having dedicated their lives and fortunes to "developing homes for the performing arts."
Unfortunately, this ambivalence comes to a head in Ms. Marquis's proposed solution. For every locality, she would appoint a "public impresario" who would use government money to facilitate unlimited public access to unlimited arts activities. This is a bizarre proposal: First, it takes as its model the colorful impresarios of the last century, who were nothing if not creatures of the marketplace. And second, it sidesteps the likelihood that these public impresarios would be gatekeepers of the worst sort.
The ultimate questions are philosophical: Is artistic excellence possible in a democratic society? And if so, how is it to be sustained? By challenging the stale orthodoxies of both sides in the current debate, this fair-minded, bracingly irreverent book moves us closer to the answers. But by glossing over the real tensions between democratic taste and inherited standards of excellence, it leaves the hardest lessons unlearned.

HEADLINE: Spies & Thrillers

BYLINE: By Newgate Callendar 

 BODY:
THE LAST HIGH GROUND, by Robin A. White (Crown, $23), features Shig Onishi, a smart, determined accountant who works for the Economic Crimes Section of the National Police Agency in Tokyo. Compare him with Brian J. MacHenry, an equally smart and determined American investigator and former airline pilot. Each of them is trying to discover why new Boeing planes, the pride of the fleet, are going down.
The American and the Japanese get together to pool their findings. They have different mind-sets, and the result is a cultural clash. What is obvious to one is not so obvious to the other. "Shig felt like reaching over and shaking this thickheaded gaijin," Mr. White writes. "MacHenry was slow! . . . Maybe MacHenry wasn't so smart." But as Shig pursues his line of thought, the American has his own doubts: "MacHenry wondered how good an investigator Onishi was." 
 Of course, they finally come to a meeting of the minds as they collaborate on a case that puts both of them in peril. It centers on a Japanese Mafioso who wants to purchase Boeing. If Boeing aircraft continue to tumble out of the skies, the great American corporation can be picked up for peanuts.
And there is more to it than that. The United States is in bad economic shape, with a restless citizenry and a feeling of revolution in the air. The loss of Boeing would be disastrous to the balance of trade. Yet there are politicians in Washington who would sacrifice their country for personal gain.
MacHenry and Onishi have to cope with a variety of crises. There is a computer virus to be overcome. There is an enigmatic woman who is as lethal as any of the yakuza. There are powerful Beltway figures who can command immense resources as they set out to destroy anybody who threatens them.
It is a heady brew that Mr. White, the author of "Angle of Attack" and "The Sword of Orion," has concocted. If the battle at the end is a bit too contrived, no matter. "The Last High Ground" soars.
John Lawton's BLACK OUT (Viking, $22.95) is a fine first novel. The setting is London during the blitz of 1944. Detective Sgt. Frederick Troy is investigating a series of murders. The son of an aristocrat, Troy is an unusual type -- literate, sophisticated and highly intuitive.
With very little to go on, he eventually realizes that all of the victims were foreign scientists working for the Allied war effort. Trying to get more information, he has to deal with the Americans, specifically with a new, mysterious group known as the O.S.S.
Mr. Lawton, who produces television documentaries in Britain, is an elegant writer. His plotting is logical, and his backgrounds are haunting. Anybody who was in England during the blitz (as this reviewer was) will testify to the accuracy of the author's descriptions: the stoicism and heroism of the people, the Hyde Park orators spouting the Communist Party line, the ersatz food, the chippies in Piccadilly -- all of it is here.
In NIGHT OF THE APOCALYPSE (Harper Collins, $24), Daniel Easterman is concerned with Irish terrorism. The protagonist, Declan Carberry, heads the Irish Republic's Special Detective Unit, which handles counterterrorism. He is given a delicate assignment. Muslim leaders are meeting in Dublin, and Carberry is put in charge of security. Things go wrong, and he is made the scapegoat.
Terrorists capture Muslim delegates, make crazy demands and start killing off hostages when their demands are not met. They seem to be religious lunatics of some kind. Carberry finds himself working with a notorious Muslim terrorist, who has come to Ireland to get several of his friends out of the hands of their captors.
The book is full of wild action, with a terrific shoot-out. Mr. Easterman, whose previous novels include "Brotherhood of the Tomb," "Name of the Beast" and "The Judas Testament," even manages to find space for a romance amid all the gore.
The world of pumping iron is examined in Richard La Plante's STEROID BLUES (Forge/Tom Doherty, $22.95). This is a psychothriller, dominated by two freaks of enormous strength who can literally tear a man apart. What with all that, plus kinky sex, skinheads and the underbelly of Philadelphia, Capt. Bill Fogarty has his hands full. Mr. La Plante, the author of "Mantis" and "Leopard," tells the story skillfully, creating tension and a mounting feeling of horror as he peers into some very sick minds.
