HEADLINE: CHOICE TABLES;
Los Angeles Dining Is Back, With Gusto

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER; BRYAN MILLER is a reporter for the style department of The Times.

 BODY:
THIS year appears to mark the beginning of Los Angeles's recovery from those urban afflictions -- a major earthquake, riots, floods and brush fires -- that affected the city's economy on many levels. The restaurant scene that had come to a near standstill a year and a half ago is burgeoning once again. Two areas covered here -- Old Town Pasadena and Santa Monica -- mirror the new vitality and optimism that are restoring Los Angeles to its role as a center of gastronomy.
All lunch and dinner prices listed below are for a three-course meal for two, with a glass of wine and tax, but not tip. 

 
Les Arts
Old Town Pasadena has undergone a remarkable renaissance in the past five years, with the restoration of vintage buildings and an influx of business, young professionals and new restaurants. Many of the dining spots lining Colorado Boulevard, the main commercial artery, are undistinguished pasta joints and forgettable Chinese outlets. Others, like winsomely designed Twin Palms, owned by the actor Kevin Costner, are exuberant places for people watching, while the food receives mixed reviews. For more ambitious food in Old Town, it is best to head to Raymond Avenue, which intersects Colorado Boulevard.
 One place you will find on Raymond Avenue is Les Arts, an eight-month-old French restaurant offering refined contemporary fare at reasonable prices. The low-key dining room is a canvas of white displaying a changing gallery of paintings by local artists -- an exemplary idea, sometimes. On a recent visit, the overbearing wildlife paintings appeared ready to jump out and snatch your appetizer.
The menu at Les Arts is grounded in traditional French cooking, and lunch is an extraordinary bargain. One classic dish is the starter of veal shank terrine layered with artichokes and asparagus. Unfortunately, the terrine was served so cold that its flavors were muted. Zucchini flowers are stuffed with a sprightly combination of tomatoes and zucchini, and served with a Provencal-style tomato and herb sauce.
The French-American wine list offers some splendid selections at fair prices, including a 1990 Quincy, a faintly tart white, for $25, and a 1991 Cahors, a robust red, for $19.
Main courses are straightforward and well-focused: salmon wrapped in bacon with a red wine sauce and potato cake; fillet of beef in a sauce of sweet shallot confit and balsamic vinegar; and perfectly cooked tuna steak ringed with spring vegetables and served over a sweet-onion compote with well-seasoned zucchini slivers.
Les Arts also serves one of the few assorted cheese platters I saw in Los Angeles. As for dessert, the kitchen was out of saffron ice cream with green-apple sauce, so we chose a homemade ice cream assortment (cinnamon is best). Assorted tarts looked wonderful.
Dinner at Les Arts is about $70; a little-advertised prix fixe lunch (three courses) is $11 a person, while the regular lunch runs about $20 a person.
 
Xiomara
On the north side of Colorado Boulevard is a bistro that could be at home in the tonier environs of Santa Monica or Beverly Hills. Xiomara, named for Xiomara Ardolina, the owner, has a cool and jazzy feeling, with beveled mirrors, black lacquered chairs, white columns and sprightly artwork.
The chef, Patrick Healy, made his mark at the Champagne restaurant, which closed about three years ago. His love for home-style cooking can be seen in dinner entrees such as a seductive braised veal shank with root vegetables, and rustic cassoulet made with lamb shoulder, duck confit, slab bacon and pork ribs. Less robust options include Mr. Healy's piquant crisped salmon steak with black peppercorn sauce, and seared sea bass with a spicy stir-fry of vegetables. A $12 bouillabaisse on Monday and Tuesday evenings is a singular bargain, as is the daily lunch special for $12.50.
If you plan an extensive walking tour of Pasadena after lunch to work it off, the foie gras terrine, served at the table with delicious port jelly, is excellent. A recommendable entree is grilled sea bass enhanced with dried fennel and artichokes. Even though the thermometer was pushing 70 degrees, we could not resist the duet of full-flavored sausages (pork with garlic and thyme, and sweetbread sausage) with Swiss chard and creamy mashed potatoes.
Pear tart tatin with a brittle, airy crust was superb with vanilla ice cream.
Dinner runs about $75. A three-course bistro menu is available nightly for $25 a person. Lunch for two with wine is about $60; there is a special bistro lunch for $12.
 
Yujean Kang's
The portly, baby-faced chef who gave his name to this restaurant clearly has fun creating what might be called new wave Chinese cuisine. His presentations are often whimsical and, more important, the flavors generally harmonize.
The dining room of his four-year-old restaurant on North Raymond Boulevard is decorated in rust-brown desert tones, with Oriental prints on the walls, roomy tables and an affable staff.
One of the more popular first courses is called Pictures in the Snow, something one has to see. A julienne of chicken, smoked duck and black mushrooms is served in a rich duck stock, and the whole dish is covered with a snowfall of meringue on which the chef creates little dioramas with carved vegetables.
We did not sample Ants on the Tree (sauteed beef with black sesame seeds), but the subtle tea-smoked duck salad with black bean dressing can be recommended. The same goes for the superb loin of lamb garnished with crunchy threads of jellyfish and minced hot chilies.
Yujean Kang's has a sizable wine list, mostly Californian, and many of the selections go well with this kind of food. One to try is the dry and distinctive 1992 Chalone chenin blanc, $30.
Dinner for two is $50 to $60; about 30 percent less at lunch.
In Santa Monica, both prices and skirts are a notch higher than in Pasadena. This vivacious community attracts visitors from afar for its shopping, swimming and social scene. It is home to some stylish out-of-town restaurants, including Bice and Remi from New York. The food found in Santa Monica is as varied and unpredictable as the tides.
 
Abiquiu
Consider John Rivera Sedlar, a chef who specializes in hyphenated cooking (California-Thai, Cape Cod-Mexican) and built a fervid young following at his Japanese-influenced Bikini in Santa Monica. Earthquake damage closed it in early 1994.
The dauntless Mr. Sedlar returned to the scene last year with a new venture, Abiquiu, named after a town in New Mexico near his great-grandparents' homestead.
You suspect that you are in for a wild and woolly ride when you read in Mr. Sedlar's menu notes that his search for modern Southwest cuisine took him to Mexico, Japan, Chile, Russia, France, Italy and Hong Kong.
Abiquiu is a big, brash two-level space with water cascading down one wall and blue screens on another that look like televisions on the blink. On the upper level, a colorful tamale bar attracts a young, rakish crowd.
Among the more interesting starters are scallops wrapped in shredded phyllo paired with crisp, lemony tasting cactus and a sweet corn ragout. The peculiar sounding Cape Cod tamale is a winner, too, combining chunks of Maine lobster and steamed asparagus glossed with lemon-tarragon butter.
It is not easy matching wines to this polymorphic food. The best route might be crisp, high-acid whites, such as pinot blanc or sauvignon blanc, or low-tannin reds such as merlot from California, Spain or France. The list offers something in each categoryat average prices.
If your life has never been enriched by a Banzai Tamale of air-dried duck, this is a good place to remedy the situation. The smoky tasting duck meat is garnished with shiitakes, bok choy, ginger and soy. Also superior is the tender and lightly smoked antelope haunch in a red wine and garlic sauce.
If a coconut ice cream banana split seems too mundane, there is pumpkin brulee over a base of firm pumpkin meat.
Dinner is about $70.
 
The Ivy at the Shore
This restaurant, facing the Santa Monica Pier, is the casual and cacophonous sibling of The Ivy on Robertson Boulevard in midtown Los Angeles. With a white rattan ceiling, tropical art, tall palms and shadowy lighting, it has the feel of an island resort -- a tourist-packed island resort.
The Ivy specializes in longshoreman portions at yacht captain prices. Crab cakes are better than average, dark, crisp and well-seasoned;pizzas are a good option, too.
If you have been surfing all day, your appetite might sustain the log pile of moist and crunchy fried chicken with brussels sprouts, whipped potatoes and mango chutney. The charred lime-marinated chicken is a winner, too. Grilled fish -- swordfish, salmon, tuna -- is reliable, except for the bland summer-squash puree (ask for the excellent whipped potatoes instead). Service can be spotty because of the nightly mob scene.
Coffee is served in a gargantuan ceramic cup that could double as a birdbath.
Dinner runs about $90.
 
Valentino
In this oceanside city with its endless-summer mood, Valentino sticks out like a tuxedo on the beach. On a given night you will probably see more ties and formal dresses here than in the rest of Santa Monica combined. But Valentino is hardly stuffy, a reflection of the genial host, Piero Selvaggio, and his sharp staff.
The main dining room is soft, muted and accommodating. Several appetizers are worth seeking out, especially the house special of porcini tort with fondutas (fondue with Piemontese cheese) and the soothing barley, potato and Tuscan bean soup. One evening we sampled a delightful special of scallops wrapped in prosciutto over a ragout of artichokes and porcini.
Specials might include a perfectly roasted roulade of rabbit loin infused with thyme, brittle-skinned quail, or seasonal risotti. Dishes to look for on the main menu include pork loin with sweet peppers and tomato, herbaceous loin of lamb, sweetbreads in a mushroom-Marsala sauce, and a harmonious pasta dish, pennette alla Arrabiata.
Mr. Selvaggio has assembled one of the best wine selections in Los Angeles, with older vintages and hard-to-find wines from various regions in northern Italy.
Among desserts, there are a splendin hazelnut semifreddo; chocolate purses with custard and creme anglaise, and nougat with fresh raspberry compote.
Dinner averages about $110; Friday lunch about $40.
 
Rockenwagner
One might expect Wiener schnitzel and dumplings at a place with this name. Instead, what you find at this fantastical, big post-modern dining room a short walk from the ocean is a menu offering Vietnamese happy pancakes (a wheat flour pancake topped with shrimp), roasted duck with cherry-ginger sauce, and roasted pork tenderloin with goat cheese wrapped in shredded filo.
Hans Rockenwagner, the congenial European-trained chef, has created a setting that is as eclectic and audacious as his food. Playful log-cabin motifs overhead blend with post-modern accents in Souththwestern colors -- Daniel Boone meets Michael Graves.
The kitchen's reach is impressive, if not always successful. Look for dishes like sauteed jumbo shrimp over crisped noodle cakes with black bean sauce, and the nicely charred roasted duck set over a cherry sauce accented with ginger. Among starters, a construction of lightly smoked Atlantic salmon, potatoes and creme fraiche was ordinary. Moreover, the advertised caviar turned out to be flying-fish eggs that were mixed in with a salty sauce. The best part of the crab souffle was the intense lobster sauce served with it; the souffle itself had mostly air going for it.
Desserts are splendid, particularly the warm chocolate tart with a hazelnut parfait, and a nougat parfait with fresh berries. Rockenwagner has a well-selected, highly personal wine list with fair prices.
Dinner is about $70; lunch is about $40.

HEADLINE: 'A Moment on the Earth'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I feel I must respond to Michael Specter's review of Gregg Easterbrook's book. There are so many flaws in both the reasoning and the facts that it is difficult to know where to begin. For now, I'll target a few seemingly innocent sentences that I believe point to the nature of both Mr. Easterbrook's and Mr. Specter's biases. 
 Mr. Specter writes, "He explains with clarity why so many educated people are so afraid of tiny risks from things they don't understand, like alar or dioxin, that they will buy bottled water in a city with no water problems and extremely expensive organic fruit when there is no need to waste the money." This sentence makes clear the myopic economic analysis implicit in Mr. Easterbrook's views.
By limiting the argument to this framework, he misses what is important: face-to-face contact with the people growing the food we eat; healthier workers, farmers and communities; soil and ground water uncontaminated by pesticides, fungicides and herbicides. The organic produce I buy at outdoor markets is clearly, quantifiably, qualitatively better produce. It's fresher, sweeter and tastier. Many older, almost lost varieties are now flourishing again in family orchards and on small farms. The variety in some cases is astonishing: often four or five different types of broccoli, plums, apricots, peaches and potatoes, often a dozen different varieties of apples, tomatoes and peppers. Just as astonishing, organic produce is often less expensive than supermarket produce.
Mentioning the Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989, Mr. Specter refers to "the remarkable regenerative powers of nature." I won't argue with this statement. I tend to agree with it. I would, however, argue with the conclusion that policy makers, corporate heads, government bodies and others will draw from statements like this one.
The human body is remarkably regenerative as well -- one night's heavy drinking is, though often painful the next morning, forgotten two or three days later. But daily alcohol or tobacco abuse over decades will cause irreparable damage to the body, shortening the life span and perhaps having an insidious impact on the very quality of that shortened life. This is the real analogy, and the real danger of what we are doing to the earth. And, of course, to ourselves.
 
JOHN T. SELAWSKY
Berkeley, Calif.

HEADLINE: An Immigration Disaster?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While it is understandable that Nicholas Lemann would employ a deliberately neutral tone in his review of Peter Brimelow's inflammatory "Alien Nation: Common Sense About America's Immigration Disaster" (April 16), less detachment and more context might have proved beneficial. 
 Mr. Lemann notes in the concluding paragraph that "Mr. Brimelow's definition of 'alienated' is political . . . and his definition of 'America' is racial." But throughout the rest of the review he seems almost at pains to report even Mr. Brimelow's most outrageous assertions without comment, as in "What is required for the successful functioning of a nation, he insists, is 'a link by blood.' "
On the contrary, it is not (as Mr. Brimelow would like us to believe) the multiethnic makeup of society that leads to genocide in Bosnia and Rwanda or communal violence in India, but rather the cynical manipulation of well-founded fears among the populace to gain political advantage or provide distraction from underlying economic and social conditions. And as both Proposition 187 and Mr. Brimelow's book painfully demonstrate, political commentators and politicians in the United States have not been above such hatemongering and scapegoating.
 
ALICIA ELY YAMIN
New York

HEADLINE: GRANT US PEACE

 BODY:
I should have known from John Tierney's blase voice as we spoke on the telephone what sort of article he was writing (The Big City: "Grant Us Peace," May 7). Somehow, he didn't sound enthusiastic about Grant's Tomb.
By his reasoning, any historic site that falls out of fashion should become fodder for developers and revisionists. Why should our President be housed in an 18th-century, neo-classical palace when a modern corporate building would be more efficient and economical to run? Tierney needn't worry; I'm only joking. 
 As a museum curator and historic preservationist, I hope he, too, was joking. My great-great-grandparents' final resting place might make a nice cocktail lounge and nightspot. But to thus change it would cheapen the memory of every soldier who died during the bloodiest war ever fought in the Western Hemisphere.
 
ULYSSES GRANT DIETZ
Maplewood, N.J.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
The Price of Privatization: Will Labor Get Its Due?

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON; Iver Peterson is the Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
A large and apparently growing chorus of New Jerseyans are nervous and bitter about the drive for lower taxes and less government in the Whitman administration. They are the state employees. It used to be said that public workers accepted low salaries for high job security, but in New Jersey, public employees' salaries are often higher than in the new, depressed wage, post-industrial service sector, and their job security is dwindling every day.
Now Governor Whitman wants to privatize 25 Department of Motor Vehicles offices, the ones that handle paperwork for car titles, licenses and so on. She also wants to close North Princeton Developmental Center and the Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital, sending their patients to, yes, private, nonprofit institutions. About 350 motor vehicle workers would pass from the public to the private sector, while some 2,000 mental health workers could be out of jobs entirely. 
 Aside from Mrs. Whitman's unproven argument that private companies can do as good a job for less (remember that when the motor-vehicle offices were in private hands in the 1980's, they were so slow and so corrupt that the state took them over), the changes raise a question that isn't being asked in all the clutter. What do public employers owe their workers, and is public employment somehow different from private employment?
Clearly the Whitman administration, its members drawn from business and the law, do not think there is any difference. The state's first obligation is to operate on behalf of the public in the most efficient manner possible, the Governor says, and if privatization offers a chance to save some money, public workers have no particular claim on the public at large.
Public employee unions, the fastest-growing segment, perhaps the only growing segment, of the labor movement, obviously believe that there is a difference, and that Mrs. Whitman is missing it. For starters, no one can tell private employees in any line of work that they may not go out on strike, but public employment contracts are replete with no-strike rules.
But the unions also advance a moral or social argument on behalf of public employment. Alan Kaufman, a leader of the Communications Workers of America, maintains that the privatization plans for the motor vehicle offices discriminate against women and minorities, since these two groups are heavily represented among state employees.
"In the public sector, women and minorities are disproportionately doing the work," said Mr. Kaufman. "So when they privatize, then they are disproportionately hurting women and minorities and lowering their standards of living, which are already lower than those of men."
But why does working for the private sector "lower" your standard of living? Because, Mr. Kaufman said, in the current economic atmosphere, in which service wages are depressed, state employees now make more, not less, than their private equivalents -- $24,000 a year for a typical Motor Vehicle Services worker, compared to $18,000 in the 24 motor vehicle agencies that are already contracted to privately companies. Add in benefits the gap widens considerably: More paid holidays, a non-contributory pension plan, even the right to collect pay for unused sick leave. Under state law, the only obligation on private contractors of public services is to provide medical insurance.
Now, Mr. Kaufman said with considerable venom, Mrs. Whitman is borrowing a page from the upside-down business world, where laying off workers makes a company's stock go up.
"Higher unemployment raises the stock market," he said, "and in the public sector there is a political calculus that makes your political stock go up the more public workers you get rid of."
Yet public employee unions do not come to this argument entirely innocently. One reason their members' wages and benefits have stood up so well when everyone else's have been stagnant or falling is that the unions have played a ruthless game of politics with public employment, making campaign contributions, endorsing candidates and punishing their enemies at the polls.
Now the politics of public employment is against them, and Mrs. Whitman scores points with voters talking about the jobs she will cut.
A textbook example of the perils of public-employment politics played out in the 1991 legislative races, when the teachers' union punished Governor Florio for taking on several of its sacred financial issues, including his worthwhile attempt to make local districts, and not the state, pay for their own teachers' pensions.
The teachers' strategy worked only too well. It helped produce the landslide Republican legislature, which helped produce the Whitman administration, which is now producing privatization.
That's politics.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CONFERENCE CALL;
Privatization: Leaner Government, or Just Another Fad?

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
When Republicans talk about reinventing government, they invariably talk about turning public services over to the private sector. Governor Whitman is no exception. When she took office, she promised a far-ranging examination of how and who delivers state services, from testing motor-vehicle emissions to feeding prisoners.
Privatizing at least some of these services, she said, could save taxpayer dollars by forcing private entrepreneurs to bid against one another -- and by letting them use their competitive energy to do a better job of delivering services. 
 So far, she has recommended transferring the Division of Motor Vehicles to private control, and her administration is studying privatization at the Division of Youth and Family Services and the food-service contracts at state hospitals.
Not everyone is happy with this trend. Critics, including public-employee unions whose members' jobs are at stake, say privatization means that government has less contol of its resources and its ability to function as a watchdog. They warn that privatization can easily be just another term for political patronage. And they say that a few dollars saved here and there may cost more in the long run because of reduced services.
The New York Times arranged a conference call with experts on both sides of the issue: Lewis M. Eisenberg, a business executive who is chairman of the New Jersey Advisory Council on Privatization, and Marc Holzer, a Rutgers University professor of public adminstration who is executive director of the National Center for Public Productivity.
Q. How is privatization supposed to work, in theory?
HOLZER I think the underpinning philosophy, which is competition, is a good idea. Competition can do things like lower costs, allow economies of scale, avoid large start-up costs, provide access to specialized skills and training, etc. But I think competition doesn't have to mean privatization. We can achieve the advantages of competition without giving away control over services which really should be in the public domain. I don't think we want private-sector firms running our schools or prisons, for example, and certainly not police departments. What we really need to do is create more competitive entities in the public sector.
EISENBERG I'm not sure that I would agree, activity by activity, with the professor's comments that they shouldn't be open to private competition. The public sector should be allowed to compete with the private sector for the very same services. If you look at some of the successes we've had here at home in New Jersey, in Mercer County or Bergen County, where they've actually privatized a meaningful portion of the correctional facilities, saved the taxpayers a lot of money, and have improved, I think, both by inmate reaction and by recidivism rates.
Q. What does this mean for government employees?
EISENBERG In a free capitalist society, assuming all things are equal, government is overburdened; the costs have basically been breaking the back of the camel. I don't think it serves a worker well to argue for preserving his job by saying that someone in the private sector is willing to accept lower wages and lower fringe benefits for the same job.
HOLZER I think you cut to the core of the question. Is it the same job with the same outcome or have we changed the nature of the service when we moved it to the private sector? If you're dealing with more complicated functions, whether it's air traffic control or corrections or education, is it really the same job people are doing? Or are they operating at a lower level, which has hidden long-term costs for our society?
Q. What, then, should be the goal of government?
HOLZER I think the endgame is service. When you ask the public what it wants, it wants improved services before it wants reduced costs.
I think we're suffering from political hysteria in terms of a desire to cut taxes. If you ask them whether they want better schools or lower taxes, they will almost always select better schools because they understand that's an important long-term payoff.
They want an improved system and they're willing to pay for it, but what I think we lack is the political courage to do that.
EISENBERG I disagree with him strongly; I think the quality of service is integrally interwoven with the costs. I think the 1994 elections and Governor Whitman's election [in 1993] basically said people feel they're being taxed way too much for the services they're getting, and I think we're duty-bound to find those places to try, by using competition as an arrow and a quiver of government, to provide the same or better service at lower cost.
Q. Where do you think privatization will go in New Jersey?
EISENBERG I think the Governor has basically been cautious and at the same time has taken expeditious steps to bring in competition where it can provide the same or better service at lower cost.
There were 20 initiatives that were recommended by the Commission on Privatization at the end of 1994, and 14 of them are in some form of implementation. My expectation is that they will result in $200 million to 300 million in recurring savings to the state.
HOLZER The Governor has got well-intentioned objectives, but I'm a skeptic in terms of how much we need to do in terms of privatization. I think she should be giving public servants more opportunity to compete with the private sector and with each other.
I think there should be more competition within government before we start looking for alternatives on the outside.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "I don't think we want private-sector firms running our schools or prisons.": MARC HOLZER - Director, National Center for Public Productivity (Alan Zale for The New York Times); "Government is overburdened; the costs have been breaking the back of the camel.": LEWIS M. EISENBERG - Chairman, New Jersey Advisory Council on Privatization (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Artful Bond of Yonkers and Italian Town

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
MONTICHIARI, Italy, a city of 17,000 people near Milan, is notable for its open-air market, a 12th-century Romanesque church and a restored 15th-century castle. Except for its hills and proximity to a major city, Montichiari would seem to have little in common with Yonkers, a city of nearly 200,000 beset by all the urban turmoil of the late 20th century.
But Innocenzo Pedretti, a photographer with an open mind and an eye for beauty, was prepared to love Yonkers even before he arrived here from Montichiari one recent morning, when the trees on North Broadway were close to full bloom and the Palisades shimmered across the river like a half-forgotten dream. He had come, he said, with a proposal from the mayor of his hometown to make Montichiari and Yonkers sister cities. 
 The idea arose from a new book of photographs, "Due Paesi" or "Two Cities," which Mr. Pedretti, a retired manufacturer of farm products, produced with Frank Dituri, a Yonkers photographer and high school teacher here who taught Mr. Pedretti photography one summer in Italy. The book features black-and-white photographs of both cities and texts in English and Italian.
The unlikely pairing came about after the book's publisher, the Italian Association of Infra-Red Photography, asked Mr. Pedretti, who was vice president of the group, to produce a book comparing two cities. He invited Mr. Dituri, a specialist in infrared photography, to be the second photographer on the project. But at first the American, who said he considers himself a fine-art photographer and not a documentarian, was not interested.
"They were going to do Milan and New York City, and I thought New York City was a bit of a cliche at this point," Mr. Dituri said. He and Mr. Pedretti discussed the project's evolution the morning after the Italian photographer's arrival in the Lenoir Preserve here, where an exhibition of photographs from "Two Cities" was to open two days later. The Yonkers School District rents a historic mansion on the grounds from Westchester County for $1 a year and bases its Education Cultural Arts Center there. Cooking and horticulture programs are also held at the building.
Mr. Pedretti was accompanied by his daughter, Aida, an economist who was sent to represent Mayor Badilini Giliolo of Montichiari. Three other Montichiari residents also came on the trip, prepared to present artwork, town banners and books to Mayor Terence M. Zaleski of Yonkers at the opening of the show, which runs through June 21.
Mr. Dituri, a widely exhibited artist, said that as discussions about the book with his former student progressed, it had occurred to him to contrast two cities from "middle America and middle Italy."
"Yonkers represents to me a small big city," he said. "It has all the problems of a city, yet many parts look like Scarsdale and Bronxville. If the Yonkerses of America are not safe, then we have problems. They are the new battlegrounds."
The Pedrettis, on the other hand, painted a rosy picture of Montichiari, describing an abundance of jobs, a growing economy based on farming and light industry, a successful integration of immigrants from Ghana and other parts of Africa into the community and a forward-looking Mayor. There were no drug problems in Montichiari, they said, and the city's residents were "very supportive" of welfare programs to combat homelessness and poverty.
"Two Cities," however, does not address politics, economics or quality of life, nor does it draw a definitive portrait of either Yonkers or Montichiari. Instead, the book -- and the exhibition -- consists of highly personal images made by two photographers exploring the creative potential of infrared film. The film, which records light at the red end of the spectrum, produces dramatic effects by turning skies black and rendering foliage a ghostly white.
Mr. Dituri produces abstractions that give little hint that they depict places like Philipse Manor, Yonkers Raceway, Cook Field, Odell Avenue and Roosevelt High School, where he teaches. He called himself "a borderline Surrealist," who avoids obvious infrared effects of that film and instead seeks what he described as "the in-between moments" of experience, when things are "almost ready to happen."
Mr. Pedretti called himself "a slave to the light" who always carries a camera and who learned to see more freely after studying with Mr. Dituri. His photographs present panoramic views of street life as well as landmarks like Fontanelle, where the Virgin Mary is said to have appeared in a vision.
The 48-page book, elegantly produced with luminous reproductions, can be purchased for $10 by calling Mr. Dituri at 376-8527. By agreement with Mr. Pedretti, part of the proceeds will benefit the Roosevelt High School West Room Gallery at the Lenoir Preserve, where the "Two Cities" exhibition is hanging.
When the photographs leave here, they will travel to Montichiari, where they will be exhibited in the restored castle. Mayor Giliolo has also invited Yonkers to set up a booth at the city's yearly exposition in April.
When Mayor Zaleski was interviewed after the opening of the exhibition, he called the event a success.
"We were able to establish a beautiful linkage between two cities noted for their beautiful hills," he said. Yonkers already has a sister-city arrangement with Ternopol, Ukraine, he said, and has been approached by Fengcheng, China, to establish ties, but there is no reason why the city cannot also be a sister -- a "big sister," he emphasized -- to Montichiari as well. "You can have many sisters," the Mayor said.

HEADLINE: A House Is Not a Home (but Who's Complaining?)

BYLINE: By THOMAS STAUDTER 

DATELINE: MOUNT PLEASANT

 BODY:
ROBERT CHAMBERLAIN, seemingly well-ensconced in a 10-room "English cottage" set off from a woodsy stretch of road between North Tarrytown and Briarcliff Manor, concedes that at least six months pass before he starts feeling settled in a new home. By all appearances, the 42-year-old Tarrytown native appears comfortably established in the rambling 3,200-square-foot, one-story house he moved into last September.
His residency here, though, is temporary at best. The luxury home -- with each room attractively furnished and decorated -- is on three acres in the Pocantico Hills school district. It is for sale, and Mr. Chamberlain is merely house-sitting until the property sells. 
 The arrangement is one Mr. Chamberlain is thoroughly acquainted with. In the last five years he has lived in seven different residences and, in exchange for reduced rent or no rent at all, has served as a combination house sitter and caretaker for homes on the market. A requirement of his occupancy, however, is that the house must always be clean and presentable, because real estate brokers are allowed to show the property to potential buyers whenever possible throughout the week.
Recently, several factors have led owners and realtors to employ house sitters.
"Fluctuating interest rates, high property taxes and a glut of higher-priced homes have softened the housing market to some extent, with the most effective properties being luxury homes, which are on average for sale or listed longer to begin with, and homes in less desirable or unfavorable locations," said Jody Toth, a saleswoman at John P. Streb & Son in Tarrytown.
And some houses, because of quirky structural designs or poorly planned layouts, are simply hard to sell. Or, more likely, owners need to recoup what they paid for a property and will keep a house on the market until a suitable price is met. Whatever the reason, homeowners are sometimes forced to move, usually because of job relocation. In corporate relocations, owners are often bailed out by holding companies that purchase their homes, and in turn list the property with a real estate broker.
Because a vacant house or an unattended property can be a risk, the services of a house sitter are sometimes necessary, several real estate brokers agreed. Two businesses in Connecticut, incidentally, hire house sitters for their clients, who are typically realtors and financial holding companies. Show Homes of America, a Dallas-based company, has a branch office in Westport, and two partners, Mary Boehlert and Joanne Paone-Gill, have been operating Home Market Associates Inc. in Fairfield for five years.
Home Market Associates has 30 to 40 so-called residential managers placed at any given time, and because it is a small company, Ms. Paone-Gill said, "it provides a more personalized service in marketing the properties for the home owners."
Heather Hiltz, the placement manager and overseer of Show Homes of America's Westport office, said that a distinction exists between house sitters and home managers -- the people she contracts to furnish and decorate vacant properties. "Home sitters are either paid for their service or it's a trade-off -- the house is occupied, maintained and watched while the house sitter resides there for free," she said.
Both Home Marketing's residential managers and Show Homes's home mangers pay rents that are 60 percent to 75 percent less than the average rent for a comparable property. For instance, one manager occupied a contemporary mini-castle on a hill, which is listed at more than $1 million, for $1,000 a month plus utilities and the cost of lawn maintenance. Houses selling for $500,000 normally rent for between $600 and $750 a month plus utilities.
When Show Homes accepts a new listing, Susan Handee, an interior decorator, helps arrange the home manager's furnishings to create a model home atmosphere, which many realtors feel helps sell the property more quickly. Also, a Show Homes brochure says that with a home manager houses go for an average 10 to 15 percent higher selling price.
"The model home has to be kept in a pristine state," Ms. Hiltz said. "Looking at the pictures in the home-decorating magazines, if you don't see it in those photographs, then we don't want to see it in our show homes."
Dirty dishes left in the sink aren't tolerated, and the houses are subjected monthly to unannounced inspections, Ms. Hiltz said. "Home managing for us is like a part-time job," she said.
Most of Ms. Hiltz's home managers are saving money for a future house, and others are building houses and do not want to be locked into a lease. A few home managers are bankrupts or people unable to pass a credit check.
"I sold my house in Pound Ridge to raise capital for a business, and I was paying $40,000 a year in rent," said Dorothy Treyball, who started with Show Homes but works primarily with Home Marketing Associates.
"I was used to expensive homes, and it was going to be hard for me to move into an apartment," Ms. Treyball said. "I had too many nice things, and I didn't want to have to sell them. I saw a Show Homes ad in Greenwich Time, and it sounded almost too good to be true."
Obviously, there is an adverse side to house sitting: one year Ms. Treyball moved five times. "It's so much hard work packing and unpacking everything, even though I've gotten good at it," she said. "I really prefer at least six months in one location."
Most house sitters hope to be placed in a property that won't sell too quickly. "There is a bit of an art to picking out a house that you want to manage," said Remie Smith, who bounced from house to house with his wife and two preschool children while he renovated a house for his family.
Robert Svoboda, currently managing a property for Show Homes in Mamaroneck, said he probably wasn't going anywhere too soon because the split-level he is in "backs up to a boat yard." Also, across the street and in front of the house is the back wall of a garden apartment complex -- "not an attractive view," said Mr. Svoboda, who moved into the house last November.
Another trick, Mr. Smith said, is to rent storage space. "You don't want to move all of your possessions into a house," he said. "So, we never really moved into each house, and we never got comfortable. It was like camping out."
Midge Billingsley of Frances Billingsley Realty in Katonah said her firm does not hire house sitters. "If a house is priced correctly, we usually have an accepted offer within 30 days," she said. "So, the house will only be vacant for a total of three months, from offer to closing. Plus, any of the homes that are empty the realtors check every day."
Still, many realtors and absentee owners would rather hire a house sitter than face the anxiety associated with unattended property. Elio De Cecchis, whose Tarrytown concern De Cecchis Realty listed the English cottage that Robert Chamberlain is living in, said that the agreement Mr. Chamberlain has with the property's owner, a New York City real estate holding company, "can actually save owners and insurance companies a great deal of money."
Mr. Chamberlain kept the pipes from freezing when the electric ignition in the house's boiler malfunctioned in March.
Mr. Chamberlain is responsible for the heating costs, which will amount to more than $3,000 this year, and minor maintenance charges also come out of his pocket.
Mr. Chamberlain, a landscape architect at the Glen Gate Company in Wilton and president of the Tarrytown Historical Society, once moved three times in seven weeks, hopping between Greenwich and Somers.
"The transience used to bother me," he said. "But I've grown accustomed to it. I just call this my nomadic stage."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In exchange for keeping a house showable, Robert Chamberlain lives rent free. (Claire Yaffa for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: A Winning Formula: Forget Timing, Forget Technology

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
RICHARD GLASEBROOK doesn't think much of market timers, the investment managers who try to predict the best moment to shift assets among stocks, bonds and cash. In his experience, "very few people are consistently successful at trying to pick the most attractive market over time."
Trouble is, that's exactly what Mr. Glasebrook is paid to do. As manager of the Quest for Value Opportunity fund, an asset allocation fund from Oppenheimer Capital of New York, his responsibility is to direct $408 million into whatever is currently the most attractive investment category. 
 So he goes with the long-term favorite. "It's clear that for most five-year periods since the Depression, stocks have outperformed" all other asset classes, Mr. Glasebrook said in a recent interview. "Given that history, especially if you invest for the long run, it makes sense to have most of your money in the most attractive asset class."
Stocks now account for 79 percent of the fund's portfolio. Bonds and convertible securities represent a mere 1 percent, with the balance -- roughly 20 percent -- in cash.
That split is consistant with Mr. Glasebrook's style; since he took over management of the fund in March 1991, stocks have accounted for at least 63 percent of assets, and bonds have never exceeded 15 percent.
"We don't try to predict which markets are attractive to be in and then buy a broad cross section," Mr. Glasebrook explained. "We have the advantage of offering clients the ability to be in equities when it's attractive, but also to preserve capital" by buying bonds or Treasury bills. Primarily, however, "we look for attractive businesses in the equity market that can grow capital at a good rate."
Hardly as effortless as he makes it sound, Mr. Glasebrook's record speaks volumes. Through Thursday, Quest for Value Opportunity A shares were up 23.2 percent for the year, double the average for similar funds. That gain, achieved without a big bet on the high-flying technology sector, placed it in the top 1 percent of the 4,175 mutual funds tracked by Lipper Analytical Services, the fund researchers.
No flash in the pan, the fund posted an average annual gain of 19.3 percent over the last four years. The A shares carry a 5.5 percent sales charge, though B and C shares are available with different fee structures.
Just as it is not a typical asset allocation fund, Quest for Value Opportunity is not strictly a value fund, which its name implies. While Mr. Glasebrook certainly seeks stocks that are cheap relative to their peers, price-earnings ratios are far down on his list of qualifying criteria.
More important is a company's ability to generate cash, then plow it back into its business or repurchase its stock. "I want to own businesses that, because of their quality, are able to generate high amounts of cash over time," he said. "And I look for high barriers to entry," meaning new competitors would have trouble penetrating the market.
Few companies fit that bill. Typically, the fund holds only about 30 stocks, far fewer than the approximately 200 found in the average mutual fund. Just 10 stocks make up 45 percent of the Quest portfolio's value. Mr. Glasebrook said that plowing his assets into so few companies is not especially risky. "If I have a unique, informed opinion I can better appraise an opportunity," he said.
In fact, the strategy could be considered risk averse, said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical, "if the fund is careful in selecting its stocks."
The fund owns stocks that have lower-than-average valuations and greater-than-normal sales and earnings growth. While a downdraft in the equity market could be painful for the fund, Mr. Lipper said, "as I look at the names there, I don't think they'd have any trouble getting out of them."
The quest for value takes a slow, deliberate pace in the hands of Mr. Glasebrook, 47. He engages in lengthy discussions with company managers, poring over financial statements to help predict future returns. He invests as he speaks, in deliberate, measured amounts, and once he buys, he holds. Only about a third of the fund's portfolio is replaced each year.
Mr. Glasebrook's search for profitable investments inevitably leads him into unpopular corners of the market -- like military contracting. The fund's biggest investment is McDonnell Douglas, at 7.4 percent of assets, and it has paid off handsomely. The stock has gained nearly 50 percent this year.
"We thought the company's commercial business was undervalued," he said. "Although production of aircraft was coming down, we thought they could reduce costs faster than revenues fell."
The financial sector makes up the largest chunk of the fund's portfolio, and Mr. Glasebrook is fond of big banks, including Citicorp, Mellon and Wells Fargo. "One of the common threads that run through all of the financial companies we own is that they throw off a great deal of capital," he said.
Citicorp's management in particular, he said, has shown it can make wise use of excess cash, and he's made the company his second-largest holding, at 6.4 percent of fund assets. "This is a management team that through trial and tribulation learned the value of capital, and painfully rebuilt itself after having previously not learned the nature of risk," he said.
Unlike most of this year's other stellar performers among mutual funds, Quest Opportunity owns few technology stocks. The market's hottest sector, technology accounted for only about 7 percent of the fund's portfolio at the end of April, and most of that was in one stock -- computer chip maker Intel, at 5.5 percent of the fund.
"We added to Intel during the Pentium problem," Mr. Glasebrook said, when a bug clouded the prospects for its new microprocessor. "We thought the situation might be a blessing in disguise, that in the future customers would want to deal with a company that they knew would exhaustively test its products and that had a strong-enough balance sheet to withstand the financial costs of a recall." Intel, far more than its competitors, fit the bill.
Mr. Glasebrook also seeks companies that, because of broad distribution channels, are unlikely to attract a great deal of competition. A good example is the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, the fund's fifth-largest holding, at 4.3 percent of assets.
"Freddie Mac basically has one competitor, Fannie Mae," or the Federal National Mortgage Association, Mr. Glasebrook said. "The barriers around both companies' businesses -- their enormous economies of scale and their low overhead -- make them unlikely to engage in destructive competition."
The one blemish on Mr. Glasebrook's record since he took over management of the fund came in 1993, when the fund's 8.21 percent total return lagged behind the Standard & Poor's 500 by 1.85 percentage points.
"Our largest position that year was Honeywell," he recalled, and the fund sold at a loss when a patent infringement suit sent the shares reeling.
"I have the flexibility to decrease my equity holdings when risks suggest I should," Mr. Glasebrook said, but when he does sell, the money is most likely to go into cash.
Unlike other asset allocation funds, whose bond holdings average 31 percent of the portfolio, Quest Opportunity avoids debt. If that makes the fund not a true asset allocation fund, he says, so be it. As Mr. Glasebrook's record shows, investors could do worse.
